fields.headline: The clockwatcher
fields.trailText: Ticket to hide
fields.body:
Ticket to hide

Many types of discrimination have been eliminated from the office, but one group feels that they remain the victims of institutional prejudice. Amid all the talk of "teamwork", who fights for the loner with an aversion to working with others? Helpfully, an internet essay offers a three-point plan for those struggling with the tyranny of "teamplayermania":

1) Create teamplayer-free zones in your life. Limit the number of nights you spend out each week. Don't answer the phone during your non-teamplayer hours.

2) Take up a hobby. Gardening, say. People with hobbies see excessive peer demands as intrusions on that captivating private world of theirs.

3) Stop hustling. It goes against accepted wisdom, but too much hustle damages individuality. "We must verbalise the suspicion that teamplayermania, propagated as it often is by institutions, may serve the needs of its propagators more than those of the individuals concerned," concludes the thesis. In other words, your boss gets more out of cooperative working than you do.

2B or not 2B?

Pity the poor office workers of Baghdad. Since the Gulf war earned Saddam Hussein's regime a raft of international sanctions, Iraq's workers have had to struggle not only with limited food and medicine but an unacceptable shortage of office stationery.

Finally, good news from those nice people at the UN, who have just allowed in the first major shipment of pencils in years. It is not clear what Iraqi scribblers have found to chew on in the meantime, but the 3.5m writing implements are likely to disappear fast, since pencils hold a special place in the breast pockets of Iraqis. In less straitened times the government gave 12 pencils a year to each student; perhaps the UN hoped that cutting off this vital supply chain would spark mass undergraduate insurrection not unlike Paris in '68.

Looks like they figured wrongly - and UN officials who inspected the shipment now say pencils were never officially banned. But the Iraqi embassy in Jordan maintains the international community was worried that Saddam would use the graphite in pencil lead for military purposes. An application that George Somerwill, the UN's Baghdad spokesman, has finally conceded is "extremely unlikely".

Esther Addley

fields.headline: Chelsea fall to French resistance
fields.standfirst:
Understrength Marseille still prove too much for Vialli's men to contain
Pires 16
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Chelsea last night discovered the truth of the saying that an animal is most dangerous when it is wounded. Expecting an easy kill against a limping Marseille, they got well and truly bitten instead.
fields.body:
Chelsea last night discovered the truth of the saying that an animal is most dangerous when it is wounded. Expecting an easy kill against a limping Marseille, they got well and truly bitten instead.

With a win and a draw already under their belt, the main blow was to Chelsea's pride rather than their chances of reaching the quarter-finals. But they know they will have to improve on this patchy, slightly complacent display to be sure of progressing.

Before the match Gianluca Vialli had trotted out the usual cliche about not underestimating a struggling team. But even he must have been surprised by the way Marseille set about the task of restoring some honour to their tattered image.

The combined effects of injury, suspension and the transfer market had taken a heavy toll on their team. Last night's starting line-up included just five of the players who began October's 1-0 defeat of Manchester United .

Furthermore, every defender was missing who started Marseille's last Champions League game, December's 3-0 defeat at Feyenoord, forcing the French to field a shakily makeshift rearguard.

This included the reserve goalkeeper Stéphane Trevisan, playing his first European game, and the 20-year-old midfielder Peter Luccin, pressed into service as a sweeper despite some recent shaky form.

Yet Marseille, hovering dangerously near the relegation zone in the French league and having been beaten in both their previous two Group D games, began the game like the team which overcame United and recently beat Paris St-Germain 4-1.

When they opened the scoring just past the half-hour it was no more than they deserved. As Jon Harley was caught up-field, Robert Pires broke down the right, outpaced Marcel Desailly and cut in. Everyone was expecting the cross, including Ed de Goey who strayed away from his left-hand post in anticipation. It was a bad error, for Pires spotted the gap and whipped in a clever shot between keeper and upright.

It was not as if Chelsea had not been warned. A similar run down the right by the former Everton striker Ibrahima Bakayoko, in for the injured Florian Maurice, had almost resulted in a goal in the opening minute. But Bakayoko's cross skidded on the wet grass and caught the unmarked Cyrille Pouget flat-footed in front of goal.

Chelsea created their share of chances before half-time, all involving Tore Andre Flo. The lanky Norwegian hit the side netting, then headed down Harley's cross only to see Gianfranco Zola shoot wide. Then on 20 minutes he slipped in a shot from 19 yards which skidded low and forced Trevisan into a fine save.

But it was Marseille who had the last word of the opening 45 minutes. A deflected ball squirted into the path of the unmarked Pires. However, just as the home supporters in a half-filled Stade Vlodrome were about to acclaim a doubling of their lead, Harley stuck out a leg and diverted Pires' shot for a corner.

The first half ended against a familiarly sickening backdrop of crowd trouble involving English supporters. Some of the Chelsea fans, segregated in one corner of the ground, appeared to start baiting the nearby home terrace. However, with the surrounding high fences always going to prevent any serious escalation of the trouble, it seemed an over-reaction by police to let off tear gas to restore order. Not surprisingly there were reports of some people being taken to hospital as a result.

On the pitch the problem for Chelsea was to find a way past an increasingly confident Marseille side. In response, Chelsea's attacking efforts grew more disjointed and predictable.

After some impressive results in this season's tournament perhaps they had begun to believe their own publicity. But their past record was not going to get them back into this match.

Chelsea's frustrations were summed up on 62 minutes when the Marseille old boy Didier Deschamps was substituted after an ineffective contribution to proceedings. A minute later Jrme Leroy nearly added insult to injury but fired just wide from close range.

 Juan Veron's 37th-minute goal gave Lazio a 1-0 lead against Feyenoord only for Jon Dahl Tomasson's late double to secure the points and throw Group D wide open. In Group C last season's finalists Bayern Munich saw off the 1998 champions Real Madrid 4-2 at the Bernabeu.

Marseille (3-4-1-2): Trevisan; Cyprien, Luccin, Abardonado; Blondeau, Brando, Leroy, Dalmat; Pires; Pouget, Bakayoko (Moses, 90min).

Chelsea (4-4-2): De Goey; Ferrer (Morris, 82), Leboeuf, Desailly, Harley; Petrescu, Deschamps, Wise, Poyet; Zola, Flo (Sutton, 82).

Referee: R Pedersen (Norway).

webTitle: Many are called but few are chosen for Cayman's World Cup campaign

fields.headline: Many are called but few are chosen for Cayman's World Cup campaign
fields.trailText: Several British players have been left bitterly disappointed because all the vacant places in the Cayman Islands' squad have been filled.
fields.body:
Several British players have been left bitterly disappointed because all the vacant places in the Cayman Islands' squad have been filled.

In a bold attempt to reach the 2002 World Cup finals, the Cayman Islands have taken full advantage of the Fifa-ratified ruling that allows any British player to turn out for any country that operates inside Britain's jurisdiction.

In the hope of attracting the interest of eight players, the Caymans made formal approaches to 24 players - and were astonished to receive 22 positive replies.

"I thought that maybe I would get one out of every three players I approached," said the Cayman Islands Football Association's overseas representative, Barry McIntosh. "I wanted eight men so I contacted 24. I was amazed to receive 22 responses. In the end I had to disappoint several players."

One of only two players to have declined the offer was the Manchester United defender David May. Of those who have taken up the invitation the most celebrated is arguably Wayne Allison, the captain of Tranmere Rovers.

Allison was scheduled to depart for the tiny crown colony tomorrow after playing for the Worthington Cup finalists in their First Division game at Portsmouth tonight.

Seven other players arrived in the Caymans on Monday and featured in a friendly match against the American club side DC United last night.

Those who have already pulled on the Caymans shirt are Ged Brannan of Motherwell, David Barnett of Lincoln City, Martin O'Connor of Birmingham City, Dwayne Plummer of Bristol City, Barry Hayles of Fulham, Neville Roach of Southend United and Neil Sharpe of Boreham Wood.

All eight players are expected to play in Sunday's World Cup qualifying fixture against Cuba in Havana, the first of 22 games that the Caymans will have to negotiate if they are to realise their dream of matching Jamaica's achievement and appearing on world football's biggest stage.

Several of the players' club managers are known to be angry at the prospect of losing key personnel at such a crucial point in the season. But the Cayman Islands yesterday launched a stout defence of their recruitment policy.

"These players have agreed to join up with us not for the money but simply because they wish to play international football," said McIntosh. "They will not be earning anything like the sort of money which some people have been suggesting; to say they will pick up £70,000 if they were to reach the finals is ridiculous.

"We are doing nothing wrong and, perhaps most importantly, we are doing nothing new. The United States has taken players from Puerto Rico under the same system, as has Jamaica from England.

"The Cayman Islands is a British dependency. We use the same passports; we have the Queen's face on our currency. When you have something new in life it does take time for people to appreciate what the benefits can be."

The Tranmere manager John Aldridge, who will lose Allison for games against Blackburn on Saturday and West Bromwich next Tuesday, was rather less enthusiastic.

"It really is far from ideal but you cannot stand in the way of a player progressing to the international stage," he said.

The general secretary of the Cayman Islands FA, Costas Takkas, insisted that the players should not be condemned as sporting mercenaries.

"We are looking to build a Cayman Islands team in its own right, not a second England side," he said. "These players have been very warmly welcomed; the local public is very excited by the idea."

fields.headline: Stavrum ends Caley's great adventure
fields.trailText: Aberdeen 1 - 0 Inverness CT
fields.body:
Aberdeen made extraordinarily heavy weather of removing Inverness CT from the cup and bringing to a close one of this season's more romantic tales. The former Highland League club held out for 75 minutes in front of an 18,000 crowd before bowing to the inevitable.

The goal, when it did come, had a touch of class. Hicham Zerouali hit a crossfield ball which Andy Dow swung in from the left and Arild Stavrum headed sharply into the corner of the net to end Caley's resistance. After that, Aberdeen made it look easy.

Caley included Richard Hastings, who had been part of the triumphant Canadian team at the Gold Cup in the United States where he was named rookie of the tournament, and the defender was badly needed as Aberdeen made strenuous early efforts to settle this tie.

The Highlanders managed a burst in the first minute with a Barry Wilson shot but thereafter the Dons ran the first-half. Their best work was done by the Moroccan Zerouali and his volley in the 10th minute from a Jamie McAllister cross was proof of his quality.

When Caley's goalkeeper Jim Calder lost a 30-yard free-kick from Thomas Solberg a little later, he was extremely fortunate that the ball struck his outstretched right arm. But he showed much more authority in the 22nd minute in turning a Rachid Belabed shot against the bar and over.

Aberdeen then relaxed and Caley, relatively untroubled, managed to keep them at bay until Stavrum's breakthrough.

fields.headline: Manchester United 2 - 0 Bordeaux
fields.trailText:
Manchester United: Van Der Gouw, G. Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs, Cole, Sheringham.
Substitutes: Bosnich, P. Neville, Cruyff, Solskjaer, Berg, Fortune, Wallwork.
fields.body:
Manchester United: Van Der Gouw, G. Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs, Cole, Sheringham.
Substitutes: Bosnich, P. Neville, Cruyff, Solskjaer, Berg, Fortune, Wallwork.

Bordeaux: Rame, Grenet, Afanou, Alicarte, Bonnissel, Micoud, Martins, Pavon, Diabate, Laslandes, Wiltord.
Substitutes: Richert, Saveljic, Rouviere, Ziani, Zanotti, Batlles, Feindouno.

1 min A late start due to traffic problems on the M60 delaying spectators. Scholes is unfit and his natural replacement Butt starts the game. The dangermen for the visitors are playmaker Micoud, and the two strikers Laslandes and 'Mr. W' as he likes to be known, Sylvain Wiltord. Like Chelsea yesterday, United are expected to roll over their supposedly weaker French opponents.
4 Both teams taking a little while to settle, but Bordeaux have started positively - they were expected to come here and defend but they appear very comfortable coming forward and Stam has already made a couple of timely interceptions.
6 Irwin sends a delightful long ball from the left to Giggs running into the Bordeaux area. His cushioned back-header finds Sheringham outside the area, who holds and passes back to Giggs now in a more central position 15 yards from goal. His shot is scuffed and Rame makes the save.
10 Showing the increased confidence that brought him assists for two Premiership goals at the weekend, Ryan Giggs is primed to race down the left wing - only the offside trap stops him on this occasion, though not by much.
12 A perceptive through-ball from Beckham spots the run of Butt, who wrestles with Grenet whilst both hare towards the ball. Grenet loses the tussle and goes down and the referee's sympathies are with him.
15 Micoud picks up the ball in the centre circle and as the United defence back off en masse, he draws back the right leg and has a dig. His shot deflects to Martins on the right wing, who hits the looping ball on the volley straight into Irwin's midriff and off for a corner. Nothing comes from the set-piece but some encouragement for the visitors.
16 United break and Giggs wins a free kick on the centre-left, about 30 yards out. Beckham, who hasn't been putting these away recently, sets himself and... bends his effort up over the wall and his powerful, curling effort cannons off Rame's crossbar and back into play. The ball is cleared upfield by a relieved Alicarte.
23 After a lapse in the tempo of the game, Bordeaux break quickly down the left wing, with Diabate playing in Wiltord. His first touch is poor and his second poorer still. Martins collects on the right and crosses to Wiltord again. His first-time shot is well struck but wide of Van Der Gouw's left-hand post.
26 Bordeaux have settled into a counter-attacking strategy. So far they have held United quite effectively in defence, and have also proved proficient at working the ball upfield to Micoud and Martins.
29 A floated ball from Butt releases Sheringham through the middle and no offside flag. Rame comes outside his area to clear with his feet and his timing is perfect as he thrashes the ball away into touch.
32 Andy Cole uses his strength against Afanou through the middle and succeeds in laying the ball off to Giggs. After a few jinks and turns the Welshman twists and hits a shot across the face of goal that the Bordeaux keeper does well to grasp and hold as Cole watches for any mistakes.
34 A corner to United on the right. Beckham's cross is a high, floated delivery that Keane nods down to Cole in front Rame in the goal. As he turns and shoots, the linesman is already waving his flag to signify offside.
41 GOAL Manchester United 1 - 0 Bordeaux Finally United provide enough imagination to break down this Bordeaux defence. Beckham in space on the right has time to measure his delivery to mesh with Giggs' run into the centre of the area. The Welsh winger meets the cross on the half-volley with his left foot and Rame has no chance.
43 Acres of space on the left for Giggs as he cuts in a delivers a high outswinger that sails over Cole's head. Butt is behind him but can only direct his header wide.
45 It's Beckham's turn this time as Cole plays a crisp one-two on the right. Beckham brings the ball inside and squares, but Afanou has rushed back and is happy to concede the corner. The set-piece is punched away and then cleared. The half-time whistle cannot come quick enough for Bordeaux.
46 The visitors get their wish. Half time.

45 The match restarts. Can United rip into the French champions now that they've made the breakthrough?
47 An early chance for Bordeaux as Martins is fouled by Nicky Butt by the right cornerflag. Martins takes and Alicarte has a clear header at Van Der Gouw's near post, but his timing is off and the ball trickles out of play. Goal kick.
50 Gary Neville and Wiltord enjoy a tussle by the left-corner flag. Neville halts the Frenchman's run and is fouled for his trouble. Mr. W does seem equally at home through the middle or down the flanks.
53 Butt lunges in on Wiltord and the Frenchman skips away from his challenge. The ball is rolled out to Martins on the right side of the United area, but his touch lets him down. Van Der Gouw gathers and clears.
55 A corner for the visitors and Martins takes from the right. Alicarte has another free header and performs better than his first half effort. Beckham heads away from Van Der Gouw's left-hand post. United can clear and the ball is hoofed upfield.
58 Laslandes beats the offside trap as Jaap Stam is half a yard short on his marker. Laslandes brings it and brings it and brings it until Van Der Gouw is looming and then it's squared to Wiltord. The French international meets the ball with a relatively narrow angle to aim at, but can only hit the side netting on an open goal.
64 Bordeaux substitution: Ziani for Martins
66 United are finally looking like coming back into this game as Bordeaux have controlled the first 20 minutes of the second half. A through-ball from Butt releases Keane on the left of the area. Rame comes out and upends the United captain. One yellow card later David Beckham steps up and bends the ball over the Bordeaux wall towards rame's right-hand post. The keeper makes up the ground well and turns the free kick around the post for a corner.
69 A shorter corner sees Beckham change the angle of attack and hit an easy centre into the unmarked Andy Cole, who controls it with two touches and then rolls it gently into the arms of Rame from 5 yards out.
74 The last fifteen minutes should prove to be a more open contest as Bordeaux need to improve on their appalling European scoring record. Van Der Gouw throws out to Giggs on the left, half-way in his own half. The winger tears away from his marker and after 60 yards down the left flank finally decides to pass it to Cole, inch-perfect from 20 yards. One touch from Cole and United have lost possession. Giggs must wonder why he bothers.
79 Giggs plays through Keane through the middle and defeats the offside trap. Keane and Rame go one-on-one and Rame triumphs, narrowing the angle and making the save.
81 Manchester United substitution: Philip Neville for Cole.
83 United have stepped up a gear. The possession has been more telling and the moves more attacking in the last ten minutes. Some nervousness persists while the margin is just one goal.
84 GOAL Manchester United 2 - 0 Bordeaux Ryan Giggs the provider again as he skins his marker all along the left wing, past the corner flag and then arrowing in towards the goal. Rame comes towards his near post and Giggs chips the ball clean over him to the waiting Sheringham who nods into an empty net. Old Trafford can stop waiting to exhale.
87 Manchester United substitution: Fortune for Keane, Solskjaer for Giggs.
89 Bordeaux are still pressing forward but they don't seem to know why. Two minutes of time to be added on.
92 Full time: Manchester United 2 - 0 Bordeaux

Like Chelsea yesterday, United are expected to roll over their supposedly weaker French opponents. 4 Both teams taking a little while to settle, but Bordeaux have started positively - they were expected to come here and defend but they appear very comfortable coming forward and Stam has already made a couple of timely interceptions. 6 Irwin sends a delightful long ball from the left to Giggs running into the Bordeaux area. His cushioned back-header finds Sheringham outside the area, who holds and passes back to Giggs now in a more central position 15 yards from goal. His shot is scuffed and Rame makes the save. 10 Showing the increased confidence that brought him assists for two Premiership goals at the weekend, Ryan Giggs is primed to race down the left wing - only the offside trap stops him on this occasion, though not by much. 12 A perceptive through-ball from Beckham spots the run of Butt, who wrestles with Grenet whilst both hare towards the ball. Grenet loses the tussle and goes down and the referee's sympathies are with him. 15 Micoud picks up the ball in the centre circle and as the United defence back off en masse, he draws back the right leg and has a dig. His shot deflects to Martins on the right wing, who hits the looping ball on the volley straight into Irwin's midriff and off for a corner. Nothing comes from the set-piece but some encouragement for the visitors. 16 United break and Giggs wins a free kick on the centre-left, about 30 yards out. Beckham, who hasn't been putting these away recently, sets himself and... bends his effort up over the wall and his powerful, curling effort cannons off Rame's crossbar and back into play. The ball is cleared upfield by a relieved Alicarte. 23 After a lapse in the tempo of the game, Bordeaux break quickly down the left wing, with Diabate playing in Wiltord. His first touch is poor and his second poorer still. Martins collects on the right and crosses to Wiltord again. His first-time shot is well struck but wide of Van Der Gouw's left-hand post. 26 Bordeaux have settled into a counter-attacking strategy. So far they have held United quite effectively in defence, and have also proved proficient at working the ball upfield to Micoud and Martins. 29 A floated ball from Butt releases Sheringham through the middle and no offside flag. Rame comes outside his area to clear with his feet and his timing is perfect as he thrashes the ball away into touch. 32 Andy Cole uses his strength against Afanou through the middle and succeeds in laying the ball off to Giggs. After a few jinks and turns the Welshman twists and hits a shot across the face of goal that the Bordeaux keeper does well to grasp and hold as Cole watches for any mistakes. 34 A corner to United on the right. Beckham's cross is a high, floated delivery that Keane nods down to Cole in front Rame in the goal. As he turns and shoots, the linesman is already waving his flag to signify offside. 41 GOAL Manchester United 1 - 0 Bordeaux Finally United provide enough imagination to break down this Bordeaux defence. Beckham in space on the right has time to measure his delivery to mesh with Giggs' run into the centre of the area. The Welsh winger meets the cross on the half-volley with his left foot and Rame has no chance. 43 Acres of space on the left for Giggs as he cuts in a delivers a high outswinger that sails over Cole's head. Butt is behind him but can only direct his header wide. 45 It's Beckham's turn this time as Cole plays a crisp one-two on the right. Beckham brings the ball inside and squares, but Afanou has rushed back and is happy to concede the corner. The set-piece is punched away and then cleared. The half-time whistle cannot come quick enough for Bordeaux. 46 The visitors get their wish. Half time. 45 The match restarts. Can United rip into the French champions now that they've made the breakthrough? 47 An early chance for Bordeaux as Martins is fouled by Nicky Butt by the right cornerflag. Martins takes and Alicarte has a clear header at Van Der Gouw's near post, but his timing is off and the ball trickles out of play. Goal kick. 50 Gary Neville and Wiltord enjoy a tussle by the left-corner flag. Neville halts the Frenchman's run and is fouled for his trouble. Mr. W does seem equally at home through the middle or down the flanks. 53 Butt lunges in on Wiltord and the Frenchman skips away from his challenge. The ball is rolled out to Martins on the right side of the United area, but his touch lets him down. Van Der Gouw gathers and clears. 55 A corner for the visitors and Martins takes from the right. Alicarte has another free header and performs better than his first half effort. Beckham heads away from Van Der Gouw's left-hand post. United can clear and the ball is hoofed upfield. 58 Laslandes beats the offside trap as Jaap Stam is half a yard short on his marker. Laslandes brings it and brings it and brings it until Van Der Gouw is looming and then it's squared to Wiltord. The French international meets the ball with a relatively narrow angle to aim at, but can only hit the side netting on an open goal. 64 Bordeaux substitution: Ziani for Martins 66 United are finally looking like coming back into this game as Bordeaux have controlled the first 20 minutes of the second half. A through-ball from Butt releases Keane on the left of the area. Rame comes out and upends the United captain. One yellow card later David Beckham steps up and bends the ball over the Bordeaux wall towards rame's right-hand post. The keeper makes up the ground well and turns the free kick around the post for a corner. 69 A shorter corner sees Beckham change the angle of attack and hit an easy centre into the unmarked Andy Cole, who controls it with two touches and then rolls it gently into the arms of Rame from 5 yards out. 74 The last fifteen minutes should prove to be a more open contest as Bordeaux need to improve on their appalling European scoring record. Van Der Gouw throws out to Giggs on the left, half-way in his own half. The winger tears away from his marker and after 60 yards down the left flank finally decides to pass it to Cole, inch-perfect from 20 yards. One touch from Cole and United have lost possession. Giggs must wonder why he bothers. 79 Giggs plays through Keane through the middle and defeats the offside trap. Keane and Rame go one-on-one and Rame triumphs, narrowing the angle and making the save. 81 Manchester United substitution: Philip Neville for Cole. 83 United have stepped up a gear. The possession has been more telling and the moves more attacking in the last ten minutes. Some nervousness persists while the margin is just one goal. 84 GOAL Manchester United 2 - 0 Bordeaux Ryan Giggs the provider again as he skins his marker all along the left wing, past the corner flag and then arrowing in towards the goal. Rame comes towards his near post and Giggs chips the ball clean over him to the waiting Sheringham who nods into an empty net. Old Trafford can stop waiting to exhale. 87 Manchester United substitution: Fortune for Keane, Solskjaer for Giggs. 89 Bordeaux are still pressing forward but they don't seem to know why. Two minutes of time to be added on. 92 Full time: Manchester United 2 - 0 Bordeaux

webTitle: Frandsen leaves it late for Rovers

fields.headline: Frandsen leaves it late for Rovers
fields.trailText: Blackburn 1 - 1 Norwich
fields.body:
It is possible to feel sympathy for the supporters of Blackburn Rovers. They may have won the Premiership five years ago with a team largely made up of expensive signings, but many clubs have tried to do that in the past decade without ending up in the purgatorial world known as the middle of the First Division.

Blackburn dominated here but all they had to show at the end was a point from a last-minute goal from a substitute, their Danish midfielder Per Frandsen.

Before that, it looked like a fruitless evening for the home team with Norwich holding on to the lead acquired when the Norwich midfielder Daryl Sutch escaped his marker and hit the ball into the roof of the net with venom on 24 minutes.

Before that and after, Blackburn threatened to run riot but simply could not make their pressure tell. And that is where the sympathy vote comes in.

Tony Parkes, charged with picking up the pieces from the prodigal regimes of Kenny Dalglish, Ray Harford and Brian Kidd, may have Jack Walker's chequebook at his disposal but, with the legacy of a decade of extravagance already weighing the club down, it would appear an unenviable task.

Having served the club for 30 years, Parkes must wonder what the world is coming to when a club which has spent just seven years playing top-flight football in that time - far less than Norwich, for example - is so desperately unhappy with a performance which leaves them six points shy of the the First Division One's play-off zone; their buoyancy level until Walker, among others, changed the club's whole outlook for ever.

Blackburn may have monopolised in terms of territory, with Damien Duff and Nathan Blake coming closest, but Sutch's goal had a deflating effect. Blake looked their most likely saviour but his admirable efforts came to nought.

Norwich, for their part, looked likely scorers on each of the rare occasions they crossed the halfway line. In reality, it could have been worse for Rovers.

webTitle: Wiltord willing and more than able

fields.headline: Wiltord willing and more than able
fields.trailText: Bordeaux's main striker Sylvain Wiltord has ended a self-imposed ban on talking to the media to declare an interest in moving to Old Trafford.
fields.body:
If Elie Baup is invited to Sir Alex Ferguson's office after tonight's match, the two managers may be there until the early hours swapping hard-luck stories.

While United's love affair with David Beckham teeters on the brink of divorce, Bordeaux were left in little doubt that their main striker Sylvain Wiltord considers himself too big a fish for the French pond.

Displaying impeccable timing, the 25-year-old Parisian ended a self-imposed ban on talking to the media to declare an interest in moving to Old Trafford. "It has always been my dream to play in England and I'm using this as my chance to show the Premiership clubs what I'm capable of," said the striker.

"When I was younger I used to support Liverpool but now my ambition is to play for United. There is only so far you can go in the French League; it is more exciting in England."

Wiltord's curriculum vitae is impressive: France's footballer of the year and the Golden Boot winner, he averages a goal every three games. Now regarded as an automatic choice for the national team, he also insists on being called "Mr W". Pretentious, moi?

However, it has been Bordeaux's defenders who have impressed in Europe this season. The French champions were involved in three scoreless draws to progress as Group G runners-up, although their league form is patchy; they are sixth in the table, 17 points behind Monaco. "We have found it hard," Baup said. "But we're not coming here to be spectators."

Close inspection of the pictures of Beckham in the stand at Elland Road 10 days ago reveals Marius Trésor a few places away. Now on Bordeaux's backroom staff, the former France captain was not impressed by United. "Jaap Stam is a great defender but he lacks mobility and Wiltord can make the difference with his pace."

webTitle: United drilled to withstand the long March

fields.headline: United drilled to withstand the long March
fields.standfirst: Bordeaux offer fresh challenge to Ferguson's men but lack vintage finish
fields.trailText: Starting tonight Sir Alex Ferguson's team will play four Champions League matches in 21 days, plus the small matter of Liverpool's visit to Old Trafford in the Premiership on Saturday morning. Most clubs would find this a daunting prospect but United should thrive on it.
fields.body:
The month of March is what Manchester United are about. Starting tonight Sir Alex Ferguson's team will play four Champions League matches in 21 days, plus the small matter of Liverpool's visit to Old Trafford in the Premiership on Saturday morning.

Most clubs would find this a daunting prospect but United should thrive on it. As European champions and likely English champions for the sixth time in eight seasons Ferguson's squad has been developed to meet precisely this sort of challenge.

This evening United will expect to resume their defence of the European Cup with a victory over Bordeaux, although Ferguson, knowing the cat-and-mouse nature of European games, feels his side may have a better chance of winning back at the Parc Lescure next Wednesday, when the same opposition should be less defensive.

Yet with Dwight Yorke recovered from a thigh injury and set to rejoin Andy Cole up front, anything other than a home win tonight will be a surprise, for although the French champions were unbeaten in the first group stage of the Champions League they began the second by losing 3-0 to Valencia, who were then defeated by a similar score at Old Trafford.

Last season Bordeaux were stylish winners of the French league, their first title for 12 years, and on entering the Champions League they managed to edge out Spartak Moscow after beating them twice. Two scoreless draws with Sparta Prague and another with the Dutch side Willem II suggested that defending was their strong point, although Valencia clearly found a way through.

So far this season United have only occasionally given full rein to their talents, being content for much of the time to accumulate Premiership points while on automatic pilot.

Nevertheless they are re- entering Europe with their home affairs in good order: a six-point lead at the top of the table and a 10-point gap between themselves and Liverpool, the team lying fourth. Whether or not the European Cup stays at Old Trafford, a place for United in next season's Champions League seems all but guaranteed.

Lack of strength in depth was considered Bordeaux's biggest handicap at the start of the season and their recent signings, Christophe Dugarry and Sylvain Legwinski, are both ineligible tonight, as is United's Mickaël Silvestre. Yet Elie Baup, the club's coach, feels that the extra competition for places has sharpened up his squad.

"We have a turnover that didn't exist before," he said. "There is a new dynamism and freshness which keeps people on their toes."

Johan Micoud, who helps form the creative heart of Baup's side, is expected to be fit after a knee injury and Baup is likely to prefer Stéphane Ziani, who broke a leg at the start of the season, to Corentin Martins, the man who replaced him in midfield.

fields.headline: Celtic push for Atlantic league
fields.trailText: The prospect of a breakaway league for Europe's second tier of clubs came closer yesterday when one of the biggest clubs involved, Celtic, said it was the only way of generating much-needed television revenue to keep pace with the continent's elite.
fields.body:
The prospect of a breakaway league for Europe's second tier of clubs came closer yesterday when one of the biggest clubs involved, Celtic, said it was the only way of generating much-needed television revenue to keep pace with the continent's elite.

Speaking at Football Expo here, Celtic's head of multimedia David Heath confirmed that his club and Rangers were keen on setting up the so-called Atlantic league but stressed that nothing would be done without the blessing of the Scottish Football Association and Uefa, Europe's governing body.

Heath said such a league, banding together clubs from Scotland, the Netherlands, Norway, Belgium, Portugal and Denmark, was the only way of helping well-supported clubs from smaller nations to remain competitive in Europe.

"It is certainly something that will be considered further," said Heath, whose club have already met Ajax, PSV Eindhoven and Benfica to discuss forming the Atlantic league, which would have a potential audience of 50m.

Celtic and Rangers, who receive a fraction of the television revenue of clubs such as Manchester United and Barcelona, almost certainly would be forced to pull out of Scottish domestic football to take part in the new league. But Heath emphasised there would have to be some sort of agreement to compensate other Scottish clubs who rely on big paydays against the Glasgow giants.

"We have an economic responsibility to those clubs that would have to be taken care of," he said. "This club wants to return to the top level of European soccer but are faced with the situation of generating only £3m in TV revenue when other teams are getting £40m and have far more to invest."

He added: "We want to work within the existing structures and are talking to both the SFA and Uefa."

But it is almost certain that Celtic and other clubs trying to form an Atlantic league will face fierce opposition. "I can't see Fifa or Uefa allowing this, simple as that," said one source close to Fifa, the world governing body.

 Uefa has instructed match officials across Europe to tidy up substitutions. From yesterday a linesman is required to join the fourth official on the halfway line to assist with all substitutions. The move follows the recent FA Cup tie when Tranmere played briefly with an extra man against Sunderland. Referees have also been reminded that they must caution any player who completely removes his shirt while celebrating a goal, even if he is wearing an identical shirt underneath.

webTitle: Aldridge charged for 'clip around the ear'

fields.headline: Aldridge charged for 'clip around the ear'
fields.trailText: John Aldridge yesterday admitted giving Leicester's Theo Zagorakis a "clip around the ear" at the Worthington Cup final as the Football Association charged him with misconduct.
fields.body:
John Aldridge yesterday admitted giving Leicester's Theo Zagorakis a "clip around the ear" at the Worthington Cup final as the Football Association charged him with misconduct.

The Tranmere manager said he lost control when he saw the Leicester substitute applauding the dismissal of Clint Hill for a foul on Emile Heskey.

"I got carried away in the heat of the moment," Aldridge said. "I was really upset to see a fellow professional applauding a sending-off. I didn't punch him but I gave him a little clip around the ear. There was nothing malicious in it.

"Zagorakis apologised after the game. I had a word with him; he had no problem with me and just wanted to say sorry for applauding. I am sure, however, some of the critics would love to think I had actually punched him."

Aldridge is already due at Lancaster Gate a week tomorrow on an earlier misconduct charge relating to comments about the referee Jeff Winter.

Everton's attempt to sign Arsenal's Stephen Hughes collapsed last night over the mid fielder's personal terms. Although he indicated he was happy to move for £3m, he was unable to agree a contract at a meeting with Everton officials. With Everton £14m in debt, the 23-year-old was told to lower his demands or pass up the opportunity of the regular first-team football he has been denied at Highbury. He refused.

Everton have parted company with the Croatia defender Slaven Bilic, who has made only one senior appearance in the past 18 months because of a serious pelvic injury. He accepted a pay-off in the region of £1m for the remaining 30 months of his contract. He is to return to Croatia, where he aims to become involved with his former club Hajduk Split.

 The Bari coach Eugenio Fascetti has been ordered before Serie A's disciplinary committee to explain alleged racist remarks after a clash between Torino's Senegalese defender Djibril Diawara and Bari's Luigi Garzya. "Diawara spat in the face of Garzya," he said. "It's better that they stay at home, also because the spit could be infectious." Fascetti denies his remarks were racist.

fields.headline: Debutant Younis defies Sri Lanka
fields.trailText: Younis Khan joined a select band of six batsmen yesterday with a century on his Test debut for Pakistan as he and the former captain Wasim Akram launched a determined fightback to set Sri Lanka a target of 220 to win the first Test in Rawalpindi.
fields.body:
Younis Khan joined a select band of six batsmen yesterday with a century on his Test debut for Pakistan as he and the former captain Wasim Akram launched a determined fightback to set Sri Lanka a target of 220 to win the first Test in Rawalpindi.

With his 322-minute 107 the 23-year-old emulated the illustrious likes of Salim Malik and Javed Miandad. He was last man out after he and the groin-strained Wasim, who hit out to score 79 despite needing a runner, compiled a Pakistan-record ninth-wicket partnership of 145 in 195 minutes.

Wasim struck 10 fours before he was adjudged out - a decision given the fullest consideration by the home umpire Athar Zaidi - to a bat-and-pad catch off the off-spinner Muttiah Muralitharan.

The home side mustered 390 in their second innings, a lead of 219. The tourists were 11 without loss at stumps.

Meanwhile, Brian Lara has been named in a 20-man West Indies training squad to assemble in Jamaica next month to prepare for the home series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan. It was thought he would take an extended break after resigning the captaincy.

The veteran fast bowler Curtly Ambrose has been recalled and an interesting newcomer is the Guyanese leg-spinner Mahendra Nagamootoo, who with 31 victims was leading wicket-taker in this year's Busta Cup competition, which Jamaica clinched with a draw against the Leeward Islands.

He was last man out after he and the groin-strained Wasim, who hit out to score 79 despite needing a runner, compiled a Pakistan-record ninth-wicket partnership of 145 in 195 minutes. Wasim struck 10 fours before he was adjudged out - a decision given the fullest consideration by the home umpire Athar Zaidi - to a bat-and-pad catch off the off-spinner Muttiah Muralitharan. The home side mustered 390 in their second innings, a lead of 219. The tourists were 11 without loss at stumps. Meanwhile, Brian Lara has been named in a 20-man West Indies training squad to assemble in Jamaica next month to prepare for the home series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan. It was thought he would take an extended break after resigning the captaincy. The veteran fast bowler Curtly Ambrose has been recalled and an interesting newcomer is the Guyanese leg-spinner Mahendra Nagamootoo, who with 31 victims was leading wicket-taker in this year's Busta Cup competition, which Jamaica clinched with a draw against the Leeward Islands. Pakistan first innings 182 (P Wickremasinghe 4-37, M Muralitharan 4-45). Sri Lanka first innings 353 (A de Silva 112; Waqar Younis 4-103). fields.headline: England come calling for players
fields.standfirst: Game faces fundamental change as elite get their contracts today
fields.trailText: English cricket will undergo a massive face-lift at Lord's today when the names of the players to be offered contracts by the England and Wales Cricket Board are revealed.
fields.body:
English cricket will undergo a massive face-lift at Lord's today when the names of the players to be offered contracts by the England and Wales Cricket Board are revealed. Neither the international nor the domestic game will be the same again.

The principle of such contracts, which make players responsible to England rather than their counties, was agreed a year ago but it was not until the autumn that the details began to emerge.

Up to 16 players can be contracted for this summer. At first it seemed that only 10 or 11 would be recruited at this stage, but some one-day specialists have been included as well, which may swell the numbers to the original target figure.

The venture had been allocated £1m, although because of financial difficulties this sum has already been slashed by a quarter.

Players will continue to be paid by their counties, as well as by the ECB. The ECB will pay compensation to the counties - amounting, it is believed, to 80% of the player's salary - for the loss of the player's services. Players will be allocated to one of three salary bands according to their international experience.

The counties will have first call on their players' services for Benson & Hedges Cup and NatWest Trophy matches, but for the remainder of the sea son the players will be available only at the discretion of the England coach Duncan Fletcher.

David Graveney, the chairman of the England selectors, said: "The main point is the realisation that the international cricketer cannot fulfil everything in a 12-month period in terms of playing all the domestic and international cricket.

"The bowlers in particular aren't going to be around for county cricket. I think that has been accepted by everyone now. I think we have to pencil in names we think will be the backbone of the team to play against Australia next year."

At present too many of England's pace bowlers are susceptible to long-term injury; Darren Gough has been sidelined for lengthy periods and last winter England were deprived of Dean Headley for virtually the entire tour and Alan Mullally for a significant period of it. Quality practice, rest, treatment and advice will be the order of the day.

Among the contracted players may be youngsters such as Surrey's Alex Tudor and Durham's Steve Harmison, who have the potential to generate authentic pace but whose development requires careful monitoring. Spinners will be sparse on the list, a comment on the state of that art in the domestic game; the young Lancashire leg-spinner Chris Schofield may find himself the sole representative.

With the England captain Nasser Hussain's declaration that several experienced performers are sure to return, it will be interesting to see which of Graham Thorpe, Graeme Hick and Mark Ramprakash are included.

Whispers suggest that only the last may miss out, but in view of the vacancy at the top of the order this would seem bizarre.

fields.headline: A cautious thumbs-up
fields.standfirst: England reveal hand for first Test
fields.trailText: England's first batch of central contracts were widely leaked - and all the leaks turned out to be wrong. Late in the day, the selectors decided not to go by potential, or past performance, or preservation from injury, but to use a more radical yardstick - picking the best team.
fields.body:
England's first batch of central contracts were widely leaked - and all the leaks turned out to be wrong. Late in the day, the selectors decided not to go by potential, or past performance, or preservation from injury, but to use a more radical yardstick - picking the best team.

The names were announced in alphabetical order, true to the unhelpful traditions of Lord's press-releases, which means the first thing you have to do is scribble the batting order in the margin.

It looks something like this: Mike Atherton, Mark Ramprakash, Nasser Hussain (capt), Graeme Hick, Michael Vaughan, Alec Stewart (wkt), Andrew Flintoff or Craig White, Chris Schofield, Andy Caddick, Dean Headley, Darren Gough.

As ever, there are good things and bad things, but no ugly things. The brainless experiments of the winter have been abandoned. There is only one name that could be described as wacky (clue: his first name is Craig). There has been the customary clear-out - five of the winning team from the last Test have been dumped - but the result is a team that is definitely stronger, if curious in places.

Here's the Wisden Verdict, decision by decision.

Ramprakash recalled

The best decision of the lot. Ramps recovered from an awful, nervous, fragmentary start to his Test career to become England's most consistent batsman in the 18 months from March 1998 to last August. He was dropped, as he himself openly complained, because a scapegoat was needed after the shock defeat by New Zealand, although a tendency to volcanic behaviour in the dressing-room may have played a part. The selectors could have waited and demanded that he show some county form, as if that would prove anything. Instead they have been big enough to admit that they were wrong to leave him out in the first place. They have also said that he may open the batting, which would mean renewing a successful partnership with Mike Atherton that began back in the mists of 1986-87, in the England Under-19s.

Thorpe left out in the cold

Tricky one. Graham Thorpe missed the Test series in South Africa at his own request, which seemed fair enough after 10 successive tours with England or England A. He was avilable for the one-day series, but the selectors preferred to stick with Adams and Co - a decision which probably cost England the triangular trophy. Now he is being punished again. Who has more Test runs left in him, Thorpe or Atherton? Surely Thorpe. In his absence, the selectors seem to have forgotten that he is a lefthander. Their squad contains not a single player who either bats or bowls left-handed.

Hick recalled again

Hmmm. He's a better player than his detractors make out. On the other hand, should he be recalled just because he had two excellent one-day games in Zimbabwe (following several bad ones in South Africa), and because he and Duncan Fletcher go way back? His catching is useful, and his bowling may have been a factor in a party that contains not a single specialist finger-spinner. But just as he has often been unluckily dumped, so now he is fortunate to be included. Worcestershire certainly weren't expecting it, or they wouldn't have made him their new captain.

Only three fast bowlers

Baffling. Half the point of central contracts is to stop the Test seamers being flogged into the ground by their counties. The newspapers confidently expected to see five or six fast bowlers given contracts. Instead the two automatic selections, Gough and Caddick, have been joined only by Dean Headley. So we have three seamers, two of whom are injury-prone, and all of whom are the wrong side of 29. The suspicion is that the selectors couldn't agree on who was fourth in the pecking order: Tudor, Silverwood, Mullally, or someone from outside the winter tour party, such as Dominic Cork (still the best swing bowler in the country), Angus Fraser or Ed Giddins. The end result is plain silly. Almost any Test XII or XIII these days contains four front-line seamers: sometimes there are six. So why only three? Perhaps because Silverwood is from Yorkshire, and the ECB didn't want to take four players from one county. But that doesn't explain the cursory handling of Tudor, who has made major contributions in two of his three Tests and needs exactly the sort of nursing that central contracts are intended to bring.

Schofield the sole spinner

A bold move. It's good to have someone of 21 in a squad in which eight players are past 30 and Darren Gough, at 29, is the fourth-youngest member. It's good to see the selectors recognising that orthodox finger-spin is now a thing of the past. But there are signs that they haven't thought this through. An attack of Gough, Caddick, Headley and Schofield, with Flintoff or White as back-up, would take wickets, but at a price: only Caddick can be relied upon to keep the runs down. Both England's existing stock bowlers, Mullally and Tufnell, have been dropped, and the selectors have mysteriously not taken up wisden.com's preferred choice to replace them - Mark Ealham, who is equally economical and a far better batsman. Schofield may just be the new Shane Warne but he is more likely to be the new Ian Salisbury, going for four an over. Brian Lara, freed from the shackles of captaincy, might decide to break one of his own records. Schofield is a good pick, but surely didn't need to be given a contract - especially as his new boss at Lancashire is Bob Simpson, who nurtured Warne to greatness and almost certainly has more wisdom to impart to a young legspinner than Fletcher does.

No dud batsmen

In their last home Test, England had three No.11s: Mullally, Tufnell, and Ed Giddins. In their next one, they may have none, unless you count Darren Gough, whose considerable batting ability vanished without trace about three years ago. England's weakness as a batting team has not been the top six, contrary to the view held by Hussain and most of the press box. The top six, playing on some dodgy pitches, have done no worse than their opposite numbers. It's the tail that has been massively outgunned. If your name is Glenn McGrath, you can afford to be an idiot with the bat, but no English bowler is that good. The fringe bowling places must go to people who can bat at least a bit. Fletcher has worked miracles with the fielding; now he must shorten the tail. The task would be less daunting if this squad had included one more bowler-who-can-bat, such as Ealham or Cork.

The return of Craig White

In one-day tournaments in Australia or the subcontinent, the man of the series sometimes wins a car. Craig White has gone one better: his reward for coming in as a late replacement and turning in a string of goodish displays in South Africa and Zimbabwe is a contract worth at least £20,000. What those performances have to do with Test cricket is not clear. White is a handy change bowler and apparently impressed Duncan Fletcher with his attitude, but he is injury-prone, was well out of his depth in his previous eight Tests, and he is 30. Mark Ealham is a better bet in the short term; Ben Hollioake or Paul Franks in the long term. Born near Leeds, brought up near Melbourne, White is now officially the luckiest man in England.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. He was recently named an Editor of the Year by the British Society of Magazine Editors.

fields.headline: No hiding place
fields.standfirst: Harrow council in London has thrown open its  doors to let the public see it at work. Peter  Hetherington sat in on a meeting
fields.trailText: Harrow council in London has thrown open its doors to let the public see it at work. Peter Hetherington sat in on a meeting.
fields.body:
Bob Shannon says it's like democracy on show, an insight into the deeper workings of a big council. "We'd far rather have people coming and seeing us at work, warts and all," he smiles over a cup of tea during a break in proceedings. "Mind you, we've had private criticism from other councils - 'if you do it, you're putting pressure on us' - but what have they got to fear?"

As leader of the London borough of Harrow, Shannon, who juggles his job as a national union official with the rigours of heading the council, is far too disciplined a politician to provide the obvious answer - "the public, that's what."

He's also too modest to volunteer that his authority is leading a revolution in local government, where secretive, cabinet-style structures are prevalent.

To many critics, these are invariably cosy little cabals created to ensure that important decisions are taken well away from the public gaze and, more importantly, out of sight of troublesome local papers, which tend to ask awkward questions while calling the executive to account.

That's where Harrow, serving 210,000 on the capital's north-western fringe, is different. As a model New Labour authority - albeit with a majority of only one - it has embraced reform with enthusiasm. But in scrapping most of its committees, while creating a special committee to call the new executive to account, it has parted company with other town halls. Three months ago, it threw open its new cabinet to public scrutiny.

People are not only actively encouraged to attend; they are also presented with agendas, appendices and thick, stapled reports to wade through as they are welcomed to Harrow's civic centre for the monthly meeting.

While including nine key Labour councillors overseeing strategy, human resources, finance, social services, education, environment, communications, planning, as well as (nice one, this) a partnership member charged with looking after stakeholders in the borough, it also embraces five Tories, two Lib-Dems and one independent as "members without portfolio".

They chat amicably, address each other by first names and occasionally engage in political point- scoring, although Shannon frowns on such activity.

At the meeting which I attended, 10 members of the public had turned up to view the spectacle. It began with Shannon taking a back seat. Tories have complained that he travelled to York, at public expense, to accept a government award conferring "beacon" status on the council for "modern service delivery" - and they weren't invited. "Very important, this was seen as non-political and it blatantly was not," complained Tory leader John Cowan to Paul Fox, the cabinet member for social services. A vote was taken. The cabinet split nine to six against the Tories.

A representative from the public service union, Unison - who has a right to attend the cabinet, but not to vote - then voiced concern about the council closing its last old people's home. Shannon noted the comment. He was supported by Jean Lammiman, a Tory member, who felt it was right for the council, as a good employer, to have a dialogue with the unions.

Grinding through the agenda, an item on health provision provoked the first political skirmish as Cowan noted dryly that he was pleased to see Labour adopting some Tory policies, prompting Shannon to reply: "We will take on any policies that work." Voices were raised. Shannon, eyes on the long agenda, cautioned his colleagues: "Let's get on. We're splitting on traditional lines. Let's do it properly."

The council likes to do things properly. That's why it consults regularly with its electorate, through a glossy council magazine, and encourages locals to help them make the biggest decision of all - how much council tax to pay in the financial year beginning April 1. Over 8,000, 10%of households in the borough, have responded to three options: rises of 9%, 7% or 5%. Almost 60% opt for the middle course. "Other boroughs can't match this consultation process," says Shannon.

But many battles lie ahead, not least how much councillors should be paid for being in the cabinet. Many authorities have already elevated cabinet members to the status of full-time politician, with big pay rises. Harrow has yet to do so.

"Totally wrong to give ourselves a pay increase," storms Cowan. "The money should go to teachers and children." This argument promises to run and run. But at least it will take place in public.

fields.headline: A question of trust
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill on why people need to be sure they are not  being ripped off
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill on why people need to be sure they are not being ripped off.
fields.body:
Charities generally enjoy a high level of trust in their work. But, as the medical profession experienced with the Harold Shipman case, this can easily take a knock.

Trust and confidence have been described as the exchange rate of charities and if this falls so too does their revenue. A Charity Commission investigation of the Roy Castle Lung Cancer Foundation and the £0.5m spent by the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund on legal fees were both recent stories which chipped away at charities' equity.

Last month, accountants Sayer Vincent hosted a seminar on "reputational risk". Gill Astarita, director of development at Action for Blind People, recommended risk analysis. She believes this exercise will highlight potential areas of scandal and prevent them from happening.

Astarita strongly advised all charities to have a crisis plan to deal with allegations of mismanagement. She said: "If a scandal is brewing you need to set up a crisis centre, inform key stakeholders about the facts of the case and devise a damage limitation exercise with some positive PR stories at the ready."

Joanna Scott, head of comm unications at the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund, concurs with this advice. The fund has encountered a plethora of bad publicity, from using Diana's signature on Flora margarine to the fundraising manager and Diana's former butler, Paul Burrell, leaving under a cloud, to legal wrangles with Franklin Mint over the use of Diana's image.

Despite this, Scott says, "We are working with the media to show how the money is spent on projects. Unfortunately, what is worthy isn't always newsworthy." But, she adds, analysis over the past six months has shown 80% of news coverage has been positive and the fund hasn't seen a drop in income.

Fundraising is one of the most sensitive areas of charitable activity where public scepticism is likely to be triggered easily. To protect against the erosion of trust and confidence, a project called Giving with Confidence has been set up jointly by the Charities Aid Foundation, the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers and the National Council for Voluntary Organisations.

The project aims to develop ethical standards in fundraising, focusing on donor care. John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, in charge of the civil service department which polices and advises the sector, says: "Charities need to look at the banking and retail sector's efforts to understand their customers." Taking heed of this, the project aims to develop a donor charter which will be a bullet point guarantee stating what a donor can expect.

John Kingston, chair of the Giving in Confidence project, says: "There is a reservoir of trust and confidence which feeds the voluntary sector, although we are not expecting a dam burst, we cannot rely on it filling up automatically. Damaging media stories, even if unfounded, lead to evaporation."

The head of policy and research at NCVO, Margaret Bolton, says public criticism centres on the perceived lack of regulation and accountability, the proliferation of charities, pressurised fundraising and how much of a donation goes on administration.

Kingston urges charities to be up front about the cost of fundraising and administration. Research by the Henley Centre for Forecasting has shown that the public thinks charities spend more on administration than they do in reality. The project will also look at issues of management effectiveness, competition between charities and the possibility of collaboration to save costs and improve efficiency.

In a further attempt to fill the reservoir, there is an increasing trend among charities to implement quality assurance systems. Jane Hatfield, manager of the sector's Quality Standards Task Group says: "Charities are looking at ways of improving their credibility by complying with accredited systems such as Investors in People or adapting the business excellence model to show commitment to quality."

Kingston says research in the US demonstrates that public confidence in a company correlates with its share price.

He concludes: "If this is true in the commercial sector it must be even more pertinent in the voluntary sector with 70% of people thinking the most important things about charities is the values they hold."

webTitle: Straw makes decision on Afghan hostages

fields.headline: Straw makes decision on Afghan hostages
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw has granted refugee status to two passengers from the   hijacked Afghan jet which landed at Stansted last month.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw has granted refugee status to two passengers from the hijacked Afghan jet which landed at Stansted last month.

He has rejected 27 other appeals for asylum. The remainder of the passengers are either the subject of criminal charges or, in six cases, a decision has been postponed.

The recent siege at Stansted involved 142 people including crew. A total of 73 people, including 15 crew, returned voluntarily to Afghanistan.The rest have remained in Britain hoping to claim asylum. Of the unsuccessful applicants, Mr Straw said he was "not satisfied that they have a well founded fear of persecution" in their native land.

In a written Commons answer, Mr Straw said: "In both cases, as it happens, the applicant's case for asylum arose before they had boarded the flight, and it was a matter of chance for them that it was hijacked."

Mr Straw said one of the two people granted asylum had a wife who was also being given exceptional leave to enter the country. They also had five children who would be allowed to stay. He did not believe the 27 rejected applicants were in danger of persecution "by reason of their race, religion, nationality or membership of a particular social group or political opinion.

"In these cases, I have decided that the public interest in deterring future hijacks for the purposes of claiming asylum is a very strong one and, therefore, I have decided that they should not be given permission to stay in this country," he said.

Human rights campaigner, Lord Avebury, today condemned the government' s policy towards asylum seekers in a parliamentary debate on the issue. He said Mr Straw had "made arrangements which were designed to ensure that as many as possible of the passengers were induced to return ... by fair means or foul."

He said: "The home secretary doesn't have to adjust our asylum policy to the demands of the gutter tabloids, and the would-be Jorg Haiders on the extreme right of the Tory party." Lord Avebury condemned the fact that Afghan women and children were still "locked up for something that had been totally outside their control. The reception given to these people, and their treatment since, has been not only inefficient and inhumane, but probably unlawful."

fields.headline: American Beauty dominates Bafta nominations
fields.standfirst: Click here for a full list on the nominations on the Bafta official site.
fields.trailText: American Beauty seems set to dominate the awards ceremonies both sides of the Atlantic. The nominations for Britain's Bafta awards, announced this morning, saw British director Sam Mendes's debut film short-listed for awards in 14 categories, including best film, best director, best cinematography and best original film music.
fields.byline: By Film Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
American Beauty seems set to dominate the awards ceremonies both sides of the Atlantic. The nominations for Britain's Bafta awards, announced this morning, saw British director Sam Mendes's debut film short-listed for awards in 14 categories, including best film, best director, best cinematography and best original film music.

British-made movie East is East was nominated for five awards, including best film, outstanding British film of the year and best adapted screenplay.

Its stars, Linda Bassett and Om Puri, were named in the leading actor categories. Director Mike Lee's Gilbert and Sullivan biopic Topsy Turvy, was also nominated for five awards, including best original screenplay and best actor for star Jim Broadbent, and best supporting actor for Timothy Spall.

Michael Caine matched his success in the Oscar nominations when he was short-listed for best supporting actor in Cider House Rules. He is up against among others fellow-Britons Rhys Ifans for Notting Hill, Jude Law for The Talented Mr Ripley and Timothy Spall.

 The ceremony will be held on Sunday 9 April, 2000 at the Odeon, Leicester Square, London.

webTitle: ITN reporter 'bent over backwards for accuracy'

fields.headline: ITN reporter 'bent over backwards for accuracy'
fields.trailText: An ITN reporter told the high court yesterday that he bent over backwards to present an accurate picture of the "terrible inhumanity" and appalling conditions in a Serb-run detention camp in Bosnia.
fields.body:
An ITN reporter told the high court yesterday that he bent over backwards to present an accurate picture of the "terrible inhumanity" and appalling conditions in a Serb-run detention camp in Bosnia.

Ian Williams, who is suing Living Marxism magazine for libel over claims that he and other ITN journalists deliberately fabricated an image of an emaciated Muslim prisoner which became one of the most powerful and enduring images of the conflict, denied that he had taken sides against the Serbs.

He said: "The only attachment we had was to find out the truth and present what we found in a properly balanced manner. I believe we bent over backwards to present the pictures we obtained in context."

Mr Williams, 41, said he stood by his August 1992 report for Channel 4 news on the camp at Trnopolje. He rejected a claim by Living Marxism that the image of Fikret Alic, the emaciated man behind barbed wire, was misleading and had been created by "camera angles and editing".

Mr Williams, his colleague Penny Marshall, and ITN are claiming damages over a press release, editorial and article headed The picture that fooled the world, published by the magazine.

The article, published in February 1997, asserted that the camp was not a prison but a collection centre for refugees, and that the barbed wire surrounded the news team who were filming from a small enclosure next to the camp.

Mr Williams told Mr Justice Morland and the jury that he was at first incredulous and then angered by the "outrageous" allegations. "I don't think that image is at all misleading. It is a perfectly apt image encapsulating the suffering of those men in that field," he added.

Mr Williams, who travelled by bus to Trnopolje in north-west Bosnia with his ITN colleagues and Guardian journalist Ed Vulliamy, described the men in the camp as "in an appalling physical state ... emaciated, dirty and clearly very, very frightened".

He told Tom Shields QC, for ITN, that it was "absurd" to claim that the ITN crew had filmed from a compound surrounded by barbed wire. "Our report never suggested there was barbed wire surrounding the camp. What it showed was that there was a compound in which men were clearly imprisoned."

Earlier, Mr Shields said Living Marxism's editor, Michael Hume, was "intent on adopting a hostile stance to journalists of the west and western powers".

Mr Shields said the allegations had "gravely defamed" ITN and its reporters, suggesting that they had conspired to "distort the truth to fit in with their supposedly anti-Serb and pro-Muslim views".

Living Marxism, which denies libel and pleads fair comment, claims that no one would have understood its publications to refer to ITN, and claims Ms Marshall and Mr Williams deliberately misrepresented the situation in the camp.

fields.headline: A royal family matter
fields.standfirst: John Ezard finds the powers of protection and censorship around the House of Windsor remain strong
fields.trailText: Hopes of important revelations about the royal family's past were dashed at the last minute today. Historians and journalists gathering to read newly opened official files at the Bodleian library, Oxford, discovered that the most crucial personal papers had been weeded from the archive and sealed until the year 2037.
fields.body:
Hopes of important revelations about the royal family's past were dashed at the last minute today. Historians and journalists gathering to read newly opened official files at the Bodleian library, Oxford, discovered that the most crucial personal papers had been weeded from the archive and sealed until the year 2037.

Historians already know in outline of the resentment which the Queen Mother felt for more than 40 years about the 1936 abdication crisis.

She was bitter because it forced her husband - younger brother of King Edward Vlll - on to the throne reluctant and unprepared. She was also convinced that this had shortened King George V1's life, leaving her to fill most of her later years as a widow. The late king's doctors would almost certainly have agreed with her.

She and George had knelt and prayed that the royal succession would not come to him. Shortly after he was crowned, someone remarked to her that the former King Edward, who became Duke of Windsor and lived abroad in virtual exile, no longer had bags of exhaustion under his eyes.

"Yes," she replied bitterly. "Who has the lines under his eyes now?"

She strongly supported George in refusing the title "Royal Highness" to the Duchess of Windsor, the American divorcee Wallis Simpson whom Edward had left the throne to marry. According to some, this refusal was constitutionally unjustified. But it served the purpose of enraging the duke so he, in turn, refused to return to Britain, where he had once been almost as much of a popular as Diana, Princess of Wales, later became.

But, for public consumption, the Queen Mother was said to have taken a much more philosophical view of the crisis. Officials stressed her words to the then archbishop of Canterbury: "I can hardly now believe that we have been called to this tremendous task - and the curious thing is that we are not afraid. I feel that God has enabled us to face the situation."

Her hostility to the principle of royal divorces was said to have coloured her attitude to her daughter Princess Margaret's desire to marry a divorced royal equerry, Peter Townsend, in the 1950s.

When the Duchess of Windsor died in 1987, the Queen Mother attended her funeral at St George's chapel, Windsor, but not her burial. However, it was later discovered that she had been sending the duchess friendly Christmas cards since the duke's death in 1972.

Now in her 100th year, she has always refused to discuss the abdication outside the family. The broadcaster Ludovic Kennedy once raised it with her while discussing a television series.

"I'm afraid I just can't talk about it," she said. "But ma'am, it conditioned your whole life," persisted Kennedy. "Yes, I know - but I just can't," she said.

It was this void which scholars hoped the Monckton papers would throw light on. But the powers of protection and discreet censorship around the royal family remain strong.

webTitle: Oxfam's protest wins backers for action plan

fields.headline: Oxfam's protest wins backers for action plan
fields.trailText: A radical plan to tackle the education crisis in developing countries is expected to receive a substantial boost in funding after an embarrassing international row over a flagship United Nations conference.
fields.body:
A radical plan to tackle the education crisis in developing countries is expected to receive a substantial boost in funding after an embarrassing international row over a flagship United Nations conference.

Scandinavian donor countries and World Bank officials are calling on western governments to pledge additional resources for an ambitious strategy to be considered at the world forum on education for all (FEA) in Dakar, Senegal, next month.

The gathering momentum in support of a £2.3bn "Compact for Africa", proposed by Oxfam, comes after the British charity resigned last month from the FEA's organising committee in protest at what it saw as its failure to mobilise international funding and lack of coherent education targets.

Oxfam accused international organisations and western aid donors of a lack of political will. The draft agenda for the Dakar conference was "woefully inadequate" and offered nothing for the world's poorest children, 125m of whom are not at school, the charity warned.

The conference should do for education what the earth summit did for the environment, rather than offering a "teddy bears' picnic for international bureaucrats".

The Dakar forum will mark the 10th anniversary of the international pledge on basic education for all, which was supposed to have been achieved this year. But in many countries the number of children who do not attend school has increased since 1990, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.

Oxfam's withdrawal has triggered a change of attitude among some donor countries and international bodies. Senior officials from the World Bank and the UN development programme are now calling on western countries to draw up a Compact for Africa.

Supporters of a special initiative for Africa have called for African governments to draw up infrastructure reform plans specifying targets for the year 2015 before they qualify for extra aid. Participating officials from Finland, Norway and the Netherlands have also come out in support of Oxfam's programme.

"We are still lacking the political leadership for Dakar," an Oxfam spokesman said. "This conference provides an opportunity to tackle what is the biggest single cause of global poverty and inequality. We are calling on Tony Blair to start providing the leadership role which would drag this out of the mire and turn it into something meaningful."

The prime minister's interest in improving internet access around the world, Oxfam fears, will do little to tackle the fundamental causes of poverty in remote villages where there are no computers. "There is no technical quick-fix available. Tony Blair needs to do for education what Gordon Brown has done for debt cancellation."

The department for international development said yesterday that it regretted Oxfam's withdrawal from the conference's steering committee. "We do share some of Oxfam's frustrations but we would like them to stay in and strengthen the process," said a department spokesman.

Improving education - particularly among girls - is increasingly seen as a key to stimulating economic growth, controlling population and increasing health awareness.

But last month Dieter Berstecher, the head of the organising committee at the UN education, scientific and cultural organisation, said Oxfam's appeal for a £2.5bn global education fund was unrealistic.
