webTitle: Schools told to improve or close

fields.headline: Schools told to improve or close
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tough targets for the poorest performing secondary schools, to be announced by David Blunkett today, could lead to the closure of dozens of under-achieving comprehensives.
fields.body:
Tough targets for the poorest performing secondary schools, to be announced by David Blunkett today, could lead to the closure of dozens of under-achieving comprehensives.

Schools which fail for three years in a row to get at least 15% of their pupils through GCSE with five good passes at grade C or above will be targeted for closure.

Local education authorities will be encouraged to put them into the government's "fresh start" programme which involves reopening with a new name and a new head. Teachers will be obliged to reapply for their jobs and those not meeting the required standards will face redundancy.

The education secretary hopes that few comprehensives will fail to reach the target. He will be offering a range of remedial measures including a pilot programme for appointing "superheads".

Mr Blunkett says in an interview in the Times: "The challenge will be difficult and I can already hear the cries from those who say it can't be done. Yet I am convinced that we can and must meet this challenge - and we will be monitoring those schools which fail to reach the benchmark and taking action where necessary."

His plans for "superheads" involves bringing in experienced head teachers who will be used to try to rescue schools with failing results, or others at risk of failing.

Mr Blunkett dismissed the idea that failing schools are often those in deprived areas and said that there are as many failing schools in leafy suburban areas. "New research by my department shows that schools with the poorest GCSE results are often found in suburbs."

Mr Blunkett is expected to announce his plans at a conference on secondary education organised by the National Union of Teachers in London.

In addition to the closure threat to the poorest performers, there will be GCSE targets for all schools. He will say none should fall below a 20% pass rate by 2004.

Mr Blunkett dismissed the idea that failing schools are often those in deprived areas and said that there are as many failing schools in leafy suburban areas. "New research by my department shows that schools with the poorest GCSE results are often found in suburbs." Mr Blunkett is expected to announce his plans at a conference on secondary education organised by the National Union of Teachers in London. In addition to the closure threat to the poorest performers, there will be GCSE targets for all schools. He will say none should fall below a 20% pass rate by 2004.

webTitle: Whitehall argues over helicopters as waters rise

fields.headline: Whitehall argues over helicopters as waters rise
fields.standfirst:
More about the floods in Mozambique
Listen to Chris McGreal in Mozambique
fields.trailText: Whitehall departments spent yesterday locked in a ministerial-level dispute over funding and logistics in a belated attempt to scramble RAF helicopters for life-saving airlifts in Mozambique.
fields.body:
Whitehall departments spent yesterday locked in a ministerial-level dispute over funding and logistics in a belated attempt to scramble RAF helicopters for life-saving airlifts in Mozambique.

The international development secretary, Clare Short, and the ministry of defence discussed the possibility of transporting military helicopters more than 3,000 miles to southern Africa before rising floods swept away remaining survivors.

But late last night her department (DfID) claimed that it had located three previously unused helicopters within Mozambique which it could put into operation faster than flying out RAF or Royal Navy aircraft. It was not clear whether the Mozambique helicopters were airworthy or would need major repairs.

If successful, it would add to a further £450,000 the DfID has pledged to the World Food Programme to hire an extra two helicopters from South Africa, and bring to nine the number of aircraft it is paying for in Mozambique.

"The extra funding will keep at least two more helicopters flying for the next three weeks," said a department spokeswoman.

As the department announced that its total aid package to the region had risen to £3m, aid agencies were insisting that it was not their role to provide the extra helicopters and boats urgently needed.

As few as 12 South African and Malawian helicopters were yesterday involved in the frantic search and rescue missions - although another six South African aircraft have now been promised.

International development department officials had earlier warned that there was a desperate shortage of helicopters and that "local capacity is not up to dealing with the problem". The Red Cross also claimed some South African companies were charging up to £50,000 a day for flying into the inundated Limpopo and Save river valleys.

The MoD yesterday said it did not have the resources to fly the required Puma or Sea King helicopters to the region. The nearest aircraft are 3,000 miles away on HMS Illustrious in the Gulf, nine days' sailing from Mozambique.

"We don't have the capacity to fly helicopters by air," an MoD spokesman said. "Hercules aircraft cannot lift them. We would need to charter larger Antonov 124 planes. DfID are in discussion with us but they have not yet made a formal request for help. The cost would be for them to meet."

In Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, the World Food Programme spokeswoman Michele Quintagile urged: "We've got families who are not going to be able to hang on much longer. We should be flying helicopters in, if necessary, from Europe."

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said last night: "We are all deeply concerned at the human suffering in Mozambique."

fields.headline: Horror mounts for Maputo
fields.standfirst: International aid is starting to trickle in to the flood-ravaged country, says Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Hour by hour the horrors grow. It is now known that 1m people have been displaced by the Mozambique floods, and that 200,000 have lost their homes in the surging waters. Officially, the death toll stands at 200, but that bureaucratically contrived figure is certain to be dwarfed when the flood recedes and yields its ghastly evidence of death.
fields.body:
Hour by hour the horrors grow. It is now known that 1m people have been displaced by the Mozambique floods, and that 200,000 have lost their homes in the surging waters. Officially, the death toll stands at 200, but that bureaucratically contrived figure is certain to be dwarfed when the flood recedes and yields its ghastly evidence of death.

Though the rains have eased, torrents of water are still flowing into the worst stricken areas of Mozambique from saturated parts of South Africa, Zimbabwe and neighbouring nations.

Slowly and belatedly international aid is coming in. Britain announced today that it will send two heavy transport aircraft with 30 trained rescue workers, 69 inflatable motorboats, 39 life rafts and emergency vehicles. The aid pledged by London now stands at £4.5m.

The US, which this morning had offered just £600,000, now says it will give 10 times that figure. An American C-17 Hercules plane arrived in Mozambique's capital, Maputo, carrying blankets, food, and other emergency supplies.

Distribution of emergency aid has been slowed by the diversion of scarce helicopters and other aircraft to the more urgent task of rescuing stranded flood victims, many of whom have been without food or clean water for more than a week. The British government announced that it will send five more helicopters, chartered in South Africa, to join the rescue effort.

Total international aid is now estimated to have reached some £13.5m. Though that figure is steadily rising, it is only a fraction of what is needed to rescue and sustain the flood victims. And rehabilitation of the stricken landscape will cost infinitely more.

Last week, Mozambican foreign minister Leonardo Simao appealed for some £40m for reconstruction of vital services and facilities. That figure now looks woefully inadequate as aid and rescue workers talk of wholesale destruction of roads, bridges, rail links and other infrastructure.

More immediate is the threat of starvation and disease. At least one third of the country's emergency supplies of food has disappeared beneath the flood waters. As cyclone Eline recedes and the floods subside, there is a risk of infection from the thousands of corpses feared trapped in the debris.

Domestic and wild animals too have perished in incalculable numbers, and international animal welfare charity Vetaid is urgently appealing for funds for an emergency clean-up and to replace vital farm stock and draught animals.

webTitle: Fate of flood victims hangs on meagre aid

fields.headline: Fate of flood victims hangs on meagre aid
fields.standfirst:
Anger is mounting at the world's inadequate response to the Mozambique disaster as agencies plead for help

More about the floods in Mozambique
Listen to Chris McGreal in Mozambique
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of missing people are beyond the reach of the international rescue operation in Mozambique because of insufficient helicopters and boats, despite the promises of millions of pounds in foreign aid in recent days.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of missing people are beyond the reach of the international rescue operation in Mozambique because of insufficient helicopters and boats, despite the promises of millions of pounds in foreign aid in recent days.

A few South African helicopter crews yesterday continued to pluck hundreds of people from flooded towns and villages in Gaza province along the Limpopo river, less than an hour's flight from the capital, Maputo. But there is growing concern about the fate of entire towns near the badly flooded Save river further north, and the United Nations predicts that a new wave of floods will hit the region within days.

At least 50,000 people are unaccounted for in towns and villages along the Save river valley. The towns of Massangena and Zinavane were already flooded before further floods on Saturday night. But with rescue efforts concentrated elsewhere, there is no word on the fate of the inhabitants.

Roy Trivedy, director of Save the Children in Mozambique, which is working in two other flooded towns at the mouth of the river, said there is an urgent need for a rescue mission to explore the rest of the region.

"The big question is that those people aren't here, so where are they? Clearly there is a very sizeable number of people unaccounted for. Almost all the people rescued reported seeing people washed away. There is a high likelihood of very high casualties," he said. "We have two helicopters trying to save several thousand people we already know are stranded. We need more helicopters. The need for more boats and fuel is urgent."

Save the Children is working with 10,000 survivors at the mouth of Save river. Many are sheltering in trees or on roofs.

"Roughly 85% of the efforts are going into Gaza," said Mr Trivedy. "There may be very good reasons for that because of the numbers of people and the major cities that are affected there. What is going on in Gaza is really terrible, but what's going on in Save is equally terrible and it needs more help."

So far, however, there are simply not enough helicopters and other means of rescue to serve both regions at once.

Jean-Jacques Graisse, the World Food Programme director of operations, warned that the situation for thousands of people is worsening, saying they "increasingly run the risk of illness and starvation if humanitarian assistance is not immediately expanded".

He added: "With more water coming, the disaster could spread much wider. Thousands of people are stranded, some on rooftops, in trees, on anything they can cling too."

He said the priorities are threefold: tens of thousands of people still urgently need rescuing from flooded towns and valleys.

Once most of the destitute have been plucked to safety, they have to be housed and fed. It will take a massive airlift to bring hundreds of tons of food and water purification equipment, and tents and blankets, to the camps being set up.

Then there is the urgent need to rebuild Mozambique's infrastructure, particularly its roads, to ease the delivery of aid over the coming months and limit long-term damage to the economy.

The WFP has delivered tons of maize to some areas, and aid workers say many survivors are in better condition than might be expected. But there are fears that without access to clean water soon, diseases such as cholera and dysentery could take hold.

Emergency workers say there is confusion about the time and place of the arrival of aid. Some point out that the floods began three weeks ago, which gave the UN time to organise a more substantial relief effort. They note that the two most senior UN officials in Mozambique have both been abroad since the crisis struck.

Many Mozambicans have wondered about the role of their own government, particularly President Joaquim Chissano, who has had little to do or say during the crisis. He finally flew to Gaza yesterday.

"I saw three corpses uncovered by the water and so there must be many more," Mr Chissano said.

Telephone: 0870 6060900

Unicef Mozambique children's emergency appeal

By post: Unicef Mozambique children's emergency appeal, Unicef, Room MOZ, Freepost, Chelmsford, CM2 8BR

webTitle: Britain announces more aid for Mozambique

fields.headline: Britain announces more aid for Mozambique
fields.trailText: Britain has found more planes, helicopters, boats and volunteers to help flood stricken Mozambique, international development secretary Clare Short announced today.
fields.body:
Britain has found more planes, helicopters, boats and volunteers to help flood stricken Mozambique, international development secretary Clare Short announced today.

Ms Short said two more helicopters, two planes, 79 boats and 30 volunteers and emergency experts from Britain were being sent to the region. This was in addition to the government's announcement yesterday of a further £500,000 in aid to help the people of Mozambique after floods stranded thousands and killed an unknown number.

Ms Short warned the Commons: "I'm afraid the situation is terrible and going to get very much worse. There's another cyclone coming in, another river is about to overflow."

Earlier today Mozambique's president asked the world to help his flood-ravaged nation, where thousands of people are feared dead and thousands more are trapped on rooftops or in waist-deep water after weeks of rain. "We speak of 1m people on the move at the moment," president Joaquim Chissano told reporters.

The latest official estimate is that 200 people have died in the floods that have devastated the southeast African country since the beginning of last month. But aid agencies expect the death toll to run into the thousands. Bodies are believed to be trapped inside huts or underwater. More water is expected to flow into Mozambique over already saturated areas from neighboring South Africa and Zimbabwe, where there have also been heavy rains. Officials warned that new floods might hit rivers further north. "Our greatest fear is that the rainy season will progress and there will be pressure on the Zambezi and Licungo rivers," said Tom Harrer, an adviser to the Mozambican government's national disaster management services.

Those rivers, fed by heavy rains in neighboring Zimbabwe and Zambia, traverse Mozambique's Zambezia province. Zimbabwe has already opened two of the three gates from the overflowing Kariba dam, releasing water at a rate of 3,000 cubic metres a second. If the third gate is opened, the outflow rate will double.

A refugee camp has been established at the southern village of Chaquelane, 100 miles northeast of Mozambique's capital, Maputo, where 30,000 people have gathered. On Tuesday, 30 tonnes of aid were delivered to the camp. In the Commons Liberal Democrat Jenny Tonge said that Mozambique would still have pay £62m servicing debts this year - more than its health and education budgets combined. "It will be years before Mozambique reaches the level it was even two weeks ago," she said.

webTitle: Relatives of hanged Telford men meet police chief

fields.headline: Relatives of hanged Telford men meet police chief
fields.trailText: The relatives of Harold (Errol) and Jason McGowan, found hanged within six months of each other, today met the head of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crime task force at Scotland Yard.
fields.body:
The relatives of Harold (Errol) and Jason McGowan, found hanged within six months of each other, today met the head of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crime task force at Scotland Yard.

The family arrived in a 55-seater coach from Shropshire. They were accompanied by a band of around 40 protesters demanding: "Justice for Errol and Jason". The family were today urging the task force to take over the investigation of the two men's deaths.

Harold McGowan's brother Leroy said: "It is our understanding that John Grieve will be willing to take over the case. It is our wish that he do so."

The delegation to Scotland Yard included four of Errol's brothers, his mother and his widow Sinead. His father, Robert King, who has said in the past he believed Jason had committed suicide, was not present.

When the family emerged from their meeting with Mr Grieve they refused to be drawn on the full contents of the their discussions. Sinead McGowan said: "We are satisfied with the way things have gone."

They were due to meet home secretary Jack Straw at the House of Commons where a full statement will be made later today.

A spokesman for West Mercia Police said: "West Mercia constabulary welcomes the support of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crime task force in relation to the ongoing inquiry into the deaths of Harold and Jason McGowan, which was launched on February 1.

"It has always been the force's wish to work with the McGowan family in relation to this matter and the task force who were asked to meet with the family and their representatives to enhance our ongoing relationship with them."

The chief constable of West Mercia police, Peter Hampton, last month rejected the families' demand that the inquiry be handed over to the task force. Mr Hampton, who earlier agreed to a joint re-investigation of both deaths, has said he has confidence in his own officers to conduct the new inquiry.

The families' solicitor, Imran Khan, urged the task force to take over the case earlier today, saying that the families had "lost all confidence" in the West Mercia force.

fields.headline: Lover's anger over race attack
fields.standfirst:
White woman launches campaign to find Asians who beat her boyfriend 'because of their wedding plans'

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Kasia Myers is determined to track down the six men who attacked her boyfriend the night before Valentine's Day, leaving him with footprints all over his face. She is so determined that she has printed wanted posters showing the injuries to her boyfriend's face and appealing for information on his assailants.
fields.body:
Kasia Myers is determined to track down the six men who attacked her boyfriend the night before Valentine's Day, leaving him with footprints all over his face. She is so determined that she has printed wanted posters showing the injuries to her boyfriend's face and appealing for information on his assailants.

Angry at what she saw as a lack of action by Wiltshire police after the attack, she plastered Swindon town centre with the posters naming two of the men she believes were involved in the attack.

Ms Myers, 34, is white. Her boyfriend, Hardip Samra, 25, is Indian. She firmly believes he was the victim of a racist attack: provoked by the news that the couple may soon become engaged.

Mr Samra had been at an all day Indian party on the day of the assault, where he told friends he planned to propose to his girlfriend on Valentine's Day. But outside the club, as he stood in the queue at a kebab van, he was attacked by six Asian men who had also been at the party. Mr Samra lost consciousness as the men punched, kicked and stood on his face. His nose had to be reset in hospital.

It was the state of his face and frustration that provoked Ms Myers into action. "I was desperate. It just seemed that nothing was being done. I had gone to the police station with his bloodstained jumper. After the assault, I received threatening phone calls and the numbers were still on the phone. But the officer was too busy," she said.

Mr Samra told Ms Myers he believed he had been attacked because of his intention to propose to a white woman.

Police are investigating the attack and have called it a serious assault, although it is not known whether they are treating it as a racial attack.

Ms Myers, who is unemployed, said she had been in hiding since speaking out. She claimed she had been followed, had people battering at her ground floor flat windows in the middle of the night and had been verbally abused.

She said: "The point is that me and Hardy are lying low, and the people involved are out all over town."

Sitting in a pub in a village near Swindon, Ms Myers had tears in her eyes as she realised her actions had jeopardised the future of her three-and-a-half year relationship. However, she had no regrets.

"From the beginning our relationship has been about what everyone else thinks. It's all right ignoring that but not this. When someone does this kind of physical damage, I just can't sit back," she said.

She went to the Swindon Evening Advertiser and told her story. Since it appeared in the newspaper the Samra family have closed ranks around their son, who recently sent Ms Myers a text message saying: "They are all having a go at me because of you."

She said: "I don't think we will get married now. I think there will be pressure from the Indian community. I love him and I want to be with him but I don't want those people to get away with what they did."

Inspector Steve Kellow, of Swindon police, said: "There is an investigation ongoing. This was a very serious assault and these people need to be caught. If anyone knows where they are we are very keen to talk to them.

"We have been in contact with Ms Myers and are keen to hear of any more information she might have."

Ms Myers, who is unemployed, said she had been in hiding since speaking out. She claimed she had been followed, had people battering at her ground floor flat windows in the middle of the night and had been verbally abused. She said: "The point is that me and Hardy are lying low, and the people involved are out all over town." Sitting in a pub in a village near Swindon, Ms Myers had tears in her eyes as she realised her actions had jeopardised the future of her three-and-a-half year relationship. However, she had no regrets. "From the beginning our relationship has been about what everyone else thinks. It's all right ignoring that but not this. When someone does this kind of physical damage, I just can't sit back," she said. She went to the Swindon Evening Advertiser and told her story. Since it appeared in the newspaper the Samra family have closed ranks around their son, who recently sent Ms Myers a text message saying: "They are all having a go at me because of you." She said: "I don't think we will get married now. I think there will be pressure from the Indian community. I love him and I want to be with him but I don't want those people to get away with what they did." Inspector Steve Kellow, of Swindon police, said: "There is an investigation ongoing. This was a very serious assault and these people need to be caught. If anyone knows where they are we are very keen to talk to them. "We have been in contact with Ms Myers and are keen to hear of any more information she might have."

webTitle: DJ attacked over remarks about black athletes

fields.headline: DJ attacked over remarks about black athletes
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Radio 2 presenter Sarah Kennedy was under fire last night after suggesting that black people make good runners because they are used to being chased by lions.
fields.body:
Radio 2 presenter Sarah Kennedy was under fire last night after suggesting that black people make good runners because they are used to being chased by lions.

The comments, which drew criticism from race relations groups, athletes and politicians, were made on her pre-breakfast programme on Radio 2 during an informal discussion of genetics.

Speaking shortly after 6.30am yesterday, Miss Kennedy said it was odd that she could think of no competitive black swimmers despite the fact "you black people are all so marvellous at running". She then read a letter from a listener who claimed to have asked a Zambian athletics coach in the 1960s why there were no champion black swimmers, and received the answer: "Crocodiles."

Miss Kennedy then said: "That's why you black people make such good runners - lions. I thought that was a great letter."

The Campaign for Racial Equality condemned Miss Kennedy's comments as offensive and potentially dangerous. "People who make comments like these are pathetic," said a spokesman.

"All one can hope is that someone in a position with responsibility for broadcasting standards at the BBC takes some action to make sure this sort of stuff doesn't get on to the airwaves.

"This kind of talk does a great deal to perpetuate these ideas which so many people find truly offensive. This is the soft end of prejudice. It can lend authority to racist prejudices which can lead to lives being damaged and people getting hurt," the spokesman added.

The writer and broadcaster Trevor Phillips called on Miss Kennedy to apologise: "I know Sarah. She's a decent and quite clever woman, but I think were she to stop and think for 30 seconds she'd realise how stupid, offensive and unfunny her comments were," he said.

"I hope she will apologise to those people who may have been offended despite having grown up somewhere without a lion in sight."

Mike McFarlane, former Olympic sprint finalist and British team coach at the European Indoor Championship last weekend, said: "People who say things like this are ignorant and shouldn't have a job. People in the black community will take this with a pinch of salt and not rise to it. There are more important things to worry about than listen to a prat. We've heard this rubbish too many times."

Reigning Commonwealth triple jump champion Ashia Hanson said: "It's a bit close to the bone. Black people have had a difficult enough time without people making comments like this. Saying things like this mean you can be considered racist even though she's probably not."

Yesterday afternoon Miss Kennedy, 48, denied intending to cause offence. In a statement she said: "Regular listeners will know that over the last few weeks we have been discussing the facts about genetics. No offence was meant, I haven't a racist bone in my body."

A BBC spokeswoman said they had not received any complaints from listeners about the programme.

Miss Kennedy has presented the Radio 2 Early Show since 1993, after establishing herself as a TV presenter. She found fame as a presenter on ITV's Game For A Laugh, and went on to work on Busman's Holiday for Granada. Last May she took a week off citing tiredness after more than 20 listeners complained when she deputised for Terry Wogan on Radio 2.

fields.headline: Irving 'committed to neo-Nazism in Germany'
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: The historian David Irving had "committed himself wholeheartedly" to the cause of neo-Nazism in Germany, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The historian David Irving had "committed himself wholeheartedly" to the cause of neo-Nazism in Germany, the high court was told yesterday.

The claim was made by Hajo Funke, of the Free University of Berlin, during Mr Irving's libel action against the American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books over allegations that he is a "Holocaust denier".

Professor Funke told the court that Mr Irving's unconditional expulsion in 1993 "indicated the authorities' unwillingness to further tolerate his use of Germany as a 'playground' for his rightwing extremism". Mr Irving, of Mayfair, London, is seeking damages over Professor Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, which he says has generated waves of hatred against him.

Prof Funke, an expert witness called on behalf of the defendants, who deny libel, compiled a lengthy report for the hearing relating to Mr Irving's alleged connections with rightwing extremists and neo-Nazism in Germany.

He claimed Mr Irving had, from the early 1980s, been one of the "main speakers and agitators" for the "rightwing extremist" DVU party until he was banned from entering Germany in 1993.

The party was extremist, anti-Semitic and "propagates racial hatred", he said. The court saw video footage of a meeting in Germany in the early 1990s, at which Mr Irving was a speaker, showing skinheads demonstrating and chanting sieg heil.

Mr Irving said he had put up his hand to tell them to stop and said it was not impossible that "the skinheads had been bribed to come along and shout these slogans". He denies having had connections with any extremist German group.

His case is that the DVU (German People's Union) is a long-standing democratic and lawfully constituted German political organisation which has competed in the national and municipal elections. The 62-year-old author of Hitler's War is representing himself in the hearing before Mr Justice Gray, sitting without a jury.

Mr Irving said he accepted invitations from "whichever body invites me", provided he could fit it into his timetable.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Words written in blood
fields.standfirst:
We've heard all these whining excuses before, says David Cesarani
The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: Eichmann's prison memoir is a darkly fascinating document which contains details that historians will pore over for a long time. But it does not tell us anything of significance that is new about the Final Solution, nor much that is new about Eichmann. It is hard to see how it will have much effect in the Irving v Lipstadt trial.
fields.body:
Eichmann's prison memoir is a darkly fascinating document which contains details that historians will pore over for a long time. But it does not tell us anything of significance that is new about the Final Solution, nor much that is new about Eichmann. It is hard to see how it will have much effect in the Irving v Lipstadt trial.

The prison writings repeat, in essence, the "memoir" that Eichmann dictated to Belgian journalist Willem Sassens in the 50s. This was published in truncated form in Life magazine in 1960. They closely resemble the extended memoir, Ich Adolf Eichmann, based on Eichmann's notes for these interviews, which appeared in 1980, edited by a rightwing German lawyer called Rudolf Aschenauer. In both cases the tone is one of whining exculpation and self-justification. Eichmann also took the opportunity to settle a few old scores, too.

In 1992, David Irving created a typical sensation by revealing that he had obtained the original tapes and transcript of the Sassen interviews. The following year, writing about the tapes, he claimed that Eichmann never mentioned homicidal gas chambers. Most historians dismissed the extra material served up in 1992 as valueless: more of the same "it wasn't me, guv" tosh that had been served up earlier.

Yet Irving had to admit that there were details which posed a problem for those who disputed the central facts of Holocaust history. In particular, Eichmann recalled a meeting with Heydrich at which he was told: "The Führer has ordered the physical extermination of the Jews." In the latest version of his life left by the wily Eichmann to posterity, there are similar asides. He remembers: "In Treblinka and Belzec, Globocnik [senior SS officer in the Lublin district of occupied Poland] had erected gassing camps on the orders of Himmler and Kruger."

However, a question mark looms over the reliability of the memoir. At the start, Eichmann talks about his precarious situation, his relationship with his lawyer, and the conditions under which he was writing. He constantly shifts the blame and wriggles out of awkward questions, presumably in the hope of justifying a final reprieve.

He certainly acknowledges the mass murder of Jews and says he saw with his own eyes "the killing fields" and the "machinery of death" but Irving is practised at dismissing prison-house confessions such as these. They are as dubious as his account of his schooldays when he recalls that his best friend was a Jew. They are as unconvincing as his disavowal of anti-Jewish feeling, even when he was in the SS. But as an insight into a poisoned mind, his mordant reflections on life and nature, and his lack of self-criticism, they are priceless.

fields.headline: 'A monumental dance of death'
fields.standfirst:
As he awaited execution by Israel in 1962, Adolf Eichmann, the architect of the Holocaust, wrote a 1,300-page diary of his time at the top of the Nazi regime. For 40 years, the manuscript has been kept under lock and key. Now, to help a US academic in a libel suit brought by the author David Irving, it has been released. Suzanne Goldenberg was one of a handful of journalists to see the document.
The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: As he awaited execution by Israel in 1962, Adolf Eichmann, the architect of the Holocaust, wrote a 1,300-page diary of his time at the top of the Nazi regime. For 40 years, the manuscript has been kept under lock and key. Now, to help a US academic in a libel suit brought by the author David Irving, it has been released.
fields.body:
I will recount the genocide against Jewry, as it occurred, and describe my thinking both yesterday and today about this. For not only the fields of death did I have to see with my own eyes, the battle fields where life itself died, I saw much worse. I saw how, by a few words, through a single, abrupt order of one individual, whom the regime empowered, fields of annihilation were created. I saw the eeriness of the death machinery; wheel turning on wheel, like the mechanisms of a watch. And I saw those who maintained the machinery, who kept it going. I saw them, as they rewound the mechanism; and I watched the second hand, as it rushed through the seconds; rushing like lives towards death. The greatest and most monumental dance of death of all time.

"This I saw."

The passage, written in blue ink in an even hand, was written by Adolf Eichmann on September 6 1961 as the Nazi officer who masterminded the destruction of Europe's Jews awaited sentencing in an Israeli court on crimes against humanity.

Eight months later, Eichmann was hanged and his ashes were scattered over the Mediterranean. His memoirs - which he intended as the basis of a book to be entitled False Gods - were lodged in a locked safe in the Israeli state archives. And there they lay, all but forgotten, until yesterday when the Israeli state archives handed out a limited number of copies of the manuscript on computer disk.

Despite misgivings about the surfacing of so self-serving an account of the Nazi holocaust by one of its main perpetrators, the justice ministry felt moved to intervene in a libel trial now under way in London. Lawyers for an American academic and Penguin Books, had requested the document for their defence in a libel suit brought by the writer David Irving.

The memoir is a rambling and often repetitive account of Eichmann's life and the Nazi killing machine. Replete with philosophical meanderings and references to the Fatherland, duty and service, it stretches to some 1,300 pages. While Eichmann does not flinch from using the German word for genocide - völkermord - he never admits to his own guilt or betrays any sign of personal remorse. Instead, he portrays himself as a man caught up by powers beyond his control.

Written in longhand, and in out-moded script in a series of A4-sized notebooks that have barely yellowed with time, the manuscript is divided into chapters and includes footnotes. Each page contains Eichmann's signature along the left margin, the final "n" of his surname trailing into oblivion. It also contains Eichmann's last will and testament with elaborate instructions for the disposal of his mortal remains. Eichmann wanted to be cremated along the Danube, at Linz, and his ashes divided into seven piles - one to be put into his parents' grave in Linz, one to be buried in his garden in Argentina, and one each to go to his wife and four sons. He adds: "Death is no worse than birth, and a thousand times a thousand lives await us after ours." He dates the passage August 15 1961 and notes that is the 30th anniversary of his engagement to his wife, Vera.

It is unclear how the memoirs will serve in defending the libel suit brought by Irving. In a book published in 1993, Professor Deborah Lipstadt of Emory University, the academic who is being sued, calls him a "Nazi partisan" for denying the systematic slaughter of Europe's Jews; Irving insists he is not a denier of the holocaust.

Israeli scholars say the memoirs add little to the volume of evidence accumulated during Eichmann's trial in Jerusalem - which runs to some 3,000 pages. "It restates all the things Eichmann said at the trial, including the statement that the annihilation of the Jews is the worst crime in recorded history," says Professor Yehuda Bauer, director of research at the Yad Vashem holocaust memorial museum in Jerusalem. "He says he and Hitler were responsible and he talks about pagan gods whom he, unfortunately, came to believe in."

However, Evytar Friesel, Israel's state archivist, says the manuscript is valuable for the insight it offers into Eichmann's psychology. "There is an interesting insight into the personal aspect of the matter. Eichmann has become a kind of symbol and here there is someone who is dealing with him as a very, very ordinary normal man."

Throughout the memoir, which begins with Eichmann's birth at Solingen, Germany, in 1906, there are references to his family life. It describes his childhood, and years as a young man, trips to the mountains and beer parlours, and flowers for his girlfriends - an idyll that was interrupted when the "False God" of National Socialism beckoned in 1931.

Eichmann was entranced by the symbols of the Fatherland, and the promise of renewal. "I served the gods with my whole being and faith. There was nothing I wouldn't do for them," he writes. Much later the memoir describes in detail the system of ghettoes, cattle trains and death camps that Eichmann devised for the slaughter of the Jews.

"In January 42 I was given orders by Mueller to drive to Posen and give him a report on the killing of Jews. Before that, I had read some secret circulations [memos] of shooting of Jews in the East. But it was not real for me, I couldn't imagine it. What I got to see now was horror personified, nothing like last autumn in Lublin. I saw naked Jewish men and women entering an omnibus without windows. The doors closed and the motors started. The exhaust gases did not escape on the outside, they were directed inside. A doctor in a white coat pointed out a little spyhole in the driver's window and asked me to watch through it, but I couldn't. Everything seemed unreal. I couldn't stop the killing in any case. I would not have been able to, physically."

And in his foreword, which was appended to his memoir, he admits: that the Nazi ideology was responsible for "the greatest crime committed in the history of humanity." But throughout the diary, details of Eichmann's personality constantly intrude.

He talks about coffee houses, and the difficulty of negotiating highly polished floors in heavy boots. He describes his irritation with desk duty, and with initially being assigned to the wrong corps of the SS, and the strange ceremony at which he was inducted into the Nazis' elite unit. During the oath-taking, he describes seeing a human skeleton in a coffin. "Strange, I thought, very strange, all of it, but perhaps this corpse was housed in a museum."

The manuscript's value to scholars lies in such details - along with Eichmann's later descriptions of the horror he created.

"You have a human being, there is no doubt, you do not have a monster," says Friesel. "You have a man, living and talking like a human being who is beginning to recognise he is part of a terrible crime, but is saying: 'what could I do'."

On that crucial point all the scholars who have seen the memoirs agree: it is utterly self-serving. Eichmann repeatedly describes himself as one in a team of horses, driven by a relentless coachman. "Regarding his own role, he lied through his teeth," says Bauer.

It is perhaps Eichmann's efforts to minimise his personal guilt in the annihilation of the Jews that guided the decision of David Ben-Gurion, the Israeli prime minister at the time of his trial, to order the memoirs to vanish into a locked safe at the state archives. Although Ben-Gurion wanted Eichmann's prosecution to be highly public - it was the world's first televised trial - there was concern that the memoir would confuse the truths established there.

And so the mansucript lay in the state archives, stacked up in manila envelopes and a medium-sized cardboard box. The Israeli authorities were reminded of the existence of the memoirs last August, when Dieter Eichmann, one of his four sons, approached the attorney general and requested the manuscript. After much deliberation, the Israeli justice ministry decided to hand it over. But for the urgency of Liptstadt's case, the process would have taken months.

Holocaust scholars would also have preferred the text to have appeared in edited form, so that Eichmann's assertions that he was powerless to stop the killing would not have gone unchallenged. But as the copy right of the memoirs rests with Eichmann's survivors, that option was not legally possible. Now, with its reappearance, among the striking aspects of the memoir - excluding of course the mendacity in his denial of his own guilt - is its sheer vanity.

In his foreword, Eichmann frets about his abilities as a writer, fearing that his explanation of the horrors that he orchestrated may be "empty and superficial", and that his writing style would be more suitable to humorous, light-hearted stories.

He stipulates that he would like his version of the Nazi horrors to be bound in dove grey, or pearl, with a simple typeface on the cover and dictates the inscriptions to be made on the copies to be given to his four sons: "This is the way it was." He does not want the work to be published under a pseudonym and, although he must have known he could be hanged for his crimes, he asks to be consulted in case future editors deviate from his two suggested titles: False Gods, or a Greek maxim meaning Know Thyself. Eichmann turns to the classics again for the quotation to be placed on the frontspiece of his memoir, suggesting a passage from Plato's cave parable: "And he would consider his shadow world as true, but the real world as an illusion."

Above all, Eichmann seems to be writing from a sense of mission. Although the text was never admitted as evidence during his appeal, it seems clear that he wanted to set out his version of the hell he helped to create.

"I have therefore decided, to use time until the sentence is handed down, rather to make use of it, and to put into action what I declared. It cannot hurt; rather it can make people think what life can throw at a person," he writes in the foreword. "I was inspired by a thousand ideals and like many others I slid into something from which I could not extricate myself. Today, I have a distance of time from the events. Much that was valid then has become invalid. Previous 'philosophical values' I have discarded as obsolete junk and thrown overboard in the course of the years one by one.

"Because I saw hell, death and the devil, because I had to witness the insanity of annihilation, because I was reined in as one of the many horses and could not break out either to the right or the left because of the will of the coachman and his orders, I feel called to, and I have the desire to, recount here and to give account of that which transpired."

Eichmann was entranced by the symbols of the Fatherland, and the promise of renewal. "I served the gods with my whole being and faith. There was nothing I wouldn't do for them," he writes. Much later the memoir describes in detail the system of ghettoes, cattle trains and death camps that Eichmann devised for the slaughter of the Jews. "In January 42 I was given orders by Mueller to drive to Posen and give him a report on the killing of Jews. Before that, I had read some secret circulations [memos] of shooting of Jews in the East. But it was not real for me, I couldn't imagine it. What I got to see now was horror personified, nothing like last autumn in Lublin. I saw naked Jewish men and women entering an omnibus without windows. The doors closed and the motors started. The exhaust gases did not escape on the outside, they were directed inside. A doctor in a white coat pointed out a little spyhole in the driver's window and asked me to watch through it, but I couldn't. Everything seemed unreal. I couldn't stop the killing in any case. I would not have been able to, physically." And in his foreword, which was appended to his memoir, he admits: that the Nazi ideology was responsible for "the greatest crime committed in the history of humanity." But throughout the diary, details of Eichmann's personality constantly intrude. He talks about coffee houses, and the difficulty of negotiating highly polished floors in heavy boots. He describes his irritation with desk duty, and with initially being assigned to the wrong corps of the SS, and the strange ceremony at which he was inducted into the Nazis' elite unit. During the oath-taking, he describes seeing a human skeleton in a coffin. "Strange, I thought, very strange, all of it, but perhaps this corpse was housed in a museum." The manuscript's value to scholars lies in such details - along with Eichmann's later descriptions of the horror he created. "You have a human being, there is no doubt, you do not have a monster," says Friesel. "You have a man, living and talking like a human being who is beginning to recognise he is part of a terrible crime, but is saying: 'what could I do'." On that crucial point all the scholars who have seen the memoirs agree: it is utterly self-serving. Eichmann repeatedly describes himself as one in a team of horses, driven by a relentless coachman. "Regarding his own role, he lied through his teeth," says Bauer. It is perhaps Eichmann's efforts to minimise his personal guilt in the annihilation of the Jews that guided the decision of David Ben-Gurion, the Israeli prime minister at the time of his trial, to order the memoirs to vanish into a locked safe at the state archives. Although Ben-Gurion wanted Eichmann's prosecution to be highly public - it was the world's first televised trial - there was concern that the memoir would confuse the truths established there. And so the mansucript lay in the state archives, stacked up in manila envelopes and a medium-sized cardboard box. The Israeli authorities were reminded of the existence of the memoirs last August, when Dieter Eichmann, one of his four sons, approached the attorney general and requested the manuscript. After much deliberation, the Israeli justice ministry decided to hand it over. But for the urgency of Liptstadt's case, the process would have taken months. Holocaust scholars would also have preferred the text to have appeared in edited form, so that Eichmann's assertions that he was powerless to stop the killing would not have gone unchallenged. But as the copy right of the memoirs rests with Eichmann's survivors, that option was not legally possible. Now, with its reappearance, among the striking aspects of the memoir - excluding of course the mendacity in his denial of his own guilt - is its sheer vanity. In his foreword, Eichmann frets about his abilities as a writer, fearing that his explanation of the horrors that he orchestrated may be "empty and superficial", and that his writing style would be more suitable to humorous, light-hearted stories. He stipulates that he would like his version of the Nazi horrors to be bound in dove grey, or pearl, with a simple typeface on the cover and dictates the inscriptions to be made on the copies to be given to his four sons: "This is the way it was." He does not want the work to be published under a pseudonym and, although he must have known he could be hanged for his crimes, he asks to be consulted in case future editors deviate from his two suggested titles: False Gods, or a Greek maxim meaning Know Thyself. Eichmann turns to the classics again for the quotation to be placed on the frontspiece of his memoir, suggesting a passage from Plato's cave parable: "And he would consider his shadow world as true, but the real world as an illusion." Above all, Eichmann seems to be writing from a sense of mission. Although the text was never admitted as evidence during his appeal, it seems clear that he wanted to set out his version of the hell he helped to create. "I have therefore decided, to use time until the sentence is handed down, rather to make use of it, and to put into action what I declared. It cannot hurt; rather it can make people think what life can throw at a person," he writes in the foreword. "I was inspired by a thousand ideals and like many others I slid into something from which I could not extricate myself. Today, I have a distance of time from the events. Much that was valid then has become invalid. Previous 'philosophical values' I have discarded as obsolete junk and thrown overboard in the course of the years one by one. "Because I saw hell, death and the devil, because I had to witness the insanity of annihilation, because I was reined in as one of the many horses and could not break out either to the right or the left because of the will of the coachman and his orders, I feel called to, and I have the desire to, recount here and to give account of that which transpired."

fields.headline: The Guide, Guidelines and Guidance
fields.trailText: MATCH OF THE EARLY EVENING
fields.body:
MATCH OF THE EARLY EVENING

Imagine the scene. It's Saturday night and you've drank far too much continental lager. But it doesn't matter, because you're staggering home with some more booze under one arm and a kebab under the other, and Match of the Day is about to start. Wahey! Except that in our parallel world it isn't, because your favourite football digest has been moved to an early-evening prime-time slot, thus ruining your whole evening. Now even your freshly-opened tinnies taste flat.

If you believe what you read in the Mirror, 'BBC chiefs' want to bring MotD forward to the 6pm slot to improve ratings, which have been steadily decreasing for the last 20 years. The rescheduling would also "be a smart move ahead of the next round of football bidding because it would show... how much the BBC wants to keep Match of the Day," according to a 'BBC source'.

Don't panic, though. We're not too sure how accurate this story is - compare it with this quote from 'BBC spokesperson who actually has a name and definitely exists': "There are no plans to move Match of the Day," said Mike Hayles (for that is his name). "The schedules for that period of time, towards the end of the season, have already been loosely cast and a major move like this would have been signalled by now."

So there you go. But it's true that the ratings are slipping, isn't it, Mike? "Ratings are not flagging! Viewing figures may have been at 10m in the 1970s but they are calculated in a totally different way now." How? Did they used to count dogs and budgies as well in those days? "Match of the Day's viewing figures are actually going up," said Mike. At which point he nicked off before explaining exactly what he meant.

THIS IS LIVE

More live minute-by-minute Big Cup coverage - this time Manchester United take on Bordeaux. Pretend it's on onDigital, not ITV, and follow it at Football Unlimited.

BET LYNCHED

"Bet you'll be bored rigid by this anecdote about John Beck and a bucket of cold water!" "A tenner says my socks will be round my ankles before the first five minutes are up!" "Double or quits on me winning us promotion just by using my shin!" Three things the Fiver wouldn't be surprised to find out Steve 'Tramp' Claridge had once said - after all, he famously likes a flutter. Sadly, this harmless pursuit has landed the veteran striker in a spot of trouble, because the FA has charged him with misconduct after an alleged breach of its betting rules.

Claridge has admitted placing a bet on Portsmouth to win their home game against Barnsley on January 29. Seeing as he plays for Pompey and scored all the goals in their 3-0 win, we're not too sure what the problem is (and neither is Claridge, who claimed he did not know it was against the rules for players to bet on football matches). Luckily, here's Steve Double of the FA to tell us what he's done wrong:

"Players, managers and directors have to realise," began Double in a monotone nasal whine, "that even betting on their own team to win is a breach of football rules on betting. Players and officials have access to information which those outside the game do not," he went on (and on). "For instance, only those inside a club may know that the team's top scorer has returned to full..." Actually, have you got any more of those stories about John Beck's management methods, Tramp?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I will not be leaving Cuba until my heart problems are cured, and that is going to take time. When I do leave, it will be with a passion to both work and play football." - Diego Maradona, undergoing treatment in Havana for cocaine addiction and heart problems, reveals a new-found confidence. Erm, hold on...

BENI'S TROUBLE AND STRIFE

As many a manager knows, their troubles are only just beginning when their star player cuts out the 5am Red Bull, vodka and bevy-of-busty-glamour-model benders and settles down with a wife in a mock-tudor mansion. John Gregory is the latest boss left scratching his head at the power of players' wives as Mrs Carbone joins Mrs Beckham, Mrs Barmby, Mrs Emerson, Mrs Unsworth and Mrs Zidane in the ranks of missuses not to be messed with.

Poor Mr Carbone is sick with worry about Olga. "I have a big problem with my family. My wife hasn't spoken to anyone for three years. She doesn't know anybody," Beni confided to Match of the Day magazine. "I go training all the time, so I'm talking all the time and it's easier to learn [English]. She doesn't talk to anyone, and when she does it's only in Italian. For her it's so, so difficult."

It is not in quite the same class as Andrea "Middlesbrough is a strange and terrible place" Emerson - who dragged Mr 'Emerson' Emerson back to Brazil - but clearly Olga's silent treatment calls for Gregory to flex his famed people-management muscles. When David Unsworth signed for Villa only to flee to Everton six days later, ever-understanding Gregory said: "I think his wife said he had to be home at 1pm for his dinner. We told him to try and sort his head out." So come on John, can't you see Beni and Olga need your liberal hand to guide them?

THE RUMOUR MILL

According to Teamtalk, Leicester are interested in West Ham striker Paulo Wanchope.

Newcastle are willing to pay £5m for Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson.

Fulham want Bradford's Lee Sharpe for £1m.

Aston Villa centre-back Colin Calderwood could be in line for a move to Portsmouth for a nominal fee.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Birmingham defender Michael Johnson has been issued with a death threat by neo-Nazi group Combat 18.

Two Chelsea fans are being detained by police as a result of crowd disturbances during the Big Cup match in Marseille last night. "Two people are still in custody - one for carrying a knife-lighter, and the other was arrested because he hit one of the match stewards," a spokesman said.

Marc Overmars is fully fit again and looks set to start for Arsenal for the first time in seven weeks in tomorrow's Uefa Cup fourth round first leg tie against Spanish League leaders Deportivo La Coruna at Highbury.

Real Madrid have been ordered to pay their former head coach John Toshack £590,000 in compensation for his sacking last November. The payout is based on both breach of contract by Real and unpaid wages. Real are to appeal against the decision.

The route for Sir Stanley Matthews' funeral cortege on Friday will begin at Stoke City's Britannia Stadium before moving off at 11.30am on to Stanley Matthews Way. It will then make its way to the Sir Stanley Matthews statue in the city centre and then on to Boothen Old Road, the site of the former Victoria Ground. The funeral will take place at St Peter's Church at 12.50pm.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live (7.30pm)

Manchester United v Bordeaux in Big Cup. Programme by programme, advertising breaks chip away at Des Lynam's resolve. Will this be the night he cracks?

The Big Match (11.30pm)

Gabby and Barry. We missed you. Although we were quite prepared to continue missing you for a good while yet.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 12.15am)

Action involving a fut and a mund.

Sky Sports 2: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am)

Sky Sports 2 again, McCaff? My, we are taking the Chris Evans career slide down the schedules, aren't we?

Sky Sports 3: Premiership Classics (10pm)

Another brawl involving those cheeky scamps, Arsenal and Manchester United.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

A picture can paint a thousand words. But can you draw a damn good moan?

fields.headline: The leaning tower of Pisa
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Italy's not-so-leaning edifice
fields.trailText: 1. The Leaning Tower of Pisa, northern Italy's gravity-defying tourist attraction, is finally starting to straighten itself out.
fields.body:
1. The Leaning Tower of Pisa, northern Italy's gravity-defying tourist attraction, is finally starting to straighten itself out.

2. Scientists say the wayward tower has not moved one millimetre in the last three months.

3. 800 tons of lead weights on the non-leaning side of the tower are finally having the desired effect.

4. But just in case it does collapse, a research group has put a 6,400 photo study on the net recording every detail of the eight storey tower.

5. The tower, one of several impressive buildings in the city, is a fine example of the Tuscan romanesque style of medieval art and architecture.

6. Construction started in 1173 when the widow Berta of Bernardo left money in her will to build a bell tower for Pisa's cathedral.

7. Three floors later its foundations on the Piazza dei Miracoli (the sands of a former estuary) gave way and the tower started to tilt.

8. An unknown architect tried to compensate by making the new stories slightly taller on the short side, but the extra masonry made the structure to sink still further.

9. The tower originally tilted to the north, but after medieval corrections went one degree to the south. From then it leaned until it reached its present position five metres off vertical at the top.

10. Having rescued Pisa, saving Venice from the floods may be next.

fields.headline: Country of the month: Japan
fields.standfirst:
Living | Teaching | Key points to remember | Useful contacts
Plus: Teachers in Japan talk about their lives in the field.
fields.trailText: Introduction
fields.body:
Introduction

Japan may be thousands of miles away but new arrivals from England may be surprised by the similarities these islands share: a long and colourful history, a generally hard-working and reserved people, and a fondness for talking about the weather.

Even the government is modelled on the UK's constitutional monarchy. The economy is growing slowly but job insecurity is rising fast. The unemployment rate is 4.7% - low by European standards but an all-time high in a country where employees rarely change companies.

75% of Japan is mountainous. Combine this with the world's 7th largest population (120 million) and the end results are some very dense cities. The country extends about 3,000 kilometres from subtropical seas (Okinawa) to sub-arctic climes (northern Hokkaido). This provides for popular leisure sports such as skiing and scuba diving.

Living

Living in the city and in the countryside are two completely different experiences in Japan. JET participant Ryan Olson has experienced both: "Basically, big Japanese cities are lots of fun so long as you don't have to live in them. I lived in a small cell of an apartment about fifteen minutes outside the Yamanote loop (which encircles inner Tokyo) and shared a kitchen and bathroom with three other guys. Here in the country, I command a modest two-room plus kitchen and bath apartment suitable for a small family, approximately six times the space at the same rent."

Tokyo and its surrounding towns form a megalopolis with 30 million people. One-hour plus commutes to work is the norm in trains designed more for maximising standing room than comfort. Japanese cities look ugly from a distance but offer some very interesting sights at street level: small wooden noodle shops side-by-side with high-rise modern buildings, and rich fields in the middle of dense residential areas are some examples. The countryside is more spacious and picturesque, offering a slower pace of life. The further out you go the fewer foreigners there are and the less English is spoken, so learning Japanese is essential.

Salaries for teachers are high compared to Europe with salaries starting at 250,000 yen a month (approximately £1,410 at the time of writing). However, the cost of living can be very high. Don't be surprised on spending £50 on a simple night out with your friends. Everything from rent and utility bills to clothes and food cost more. Consumer and household electronics goods, on the other hand, are cheap.

Japan is a shopping and eating paradise. Department stores and restaurants are abundant and you will be spoilt for choice with the range of goods and cuisine on offer. The service is attentive (sometimes overly so) and the Japanese in general are very polite and courteous.

The Japanese love to travel (and when your students say they have been to America they usually mean Hawaii!) and during the low-season air tickets can be very cheap. Trips to Thailand, Hong Kong and Seoul are very popular for many teachers. Sumo is considered Japan's national sport but baseball has the largest armchair following. Football is gaining rapid popularity and Japan will be hosting the next World Cup. The island has 67 active volcanoes and thousands of hot springs, the latter being the source of one of Japan's most popular pleasures - sitting in steaming hot water.

Teaching

ELT in Japan is a multi-billion pound business and there are year-round opportunities for teachers to find work. The big national private schools such as Nova and Aeon have branch schools all over Japan and they have recruitment offices in England. Interviews are usually conducted in London and the schools will arrange the work visa and accommodation. These schools provide initial training, have a low teacher/student ratio and use their own textbooks. Applicants can also specify a location preference though most will be hired for the main cities.

The Japanese Government recruits native speakers as ALTs - 'Assistant Language Teachers' - for its high schools under the JET Program. There are currently about 6000 ALTs and from 2001 English will be introduced into the elementary curriculum so the demand for JET teachers will increase. Foreigners team-teach with their Japanese counterparts and receive around £23,000 a year.

Amazingly, none of these jobs require a formal teaching qualification - only a university degree is required to apply for these jobs. In fact, only one school in Japan offers the CTEFLA and that's on a part-time basis!

Overall, Japanese students try hard and are enthusiastic learners. Housewives form a big percentage of morning and afternoon students, while office workers go to evening classes after work. Newly arrived teachers are often frustrated by a Japanese student's shyness and reluctance to offer opinions.

AEON teacher Mike Horricks comments, "It's true that they are not very good at debates and discussions. The culture is consensus-based so there is a tendency not to voice personal opinions or openly disagree with others."

Colleague Steven MacLean adds, "Many of the students are not used to being with foreigners, let alone speaking to them. They will be very nervous initially so new teachers need to be patient with them and let them progress at their own pace".

Whether you are going to Japan to take a year off, start your TEFL career, make money, explore Asia, or just expand your life experience, you will find that Japan has plenty to offer. As one teacher put it: "I had planned to be here for one year. It is now my 5th and I still have so much I want to do!"

Gambatte!

Key points to remember

Housing deposits are very expensive in Japan. Make sure to check if your employer is paying for it before you arrive.

You may not get your first paycheque until after 6 weeks after starting your job. Make sure you have enough money to live on during this time. Some companies will offer an initial loan but most won't.

Application forms for the JET Program can be obtained at the Japanese embassy.

Useful Contacts

JALT (Japan Association for Language Teaching) Ministry of Foreign Affairs - JET Program Pages
ELT News

Michael Chan is the Editor of ELT News, a web site for English teachers in Japan. He can be contacted at michael@eltnews.com

Teaching ELT in Japan is a multi-billion pound business and there are year-round opportunities for teachers to find work. The big national private schools such as Nova and Aeon have branch schools all over Japan and they have recruitment offices in England. Interviews are usually conducted in London and the schools will arrange the work visa and accommodation. These schools provide initial training, have a low teacher/student ratio and use their own textbooks. Applicants can also specify a location preference though most will be hired for the main cities. The Japanese Government recruits native speakers as ALTs - 'Assistant Language Teachers' - for its high schools under the JET Program. There are currently about 6000 ALTs and from 2001 English will be introduced into the elementary curriculum so the demand for JET teachers will increase. Foreigners team-teach with their Japanese counterparts and receive around £23,000 a year. Amazingly, none of these jobs require a formal teaching qualification - only a university degree is required to apply for these jobs. In fact, only one school in Japan offers the CTEFLA and that's on a part-time basis! Overall, Japanese students try hard and are enthusiastic learners. Housewives form a big percentage of morning and afternoon students, while office workers go to evening classes after work. Newly arrived teachers are often frustrated by a Japanese student's shyness and reluctance to offer opinions. AEON teacher Mike Horricks comments, "It's true that they are not very good at debates and discussions. The culture is consensus-based so there is a tendency not to voice personal opinions or openly disagree with others." Colleague Steven MacLean adds, "Many of the students are not used to being with foreigners, let alone speaking to them. They will be very nervous initially so new teachers need to be patient with them and let them progress at their own pace". Whether you are going to Japan to take a year off, start your TEFL career, make money, explore Asia, or just expand your life experience, you will find that Japan has plenty to offer. As one teacher put it: "I had planned to be here for one year. It is now my 5th and I still have so much I want to do!" Gambatte! Key points to remember Housing deposits are very expensive in Japan. Make sure to check if your employer is paying for it before you arrive. You may not get your first paycheque until after 6 weeks after starting your job. Make sure you have enough money to live on during this time. Some companies will offer an initial loan but most won't. Application forms for the JET Program can be obtained at the Japanese embassy. Useful Contacts JALT (Japan Association for Language Teaching) Ministry of Foreign Affairs - JET Program Pages ELT News Michael Chan is the Editor of ELT News, a web site for English teachers in Japan. He can be contacted at michael@eltnews.com

webTitle: Hague upbraids 'Polaroid prime minister' on NHS

fields.headline: Hague upbraids 'Polaroid prime minister' on NHS
fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague accused the prime minister of ignoring the crisis in the nation's hospitals in the Commons today.
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague accused the prime minister of ignoring the crisis in the nation's hospitals in the Commons today.

He said Tony Blair did not dare give waiting list figures to the Commons and attacked the Labour leader as a "Polaroid prime minister" who "turns up for photo calls at hospitals but does not listen to what is happening".

The Tory leader quoted a department of health briefing for a previous prime minister's questions, which, he said, showed that at the end of September last year 264,000 more patients were waiting over 13 weeks for operations than at the end of March 1997.

Mr Hague said the prime minister had not volunteered this information to the Commons when asked. He then claimed that the government's waiting list initiative had ignored clinical priorities.

Mr Blair said that in one clinical area, cardiac treatment, the principal problem was the shortage of specialists doctors and nurses. He said 400 extra cardiac specialists were in training, which would mean a 50% increase by 2005.

Mr Blair replied that the government saw NHS problems as "a reason for action", while the Tories viewed them as "an excuse for undermining the NHS in principle".

He said that NHS funding could only increase if the economy continued to grow.

Cash machines: There are "legitimate concerns" about the decision by banks to charge customers for using cash machines, the prime minister said, and there was a "need to know" how charges would affect pensioners, low-income families and rural communities where there may only be one cash machine.

London mayor: Mr Blair said he could not comment on rumours sweeping the House that Frank Dobson had stepped down as Labour's mayor candidate. In later questions Mr Hague said that neither Mr Dobson or his rival Ken Livingstone supported the government plans for partial privatisation of the London Underground.

Volunteers: The prime minister will spend one day working as a volunteer. A number of major companies intended to back a scheme which would allow employees to take a paid day off, once a year, to work in the voluntary sector.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst:
The Question: A survey out this week shows primary schoolchildren are spending far less time doing PE today than five years ago. Should parents be worried by this?
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Question: A survey out this week shows primary schoolchildren are spending far less time doing PE today than five years ago. Should parents be worried by this?
fields.body:
John Bangs Head of education at the National Union of Teachers

Research suggests that primary school teachers would love to spend more time on sport and PE but they feel under pressure, especially at Key Stage 2, to get through the work. Unfortunately, there's this feeling that you can spend too much time on PE and not enough on the core subjects. But the evidence suggests that parents want their children to be happy at school, and PE contributes to that. Teachers are faced with contradictory messages: they're told they've got to concentrate on core subjects, and the next minute they're told children aren't getting enough sport.

Trevor Brooking Chair of Sport England

Children need to learn skills such as how to hold a racket or kick a football while they're young. I can't think of any major figure in football who didn't have basic skills by the age of seven or eight. PE is being squeezed out. Children are often taken off site to play sports and the time they take getting to and from the sports field is counted as time spent on sports. Sports are about accepting rules, winning and losing, discipline and building character. If more time was invested in PE at primary level, maybe we'd see fewer discipline problems later on.

Dr Vivienne Press Assistant medical director at the British Heart Foundation

Learning at an early age that sport and physical activity are not only beneficial to health but also enjoyable is an important step in establishing good exercise habits for life. Given that physical activity could significantly lower the high rates of coronary heart disease in the UK, improvements in physical activity levels are vital for the longer term health not only of our children, but of the whole nation. Parents should be encouraging their child's school to increase the amount of activity on offer, and taking up physical activities with their children outside school hours.

Stuart Thackrah Head of Holmwood House preparatory school in Colchester

Sports help children perform better academically. Also, fresh air and exercise stimulate the brain. Another advantage, where children are taught sports and academic subjects by the same teacher, is that they'll try harder in, say, maths because there's an extra bond between them. We could see a situation in the future in which independent schools are almost seen as specialist sporting institutions, so poor will sports in state schools have become. And team sports such as cricket and rugby will once again be elitist, because all the players will come from the private sector.

John Coe National Association of Primary Education

Many teachers are simply exhausted by all that's being asked of them, and they're working many hours outside the school day as well. Good sports education, just like good academic education, requires an enthusiastic and upbeat teaching team, and those are in a minority in our schools. You could argue that sports could become an out-of-school activity; in many areas, fathers have taken over football practice on Saturdays, but the downside is that they can be over-competitive, and it doesn't include children who need drawing out or need skilled teaching.
