fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: 12: A brief guide to first shoes
fields.trailText: 12: A brief guide to first shoes
fields.body:
Miranda is 16 months old and has been walking for four of those. I thought my daughter might be ready for her first pair of shoes. It is essential that children's shoes fit properly, not just so that they can walk comfortably but because their bones are soft and must have room to develop and grow to maturity straight and strong. However, children's shoe shops can be a maze of conflicting information about sizes and width fittings, as Miranda and I found on a shopping trip in London.

At InStep in Wandsworth, which is part of a small chain, there was a queueing system which dispelled some of the stress of a long wait. The fitter asked how long Miranda had been walking and said she would be ready for shoes. She judged her feet to be size 4F although a 4E seemed to fit better. We tried two pairs of Start-Rite and a pair of Clarks, but didn't buy.

We fared less happily at Daisy and Tom's on King's Road where, on a quiet afternoon, we had to wait 50 minutes before the one assistant was free to measure. The shop has no queueing system, an advertised puppet show never materialised and Miranda kept disappearing into the adjacent book department through an interconnecting door which, irritatingly, was jammed open. Miranda was finally measured as a 4F, but the pair I wanted her to try on - Start-Rite Mary Janes in blue - wasn't available.

Next we went to our local Clarks branch which, while full of shoes, was empty of people so easier to get a fitting done. Here, we had a surprise: according to the fitter, Miranda was a 5E which left me wondering whether manufacturers use a different scale. The answer is that they do, so if you're offered various makes, check that the fitter measures for each kind.

Finally we tried Peter Jones, part of the John Lewis empire. It was now nearly closing time, which accounted for the rare spectacle of a deserted children's shoe department, so Miranda had the benefit of not one assistant but three - two fitters and the manager. I was instructed to take off her socks and allow her to run around. All three were in no doubt - Miranda was still curling her feet when she walks so I was advised to wait at least another month.

How does the confused mother make sense of this? According to Laura West, of the Society of Shoefitters, Peter Jones may have had a point - some children do curl their toes for a while and it's usually best to put off buying shoes as long as possible. Many parents seem to see getting the first shoes as, literally, a step forward in a child's development but it is better to let them go barefoot or in socks or padders. "The bones in a child's feet are very soft and can be easily damaged. Damaged feet can affect all sorts of things - as well as painful feet in later life, you may develop a bad back, posture problems, even migraine. "Have your children's feet properly measured and don't skimp on quality." she says.

Clarks

The best known name in children's shoes in the UK. They come in half-sizes, giving a better fit, and all seem hard-wearing and well-designed, with a bar or laces, which all young children need. Lots of pretty "girly" styles: flower and heart-encrusted offerings, for example, but boys are well served, too, with a range of multi-coloured kickers. Prices are around £20-25.

Rating: 9/10

Start-Rite

The Rolls-Royce of children's shoes - extremely well-made. Like Clarks, available in half-sizes and a wide range of width. Best known for "traditional" shoes: these are the ones most often available in shops. But the company's brochure lists a much wider range, including boots in gunmetal and floral-patterned lilac and raspberry, as well as styles in hot fuchsia, and inspired by Prada. The only gripe is cost - most are around £30.

Rating: 8/10

Early Days

Early Days only makes shoes in full sizes and F fittings, so you can't be sure of finding a pair that will fit perfectly - you'll need advice from a fitter. But if a pair is a perfect fit, you've got a bargain - this navy lace-up boot, which would be equally cute on a boy or girl, is around £15. All the shoes have synthetic uppers, but on the plus side these are lightweight and easy to clean - some can be machine-washed.

Rating: 8/10

Elefanten

Vibrant colours are a trademark of these German shoes - the lovely multi-coloured boots ("Jeff") are perfect for new walkers. Lots of the shoes are lace-ups, which are a better buy than Velcro fasteners because Velcro sometimes loses its adhesion. Continental sizings so it's essential to buy from a shop with a fitter. Prices are steep, however, at around £35.

Rating: 7/10

Baby Deer

Limited range of classic first-walker styles. These are nice-looking shoes which don't have fancy names, but include plain bar shoes for girls which come in white, navy and black patent. Also available are nubuck closed-toe sandals in brown and blue. No half sizes, however, and F fitting is standard. Good value at around £18.

Rating: 7/10

Buckle My Shoe

If your toddler is a fashion victim, Buckle My Shoe is probably the range for her (or him). Mini Erika is a funky 70s-inspired girl's shoe which combines high fashion with a sensible, healthy bar-style; Mini Pedal is a great-looking kicker in five earthy colours. But the prices! You'll pay around £40 for the Erikas, and a whopping £47 for the Pedal. Probably best to avoid fashion shoes until the kids ask for them.

Rating: 5/10

 For a list of qualified fitters of children's shoes and a leaflet on children's foot health, send £5 plus an SAE to the Society of Shoefitters, The Anchorage, 28 Admiral's Walk, Hingham, Norfolk NR9 4JL.

fields.headline: Well, we've all done it
fields.standfirst: Posh has her son's name emblazened in studwork on her T-shirt. Naff, say her critics. Give her a break, says  Dave Hill
fields.trailText: Posh has her son's name emblazened in studwork on her T-shirt. Naff, say her critics. Give her a break, says Dave Hill.
fields.body:
So what do we all think about the latest tabloid appearance of Victoria Beckham? Yesterday, she was photographed dropping round to her mum and dad's house in a tangerine T-shirt with the single word "Brooklyn" picked out in glittering studwork on the back, like on a football shirt.

What does it say about Sir Alex Ferguson's least-favourite Spice Girl that she's had a garment specially made to advertise her baby son's name? And what does it say about the other pop star in the Manchester United manager's life - Victoria's husband, David - that he has Brooklyn's moniker tattooed upon his boyish back? Are these glittering parents simply ghastly? Or are they absolutely fab?

The only proper answer is, of course, the latter. Yes, yes, you might have quibbles about Mr and Mrs Becks, what with the massive mountains of money they seem so keen to keep all to themselves, and their not-always-welcome talent for being the centre of national attention. And, yes, many will consider their wish to be emblazoned with their infant's name as final confirmation that David and Victoria are a truly gruesome twosome, the viziers of vulgarity, the nabobs of naff. But soft. Just because their style may be un soupçon ostentatious, it doesn't mean the sentiments behind it are unworthy. Before rushing to judgment, it might be worth reflecting that all sorts of parents advertise their adoration of their children to the world in all sorts of ways, some of them embarrassing, most of them sentimental, and nearly all of them entirely forgivable.

The thing about Posh and Becks is that they do parenting their way; and their way is the way of many doting Essex Boys (as Becks is, in spirit) and Hertfordshire Girls (that's Posh). The difference with Mr and Mrs Becks being that they have more to spare than most. When baby comes, there's big, big, prams; big, big cot; very expensive clothes from Baby Versace (or whatever); and, hey, why not a T-shirt or tattoo to mark the miracle of a birth and announce to the world their enduring dedication to the newborn in their arms?

Other sorts of people also do such things, but do them in other ways. Conventional, white-collar men who spend most of their working lives keeping soppiness at bay, cram their desks with framed photos of their broods, not just for their own delectation, but for every chief executive or underling to see as well.

Other folk use images of their kids as computer screen savers. Or they incorporate their nippers' names into their email addresses. Or, back in the brick-and-mortar world, they concoct little composites to adorn the front of their homes. I grew up near a house named "Kenessa" - Kevin, Neil, and Vanessa.

With such offspring-inspired nomenclature, buildings are just the beginning. The boat from which Robert Maxwell plunged to his death was named the Lady Ghislaine, after his youngest daughter. Whole businesses may bear the names of their proprietors' progeny. When my in-laws ran a mini-cab firm they pondered which of their 10 children to name it after. In the end, they christened the enterprise after their firstborn, thereby enjoying the benefits of alliteration: Carmel Cars.

Of course, there is a fine line between admirable pride and unpleasant boastfulness. But it's better that parents overdo it than never feel moved to do it at all. I've gone in for a bit of showboating myself. All the books I've written are dedicated to my children. Pretty gushing some of it, I guess. But let's live with a bit of gushing if it's in the name of love.

fields.headline: Gran, we hardly knew you
fields.standfirst: Battles over access to children used to be fought just by parents - now grandparents are joining the fray.  Yvonne Roberts reports
fields.trailText: Battles over access to children used to be fought just by parents - now grandparents are joining the fray.
fields.body:
Four months ago, Alice had her 10-year-old granddaughter, Amy, to stay for the weekend. "We had the most magical time," she says. "Amy and I made up special names for each other and had lots of fun." Shortly after Amy returned home, Alice received a letter from her daughter, Charlotte. "She told me that Amy had been distressed by the weekend and she, Charlotte, would no longer trust Amy with me. I've seen my granddaughter only once since then."

Battles over access have become common but are usually between parents. What is only now becoming recognised is that grandparents, too, pay a price when family ties are loosened. In the US, the supreme court is now pondering the question: does a grandparent have the right to see a grandchild against the wishes of a parent?

The nine judges (six of them grandparents) have before them the case of Gary and Jenifer Troxel. The Troxels have two grandchildren: Natalie, 10, and Isabelle, eight. Seven years ago, Brad, the girls' father and the Troxels' son, committed suicide. His common-law wife, Tommie Wynn, has since remarried. The Troxels went to court to increase their visitation rights, agreed at once a month.

Wynn objected, arguing that the girls needed time to settle with their new family. The court agreed. The judge argued that it was not advisable for the law to become involved in "micromanaging an intact family".

The Troxels have now appealed against that decision, backed by the American Association of Retired People, which supports the right of a grandparent to develop a relationship with a grandchild. Wynn, in turn, is supported by the American Civil Liberties Union, which is defending her right to raise her family without interference from the state. A decision is due in July.

In Britain, says Linda Drew of the University of London, who has conducted a study on parental separation and its effects on grandparents, only a fraction of cases go to court. If a child lives with its parent, it is unlikely that a court would overrule parental wishes. On the rare occasion when a contact order stipulating access terms for a grandparent is given it is difficult to enforce it if the parent continues to be hostile to the idea.

"In theory, the punishment for refusing to abide by a contact order is 28 days in prison," Drew explains, "and few courts are willing to put a parent in prison in those circumstances."

Drew has conducted two studies of grandparents. She says that family disruptions have a variety of causes, such as different attitudes to parenting or a rift with a daughter-in-law. "What one side sees as helping, the other side may regard as interfering. If grandparents lose touch, they talk in terms of surprise. Grandparenting was a role they never expected to lose."

Alan and Val are in their late 60s. Their son Ian is married to Jenny, and they have twin boys of seven. "We used to pop in a couple of times a week and the boys would sometimes spend a Saturday night here," Alan explains. "I think there was a bit of tension between Val and Jenny. Then, it all blew up. We looked after the boys and let them stay up a bit later. The next morning, when Ian and Jenny came to pick them up, the boys didn't want to go home." Jenny exploded. She said that we overruled everything she told the boys. That we spoiled them and it took them ages to settle after they'd been with us. And that she hated our summer holidays together."

That was four months ago. Alan and Val have seen the twins twice since then, visits arranged by their father. "We're in exile but Jenny's parents are there all the time," Val says. "Time will probably heal but I won't ever forget that Jenny's stolen our time."

According to Francis McGlone of the Family Policy Studies Centre, research into grandparenting is relatively new in this country. A study by Age Concern tells us that one in three adults has grandchildren, the average age of a grandparent is 50 and the majority maintain steady contact with their grandchildren.

Geoff Dench, senior research fellow at the Institute of Community Studies, has revealed that after divorce or separation, the paternal grandparents may find themselves excluded.

In a study of five generations within families, Michael Anderson, of the Newcastle Centre for Family Studies, has established that, even then, relationships may be durable. "Children who find themselves with three or four sets of grandparents will develop a special relationship with one grandparent, while his or her sibling will develop a relationship with another."

If conflict exists, he concurs with Linda Drew that it might be the grandparents who have to make the extra effort. "They may have to back down or try to put themselves in others' shoes. Good communication counts."

The feud between Alice and Charlotte has a long history, according to Alice. It began when Charlotte, at 15, became anorexic and hostile.

"I came to realise that my daughter wanted someone other than me for a mother. I divorced her father when she was six and I went on to have a successful career. Now, in retirement, I have an interesting life. I think Charlotte resents that. She would prefer that I was a little old lady she could patronise.

"She tells me: 'If you can't find some way of dealing with me, you won't be able to deal with Amy.' But if our relationship hasn't gelled by now, it never will. I've already mourned the loss of a daughter; I don't want to lose a granddaughter too."

Recently, Alice agreed to go to mediation with her daughter. "I felt as if I was on trial for three hours. I've now been told I can see Amy for half a day in half-term but not at my home. It seems I have two choices. I can walk away from my granddaughter and hope that when she's older, she will make her own decisions. Or I can jump through Charlotte's hoops in the hope that she might allow me a little of my granddaughter's time.

"When Amy asks why she hasn't seen me, I know she's told, 'Grandma's busy,'" Alice adds. "I think that's wicked. It implies I'm not interested when the opposite is true. But what can I do?"

fields.headline: Can he play football?
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. For eight years his mother has been asked questions. Does he know his name? Does he keep still when he sleeps? And always lurking in the background is the Big One: what's it like to have a disabled child? In her fortnightly column, she reveals all.
fields.body:
Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. For eight years his mother has been asked questions. Does he know his name? Does he keep still when he sleeps? And always lurking in the background is the Big One: what's it like to have a disabled child? In her fortnightly column, she reveals all.

It's "carpet time" in year two. Alex snuggles up on the sofa next to his best friend, Simon. At their feet, with his arm lightly draped over Alex's knees, sits another good friend, Tom. The other 16 children sit cross-legged on the carpet, listening with rapt attention to a story.

The class includes many children with special needs, a few very bright ones, one or two with little English, a girl with Down's syndrome. Some have emotional problems, one is hyperactive. It's just an ordinary, inclusive, mainstream class, with helpers to support those who need it.

It had taken a while for Alex to make real friends - with boys on an equal level rather than girls who wanted to mollycoddle him. But he did it. Then, in autumn 99, the class moved on to class three. They went upstairs; Alex was left behind.

This latest in a long chain of battles for Alex's rights involved as many tears, threats, pleadings, meetings, letters, faxes and phonecalls as any of the battles I have had to fight. But after various reports and inspections by fire officers, psychologists, occupational therapists and engineers, the education authority finally agreed to pay for a platform lift.

It was supposed to go in over the Christmas holidays. The kids all watched and waited with great anticipation. Then someone, somewhere announced that it would take 13 weeks to order from Switzerland.

Meanwhile, Alex asks every day: "When can I go upstairs?" He is nearly nine in a class of six and seven-year-olds and has no special friends now because Simon and Tom play football at playtime. He worries touchingly about "poor Simon", who has gone upstairs without him. Tom has invented his own lift just in case no one comes up with one. It will cost the same to put in a lift as it would to bus Alex to a special school for four years. So why the reluctance?

A friend phoned this week and asked: "What's the latest on the lift?"

"It's going in at Easter," I said.

"Well done, you must be elated!" I'm not. I just feel drained. Time to gather strength for the next battle.

fields.headline: Then there were three
fields.standfirst: Children, it has been said, are like a hand grenade thrown into the heart of a marriage.  Luisa Dilner  talks to childcare guru, Steve Biddulph, who says he can help parents survive the fallout
fields.trailText: Children, it has been said, are like a hand grenade thrown into the heart of a marriage. Luisa Dilner talks to childcare guru, Steve Biddulph, who says he can help parents survive the fallout.
fields.body:
It's Sunday morning. Stretching out in bed, your toes touch your partner's leg. In that warm languid moment between dreaming and waking, you reach over for a kiss. But you never make it. A little voice at the end of the bed shrieks: "Get up, mummy! Get up!"

However much you've longed for children by the man or woman of your dreams, their arrival disrupts romance and can destroy intimacy. In 1998, 145,000 couples divorced, according to the Family Policies Study Centre in London. These divorces involved more than 150,000 children under 16. One in four of these children were under four years old.

While children might not wreck marriages, they make it harder for relationships to stay on track. In the heady days of early courtship not only do you find each other interesting and adorable most of the time, but when you do fall out you have a whole weekend to row about it. Try having any two-sentence discussion in the presence of a toddler.

It has been said that a baby is a hand grenade thrown into the heart of a marriage. Steve Biddulph, father of two (15 and 8), psychologist, counsellor of children and parents, and childcare guru (he wrote the bestsellers Raising Boys and The Secret of Happy Children), agrees that the arrival of a child is potentially explosive. But in his latest book, How Love Works (subtitle: How to stay in love as a couple and be true to yourself . . . even with kids), he claims that couples can stop the bomb from going off.

The first step is patience. Biddulph believes that most of us are in love with a fantasy when we get together. "Learning to love another human being takes 10 years," he says. "People are often just beginning that process when they have kids." All marriages (defined as any committed relationship) have make or break crises, he says. "Our work as counsellors has made us believe that two thirds of divorces are preventable. Life is tough. You don't get a relationship that's life-enriching just fall into your lap; it's a long-term project."

And central to this project are the arguments that many couples - particularly those with children - try so hard to avoid. You have to fight your way to closeness, Biddulph insists. Many couples go through a period of disengagement after having children. Broken nights, the social isolation of being at home with a child or the dual demands of working and childcare can make couples lose touch with each other. "It happens by accident," says Biddulph. "Often the couple used to argue but they become afraid to fight in front of the kids. You can achieve things by rowing, people are often willing to change their behaviour when they understand a person's view."

Often the changes may be practical: a man may want to have more responsibility for the child without being supervised; a woman may feel that her partner works too hard. The golden rule of rowing is to focus on the specific, and don't be abusive. "Research shows that couples who fight quite a bit are happier five years later, as long as they are not fighting abusively," says Biddulph. "If you call each other names, that's death to a relationship. You have to fight clean in front of kids, but you can be upfront about your feelings. When I was a kid my parents would go into the bedroom and I'd hear some intense whispering but never know what was going on, and that was scary. Then, maybe, my dad would storm out to the car. When Shaaron [his co-author, partner of 25 years and wife for the past 16 of those] and I started rowing we had to have ground rules. Her family had been violent, so she needed us to agree that no one would hurt anyone and my need was to agree that neither of us would walk out. We had our first row 20 years ago and it was so intense that at one stage I lifted a door off its hinges. I can't remember what it was about. I'd say it's OK to throw crockery - just not at each other."

Some of the difficulty in maintaining a relationship when couples have children is the lack of time they have to discuss how they feel about things. Partners may have different ideas about what mothers and fathers roles should be - often inherited from their own childhoods. "You accumulate misunderstandings," says Biddulph. "When we first managed to have a weekend away together without the children, we argued all the time. We had catch-up fighting to do. When you have little kids you can go for two years passing in the corridor, living on the memory of when you used to be in love. You need to ask each other, 'how's your life going?' "

Sex can become a minefield, too. "Tiredness, especially for women, is often a barrier," says Biddulph. "If a man takes his share of the childcare and housework, the couple are more likely to have sex. It's hard to feel loving towards someone who you are angry with for not pulling their weight. You have to be creative, too, just to have time together. I know couples who go home in the middle of the day to be together."

While it might seem idyllic to do everything together as a family, Biddulph cautions against it. "We find that couples with strong relationships, who have been together for a long time, often take a holiday separately once a year. Being separate for a while creates an electrical charge between you."

David and Maureen are an example of such a couple. Both 40, they have been married for 15 years and have two children, aged nine and six. They spend a week or so apart each year; David playing golf, Maureen on work-related trips. "You have to be terribly good friends for your relationship to work once you have kids," says Maureen. 'We go out together at least once a week for a meal and to watch a film. It's an expensive way of maintaining a relationship - about £100 a night once we've paid the babysitter - but eating out is important because it makes you talk. The children need to know that we lead our own lives and we are together because we want to be."

If you can't remember why you are together, Biddulph advises seeing a marriage counsellor and working at your relationship. "It's not that I don't believe in romantic love but in most societies in history, people are thrown together and learn to love each other," he says. "In our society, love starts as a blessing and continues as an accomplishment."

 How Love Works is published by Thorsons at £7.99.

Trouble through the ages: damage-limitation exercises

New baby

Some problems: brings responsibility, sleepless nights. Mother often feels uncomfortable with body changes. Father often feels left out.

Action plan

 Beg, scream for or buy in help. This will allow you to sleep when the baby sleeps and more besides.

Go out alone with your partner as soon as you can and don't talk about the baby.

 Get your baby to take expressed breast milk through a bottle so the father does some feeding.

 Be considerate about each other, ask how the other is doing and listen. Remember that you used to love each other and believe that you'll do so again, with more depth and maturity.

The toddler

Some problems: child can develop forceful personality and have tantrums. The novelty wears off.

Action plan

 Discuss how you'll deal with tantrums to avoid conflict (eg taking time out).

 Go out once a week on a date, taking it in turns to organise where you go, but it must involve talking.

 Establish a reasonable bedtime so you have evening time together.

 Make sure you see your friends on your own sometimes.

 Keep your toddler active.

School age

Some problems: child experiences emotional rollercoaster of making friends at school. Pressure on parents to meet child from school and cover holidays. Rows over bedtime.

Action plan

 Share responsibility of meeting child from school/holidays or get help.

 Make it clear your bedroom is your room - they should knock.

 When you get home, have 10 minutes together and have a nutritious snack - this avoids low blood sugar and loss of patience during the evening.

 Hold sleepovers for the children.

 Discuss how you will handle your child's fears - try to be consistent in your parenting.

The teenager

Some problems: stroppiness kicks in. Parents can be used as taxi service. Child experiences exam pressure.

Action plan

 Discuss how you are going to deal with arguments/rudeness/homework.

 Both get involved in discussing issues with your teenager - you can disagree but don't put each other down.

 Encourage your teenager within limits to use public transport/taxis.

 Go out at least once a week - not only to talk, but also to go to the cinema and theatre and play sport. Relax.

 For younger teenagers, maintain a bedtime.

fields.headline: Government surveillance bill arouses alarm
fields.trailText: The government is moving ahead with plans to regulate covert surveillance, saying it needs to update existing phonetapping powers to keep pace with the internet and mobile phones.
fields.body:
The government is moving ahead with plans to regulate covert surveillance, saying it needs to update existing phonetapping powers to keep pace with the internet and mobile phones.

But the regulation of investigatory powers bill, which gets its second reading in parliament next week, has provoked widespread alarm. Internet experts and civil liberties campaigners fear that the legislation threatens human rights by opening the doors to unchecked powers for mass surveillance.

Britain already has wide powers to intercept communications, but until now it has lacked a regulatory framework for use of informers, a situation the bill is designed to rectify. The proposals cover the monitoring and interception of communications by law enforcement and security agencies. The bill lays down the rules to be followed by the police and security services when they tap private phones, pagers, mobiles or private networks, including office switchboards.

The bill will cover activities well beyond those of the security and intelligence services and the police. Ministers will be able to issue orders allowing surveillance by other agencies such as the department of health and social security, the ministry of agriculture and the department of trade and industry, as well as local authorities.

The government argues that it needs this power to combat criminal groups such as paedophile gangs that send encrypted messages over the internet. Civil liberties groups welcome the introduction of a systematic legal framework for surveillance activities while expressing deep unease at the government's wide sweep of powers and the lack of oversight and redress procedures.

The authorities will be able to force anybody to hand over the text of or decryption keys for computer communications such as emails. Those who refuse could face jail.

A key issue is the burden of proof. Critics of the legislation say innocent computer users who had lost software codes could end up in jail as it would be impossible for them to prove that they did not have the requested key.

The government believes it has built sufficient safeguards into the legislation. But Caspar Bowden of the Foundation for Information Policy Research think tank, says the law as drafted is "impossible". He accuses the government of ignoring all the advice and lobbying it has received from the internet community in the past year.

"This law could make a criminal out of anyone who uses encryption to protect their privacy on the internet," Mr Bowden said. He claimed that the department of trade and industry dropped decryption powers from its e-communications bill last year because the measure was incompatible with the human rights act. "The corpse of a law laid to rest by trade secretary Stephen Byers has been stitched up and jolted back into life by home secretary Jack Straw," he said.

Mr Straw says none of the law enforcement activities specified in the bill is new. Covert surveillance is old as policing itself, he points out. "What is new is that for the first time the use of these techniques will be properly regulated by law, and externally supervised, not least to ensure that law enforcement operations are consistent with the duties imposed on public authorities by the European convention on human rights."

The regulation of investigatory powers bill
The Foundation for Information Policy Research's discussion of the bill
Caspar Bowden profile

News Unlimited special report: free speech on the net

 FIPR is organising Scrambling for Safety (see last September's programme here), a free public conference to discuss the bill, on Wednesday 22 March in London. The government and opposition parties have agreed to participate. Registration details and further information are on the FIPR site or e-mail i.want.sfs2000@fipr.org.

fields.headline: What revolution?
fields.standfirst: Most local authorities are way off message when it comes to  making full use of the internet, reports Steve Brown
fields.trailText: Most local authorities are way off message when it comes to making full use of the internet, reports Steve Brown.
fields.body:
One of Frank Dobson's key promises in his successful campaign to become Labour's candidate for London mayor was to get four out of five of the capital's households connected to the internet by 2004. But what will this new wave of net surfers find in the way of virtual public services?

Precious little, it seems. Following last December's conclusion by the National Audit Office that central government's progress with the internet was "patchy and slow", a new survey, due out next week, shows that town halls are faring little better in their efforts at e-government.

The survey, by the councils' IT body, the Society of IT Management (Socitm), provides a snapshot of local government on the web this winter. Its findings make grim reading. Some 401 or 86% of the 467 local authorities in the UK have websites. That is nearly 60 more than the same time last year and many sites have improved, but Socitm say that, overall, the content of the sites remains poor. Nearly 60% of sites are identified as merely promotional, concentrating on tourism and economic development. These sites make little use of email or on-line feedback and provide only limited information on local services. Instead, councils should be aspiring to transactional sites where citizens can pay council tax over the net or fill forms in on-line. Yet, while some councils are beginning to allow more interaction via the internet, not one site was judged to be transactional.

The government targets for public service delivery - half of all the public's dealings with government to be deliverable electronically by 2005 and 100% by 2008 - are, officially, for central government. But, according to Barry Quirk, chief executive of the London borough of Lewisham, they are taken as de facto standards for the whole public sector. Quirk, part of a group helping the government to drive forward its modernisation agenda, says the survey results are not a surprise.

"The internet is producing a tidal wave of demand, and councils have to change or lose credence in the eyes of the public," says Quirk. He believes councils need to be far more ambitious in their use of the internet and become the focal point for all local information, including health services and travel. It is a vision that is a far cry from today's reality.

The survey judged sites on how they coped with "real life" situations. For instance, it examined how web- sites helped a person needing to find long-term care for an elderly parent from another part of the country. Sites were examined to see if they included useful information about local residential homes, for contact information and for the ability to make an appointment by email. Only 9% were judged satisfactory.

One of the simplest demonstrations of joined-up government for the public would be if changes of address could be notified to different parts of central and local government in a single transaction. That seems light years away when currently less than 10% of town halls allow address changes even for council tax purposes via the internet. Perhaps most startling was councils' response to a simple email, asking for details of disabled access to libraries and swimming pools. Over half the councils who could be contacted simply did not reply. Of those that did, over a quarter failed the five-day test deemed to be satisfactory by the research team and took up to three weeks to reply.

Councils claim that investment is needed to make progress. Until then, councils argue, they will have to retain their traditional service out lets. John Serle, Socitm spokesman and head of IT at Lincolnshire county council, says local government has to move on from these "stereotypical excuses".

In the real world of heavily constrained public sector expenditure, this could well mean closing traditional public service outlets. "We are talking about models of service delivery - libraries and schools, for instance - that are over 100 years old in some cases," Serle says. Breaking up the existing infrastructure will take "managerial and political courage", he says. But eventually the public's frustration at councils' failure to work electronically will overcome any nostalgic attachment to the old institutions. And that, says Serle, is when town halls' e-revolution will begin.

 Socitm can be contacted on its website at www.socitm.gov.uk/

fields.headline: The new givers
fields.standfirst: Rose Robinson on the four years she spent  working with women villagers in Honduras
fields.trailText: Rose Robinson on the four years she spent working with women villagers in Honduras.
fields.body:
There is, I'm convinced, a new community spirit in this country. It's a real shift away from the selfish individualism that dominated the 1980s and 1990s, with more and more people looking at ways of giving something back, of being part of something that is bigger than themselves.

This week sees three events which are helping to underline the rebirth of this community spirit.

Yesterday saw the launch of the TimeBank, an exciting initiative, developed by voluntary organisations with the BBC, to encourage more people to give their time.

Today, a group of millennium volunteer ambassadors will commit themselves to bringing a new generation into volunteering.

Tomorrow, nearly 3,000 people will gather in London to celebrate the best of what is happening in Britain's communities and to commit themselves to do more.

It was this new spirit I spoke about a year ago to the National Council for Voluntary Organisations. I said I hoped that the millennium would be marked with an explosion in giving - acts of community that touch people's lives. And I promised that government would play its part in helping put this goal into practice.

Since then, we have been working hard with the voluntary sector to put together a comprehensive approach to volunteering. Gordon Brown last month described some of the major changes in support for the giving of money that he plans to announce in the budget; in particular, plans for simpler, more generous tax incentives for charitable donations. This week we will set out ways to help more people give their time as well.

Millions of people are already active in their communities. But many are not. Barely one in five young people, and fewer than one in three of all adults, gave time last month. Yet many of those who aren't involved say that they would like to be, given the right encouragement and opportunities.

I want it to become as natural to be involved in the community as it is to watch television or go to the cinema. But for that to happen we will need to bring about far- reaching changes in the ways in which volunteering and community involvement are encouraged, supported and managed.

The first priority is to encourage people to become involved. Volunteering sometimes suffers from a rather fusty image. Yet when people do take part they often find it one of the most fulfilling parts of their lives. That is why, over the last year, we have been working with the media, voluntary organisations, business and a new charity, ONE20, on a long-term strategy that will use new methods to encourage people to volunteer.

This week, some of the first signs of that collaboration are becoming visible with the launch of the TimeBank, which could in time become as much part of the scenery in Britain as the national lottery has. Later this year, the new Community Channel will go on air to provide the first ever dedicated broadcasting outlet for the voluntary sector.

But we also need to modernise the ways in which people offering their time can be linked to opportunities in their community, whether it is a school needing people to help with reading, or an environmental charity wanting to create a nature reserve. At the moment, these links are at best haphazard and at worst non-existent. In most towns and cities, it is much easier to find out about what is happening in the local cinemas than what is happening in the community.

To help put that right, we have provided support for The Site - a hugely impressive internet-based service which, by the summer, will have 90,000 volunteering opportunities online.

Alongside this we are planning to fund local networks, centres and printed materials. Our long-term aim is that in every community there should be someone responsible for developing volunteering and for getting people involved - not just in the voluntary sector but also in schools, hospitals, prisons and residential homes.

The third priority is to build up opportunities for people to get involved. Employers are already collaborating in 10 cities. Within three years, they - with the help of Business in the Community - aim to involve another 100,000 people in community projects. We will also give new support to volunteering in the public sector - such as those who help out in hospitals, running libraries, art classes, reading and befriending, the prison visitors and letter writers who help prisoners prepare for life back on the outside, and the parents who work alongside teachers to fill local schools with life and activity, as well as supporting new projects targeted at black and ethnic minority communities that have often been left out of mainstream volunteering in the past.

We also need to draw in the next generation. Four thousand millennium volunteers are already active around the country in some remarkable projects, doing sports coaching, mentoring, peer mediation, improving the environment and helping out in music and dance projects. In 2002, we will go further as citizenship education becomes part of the curriculum, and David Blunkett is looking at new models of graduation that will give recognition to community activity, as well as formal academic achievements.

At the other end of the age range, we also need to tap into the huge reservoir of skills, experience and enthusiasm among older people. They are already the mainstay of thousands of voluntary organisations, but many - for a variety of reasons, including the false belief they will not be wanted - do not. Fewer than one in three between 45 and 59 participate in voluntary work and that number falls to below one in four between the age of 60 and 69, even though they are likely to have more free time. We will shortly be announcing the details of an imaginative new programme that will draw thousands of older people into community activity.

Taken together, these will, I hope, reinforce a new mood, giving community activity the recognition it deserves as one of the foundations of a fair and inclusive society. But they also signal something else: a recognition that government has to work as a partner with the volun tary sector if it is to be effective. In the first half of last century, we learned that the community cannot achieve its aims without the help of government providing essential services and a backdrop of security. In the second half of the century, we learned that government cannot achieve its aims without the energy and commitment of others - voluntary organisations, business and, crucially, the wider public.

That partnership between active government and an active community is key to our success as a nation in dealing with everything from social exclusion to poor literacy, crime to ill-health.

Both right and left often failed to appreciate this. Conservatives fell for the idea that people are only motivated by selfish interests, and that the private sector has a monopoly of efficiency and responsiveness.

They still believe that a more active role for government necessarily means less space for voluntary initiative. The left sometimes belittled voluntary activity, seeing it as a poor alternative to direct state provision, and my party at times forgot its own roots in self-help, friendly societies, cooperatives and voluntary organisations, and the insights of Robert Owen and William Morris.

I believe that the modern role of government is not to supplant voluntary activity or to dominate it, but rather to work with it. That new spirit of partnership informs everything we do. Voluntary organisations are much more involved now in making policy - for example, in the 18 policy action teams set up by the social exclusion unit, and in the new task force on social investment. They are also playing a leading role in delivering policy in programmes like the New Deal for communities, Surestart or the childcare strategy. And they will soon be benefiting from a new source of funding with the launch of a Children's Fund to help voluntary organisations play their part in tackling child poverty.

These are a few examples of what I believe is a radically different approach to the voluntary sector. One that recognises its diversity, its necessary independence and its vital contribution to making Britain a fairer society. One that gives support to the quiet idealism of the millions who, through their daily actions, make this a better country to live in.

Treble chance

TimeBank: Launched yesterday, the initiative aims to create two national registers: an online register of volunteers, which will record their interests, skills, and the activity they would like to do, plus the amount of time they can give; and a second register of volunteering opportunities, provided by charities, community and voluntary groups. TimeBank has worked closely with the voluntary sector, though some local volunteer bureaux remain suspicious. But one obvious target is the 37% of people that the National Survey of Volunteering in the UK found were not currently volunteering but were willing to do so. Once registered, the potential volunteer is sent a list of opportunities in their own area linked to their own interests and time available.

The charity behind TimeBank is ONE20, set up by Jane Tewson, co-founder of Comic Relief. It is being launched with dozens of programmes on BBC national, regional and local television and radio stations, highlighting the huge variety of volunteering currently available. More than 4,000 BBC staff are being given half a day's paid leave (to be matched by a half-day of their own time) to the venture. TimeBank is being funded by £1.9m over three years from the home office. That figure has already been more than matched by sponsorship in kind from individuals and private companies. Individuals can register their interests either through the TimeBank website or by telephoning 09065 540400. Recognised charities accredited by the National Centre for Volunterring can register their opportunities direct via the Site-org website or by posting them to TimeBank, POBox 3000, Manchester M60 3LA.

Millennium Volunteers: This is a new UK-wide initiative to encourage more 16-24 year olds to volunteer their time. It was launched by the prime minister in January, 1999, to reverse the 12% fall in youth volunteering between 1991-97. It has a £15m budget from the windfall levy and a further £35m in England from the department of employment. There are currently 100 projects, with another 80 under negotiation. About 4,000 young people have started volunteering and the aim is to recruit 100,000 over the next three years.

Millennium Volunteer Ambassadors - famous names from the media, sport, music and entertainmen, who have all undertaken volunteering - will "take the message" to young people in the next two months of high profile promotion.

Opportunities available to young people under the programme include sports coaching, mentoring, peer mediation, environmental projects, youth leadership, music and dance. Helpline: 0800 9178185.

Active Community Awards: Launched last December, more than 1,000 nominations had been received by the closing date on January 11. The 90 winners - 10 from each of nine regions - will receive their awards at a ceremony and gala dinner at the Millennium Dome tomorrow.

Earlier in the day, they will join 2,000 other delegates at the Active Community convention at the Wembley conference centre to take part in workshops and plenary sessions on the nine award categories for building a community that is: learning; fair and just; active and empowered; influential; economically strong; caring; green; safe; and sustainable.

Malcolm Dean

 The Active Community Convention will be broadcast live tomorrow on the web at www.acu.communicatinglive.com

TimeBank is being funded by £1.9m over three years from the home office. That figure has already been more than matched by sponsorship in kind from individuals and private companies. Individuals can register their interests either through the TimeBank website or by telephoning 09065 540400. Recognised charities accredited by the National Centre for Volunterring can register their opportunities direct via the Site-org website or by posting them to TimeBank, POBox 3000, Manchester M60 3LA. Millennium Volunteers: This is a new UK-wide initiative to encourage more 16-24 year olds to volunteer their time. It was launched by the prime minister in January, 1999, to reverse the 12% fall in youth volunteering between 1991-97. It has a £15m budget from the windfall levy and a further £35m in England from the department of employment. There are currently 100 projects, with another 80 under negotiation. About 4,000 young people have started volunteering and the aim is to recruit 100,000 over the next three years. Millennium Volunteer Ambassadors - famous names from the media, sport, music and entertainmen, who have all undertaken volunteering - will "take the message" to young people in the next two months of high profile promotion. Opportunities available to young people under the programme include sports coaching, mentoring, peer mediation, environmental projects, youth leadership, music and dance. Helpline: 0800 9178185. Active Community Awards: Launched last December, more than 1,000 nominations had been received by the closing date on January 11. The 90 winners - 10 from each of nine regions - will receive their awards at a ceremony and gala dinner at the Millennium Dome tomorrow. Earlier in the day, they will join 2,000 other delegates at the Active Community convention at the Wembley conference centre to take part in workshops and plenary sessions on the nine award categories for building a community that is: learning; fair and just; active and empowered; influential; economically strong; caring; green; safe; and sustainable. Malcolm Dean  The Active Community Convention will be broadcast live tomorrow on the web at www.acu.communicatinglive.com

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Those searching for something positive to say about the nature of contemporary Britishness are fond of reaching for its distinctive culture. This was, after all, the impetus behind the re-branding of the country as "Cool Britannia" a couple of years ago, a campaign which expired under a pile of pejorative articles about the distinctive un-coolness of its promoters.

But the failure of that initiative may not have meant the impulse was misplaced. As social theorist Andrew Calcutt insists in the introduction to his new book on British culture, Brit Cult (published this month by Prion Books), "the common currency of British politics is not ideology and economics but lifestyle and emotion. With the collapse of empire, the demise of British manufacturing and the end of ideology, Britain is British culture, no more and no less".

This is not, however, a cue for a lengthy theoretical discourse on the nature of British culture. Calcutt seeks to show rather than to tell and does so by selecting 200 "key players in current British culture" and then writing essays on each which combine biographical details, analysis and opinion, in the hope that the whole will add up to a "composite picture of British culture as a whole".

The idea works wonderfully. It's impressive enough to study the cast Calcutt has assembled, to find Keith Allen and JG Ballard and Ozwald Boateng rubbing shoulders with Chris Morris, Harold Pinter and The Royle Family.

But what really persuades one to buy the author's thesis about the vitality of the culture which these "players" exemplify is the cool, critical command he has of their respective contributions.

These may be sketches, but the lines are taut and vigorous: "The Pet Shop Boys are an ultra-intelligent pop group - an oxymoron they are wise to"; "Malcolm McLaren combines the money-making nous of early pop managers like Larry Parnes with the revolutionary pranksterism of the Situationists"; "Comic, actor, writer, director Keith Allen has driven through life at a rate which makes Stirling Moss seem like Miss Marple".

Contemporary British culture, Calcutt sweepingly declares, "has never been so interesting". One thing is certain. No one, until now, has ever made such an optimistic reading of our current condition quite so plausible.

 Laurie Taylor presents Thinking Allowed on Radio 4 at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Road to ruin
fields.standfirst: A year after a royal commission report  called for a fairer approach to funding  long-term care, the issue is still in the  long grass, says Melanie Henwood
fields.trailText: A year after a royal commission report called for a fairer approach to funding long-term care, the issue is still in the long grass, says Melanie Henwood.
fields.body:
Today's first anniversary of the publication of the report of the royal commission on long-term care will not be greeted with the popping of champagne corks. There is little to cheer when the report continues to gather dust on ministerial desks.

As Sir Stewart Sutherland, vice-chancellor of Edinburgh university, cautioned a year ago, when a royal commission is established, the cynics believe it is because "a difficult issue is being kicked into the long grass so that someone other than the government can take the blame for problems which are impossible to solve or unpalatable in their solution".

To date, there has been merely a debate on long-term care in the House of Commons last December, which fell a long way short of offering the government's response to the commission's recommendations.

The essential issue remains that while we all expect or hope to grow old, some of us will need long-term care (the likelihood of needing residential care is estimated at one in five for men aged over 65 and one in three for women). The risk is spread unevenly, and so too are the costs.

As the commission pointed out, someone who is ill with cancer or heart disease will be cared for free of charge by the NHS; but the position of someone needing care because they have severe dementia, for example, is quite different. This care is generally not seen as the province of the health service, but of local authority social care, and social services are means tested and carry charges for the service user.

Anyone with capital assets (that is assets which include the value of their home) of £16,000 or more is responsible for the total cost of care home fees, necessitating the sale of the house to make assets liquid. Those with fewer assets have to contribute towards the fees, and it is not until assets drop to below £10,000 that no charge is made.

The system at present, as the commission observed, "helps people who are poor, demands that people of modest means make themselves poor before it will help, and affects people to a lesser degree the richer they are". The system is inconsistent. Moreover, it fails to meet "the reasonable expectations of old people" who believe that they have already paid into the system through national insurance "which they were led to believe would look after them in later life, whatever their needs".

The sense of unfairness and betrayal that older people feel is genuine and distressing. Few can have anticipated being forced to sell the family home and to part with money saved through a lifetime of making do in order to meet care fees - calculated by the commission at an average £275 per week in residential care and £350 per week in a nursing home. Estimates vary, but a widely quoted figure is that 40,000 homes are being sold every year to pay for long-term care.

The political difficulties of this issue for all parties are clear. For the Conservatives, it was clearly at odds with the aspirations of a property owning democracy, and John Major's pledge that the right "to own a home and pass it on is one of the most important rights that an individual has in a free society". For Labour, too, there are problems. The prime minister himself is on record - in his 1997 conference speech - declaiming that his vision for Britain is not of a country in which old people are forced to sell their homes to pay for care.

The alternative model presented by the royal commission attempted to break down the care bill into the constituents of living costs, housing costs and personal care costs. While the commission accepted that there could be a case for people contributing to the first two, subject to their means, they argued that the costs of personal care should be treated as something "quite different".

"These are the costs which, unpredictably and through no fault of their own, old people have to incur when they can no longer be looked after at home or cannot be sent home after hospital treatment. They reflect the true risk and 'catastrophic' nature of needing long-term care. In our judgment it is right for the state to exempt personal care from means-testing altogether. This is our key recommendation."

The price tag on this proposal is significant. It could cost an annual £1.1bn, rising to £2.6bn by 2021 and £6.4bn by 2051. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has promised that the 2000 spending review "will consider long-term care funding" and will be followed by a white paper. He also acknowledged that "we need to find a fairer way of fund ing long-term care for the future". At the same time, this objective will be set alongside the underlying principle "that people should provide for themselves where they are able to". Such a circle will be hard to square.

Milburn told the Commons that further work would include exploring "with the financial services industry how it could best design long-term care insurance products and other financial products to see if they could be made attractive to a wider audience".

This is almost certainly not the road to go down. The experience with insurance products and other financial mechanisms, such as equity release schemes, is one of a poor track record and little public confidence. The commission explored this area and offered a swingeing critique of the capacity of the private sector to adequately cover risks at an affordable price.

But the "do nothing" option cannot be countenanced indefinitely. For Labour to go into the next election campaign with no answer to the long-term care dilemma would be unforgivable. Equally, to approach it with a Toryesque model of individual responsibility and private finance - which they ridiculed while in opposition - would be foolhardy and disingenuous.

The key argument of the commission is that universal risk pooling represents the most effective way of providing the coverage required. Risk pooling does not lead necessarily to private sector solutions, and the most obvious approach would be compulsory risk sharing, either through a social insurance model (such as proposed by the Rowntree inquiry in 1996) or through a general taxation revenue base, as proposed by the commission. Indeed, as the commission urged, what it offers is "an opportunity for a new contract between government and people and between all generations of society".

One year on, that new contract is not yet in evidence. Whether it emerges will be the test of this government's commitment to an ageing population and the issue of long-term care.

 Melanie Henwood is an independent health and social care analyst.

fields.headline: Sky's the limit
fields.standfirst: Rose Robinson on the four years she spent  working with women villagers in Honduras
fields.trailText: Rose Robinson on the four years she spent working with women villagers in Honduras.
fields.body:
I've just returned to England after four years in the remote jungles of La Mosquitia, in Honduras. La Mosquitia is about the size of Wales, has just two hospitals and is only accessible by boat or by plane. I work for Tearfund, which works with indigenous organisations. One of these is Mopawi, and I went to support them on a range of programmes including agriculture, education, forestry, women's projects and land rights' issues.

This was my first experience overseas as an aid worker and it was an eye-opener to exchange the comforts of Britain for a home among people living in wood and straw houses. The tiny village of Belen, on Honduras's north coast, is situated on a narrow strip of land forming the outer curve of a large lagoon, virtually surrounded by water. It is an hour's flight from the nearest big town and only six feet above sea level; the village certainly felt vulnerable.

I realised just how vulnerable we were when hurricane Mitch struck - the most powerful hurricane there for 300 years. Belen was just 60 miles from the epicentre. The village, its occupants and a rather shaken aid-worker survived, although much of the landward defence was destroyed. One important project undertaken by the local women was to replant a protective barrier of mangroves and trees along the lagoon edge.

I quickly learned that men and women have clearly defined roles here. The women work long hours to provide for their families but earn very little income. The men often are away for weeks at a time and travel great distances to work in the lobster-diving industry or in agriculture growing the basic crops on which they depend for survival. Not surprisingly, it is the women who are the foundation of the village and it was with them that I worked most closely. Over 70% of the world's poor are women.

Mopawi is working to redress this inequality and help women to increase their earning power by initiating projects that will help them in their move away from a subsistence economy towards a viable market economy. It does this by using sustainable, natural resources that can be exploited without causing damage. A butterfly farm as a tourist attraction, for instance, provides local women with employment opportunities.

Many women have large families (nine children is average) and they are tied to their village, so we helped to set up businesses that they could run from home. These include bread and cake baking, agriculture and eco-tourism, which is providing a valuable source of income for women who are able to offer accommodation and simple meals. Mopawi has also helped to establish communal banks for women linked to these income- generating activities. This also gives them enough basic education to begin to use the banks to save their earnings for needs such as medical emergencies and to provide a more secure future for their families.

Involving the whole community, Mopawi is also developing long-term plans to help the community to take responsible decisions about its future. Concerns include an influx of new people, the preservation and use of the UN world heritage site, the Rio Platano biosphere reserve (which covers almost half of La Mosquitia), and pressure on the rainforest from logging and cattle ranching.

Mopawi's work continues. It is starting a community healthcare programme to reduce mortality rates, provide basic health education and introduce sanitation in order to avoid the risk of disease.

After all these experiences, it's a delight to find that Tearfund has launched a new education pack on the role of women in the developing world, called Women Hold Up Half the Sky. It is a great opportunity for me to celebrate the role of the women I have met and worked with for the past four years. But it is also an opportunity for everyone to recognise the day-to-day struggle many women face around the world and to help to raise funds to change their lives in practical and sustainable ways - as Mopawi is attempting to do in La Mosquitia.
