fields.headline: Forward lines
fields.standfirst: Academics were asked by the Social Policy Association to look ahead on issues close to their hearts. Here are edited extracts from three of the contributions
fields.trailText: Academics were asked by the Social Policy Association to look ahead on issues close to their hearts. Here are edited extracts from three of the contributions.
fields.byline: Marilyn Taylor, Janet Lewis and Jonathan Bradshaw
fields.body:
Community participation was flavour of the month way back in the late 1960s. But the oil crisis and then Thatcherism and the market put paid to that. It was business, not communities, who were to be the new partners. Now a range of new policies has put community participation, even perhaps community leadership, firmly back on the agenda. Will it be different this time?

The New Deal for communities and the national strategy for neighbourhood renewal that will come out of the work of the social exclusion unit, are opportunities nobody can afford to miss.

But it is one thing to apply the rose-coloured language of community and partnership to today's "wicked" issues. It's quite another to make it work, let alone keep it going after the initial fanfare of publicity has died down.

On the other hand, it's easy to be cynical - to see it as inevitable that public sector cultures will resist change and to argue that it is in the nature of capital and of power that people will be repeatedly expected to manage their own deprivation. Parts of government have demonstrated an ability to do what they've always done in a different wrapping: despite all the rhetoric, performance measures, audit systems and incentives tend to focus attention inwards and reinforce a culture of control. But policy making and implementation is more complex than this.

If local government is to be modernised, rather than re-engineered, then the rhetoric of partnership and governance needs to be driven home by those who have an investment in change. People who have lived and worked in what are variously called hard-to-let, deprived, disadvantaged estates know that there is no easy solution to social and political exclusion.

There are real tensions involved in sharing power, in reconciling leadership, participation and democratic accountability and in meeting the needs of diverse communities which may be as alienated from each other as they are from society at large.

Community participation must never be used as a substitute for addressing the economic forces that lead to exclusion.

So what do I want to see change in the coming decade? Here are a few small things to start with:

 A hands-off approach from the centre - a willingness to risk a few failures and admit to mistakes, because we can learn from them.
 New systems of professional training and accreditation which place a premium on enabling, rather than control, and which spread knowledge, rather than protect it.
 Politicians who are in the job because they want to give a voice to local people and who recognise that they need new skills to negotiate, broker, listen and mediate.
 Performance, budgetary and audit systems which are servants, rather than masters, and give the people who are supposed to benefit the opportunity to define how they will measure local needs, benchmark services and monitor progress.
 Funding programmes with language, rules, timescales and monitoring requirements that can pass a "small organisations litmus test" and reach those communities which always miss out.
 Patience on all sides. The alienation of decades won't be solved overnight, and rushing at fences to meet political deadlines will repeat the mistakes of the past, continuing to exclude the communities that are hardest to reach.
 A willingness to experiment with representative structures and find new ways of combining effective leadership with access, democratic accountability and participation.
 A new approach to benefits which allows people to be recompensed for their participation without prejudice or hassle when they are doing work that other people would be paid for.

 Marilyn Taylor is professor of social policy at Brighton university.

Help the rich to spend their money
When the rapid increase in the gap between the income of the richest and poorest in society happened in the 1980s and early 1990s, we saw it as a direct consequence of the policies of the Thatcher years. Now we have a Labour government, but policies on this front don't seem to be changing.

While the focus on work as a means of moving out of low income has many advantages, there are going to continue to be people who are not able to work for one reason or another. Whether we like it or not, there will always be some vulnerable people who need support, both financial and emotional, in order to lead a reasonable life.

The issue of income disparities is not just a matter of assisting people who receive the least. The lifecycle changes that everyone experiences also put pressure on individuals and families at different stages.

We know that children are very expensive - in income forgone by parents stopping work, as well as in direct expenditure. More costs are being shifted from the state to the family for higher education on the one hand, and to support unemployed 16 year olds on the other. We also know that many 70 and 80 year olds do not have the funds to pay for their long-term care.

While more of the future generation of older people will have occupational pensions and housing equity, it will not be the majority for many years to come. The role of the state to help redistribute funds over the lifecycle seems to have been forgotten. In many ways, the arguments in favour of redistribution have not changed since Richard Titmuss was writing in the 1950s.

But nowadays there are people whose annual earnings are huge - £1m a year or more. If you are working long hours to earn your money - as these people are - how do you find the time to spend it? There must be limits to the amount of conspicuous consumption in which one can indulge. But, apart from the Sainsbury family, there is little evidence of this new wealth finding its way into philanthropy.

The challenge I see for the future is to rediscover redistribution and to help the wealthy find constructive ways of spending their money.

 Janet Lewis is research director at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Tell us about the floating voter of Essex
I believe the biggest question facing domestic politics and every field of social policy is whether taxpayers are willing to pay more to fund public services.

Politicians' belief that they are not is the reason why the NHS is in crisis, why the living standards of families on income support are still falling, why the national insurance system has been emasculated, why there is a teacher recruitment crisis in schools, why this government will fail to achieve most of its poverty reduction objectives and why our welfare state is becoming so divorced from the European norm - why we have public squalor in the face of private affluence.

Indeed, it is arguable that this has been the main issue in social policy in the past 25 years. For almost the whole of that time, I have been reassuring my students that the empirical evidence (mainly British Social Attitudes surveys) is that a substantial majority supports increases in taxation in order to improve public services. Hardly anyone, even Conservative voters, wants to cut taxation if it means cutting public services.

It is for that reason that the Thatcher project to roll back the welfare state failed and why the Tories never got a majority of the popular vote. It is why public expenditure increased in real terms, as a proportion of GDP, and why taxation did not fall. In short, there is, in fact, massive political support for the welfare state.

My students look sceptical and ask, with reason, why the Tories won four general elections in a row; why New Labour won only after it made a commitment not to increase public expenditure for two years nor increase direct taxation for the life of its first parliament. They question my analysis, pointing to New Labour policies cutting the standard rate of income tax, starving the public sector of resources and creating the lowest level of public expenditure as a proportion of GDP in living memory (more or less).

In response I argue about the power of the floating voter, Essex Man, and about how the electoral system locks British politics into the aspirations of the lowest common denominator. But can such a deeply depressing conclusion really be true? I don't know and would like someone else to find out for me.

 Jonathan Bradshaw is professor of social policy at York university. Copies of the entire set of 18 contributions, plus a parallel set of retrospective assessments of 20th-century landmarks, can be obtained by writing to Professor Gary Craig, Social Policy Association, University of Hull, HU6 7RX, enclosing a large self addressed envelope with a 50p stamp.
fields.bodyText: Community participation was flavour of the month way back in the late 1960s. But the oil crisis and then Thatcherism and the market put paid to that. It was business, not communities, who were to be the new partners. Now a range of new policies has put community participation, even perhaps community leadership, firmly back on the agenda. Will it be different this time? The New Deal for communities and the national strategy for neighbourhood renewal that will come out of the work of the social exclusion unit, are opportunities nobody can afford to miss. But it is one thing to apply the rose-coloured language of community and partnership to today's "wicked" issues. It's quite another to make it work, let alone keep it going after the initial fanfare of publicity has died down. On the other hand, it's easy to be cynical - to see it as inevitable that public sector cultures will resist change and to argue that it is in the nature of capital and of power that people will be repeatedly expected to manage their own deprivation. Parts of government have demonstrated an ability to do what they've always done in a different wrapping: despite all the rhetoric, performance measures, audit systems and incentives tend to focus attention inwards and reinforce a culture of control. But policy making and implementation is more complex than this. If local government is to be modernised, rather than re-engineered, then the rhetoric of partnership and governance needs to be driven home by those who have an investment in change. People who have lived and worked in what are variously called hard-to-let, deprived, disadvantaged estates know that there is no easy solution to social and political exclusion. There are real tensions involved in sharing power, in reconciling leadership, participation and democratic accountability and in meeting the needs of diverse communities which may be as alienated from each other as they are from society at large. Community participation must never be used as a substitute for addressing the economic forces that lead to exclusion. So what do I want to see change in the coming decade? Here are a few small things to start with:  A hands-off approach from the centre - a willingness to risk a few failures and admit to mistakes, because we can learn from them.  New systems of professional training and accreditation which place a premium on enabling, rather than control, and which spread knowledge, rather than protect it.  Politicians who are in the job because they want to give a voice to local people and who recognise that they need new skills to negotiate, broker, listen and mediate.  Performance, budgetary and audit systems which are servants, rather than masters, and give the people who are supposed to benefit the opportunity to define how they will measure local needs, benchmark services and monitor progress.  Funding programmes with language, rules, timescales and monitoring requirements that can pass a "small organisations litmus test" and reach those communities which always miss out.  Patience on all sides. The alienation of decades won't be solved overnight, and rushing at fences to meet political deadlines will repeat the mistakes of the past, continuing to exclude the communities that are hardest to reach.  A willingness to experiment with representative structures and find new ways of combining effective leadership with access, democratic accountability and participation.  A new approach to benefits which allows people to be recompensed for their participation without prejudice or hassle when they are doing work that other people would be paid for.  Marilyn Taylor is professor of social policy at Brighton university. Help the rich to spend their money When the rapid increase in the gap between the income of the richest and poorest in society happened in the 1980s and early 1990s, we saw it as a direct consequence of the policies of the Thatcher years. Now we have a Labour government, but policies on this front don't seem to be changing. While the focus on work as a means of moving out of low income has many advantages, there are going to continue to be people who are not able to work for one reason or another. Whether we like it or not, there will always be some vulnerable people who need support, both financial and emotional, in order to lead a reasonable life. The issue of income disparities is not just a matter of assisting people who receive the least. The lifecycle changes that everyone experiences also put pressure on individuals and families at different stages. We know that children are very expensive - in income forgone by parents stopping work, as well as in direct expenditure. More costs are being shifted from the state to the family for higher education on the one hand, and to support unemployed 16 year olds on the other. We also know that many 70 and 80 year olds do not have the funds to pay for their long-term care. While more of the future generation of older people will have occupational pensions and housing equity, it will not be the majority for many years to come. The role of the state to help redistribute funds over the lifecycle seems to have been forgotten. In many ways, the arguments in favour of redistribution have not changed since Richard Titmuss was writing in the 1950s. But nowadays there are people whose annual earnings are huge - £1m a year or more. If you are working long hours to earn your money - as these people are - how do you find the time to spend it? There must be limits to the amount of conspicuous consumption in which one can indulge. But, apart from the Sainsbury family, there is little evidence of this new wealth finding its way into philanthropy. The challenge I see for the future is to rediscover redistribution and to help the wealthy find constructive ways of spending their money.  Janet Lewis is research director at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. Tell us about the floating voter of Essex I believe the biggest question facing domestic politics and every field of social policy is whether taxpayers are willing to pay more to fund public services. Politicians' belief that they are not is the reason why the NHS is in crisis, why the living standards of families on income support are still falling, why the national insurance system has been emasculated, why there is a teacher recruitment crisis in schools, why this government will fail to achieve most of its poverty reduction objectives and why our welfare state is becoming so divorced from the European norm - why we have public squalor in the face of private affluence. Indeed, it is arguable that this has been the main issue in social policy in the past 25 years. For almost the whole of that time, I have been reassuring my students that the empirical evidence (mainly British Social Attitudes surveys) is that a substantial majority supports increases in taxation in order to improve public services. Hardly anyone, even Conservative voters, wants to cut taxation if it means cutting public services. It is for that reason that the Thatcher project to roll back the welfare state failed and why the Tories never got a majority of the popular vote. It is why public expenditure increased in real terms, as a proportion of GDP, and why taxation did not fall. In short, there is, in fact, massive political support for the welfare state. My students look sceptical and ask, with reason, why the Tories won four general elections in a row; why New Labour won only after it made a commitment not to increase public expenditure for two years nor increase direct taxation for the life of its first parliament. They question my analysis, pointing to New Labour policies cutting the standard rate of income tax, starving the public sector of resources and creating the lowest level of public expenditure as a proportion of GDP in living memory (more or less). In response I argue about the power of the floating voter, Essex Man, and about how the electoral system locks British politics into the aspirations of the lowest common denominator. But can such a deeply depressing conclusion really be true? I don't know and would like someone else to find out for me.  Jonathan Bradshaw is professor of social policy at York university. fields.headline: Let off lightly
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Milton calls on MPs to tighten up  the government's plans for regulating utilities
fields.trailText: Nicholas Milton calls on MPs to tighten up the government's plans for regulating utilities.
fields.body:
If a week is a long time in politics, 11 years must seem like an eternity. But for Tony Blair the current passage of the utilities bill through parliament will surely bring back memories of his time as Labour's shadow energy minister.

In 1989, the future prime minister was scathing in his condemnation of the Tories' electricity act. "We agree that the greenhouse effect and global warming is a serious environmental problem - perhaps the most serious that we face," said a young Blair sternly in a heated debate in July 1989 on a Lords amendment to make it a duty of the secretary of state to promote energy efficiency.

Reading those words again now you would be forgiven for thinking that the passage of time may have improved the prime minister's soundbites but not his ardour to impose environmental duties on the electricity industry.

For the utilities bill, currently before parliament, which will regulate the gas, electricity, water and telecommunications industries, does not even make it a duty on the regulator to promote sustainable development, let alone deliver on the government's own carbon dioxide and renewable energy targets. With the gas and electricity industries contributing well over half of the UK's carbon dioxide emissions such a duty is vital if the government is to honour these commitments.

The task of convincing ministers to adopt such a duty will fall to MPs on the standing committee, who will be debating the bill over the coming weeks. Ignominiously, one civil servant at the department of trade and industry has already described the duty as "driving a coach and horses" through the bill. Given that the Liberal Democrats on the committee are likely to be in support of its adoption, the success of the amendment will depend upon a handful of Labour MPs. Their resolve in the face of pressure from the whips to resist the change and push through the bill as quickly as possible will be crucial.

MPs on the committee will also have to scrutinise the government's proposals for delivering on the solution to climate change, namely energy efficiency and renewable energy. On the energy efficiency side the bill does provide welcome powers for the secretary of state to place targets on electricity distributors and suppliers. However, with the government's tendency to downgrade some firm environmental targets to aspirational ones, MPs would do well to consider whether placing a formal obligation on the electricity industry might be more effective.

The bill also proposes that the current method of financing renewable energy projects, the non-fossil fuel obligation (NFFO), be abolished. In its place a "renewables obligation" will be introduced which will make it compulsory to supply a certain amount of electricity from renewable sources subject to the cost being acceptable to consumers. Significantly, those companies who cannot or do not wish to meet their obligation will be able to buy their way out of the scheme. Many in the renewables industry feel that the current penalty set by the government is not high enough to act as a real deterrent. Perversely, the bill is also unclear whether this money will be recycled back to the electricity industry as a whole or just to those companies who have met their renewable obligation.

In her defence of the obligation Helen Liddell, the energy minister, said: "It's time to make the next generation of technologies lean and mean as well as clean and green".

But by not specifying which technologies companies should buy, the renewable obligation makes it inevitable that many will opt for "cheap and dirty" renewables like waste incineration rather than truly "clean and green" ones like offshore wind. Worse still, renewable technologies which offer the greatest long term potential like solar power may be forced out of the UK market altogether.

So what changes should MPs call for? First they should ensure that a wide range of technologies is supported by the obligation. This could be done by ensuring that the money raised from companies opting out of the scheme is channelled back into a strategic renewables fund.

This could help finance technologies like solar and wave power, where UK companies lead the world, and kick start technologies like offshore wind power and biomass which must be rapidly developed if the government is to meet its renewables target.

Second, the renewables obligation must be extended to include combined heat and power schemes which are currently excluded from the bill.

 Nicholas Milton is utility bill co-ordinator for the Socialist Environment and Resources Association (SERA), the green wing of the Labour party.

fields.headline: Earth works
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Gibbs on a new buiding which is  old-tech, but houses  modern IT
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Gibbs on a new buiding which is old-tech, but houses modern IT.
fields.body:
It is the world's most ancient building material, it is cheap and sustainable, and, as the Centre for Alternative Technology (Cat) in mid Wales has now confirmed with some relief, earth actually works.

When the environmental charity decided to construct a £600,000 state-of-the-art information centre to handle the ever increasing flood of queries it receives from members of the public each year, it insisted on practising what it preached and making the new building a test bed for ecological techniques.

Now, it is close to completing what it believes will be modern Britain's first earth-built public building. It makes use of a range of other low impact materials, including three tonnes of sheep's wool for insulation, and is being constructed entirely without cement, reflecting Cat's concern at the energy intensive nature of an industry said to account for up to 10% of worldwide CO2 emissions.

"We are always looking out for ways of building more sustainably and we wanted to explore some of the interesting techniques we had heard about," says Cindy Harris, the project director. She says the project team had been keen to use sheep's wool as an insulation material because it was a locally available and renewable resource.

At present most wool used to insulate buildings in the UK has been imported from Australasia. It is hoped that by using Welsh fleeces the project may help stimulate a new market for an underused local product.

Rammed earth, the technique chosen for the construction of the new building, is well known in hotter, drier climates with clay rich soils. But it has not previously been used structurally in a modern public building in this country.

The technique involves compacting moist, loose earth in layers several inches deep with a mechanical rammer. The layers are built up by pouring the earth into a specially built box or shuttering which is later removed. Once compacted, the earth dries out slowly until it sets to the hardness of sedimentary rock.

Cat, which was keen to demonstrate the benefits of using what is a cheap and readily available natural material, brought in tonnes of waste sub-soil from a Shropshire limestone quarry to construct the columns and wall panels which sup port the new building. Staff admit to being a little nervous when temporary timber roof supports were removed earlier this month. But their faith in the rammed earth technology was not misplaced - the slender four metre high columns are now supporting the roof loads and work is pressing ahead to complete the building by early summer. Rammed earth was also used to produce the 1,700 or so blocks that have been laid to erect the UK's first public compost toilet complex on the site.

The centre, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this year, has become one of the leading visitor attractions in mid Wales, pulling in 80,000 visitors each year. Its website records some 140,000 hits a month and staff currently handle an estimated 15,000 inquiries annually from people wanting to know how to build a compost toilet, install solar water heating or seeking the answer to any number of questions about how to live more sustainably.

At present Cat's one small information point is open for only one hour a day. The new building - complete with computer terminals - will provide visitors with a much greater opportunity for talking to information officers and gaining access to the information they are after. It is expected to be open seven days a week throughout the year.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: GM debate | Weight debate
fields.body:
So what made Tony Blair change his mind, or rather distance himself from the pro-GM zealots, at the same time as pushing Mo Mowlam forward to deny his self-evident shift? Look not to the OECD conference in Edinburgh on GM safety, but to the US, where GM is liable to meltdown over the next few months as new research comes out - confirming all the scientific doubts - the tide of public opinion changes, farmers desert the new crops and the machinations of the companies in league with government are exposed. Even more to the point, a huge US lawsuit is being prepared against Monsanto and friends, which could blow their whole operation out of the water once and for all and leave Blair politically exposed come the next election.

 But the chances of GM going away are slim. Witness the nuclear industry which has been rotten to the core for as long as anyone can remember yet has continued to operate after every imaginable disaster. The ousting of BNFL chief executive John Taylor is significant, but only because the former Exxon man was actually ready and keen to clean out the stables.

 But how good to know that the OECD delegates at Edinburgh will be eating GM-free food. The caterers, Leith's, long ago took the decision to "avoid the use of GM foods". Did the OECD know this? It seems not.

 And where's the Iolcos Grace, the grain ship that Greenpeace prevented coming in to Liverpool docks last weekend. Er, no one seems to know. She was last reported sailing into deep ocean. Cargill's, whose soya is aboard, says only that it will come into Liverpool when the tide is right, the coast-guard has no information and the ship itself is not contactable via the Inmarsat telephone service that BT operates.

 For the first time in human history, the number of overweight people rivals the number of underweight people, according to the Worldwatch Institute, a Washington DC-based research group. While the world's underfed population has declined slightly since 1980 to 1.2 billion, the number of overweight people has surged to 1.2 billion. In the United States, 55% of adults are now overweight by international standards and almost one in four considered obese. And the trend is spreading to children as well, with one in five now classified as overweight.

fields.headline: Cultures of cruelty
fields.standfirst: Richard D Ryder on how far the animal welfare revolution has come
fields.trailText: Richard D Ryder on how far the animal welfare revolution has come.
fields.body:
In the past three years the government has effected more rapid progress for animals than any government at least since the first world war. The home office has confirmed bans on the use in research of great apes and primates caught in the wild, banned puppy farming, banned the testing of alcohol and tobacco products on animals, stopped the testing of cosmetics on animals and has created a forum with animal welfarists to dis cuss future reforms.

At the ministry of agriculture Elliot Morley has presided over new welfare codes for sheep, seen through bans on sow stalls and tethers, improved the enforcement of welfare standards at markets, better training guidelines for livestock handlers, tighter controls on live exports, a ban on deer hunting on Forestry Commission land, support for a bill to ban fur farming and the implementation of the welfare of animals (transport) order. Ironically, their apparent fudge of the hunting issue now threatens to blow out of the water the government's well-earned reputation based upon all this progress.

In Europe, too, there have been startling advances and the UK government helped to effect the major decisions to ban throughout the EU the keeping of calves in crates by 2006 and the use of battery cages for poultry by 2012. The UK was also a lead player in an amendment to the European Treaty signed in Amsterdam in 1997 requiring member states to "pay full regard to the welfare requirements of animals" when formulating all agricultural, transport, internal market and research policies. This proposal also recognises animals as "sentient" beings. The implementation of EU legislation, however, is patchy and, in some states, derisory. One of the next steps forward for animals would be an effective EU inspectorate and enforcement agency to crack down on corrupt and callous hauliers, abattoirs, farms and laboratories throughout Europe, and to ensure that the now considerable body of EU welfare legislation is being put into effect. Enforced or not, however, much has been achieved since the issue of animal protection came alive in the early 1970s.

How did it all happen? The answer to this sounds chauvinistic but it was, in fact, the British as a nation that led the way. The whole movement against the slavery of animals started in 18th century London and was not so much a manifestation of typical British compassion as a reaction by the intelligentsia (Alexander Pope, Richard Steele, Joseph Addison, William Hogarth, Samuel Johnson and several of the poets, among others) against the exceptional cruelty of the British, displayed everywhere by the baiting of bulls and bears, dog fights, cock fights, the overdriving of horses, the appalling slaughter houses around Smithfield and the demonstrations of pointless vivisections for public entertainment.

Foreign visitors were often shocked by what they saw. By the 1770s, according to Johnson, animal welfare was a much discussed topic and in 1789 the philosopher Jeremy Bentham attacked mankind's "tyranny" of the animals and included them within the moral community. "The question is not can they reason?" he said, "nor can they talk, but can they suffer?"

Although the Napoleonic wars set back progress in this field, almost as soon as they were over, politicians began the battle to introduce the first legislation.

Richard Martin and Thomas, Lord Erskine, both flamboyant and determined men, finally succeeded in 1822 with the passage of an act to protect cattle from cruelty - the first of its kind in the world. Two years later Martin and a few others, among them the well known anti-slavery reformers William Wilberforce and Thomas Fowell Buxton, set up the society that was to become the RSPCA. It struggled for a few years, nearly went bankrupt but was rescued by the radical author and inventor Lewis Gompertz.

The society went on to produce numerous educative tracts, employ inspectors to enforce the new laws and to lobby politically for increased protection for horses, cattle and laboratory animals. Only in the first half of the 20th century did the RSPCA lose its vision and momentum entirely, becoming engrossed in the rescue and destruction of stray cats and dogs.

Earlier, the young Victoria had become a patroness in 1835 and, despite her beloved Albert's fondness for shooting animals, she remained a stalwart and vigorous supporter of the society throughout her life, writing passionate letters to various prime ministers urging their support for animal protection reforms. Due to her known commitment, the RSPCA and animal welfare became respectable. In 1876 the cruelty to animals act was passed to control animal experimentation and in 1911 a century of reforms was consolidated in Sir George Greenwood's animal protection act, which is still the main statute protecting animals from cruelty.

The animal welfare revolution of the 1770s was repeated in the 1960s and 1970s. This time the intellectual movement started in Oxford, where some of us contributed to Animals, Men And Morals in 1971. Peter Singer's review of this book brought him into the picture and the campaign against speciesism was under way. The radical action of the decade was centred on bloodsports, in support of the hunt saboteurs, and in the campaign to reform the law on laboratory animals. This was finally achieved in 1986 with the passage of the animals (scientific procedures) act, after a long campaign led by the veteran Labour parliamentarian, Douglas Houghton.

Some of us were also involved in the successful modernisation of the RSPCA and in reviving its original role as a campaigning organisation. The modern cruelties of factory farming and animal experimentation had rapidly expanded almost unopposed for half a century while traditional forms of speciesism such as hunting, whaling, sealing, fur trapping, zoos and circuses, had continued unremarked upon. After 1975 we had some of the media on our side, aware that this was a subject that had growing public support, although politicians still tended to hold aloof, unable really to take the subject seriously at that time.

We were quick to realise the potential of the European Community and the RSPCA in 1979 set up the Eurogroup for Animal Welfare, which still functions effectively in Strasbourg and Brussels as the federal lobby on behalf of animals.

The massed lobbying of the European parliament from 1980 by Eurogroup and Brian Davies of the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW), in a successful bid to stop the importation of seal products, made a lasting impression upon European politicians. Many had not previously found themselves the centre of attention among their own constituents.

Where, then, do we stand today? After a bleak decade in Britain during the 1980s, we have had some resounding successes in the 1990s. But as a successful political movement we have been strangely ignored, no longer by the politicians (whose jobs depend upon keeping in touch with public opinion) but by political commentators.

Some seem to have difficulty in realising that this is a politically and ethically sophisticated movement and one with growing scientific involvement and huge public support across all sections of society.

We are now faced by the World Trade Organisation which threatens to prevent the EU from restricting the importation of skins, furs ripped from animals caught in steel-toothed traps, dairy products from American cows cruelly pumped full of hormones and food animals reared in the hell-holes of uncontrolled intensive systems abroad.

These cheap and nasty products threaten to undercut those produced more humanely in Europe. World free trade may be a good thing but not if it is totally lacking in a moral dimension.

 Dr Richard Ryder created the concept of speciesism and is a campaigner for animal protection. He is also the author of Animal Revolution: Changing Attitudes To Speciesism, (Berg, March 8, £14.99).
fields.bodyText: In the past three years the government has effected more rapid progress for animals than any government at least since the first world war. The home office has confirmed bans on the use in research of great apes and primates caught in the wild, banned puppy farming, banned the testing of alcohol and tobacco products on animals, stopped the testing of cosmetics on animals and has created a forum with animal welfarists to dis cuss future reforms. At the ministry of agriculture Elliot Morley has presided over new welfare codes for sheep, seen through bans on sow stalls and tethers, improved the enforcement of welfare standards at markets, better training guidelines for livestock handlers, tighter controls on live exports, a ban on deer hunting on Forestry Commission land, support for a bill to ban fur farming and the implementation of the welfare of animals (transport) order. Ironically, their apparent fudge of the hunting issue now threatens to blow out of the water the government's well-earned reputation based upon all this progress. In Europe, too, there have been startling advances and the UK government helped to effect the major decisions to ban throughout the EU the keeping of calves in crates by 2006 and the use of battery cages for poultry by 2012. The UK was also a lead player in an amendment to the European Treaty signed in Amsterdam in 1997 requiring member states to "pay full regard to the welfare requirements of animals" when formulating all agricultural, transport, internal market and research policies. This proposal also recognises animals as "sentient" beings. The implementation of EU legislation, however, is patchy and, in some states, derisory. One of the next steps forward for animals would be an effective EU inspectorate and enforcement agency to crack down on corrupt and callous hauliers, abattoirs, farms and laboratories throughout Europe, and to ensure that the now considerable body of EU welfare legislation is being put into effect. Enforced or not, however, much has been achieved since the issue of animal protection came alive in the early 1970s. How did it all happen? The answer to this sounds chauvinistic but it was, in fact, the British as a nation that led the way. The whole movement against the slavery of animals started in 18th century London and was not so much a manifestation of typical British compassion as a reaction by the intelligentsia (Alexander Pope, Richard Steele, Joseph Addison, William Hogarth, Samuel Johnson and several of the poets, among others) against the exceptional cruelty of the British, displayed everywhere by the baiting of bulls and bears, dog fights, cock fights, the overdriving of horses, the appalling slaughter houses around Smithfield and the demonstrations of pointless vivisections for public entertainment. Foreign visitors were often shocked by what they saw. By the 1770s, according to Johnson, animal welfare was a much discussed topic and in 1789 the philosopher Jeremy Bentham attacked mankind's "tyranny" of the animals and included them within the moral community. "The question is not can they reason?" he said, "nor can they talk, but can they suffer?" Although the Napoleonic wars set back progress in this field, almost as soon as they were over, politicians began the battle to introduce the first legislation. Richard Martin and Thomas, Lord Erskine, both flamboyant and determined men, finally succeeded in 1822 with the passage of an act to protect cattle from cruelty - the first of its kind in the world. Two years later Martin and a few others, among them the well known anti-slavery reformers William Wilberforce and Thomas Fowell Buxton, set up the society that was to become the RSPCA. It struggled for a few years, nearly went bankrupt but was rescued by the radical author and inventor Lewis Gompertz. The society went on to produce numerous educative tracts, employ inspectors to enforce the new laws and to lobby politically for increased protection for horses, cattle and laboratory animals. Only in the first half of the 20th century did the RSPCA lose its vision and momentum entirely, becoming engrossed in the rescue and destruction of stray cats and dogs. Earlier, the young Victoria had become a patroness in 1835 and, despite her beloved Albert's fondness for shooting animals, she remained a stalwart and vigorous supporter of the society throughout her life, writing passionate letters to various prime ministers urging their support for animal protection reforms. Due to her known commitment, the RSPCA and animal welfare became respectable. In 1876 the cruelty to animals act was passed to control animal experimentation and in 1911 a century of reforms was consolidated in Sir George Greenwood's animal protection act, which is still the main statute protecting animals from cruelty. The animal welfare revolution of the 1770s was repeated in the 1960s and 1970s. This time the intellectual movement started in Oxford, where some of us contributed to Animals, Men And Morals in 1971. Peter Singer's review of this book brought him into the picture and the campaign against speciesism was under way. The radical action of the decade was centred on bloodsports, in support of the hunt saboteurs, and in the campaign to reform the law on laboratory animals. This was finally achieved in 1986 with the passage of the animals (scientific procedures) act, after a long campaign led by the veteran Labour parliamentarian, Douglas Houghton. Some of us were also involved in the successful modernisation of the RSPCA and in reviving its original role as a campaigning organisation. The modern cruelties of factory farming and animal experimentation had rapidly expanded almost unopposed for half a century while traditional forms of speciesism such as hunting, whaling, sealing, fur trapping, zoos and circuses, had continued unremarked upon. After 1975 we had some of the media on our side, aware that this was a subject that had growing public support, although politicians still tended to hold aloof, unable really to take the subject seriously at that time. We were quick to realise the potential of the European Community and the RSPCA in 1979 set up the Eurogroup for Animal Welfare, which still functions effectively in Strasbourg and Brussels as the federal lobby on behalf of animals. The massed lobbying of the European parliament from 1980 by Eurogroup and Brian Davies of the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW), in a successful bid to stop the importation of seal products, made a lasting impression upon European politicians. Many had not previously found themselves the centre of attention among their own constituents. Where, then, do we stand today? After a bleak decade in Britain during the 1980s, we have had some resounding successes in the 1990s. But as a successful political movement we have been strangely ignored, no longer by the politicians (whose jobs depend upon keeping in touch with public opinion) but by political commentators. Some seem to have difficulty in realising that this is a politically and ethically sophisticated movement and one with growing scientific involvement and huge public support across all sections of society. We are now faced by the World Trade Organisation which threatens to prevent the EU from restricting the importation of skins, furs ripped from animals caught in steel-toothed traps, dairy products from American cows cruelly pumped full of hormones and food animals reared in the hell-holes of uncontrolled intensive systems abroad. These cheap and nasty products threaten to undercut those produced more humanely in Europe. World free trade may be a good thing but not if it is totally lacking in a moral dimension.  Dr Richard Ryder created the concept of speciesism and is a campaigner for animal protection. He is also the author of Animal Revolution: Changing Attitudes To Speciesism, (Berg, March 8, £14.99).

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: An armed robber who escaped with £12,500 from a building society in Macclesfield, Cheshire, was easily traced by police because he left behind his fingerprints, passport and driving licence.
fields.body:
Sporty gesture: Regulars at a pub in Gosport, Hampshire, have been left a vintage Cadillac Eldorado coupe by an American who used to be customer.

Knock-on effect: Noise from amorous woodpeckers has prompted parishioners in Great Henny, Essex, to raise money to have hard oak fitted during the restoration of the village church spire.

Passport to prison: An armed robber who escaped with £12,500 from a building society in Macclesfield, Cheshire, was easily traced by police because he left behind his fingerprints, passport and driving licence.

Winter of discontent: A retired man spending the winter in Portugal discovered that his home in Exeter had been squatted when he saw a picture of it accompanying a story on his local newspaper's website.

Waste of talent: Kent institute of art has presented a 'war on rubbish' award to a sculptor who made a 4ft model of a cow out of plastic milk cartons.

Crisis point: The guest speaker at a meeting in Plymouth had to abandon his talk, entitled How to Cope With a Crisis, when he was called home because his house was on fire.

Paneful truth: A benefits agency officer making a routine call at a house in Lancing, West Sussex, discovered that the man in a wheelchair claiming disability allowance was her window cleaner.

Bridging gap: Developers of a housing estate in Nottingham have been ordered not to build a bridge over a small river until May because the work would waken hibernating water voles.

High and dry: A week's supply of beer for the only pub on the Scottish isle of Easdale, near Mull, was lost when 13 kegs delivered to the pier were washed away by high seas.

Post waste: Residents of Easingwold, Yorkshire, have been mistakenly posting their letters in a bright red dog waste bin installed near a new housing development.

Shrewd move: A teacher from Barnsley is using part of the money from her divorce settlement to help fund a Royal Shakespeare Company performance of The Taming of the Shrew in a school hall.

Peak viewing: Students on a new course in popular fiction at Derby university will examine how accurately the TV series Peak Practice portrays life in rural Derbyshire.

Memory loss: The owners of a Scarborough hotel planning to mark its centenary with a display of memorabilia are offering free dinners to former guests who return stolen souvenirs.

Late call: An amnesty by libraries in Lanarkshire has enabled a mystery buyer to avoid a £900 fine by returning a leather-bound book, The Call of England, which was due back before March 13, 1930.

webTitle: Sellafield contract is suspended by Sweden

fields.headline: Sellafield contract is suspended by Sweden
fields.standfirst: More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Another blow for the Sellafield plant run by British Nuclear Fuels Ltd came yesterday when Sweden announced it was refusing to deliver 4.8 tonnes of spent nuclear fuel for reprocessing.
fields.body:
Another blow for the Sellafield plant run by British Nuclear Fuels Ltd came yesterday when Sweden announced it was refusing to deliver 4.8 tonnes of spent nuclear fuel for reprocessing.

The environment minister, Kjell Larsson, announced on Swedish television that the shipment had been suspended following the reports of falsified documents and safety doubts at the Cumberland plant.

Compared with Japan and Germany, Sweden is a small customer of BNFL - but its contract is the first to be suspended in the current safety scandal.

The spent fuel was from a research reactor, and was to be dissolved in nitric acid in the Thorp reprocessing plant; in theory, the cleaned up uranium could then be re-used, though in fact this was unlikely to happen.

BNFL confirmed last night that it had been told that a planned shipment had been suspended. "The customer is still keen to send it but the politicians have intervened," the spokesman said.

Swedish regulators passed the fuel for Sellafield last August but political approval was required. Mr Larsson said: "Considering the existing safety failures at Sellafield and the fact radioactive waste is still discharged into the North Sea, I see it as extremely unlikely that we will send more spent fuel to Sellafield."

Nuclear power is highly contentious in Sweden and successive governments have pledged to close existing plants but several times postponed the decision. The government has supported other Nordic countries in a series of protests about the sea discharges of plutonium and other nuclear wastes. As the currents take Irish Sea waters round the Scottish coasts, some radionuclides are detectable on Swedish shores.

Only last week the Icelandic environment minister was in London making another protest about Sellafield discharges on behalf of the Nordic block. Mr Larsson said the customer's decision to send the spent fuel had been taken before Sellafield's safety failures had become known: "It shows that nuclear power is not the simple solution to the energy problem that many people claim. There are still unresolved problems with nuclear power."

The decision shows that BNFL's troubles are a long way from over despite Monday's sacking of its chief executive, John Taylor, and a promise of a fresh start from its chairman, Hugh Collum.

BNFL has lost a lot of business from Japan already, and Germany is claiming compensation because it has shut a reactor loaded with fuel for which there was false documentation.

webTitle: Telford deaths family calls for Met to investigate

fields.headline: Telford deaths family calls for Met to investigate
fields.trailText: A solicitor representing the families of two black men found hanged within  six months of each other today appealed for the Metropolitan police to take over  the case.
fields.body:
A solicitor representing the families of two black men found hanged within six months of each other today appealed for the Metropolitan police to take over the case.

Imran Khan said there was "no constitutional impediment" to prevent the Met's racial and violent crime task force removing responsibility from West Mercia police.

The families of doorman Harold "Errol" McGowan, 34, and his nephew Jason, 20, believe they were killed by a racist mob after an extensive period of racial harassment in Telford, Shropshire.

Outside Scotland Yard, where the family was due to meet the head of the task force, deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, Mr Khan said: "The family have lost all confidence in West Mercia Police." He appealed to the task force to take over the case "lock, stock and barrel".

He also called for "a proper, thorough, impartial" investigation and said the McGowan family had lodged two formal complaints against police.

The families of the dead men last month demanded the inquiry be passed from West Mercia police to the task force, a request rejected by the West Mercia chief constable Peter Hampton.

Mr Hampton, who earlier agreed to a joint re-investigation of both deaths, has said he has confidence in his own officers to conduct the new inquiry.

But the McGowan family, which was meeting home secretary Jack Straw at the House of Commons today, was urging West Mercia police formally to invite the task force to take over the investigation.

Harold McGowan's body was found hanging in a house in Telford last June. His nephew was found hanging from railings early on January 1.

webTitle: Exploding the myth of Desert Storm

fields.headline: Exploding the myth of Desert Storm
fields.standfirst: David O Russell's Three Kings is the first film to show the Gulf war as the messy, chaotic conflict it really was.  Andrew Pulver talks to an unlikely leader of Hollywood dissent
fields.trailText: Three Kings may not be the only movie about the Gulf war, but it can claim to be the first movie that tries to present Operation Desert Storm for what it was: an exercise in confused motivations, undecided objectives, and media-fuelled political paranoia.
fields.body:
Three Kings may not be the only movie about the Gulf war, but it can claim to be the first movie that tries to present Operation Desert Storm for what it was: an exercise in confused motivations, undecided objectives, and media-fuelled political paranoia. And since director David O Russell spent some $48m of Warner Bros's money bringing Three Kings into existence, it also has some claim to being the most anti-American studio movie of its generation.

At first sight, Russell cuts an unlikely figure as the standard-bearer of Hollywood agit-prop. Aside from Three Kings, he has two films to his name, Spanking the Monkey and Flirting with Disaster - both stand-up independent-movie success stories, but hardly indicative of a commitment to myth-demolishing film-making. He carries a reputation for being a difficult customer: a prickly interviewee; focused on-set to the point of being a browbeater; ostentatiously turning a video camera back on those hoping to inspect him and his movie.

In the flesh, however, Russell turns out to be simply the kind of person who thinks before he speaks, who's wary of being dragged into much-ploughed side-issues (such as the vociferous arguments he apparently got into with lead actor George Clooney). He's also the very model of concise expression when a point demands it.

This last quality, clearly, is what persuaded Warner Bros that Russell could hack it in the big leagues; besides, unlike practically every other major studio, Warner possesses no pseudo-independent feeder label that, like Miramax for Disney, tends to take care of maverick talent like Russell.

"When they welcomed me, I couldn't believe they would let me do anything ," he recalls. "You may remember Warner Bros had just had a terrible two years. They'd done all these franchise movies - Lethal Weapon 4 and Batman and Robin - and all their movies had a certain flavour to them. The New York Times business section ran a piece that encouraged them to step up and start using more independent film-makers. Three Kings is now perceived as a new archetype: an independent-minded studio picture. I think it's seen as a hybrid. It was way too big to be a boutique independent film; it's not exactly the paint-by-numbers commercial film; it's somewhere in the middle."

Three Kings is undoubtedly a unique proposition. Russell has harnessed all the slash-and-burn tropes of the modern war movie, creating expansive firefights, injecting pitch-black humour wherever feasible, and unleashing unambiguous disapproval of presidential foreign policy in the wake of Operation Desert Storm. Though Warners is still celebrated for its string of social-conscience movies in the Scarface: Shame of a Nation tradition, that was decades back, and studios these days hate to dabble in political hot water.

"The politics they never much debated," says Russell, of the greenlighting process. "They were very deferential about the script. There were very few notes, very little discussion. There are projects that are studio driven, and projects that are writer-director driven; and this was clearly perceived as the latter. I think they felt it was an Oliver Stone movie - not literally , but that category. Or Scorsese. When I first set out to write it, I said, don't let me come back with a script and have it freak you out. I told them right up front what my intentions were. They said, no - we're not afraid of that, we've made films with these other guys before."

As it happens, the political content of Three Kings is perfectly in keeping with Russell's pre- film-making career. A literature and political-science student in the early 80s, Russell spent four months teaching in Nicaragua as the Contra insurgency gathered steam. Back in the US, he continued working with immigrants, before turning to documentary-making at the Smithsonian institute.

Russell isn't a firebrand, exactly; just an astute observer of American society in action. "I think the war smelled a little funny to people at the time, and they'd just as soon not think about it. And that's why, when people see the movie, it hasn't created an uproar. I think it affirms what they feel in their guts, but just haven't wanted to deal with before. People felt it wasn't all that it was presented; there was something messy about it."

Russell went about researching the Gulf war meticulously, soaking himself in the plentiful documentary material from this most media-infiltrated of conflicts. The complex torture techniques Three Kings shows were drawn from actual photographs and the testimony of US and British prisoners of war. At one point, he even contemplated crossing over into Iraq itself. "I had a businessman friend from Kuwait, who was going to help me go in. Everyone said, you shouldn't do that; which made it all the more exciting to me. And then they started bombing again..."

Three Kings, Russell says, originated with "a very two-dimensional" Desert Storm-heist script that Warner Bros already owned, called Spoils of War. It was written by John Ridley, whose manuscript novel Stray Dogs had already been through Oliver Stone's mill, emerging as U Turn. Ridley soon turned sore, accusing Russell in the entertainment press of trying to "grab credit", and blocking the book publication of the screenplay.

Ridley eventually got his "story by" credit, but Russell faced more difficulties even before the production got off the ground. "There was one guy who was pretty high up at the studio," he says, "who was, like, on a par with the chairman, but on the business side; and he was trying to cross over to the creative side. And when my head of production Lorenzo di Bonaventura, who was the champion of the production, was out of town on vacation for a week, he tried to get the plug pulled. He tried to convince Clooney to drop out, saying that the controversy, nationally and internationally, would mean trouble. Clooney, to his credit said, I don't believe you; so the whole coup attempt failed. Clooney at that point was pay-or-play, so the only way to pull the plug was to get the main pay-or-play guy to pull back."

And there were well- documented troubles on the shoot, too. The studio shaved $10m off the budget Russell had requested, resulting in a schedule truncated by 12 days. The pressure got to the whole crew, with Clooney and his director facing off towards the end of their arduous stint in the desert - Arizona, as it happens, rather than the Middle East. Clooney, who swept into London last week to support the film, remains outspoken in his praise for Russell's talent. "We had about three good screaming matches. Never a fist-fight. We had some good arguments. It was a much bigger film than David had ever been involved in, and we were having to trust that. I was in over my head too.

"David is really brilliant at this. His idea was to resensitise people to violence. He didn't just want to show the effect of the gunshot, he wanted to show it literally. He used to say to us: 'every bullet counts'. He said that every day."

For his part, Russell remains grateful to Clooney - a real Hollywood liberal, if ever there was one - for sticking his neck out for the project. "Yeah," he says. "No movie star, no budget. I was actually talking to Nic Cage at first, but he ended up doing the Scorsese movie Bringing out the Dead. Clooney was very aggressive about pursuing it; but at the time I thought of Clooney as being more of a romantic leading man. After meeting him, I was persuaded that he really got the whole thing, and had the deadpan sensibility for it. Also he has, I think, a grizzled maturity that Brad Pitt or Tom Cruise or even Cage don't exactly have."

"The main proposition," says Russell, with finality, "is to have a cinematic experience that grabs you and doesn't let go of you until the end, and constantly surprises you. And then at the end you realise - jeez, there was this historical-political exposé along the way. You want to put people in spin cycle. Because if it doesn't work at that level, then you've made a boring film."

The Gulf war in the movies

* Courage Under Fire

Rashomon-style take on a military action in the Gulf, with Lieut Col Denzel Washington investigating dead captain Meg Ryan's heroic (or otherwise) record.

* The Big Lebowski

"This aggression will not stand"; the Gulf war lurks in the background of the Coen brothers' bowling noir. Saddam Hussein turns up as a shoe cleaner; the actor who plays him, Jerry Haleva, also impersonated Saddam in Hot Shots! and Jane Austen's Mafia.

* South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut

Saddam Hussein turns out to be Satan's cruel loverboy - "Is sex the only thing that matters to you?"

* Bravo Two Zero

TV movie adapted from Sgt Andy McNab's best-selling account of the SAS's legendary operation behind enemy lines during Desert Storm. Sean Bean leads the patrol down "Scud alley" in a mission to take out Saddam's missiles.

The complex torture techniques Three Kings shows were drawn from actual photographs and the testimony of US and British prisoners of war. At one point, he even contemplated crossing over into Iraq itself. "I had a businessman friend from Kuwait, who was going to help me go in. Everyone said, you shouldn't do that; which made it all the more exciting to me. And then they started bombing again..." Three Kings, Russell says, originated with "a very two-dimensional" Desert Storm-heist script that Warner Bros already owned, called Spoils of War. It was written by John Ridley, whose manuscript novel Stray Dogs had already been through Oliver Stone's mill, emerging as U Turn. Ridley soon turned sore, accusing Russell in the entertainment press of trying to "grab credit", and blocking the book publication of the screenplay. Ridley eventually got his "story by" credit, but Russell faced more difficulties even before the production got off the ground. "There was one guy who was pretty high up at the studio," he says, "who was, like, on a par with the chairman, but on the business side; and he was trying to cross over to the creative side. And when my head of production Lorenzo di Bonaventura, who was the champion of the production, was out of town on vacation for a week, he tried to get the plug pulled. He tried to convince Clooney to drop out, saying that the controversy, nationally and internationally, would mean trouble. Clooney, to his credit said, I don't believe you; so the whole coup attempt failed. Clooney at that point was pay-or-play, so the only way to pull the plug was to get the main pay-or-play guy to pull back." And there were well- documented troubles on the shoot, too. The studio shaved $10m off the budget Russell had requested, resulting in a schedule truncated by 12 days. The pressure got to the whole crew, with Clooney and his director facing off towards the end of their arduous stint in the desert - Arizona, as it happens, rather than the Middle East. Clooney, who swept into London last week to support the film, remains outspoken in his praise for Russell's talent. "We had about three good screaming matches. Never a fist-fight. We had some good arguments. It was a much bigger film than David had ever been involved in, and we were having to trust that. I was in over my head too. "David is really brilliant at this. His idea was to resensitise people to violence. He didn't just want to show the effect of the gunshot, he wanted to show it literally. He used to say to us: 'every bullet counts'. He said that every day." For his part, Russell remains grateful to Clooney - a real Hollywood liberal, if ever there was one - for sticking his neck out for the project. "Yeah," he says. "No movie star, no budget. I was actually talking to Nic Cage at first, but he ended up doing the Scorsese movie Bringing out the Dead. Clooney was very aggressive about pursuing it; but at the time I thought of Clooney as being more of a romantic leading man. After meeting him, I was persuaded that he really got the whole thing, and had the deadpan sensibility for it. Also he has, I think, a grizzled maturity that Brad Pitt or Tom Cruise or even Cage don't exactly have." "The main proposition," says Russell, with finality, "is to have a cinematic experience that grabs you and doesn't let go of you until the end, and constantly surprises you. And then at the end you realise - jeez, there was this historical-political exposé along the way. You want to put people in spin cycle. Because if it doesn't work at that level, then you've made a boring film." The Gulf war in the movies * Courage Under Fire Rashomon-style take on a military action in the Gulf, with Lieut Col Denzel Washington investigating dead captain Meg Ryan's heroic (or otherwise) record. * The Big Lebowski "This aggression will not stand"; the Gulf war lurks in the background of the Coen brothers' bowling noir. Saddam Hussein turns up as a shoe cleaner; the actor who plays him, Jerry Haleva, also impersonated Saddam in Hot Shots! and Jane Austen's Mafia. * South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut Saddam Hussein turns out to be Satan's cruel loverboy - "Is sex the only thing that matters to you?" * Bravo Two Zero TV movie adapted from Sgt Andy McNab's best-selling account of the SAS's legendary operation behind enemy lines during Desert Storm. Sean Bean leads the patrol down "Scud alley" in a mission to take out Saddam's missiles.

webTitle: Wainewright the Poisoner by Andrew Motion

fields.headline: Wainewright the Poisoner by Andrew Motion
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss on the critical reaction to Andrew Motion's biography of painter-poet-poisoner Wainewright
Buy Wainewright the Poisoner at BOL
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss on the critical reaction to Andrew Motion's biography of painter-poet-poisoner Wainewright
fields.body:
Andrew Motion's Wainewright the Poisoner (Faber, £20) was, all the critics agreed, a brilliant idea for a book - a biography of a painter-poet-poisoner who represented the dark, selfish, anarchic side of the Romantic movement. Where they disagreed was in deciding whether the book actually worked (whatever that means). The words "honourable failure" played on many lips, but in the overcrowded world of literary biography that may be preferable to tedious success.

John Carey, in the Sunday Times, was Motion's chief supporter. "Brilliantly innovative, gripping, intricately researched, Motion's biography does justice to its subject at last," trilled Carey (that will sit happily on the paperback). Carey's analysis was itself rather brilliant, since it explored the cultural issue which makes writing about Wainewright worth while - the notion of the artist as criminal, the issue which had attracted the attention of Wainewright apologist Oscar Wilde.

"For champions of orthodoxy," wrote Carey, "it was imperative to denigrate Wainewright's work as foppish and unhealthy, otherwise it might appear that good art and immorality could be compatible. Wilde, on the other hand, cited him specifically to prove that "there is no essential incongruity between crime and culture". This is a tricky issue for Andrew Motion. By accepting the job of Poet Laureate (murderers need not apply) he might seem to have committed himself to an institutional, social-service view of culture. So presumably he should reject Wilde's thesis. In the book he hedges his bets, telling the story twice, first with Wainewright innocent, then with Wainewright guilty."

"The first version is a memoir, ostensibly by Wainewright himself, imitating his showy, dreamy Romantic prose, and indignantly rebutting the slanders heaped on him by ignorance, malice and defaulting life-insurers. The second version, supplied in Motion's notes to each chapter, records suspicious circumstances that the memoir omits. The verdict of the notes is that Wainewright was almost certainly both a ruthless murderer and an outstanding painter and critic - far ahead of his time, for example, in his appreciation of Blake and Keats."

Motion called his book an "experimental biography" - a memoir purporting to be by Wainewright himself. The experiment intrigued but on the whole failed to convince. The attractions of Wainewright as a biographical subject are clear, explained D J Taylor in the Guardian. "There is the irresistibly seductive vision of the Romantic extremist, plunging Byronically through a world of strychnine and high aesthetics; there are the tantalising byways populated by all manner of contemporary curios such as the artists Henry Fuseli and Theodore von Holst, the latter responsible for some highly graphic erotica. And above all there is the beguiling sense of a blank canvas - writing a life of which so little is known that a satisfyingly large amount can be inferred gives the biographer an importance which is not allowed him in those lives already commemorated by a dozen fat volumes of letters. This is Motion's lure and his justification, but it is also his dilemma, and one which, despite all manner of graceful flourishes and a huge amount of lightly worn learning, I don't think he comes anywhere near to solving."

"Though Wainewright the Poisoner is neatly done and crammed with beguiling detail, to read these accounts of seedy continental exile and the indignities of his final years in Tasmania (Wainewright had expected a light sentence in return for admitting to two minor fraud charges, but was grievously disappointed) is to hear a constant undertow of ghost voices, a sense of what the material would have made as a novel by Peter Ackroyd or AS Byatt rather than an "experimental biography" by the Poet Laureate. This is not an insult." Oh, yes it is.

Charles Saumarez Smith, in the Observer, also imagined what Ackroyd might have made of it. "In the end," he concluded, "[Motion's] book is clever, but not compelling, a brave attempt to re-invent the life and attitudes of an intriguing historical figure, but a book which falls between the different literary requirements of fiction and of history."

Hilary Spurling, in the Daily Telegraph, broadened the argument to make a point about the essential incompatibility of the two genres: "The result is interesting but not wholly successful, because the art of biography consists precisely in animating the subject within his or her historical context. All true biographies (including Motion's own of Keats and Larkin) breathe life into accumulated factual research by an act of emotional and imaginative possession for which ventriloquism proves an inadequate substitute."

Jonathan Bate (the Poet Laureate certainly brought out the heavyweights), writing in the Independent, thought Motion was trying to have it both ways: "The book is a broken-backed compromise. It exposes something Janus-like about our Poet Laureate. Wildean Motion delights in playing at being Wainewright. But Larkinian Motion - to name him after the authorised biography with which he made his reputation - refuses to let go of convention. So it is that Wainewright's imaginary confession is peppered with little numerals in square brackets, referring to the extensive notes at the end of each chapter in which the true facts of the case are carefully enumerated. The strange result of the Janus-effect is that Motion has produced a book which precisely reverses the normal process - whereby the reader lingers over the main text and skips through the notes. Here, it is the notes that are much the most interesting part ... We are left with a conundrum. Does the victory of the fact over the fiction represent a win on points for Larkinian Motion, or is the creation of (what shall we call it?) the superior footnote an innovation of Wildean artfulness?"

Either way, honourable failure seems a drab description for a book that can pose so many questions about crime and culture, art and life, fiction and truth.

fields.headline: Out now: the millennium edition
fields.standfirst: A glimpse of what the 137th and biggest Almanack so far has to offer. Click here to read Mark Lawson's review of the 2000 edition
fields.trailText:
Five Cricketers of the Century
The worldwide Wisden panel makes its selection
fields.body:
Five Cricketers of the Century
The worldwide Wisden panel makes its selection

Summers of the Century
Philip Eden and Frank Keating bask in the memory

Matches of the Century
A hundred games that should be cherished forever

Images of the Century
Patrick Eagar selects the top cricket pictures

A Century of Notes
Tim Rice and EW Swanton on an enduring tradition

Free Paperback Book
A Century of Wisden: a gem from each of the past 100 Almanacks

Wisden 2000 is a very special volume. The Almanack that has covered every aspect of 20th-century cricket reviews 100 years when the game changed beyond recognition.

As well as the customary Five Cricketers of the Year, this Wisden names Five Cricketers of the Century, chosen by a panel of 100 players and others whose expertise spans the globe and the generations. The verdict was clear-cut. The selections will delight many cricket-lovers, perhaps infuriate others.

The section on the 20th century includes a host of other goodies. There are two alternative choices as Summer of the Century. Using scientific formulae, weatherman Philip Eden picks one. Using unscientific memory, Frank Keating comes up with a very different answer.

Patrick Eagar, cricket's leading photographer, chooses a picture from every decade to illustrate a changing game and a changing profession. Stephen Moss assesses a century of cricket books, not all of them worth taking to a desert island. Steven Lynch picks out 100 cricket matches, every one indispensable and unforgettable.

Wisden 2000 is also the 100th edition since Sydney Pardon, the Almanack's greatest editor, started the grand tradition of Notes by the Editor, the game's famous annual sermon. Tim Rice looks back on a century of (mostly) wise comment. EW Swanton, who met Pardon and all his successors, discusses the men behind the words in an article written a month before his death in January.

All of this is in addition to the customary coverage of the year gone by: the year Australia won the World Cup, and when England - for a time - went bottom of the world. Wisden tells the stories, in words and pictures. It was the last (muted) hurrah for the old-style County Championship. Reporting on a glorious late summer's day at Taunton, Patrick Collins believes the much-maligned old game can still be idyllic. It was the year the British public had to get used to cricket coverage without the BBC; Marcus Berkmann gives his acerbic viewpoint. And Peter Tinniswood, creator of the Brigadier, harrumphs engagingly about the state of cricket literature.

It was a sad time too: the game lost some of its most famous sons: Lord Cowdrey fondly recalls his old team-mate Godfrey Evans, while Mark Nicholas pays tribute to Malcolm Marshall. Swanton, the man who chronicled more of the century's cricket than anyone else, is remembered by his friend John Woodcock. Australian Test captain Mark Taylor retired: Scyld Berry asks whether he is the greatest leader of all.

Then of course Wisden reports on the really important news of the year: how video umpiring came to the under-12s; how terrible teas stopped play in Devon; how a Gloucestershire mum earned her son a century; and on the Test match between Russia and Germany - played on Shetland. There is a special report from the country with the roughest, toughest cricket in the world. You'd never guess...

Wisden has been an essential companion for cricket-lovers since 1864. The Millennium Edition will, more than ever, be one to treasure - for the next thousand years at least.

Click here for a biography of the editor, Matthew Engel

fields.trailText: Education Unlimited is launching a competition to find the best warmer activities in the TEFL classroom.
fields.body:
Education Unlimited is launching a competition to find the best warmer activities in the TEFL classroom.

Send us a brief description of your favourite warmer activity, and whether it's suitable for a particular level or age group. The winner will be judged by EFL expert Mario Rinvolucri of Pilgrims and will receive a free copy of one of the Pilgrims Longman resource series, The Recipe Book, which is edited by Seth Lindstromberg. It contains original ideas for over 77 activities, including warmers, fillers, role plays, vocabulary practice, visuals and one-to-one teaching.

The winner and a selection of the best entries will be published on Education Unlimited.

The closing date has been extended to 28 March and the winner will be announced at the beginning of April. Send your entries to educationunlimited@theguardian.com.
