fields.headline: Abdication secrets remain sealed until 2037
fields.trailText: Crucial letters expected to cast light on the Queen Mother's attitude towards the biggest royal crisis of the 20th century were withdrawn at the last minute from a collection of official papers thrown open today.
fields.body:
Crucial letters expected to cast light on the Queen Mother's attitude towards the biggest royal crisis of the 20th century were withdrawn at the last minute from a collection of official papers thrown open today.

Scholars and journalists gathered at the Bodleain library, Oxford to begin reading 11 boxes of papers left by the former royal confidant and government minister Sir Walter Monckton. But they discovered that one box is being held back and will remain sealed until 2037.

Earlier this week the historian Andrew Roberts forecast that the archive would reveal the true extent of the Queen Mother's involvement in the feud between the Duke of Windsor, who abdicated from the throne in 1936, and her husband, who became King George V1 in his stead.

Mr Roberts said the papers could also at last solve the enduring controversy over how deeply the duke sympathised with fascism. But today Mr Roberts said: "It would appear that the crown jewels are missing from this collection."

The Oxford constitutional expert Vernon Bogdanor said the papers disclosed today contained no spectacular revelations. "This is part of history and part of the British constitution," he said. "But it is also a personal family matter and a personal family wound. I don't believe the royal family want that wound constantly exposed."

One document was a telegram from the Queen Mother's brother-in-law, the late Duke of Windsor, to Adolf Hitler just before the second world war broke out, Prof Bogdanor said. Hitler replied by saying peace depended on England, not Germany. There was no evidence in the files of any "treasonable" activity by the duke.

"The archive shows there was no responsibility to remove the king from the throne. It was inevitable from the start. It shows the king was determined to act constitutionally throughout," he said.

Oxford university said the box was being kept closed in line with public record office policy. However, "all but a small number of papers" were being made available for research.

Mr Roberts said it appeared that one or two letters from the Queen Mother to Sir Walter had been weeded out of some of the boxes made available today.

He said one of the letters from the then queen to Sir Walter in August 1940 may have thrown light on the feud between Buckingham Palace and the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. He said the letter related to the arrival of the Duke and Duchess in the Bahamas where the former king was to become governor.

"This letter could be terribly exciting and a real insight into the extent of the personal feud between the then Queen and the Windsors. By the time that the Duke of Windsor was on his way to the Bahamas it became evident that there were people at the palace, though we do not know whom, who were trying to ensure that the Duchess did not get royal treatment," he said.

"This letter may have told us something about this."

By the time that the Duke of Windsor was on his way to the Bahamas it became evident that there were people at the palace, though we do not know whom, who were trying to ensure that the Duchess did not get royal treatment," he said. "This letter may have told us something about this."

fields.trailText: Paying the Price - The Killing of the Children is John Pilger's report on the shocking realities of everyday life in Iraq.
fields.body:
Paying the Price - The Killing of the Children is John Pilger's report on the shocking realities of everyday life in Iraq.

Many thousands have starved to death in Iraq under Saddam Hussain since the end of the Gulf war. But, as Pilger graphically shows, the West must also bear responsibility for this great untold tragedy. The allies' sanctions against Iraq have impoverished its people and, in some cases, directly prevented aid reaching the needy and desperate.

We have five pairs of tickets for the special preview at the National Film Theatre in London at 6.30pm on Friday 3 March. Both John Pilger and Denis Halliday, the former assistant secretary general of the United Nations, who resigned his position in protest against sanctions, will be present at the screening.

Winners will be notified by email by 3pm that day, and tickets must be picked up from the NFT box office half an hour before the event. And even if you do not win, you can still read more in Weekend Guardian on Saturday March 4.

fields.headline: China's cradle of health
fields.standfirst: Aid workers battle to reverse decline in infant medical care in rural heartlands
fields.trailText: Aid workers battle to reverse decline in infant medical care in rural heartlands
fields.byline: John Gittings  in Zongyang county, Anhui province
fields.body:
Zhang Meifeng looks out from under the blankets of her bed in an icy rural hospital in central China, and lists the benefits of breast-feeding.

"It's more nutritious," she says. "It saves money because we don't buy milk powder; it protects against disease, and it helps mothers and babies to feel affection."

Her son was born the previous day in hospital in Zongyang county, Anhui province, just north of the Yangzi river.

Zongyang is one of China's poorer counties in one of its most deprived provinces, and the hospital facilities are basic. The delivery room bed consists of an iron frame with most of its paint chipped off, and a heavily stained rubber sheet.

But the ideas expressed by Ms Zhang are quite new. They have been inspired by the maternal and child health (MCH) project. The programme, which is now in its second term, is sponsored by Unicef and run by the ministry of health.

Breast-feeding was almost universal 40 years ago, but since then it has suffered a sharp decline. Unicef blames "the perception that bottle feeding is more scientific and modern, [and the] aggressive marketing practices of infant formula manufacturers".

The dangers to hygiene introduced by bottle-feeding may be decades old, but other causes of infant illness and mortality are more deeply rooted. The problems caused by poor sanitation are being tackled through a separate Unicef-sponsored campaign, targeted, like the MCH project, at selected counties across China.

"Before we just had an open pit," says Wei Bing, a carpenter in Hangnan village. "There were lots of flies, and sometimes the old people fell in it."

His new ceramic pan is in a clean, whitewashed shed. Behind it, concrete lids cover the compartments where the excreta turns into fertiliser.

"We just cover the pan with a lid and pour some water down each time to help it ferment," he explains.

But some habits are hard to change. In another house the new latrine stands empty beside the old one, which is filled with fresh excrement.

A mortified health worker asks for an explanation. "We were busy at [Chinese] new year and it's too much bother to put the water down each time," she is told.

Despite this lapse, the scale of public education is impressive, particularly in a society dominated by the new market economy values.

Every new mother in the designated areas gets a Unicef-MCH leaflet which explains how to rehydrate a child with diarrhoea and gives advice on everything from washing hands before meals to Aids.

A pamphlet for local medical workers on health education is illustrated by cartoons.

The projects seek to reverse a decline in grassroots medical care since a high point reached in the early decades of Maoist rule. A Unicef publication says unequivocally that "the MCH network was greatly weakened after the people's communes were abolished [in the early 1980s]".

When the communes had gone, many medical insurance schemes funded by the collective system collapsed, and some local medical workers had to support themselves instead by charging patients.

Today's peasants must pay most of the fees for childbirth. A simple birth in a township hospital with cracked tiles and unheated wards will typically cost 400 renminbi (£30) - 15-20% of many annual rural incomes. A birth in the county hospital, with better hygiene and heating, costs twice as much.

Some insurance schemes have either survived or have been restored in Anhui, but the extent of benefits varies widely.

The clinic in Great Hill village in Zongyang, which is well funded, employs two doctors - including one trained as a "barefoot doctor" in the cultural revolution.

A competent medical assistant does post-natal check-ups and child monitoring, and hands out leaflets on breast-feeding. Growth charts show that none of the village's children are under-sized.

Great Hill has spent less on building new houses and more on infrastructure for the collective good. Running water is piped from the hills and pumped through the village at fixed times of day.

Officials in Ningguo county which is also in Anhui province, claim that 80% of their townships have medical schemes but these are far from comprehensive.

The hospital scheme in Zhongxi township gets one quarter of its income from the local villages. The rest comes from money provided by a foreign-funded local factory to insure its workforce.

The fund will pay a maximum of 10,000 renminbi (£760) if a worker has a major operation - but only up to 1,000 renminbi for a peasant.

Much progress has clearly been made in rural health in the last decade, at least in those trial areas, and, with a life expectancy of 71 and countrywide provision of basic services, China compares favourably with many other large developing countries.

It is "a good place to come for those looking for examples of what can be done", Unicef's regional director, Kul Gautam, has said.

On the negative side is a rigid bureaucratic structure which separates services that should be under one roof.

In addition, unless local party cadres can be persuaded to back the health campaigns, these will get nowhere.

"We are fortunate to have enthusiastic cadres here," says a doctor in Zongyang. "Because under our system, everything still depends on renzhi - rule by man, not fazhi - rule by law."

It could be an apt comment on the health of the Chinese nation as well as the health of its children.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: The Harry Potter mystery thickens, Lord of the Rings footage screened in LA, Lock, Stock - the TV series, and, on the casting couch, Geena Davis's thinks mice are nice
fields.body:
Since Steven Spielberg jumped the Harry Potter ship, the matter of bringing the children's cult classic to the screen has been moving quickly. Steve Kloves has finished the first draft of the screenplay, which has been sent to 10 A-list directors, including Peter Weir, Rob Reiner, and Jonathan Demme, who now have to take part in what Hollywood calls a 'creative bake-off'. Each director has to pitch his vision of the young wizard and his bewitching exploits to Warner Bros executives and the film's producer, David Heyman, who are apparently considering shooting the first two Potter stories back to back with the same director helming both.

The first completed footage of Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy has been screened in Los Angeles. The New Zealand Herald reports that the six-minute showreel, which was shown to American and Kiwi VIPs, featured "dark, hooded figures against magnificent New Zealand landscapes, some of the 20,000 extras and computer clones in battle scenes, a quaint rustic Middle Earth village, artists' drawings that inspired the production design, and the stars - Sir Ian McKellen, Cate Blanchett, Liv Tyler, Christopher Lee - in costume". A seven-part TV series based on hit film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels is currently in production. The story will focus on The Lock, a London pub run by a group of wheeler-dealers who get involved in all sorts of shady scams. None of the original cast will star in the series, and director Guy Ritchie is serving only in an executive producer capacity.

Casting couch

Geena Davis will reprise her role in the sequel to Stuart Little, last year's surprise US hit about a talking mouse who is adopted by a human couple. It is not clear whether co-star Laurie, or Michael J. Fox, who voiced the animated mouse, will join Davis.

webTitle: The government's road safety strategy: text of Tony Blair's speech

fields.headline: The government's road safety strategy: text of Tony Blair's speech
fields.trailText:
Each year around 3,500 people are killed on our roads and 40,000 are seriously injured. In total,
                    there are over 300,000 road casualties every year. That is an enormous toll of lives shattered, hearts
                    broken.
fields.body:
Each year around 3,500 people are killed on our roads and 40,000 are seriously injured. In total, there are over 300,000 road casualties every year. That is an enormous toll of lives shattered, hearts broken.

I have received countless letters from parents, brothers, sisters, friends of those killed and injured on our roads. Every one tells of a family devastated, lives blighted, of pain, sorrow and anger and the waste of it. And every one is painful to read.

Just before last Christmas I met a delegation of children, parents and campaigners to talk about road safety. Many had travelled a considerable distance to tell me why they thought we should make road safety, and particularly child safety, a priority.

I was very moved by their experiences and their commitment. And I promised that we would take action.

Which is not to say we have a bad record on road safety. Britain has had remarkable success in reducing road casualties and we now have one of the best records in Europe, and indeed the world.

But a good record isn't enough.

That is why we have announced demanding new targets for reductions in the number of people killed and seriously injured on our roads.

And a particularly ambitious target for children.

By 2010 we will aim to have achieved:

* a further 50% reduction in the numbers of children killed or seriously injured;

* a further 40% overall reduction in the numbers of people killed or seriously injured in road accidents; and

* a further 10% reduction in the slight casualty rate.

Although our overall record for child safety is relatively good, our child pedestrian record is poor in comparison.

Last year, 103 children were killed as pedestrians on our roads - 103 too many.

This is why we are setting a specific, much tougher target for children killed or seriously injured in road accidents.

And drivers are far more likely to kill if they are travelling at speed.

We will expect local authorities to take action to control speeds in areas where children are most vulnerable, particularly around schools.

Our strategy is to target the problem and take effective action to deal with it. So:

* we will ensure all local authorities conduct a child safety audit. I expect local authorities to introduce many more traffic-calmed 20mph zones, as a result, focussed on schools, on where people live and on children's routes to school;

* we will improve the way we educate our children to be safer when using the road. It is not only about drivers taking care, or slower speeds, it is also about helping children and others to understand better the risks they face and how to deal with them;

* and we will do more to target those who are particularly vulnerable - children in deprived areas, and children changing from primary to secondary school.

Much has been said about speeds and speed limits. Research shows us that speed, more than anything else, is what is killing people. So controlling speed is at the heart of our strategy.

When you realise that 85% of pedestrians hit at 40mph will die, compared to 45% at 30mph and 5% at 20mph. Speed kills just as effectively as drink driving. These are impressive and telling figures.

Speed can make the difference between life and death.

Speed limits are there for a specific purpose.

With local authorities, we will take a long hard look at how we design roads and at the limits we set.

To check that local authorities get speed limits right, we will provide detailed guidance.

And we will take tough new steps to enforce speed limits and discourage dangerous driving, with tougher penalties set out in the major new review the Home Office is carrying out with the DETR.

Our new strategy is a key element in our drive to improve transport safety generally. It has my very strong personal support. I believe it is possible to achieve the new casualty reduction targets. There is no doubt that measures taken in the last few years have had an effect. Our strategy will focus especially on speed. By working in partnership we can make a difference. With your help Britain can be a safer and more civilised place for everyone.

webTitle: Government accused of 'wimping out' on road safety

fields.headline: Government accused of 'wimping out' on road safety
fields.trailText: Drink-driving and speeding will incur tougher penalties under the government's new road safety strategy launched today.
fields.body:
Drink-driving and speeding will incur tougher penalties under the government's new road safety strategy launched today.

The joint home office and transport department project will review all penalties for motoring offences and look at bringing in re-testing for serious driving offences. The government has also set ambitious targets to reduce child deaths and serious injuries on the road by 50% by 2010 and pledged to introduce more 20mph zones near schools.

But the proposals were met with dismay by road safety and transport pressure groups, with environmental group Transport 2000 accusing the government of "wimping out" of imposing more stringent speed limits.

Another safety group, RoadPeace, said Mr Blair had "caved in to the interests of the motoring lobby" in not replacing the 30mph limit with a 20mph limit in built-up areas, while Ben Plowden, director of the Pedestrians Association, said: "The question of speed limits is too important to be left to local authorities."

Helping launch the strategy today, prime minister Tony Blair said: "We have the second best safety record in Europe, but the fact that 15 children are killed or seriously injured on our roads every day is simply unacceptable."

He added: "We will target accident hotspots around schools, improve driver training and how we teach our children about safety on roads. Our 50% child casualty reduction target is a tough one. It will take a huge effort to meet it, but I believe we can."

Local authorities are being required to plan specific measures to cut child deaths and injuries as part of their local transport plans.

Total money available for these plans is to be raised from £755m in 2000-01 to £1bn in 2001-02.

The government also said it would:

 Look at possible changes to the practical driving test;
 Consult on introducing compulsory probationary P-plates for novice drivers;
 Possibly introduce specific legislation against mobile phone use while driving;
 Wait for European Commission regulations on any lowering of the legal drink-drive limit;
 Continue to support research into coach and lorry-style speed limiters in cars but this was "not an option in the medium term";
 Consider how the courts might be able to send convicted road traffic offenders on retraining courses.

Drink-drive offenders who could be at risk of an automatic two-year ban would be:
 Those found to have alcohol-blood readings of at least 200mg - the legal limit being 80mg;
 Those who re-offend against drink-drive laws within 10 years of the previous offence;
 Those who refuse to give a breath test.

webTitle: American Psycho available uncut on the internet

fields.headline: American Psycho available uncut on the internet
fields.trailText: Its makers have axed its most controversial scene to gain an R rating, but purists can see the offending material on the internet as part of a promotional campaign
fields.body:
As we reported yesterday, American Psycho's makers have axed sections from the film's most controversial scene - a three-way sex act between Patrick Bateman, (Christian Bale) and two prostitutes - in order to appease the US censors. However, purists will still able to see the offending material in a month-long promotional campaign.

Lions Gate Films and Pseudo.Com are to stream outtakes and other footage which didn't make the final print, as part of its continuation of the novel created especially for the internet. Supervised by the author, Bret Easton Ellis, the epilogues are to take the form of emails from 'Patrick Bateman', and will be released as a 'serial sequel' on different dates, starting from March 15.

The censored scenes are not live yet, but you can sign up today for your 'Pseudo Psycho' at pseudo.com

webTitle: British shoppers 'worry over clothes but not food'

fields.headline: British shoppers 'worry over clothes but not food'
fields.trailText: British shoppers are unperturbed about the food they eat but conscious of where their clothes come from.
fields.body:
British shoppers are unperturbed about the food they eat but conscious of where their clothes come from.

In contrast to the average European, they don't mind buying frozen or factory-farmed food, and are less exercised by issues of organic and genetically modified produce.

The average Briton's shopping foibles are laid bare today in a survey of the shopping habits of some 7,000 Europeans. The research, for the international real estate consultant Healey & Baker, was based on telephone interviews in Britain, Germany, Spain, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Poland, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Hungary and Sweden.

The results showed that 57% of Britons would try to buy British, as against the average 67% who would choose their country's products; and 56% would fail to check a product's country of origin, compared with the average 46%.

Forty-three per cent would avoid factory-farmed produce, compared with 50% Europe-wide. And 63% of Britons would avoid GM foods, as against the average 65%.

Only 70% of the British would prefer fresh to frozen foods, in contrast to 80% across Europe, and when it came to clothes shopping 40% preferred brand name goods, as against the average 25%.

The research, for the international real estate consultant Healey & Baker, was based on telephone interviews in Britain, Germany, Spain, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Poland, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Hungary and Sweden. The results showed that 57% of Britons would try to buy British, as against the average 67% who would choose their country's products; and 56% would fail to check a product's country of origin, compared with the average 46%. Forty-three per cent would avoid factory-farmed produce, compared with 50% Europe-wide. And 63% of Britons would avoid GM foods, as against the average 65%. Only 70% of the British would prefer fresh to frozen foods, in contrast to 80% across Europe, and when it came to clothes shopping 40% preferred brand name goods, as against the average 25%.

fields.headline: Oscar-nominated Caine is odds-on favourite
fields.trailText: With under four weeks to go, speculation about this year's Oscar winners is hotting up. At the centre of the current hype is Michael Caine.
fields.body:
With under four weeks to go, speculation about this year's Oscar winners is hotting up. At the centre of the current hype is Michael Caine.

In Monday's issue, the New York Post claimed that the world's most famous cockney is 2-1 favourite to scoop the Best Supporting Actor award for his role of the kindly doctor in Cider House Rules.

But the actor, who faces stiff competition from local boy Tom Cruise, (odds of 4-1), is not getting his hopes up. In an interview with GMTV, the actor said he was delighted to be nominated, but had not prepared a speech.

 Cider House Rules opens in the UK on 17 March. "I see people go up there and get a piece of paper and I think, 'Jesus, you must be confident!' I have no speech ready."

The veteran actor has been nominated four times before, and won the award in 1986 for his portrayal of a cheating husband in Woody Allen's Hannah and Her Sisters.

This year he faces tough opposition, not just from Cruise, but also from newcomers Michael Clarke Duncan, Jude Law, and Sixth Sense's Haley Joel Osment.

webTitle: Mixed messages Galliano parades his three style skills

fields.headline: Mixed messages Galliano parades his three style skills
fields.trailText: Not even the most seasoned fashion observer would dare predict what direction the British designer John Galliano would take next.
fields.body:
Not even the most seasoned fashion observer would dare predict what direction the British designer John Galliano would take next.

His sources of inspiration have ranged from Napoleon and Josephine to the character of Blanche Dubois in A Streetcar Named Desire.

Still, his collection yesterday for the House of Christian Dior was one of his most ambitious yet. This show was really three collections in one.

The first part of the show, with a soundtrack that included That's Why The Lady Is A Tramp and Kelis singing I Hate You So Much Right Now, was deliberately decadent: this was Missy Elliot dressed for a date with Al Capone.

There were ostentatious fur coats worn over leather dresses with gold DIOR necklaces, trilbies and trenchcoats in crocodile and ostrich, leopard-print mini-dresses and bleach-splashed, cropped denim jackets, all accessorised with versions of last season's successful kidney-shaped "saddle" bag.

The second part of the show put newsprint from the imaginary "Christian Dior Daily" on to silk dresses and stiff coats mixed with peach lace and sheer net. The dresses - bias-cut with sweeping ruffles - were perfect examples of Galliano's artistry.

In the final section of the show came elegant evening gowns in chiffon and leather. Despite the size of the collection, every detail down to the diamante soles of the shoes was pure theatre.

The House of Dior is one of the most venerable names in fashion. It was founded by Christian Dior, who stunned the world in 1947 with his first collection: a full-skirted silhouette which was dubbed the New Look. Galliano is the latest in an impressive line of designers to have succeeded Dior. Yves Saint Laurent and Gianfranco Ferre have both held the post.

Since an acclaimed first collection for Dior, Galliano's four-year reign has not been trouble free. However this brash, flash, collection for spring/summer 2000 has already brought about a renaissance for the CD monogram.

fields.headline: In the field: Japan
fields.standfirst: EFL teachers in Japan offer advice
fields.trailText: 8-hour workdays are common among the big conversation schools. These schools can open from 9am to 9pm so some teachers work from 9 to 5 and others from 1 to 9. Figure in at least an hour for commuting and it all adds to a long day. All teachers get 2 days off but very rarely are they on the weekend since Saturday and Sunday is when most students take lessons.
fields.body:
8-hour workdays are common among the big conversation schools. These schools can open from 9am to 9pm so some teachers work from 9 to 5 and others from 1 to 9. Figure in at least an hour for commuting and it all adds to a long day. All teachers get 2 days off but very rarely are they on the weekend since Saturday and Sunday is when most students take lessons.

This is not such a bad thing however - much better to go shopping and travelling on weekdays when everyone is working rather than the weekends where every place is swamped. It seems that there are always not enough teachers in Tokyo because overtime hours are readily available. I "blitzed" a month by working everyday and became £800 richer. You'd be surprised how many people do this!

A very important point about conversation schools is that they are profit-making entities. If there is ever any dispute of any kind between you and a student, your school will always side where the money is - no matter who is right or wrong.
Mike Horricks has taught in Japan for 3 years with a variety of conversation schools in Tokyo.

I'll start by saying that the JET Program has met even my highest expectations. I'm in Saitama prefecture, which is north of and adjacent to Tokyo, in a city called Chichibu. Chichibu is best described as a resort area for the Tokyo office slave family.

It's well known as a region in which "traditional Japan" has been preserved, largely untouched by urbanisation. In other words, there are lots of old temples and shrines and stuff like that. Teachers on the JET Program teach in many high schools in the local area.

Since we team-teach with Japanese teachers, no two lessons are exactly the same. Some teachers let me do whatever I want, and others feel more chained to the textbook. Third-year teachers in particular are quite understandably hesitant to break away from the standard fare of reading, translation, and drills, since the kids are preparing for university entrance exams and must cover a certain amount of material.

However, even with them I'm still usually able to work in a game or two every now and then. The JET Program is a great way to work and experience Japan because everything is arranged for you - visa, training and accommodation - and the pay is not bad either!
Ryan Olsen is in his 3rd year as a JET Program participant. He teaches in various schools in the Saitama region.

The JET Programme - money for nothing?

Quite often the role of an English teacher in Japan has been compared to that of a circus performer. A clown wheeled out to entertain the kids, the strange 'alien' from a distant land. Whilst this old clich may be true, this is certainly not the case for all those employed within the teaching profession in Japan. As the Japanese often like to say. "This is case by case".

I started my life in Japan as a JET. The Japan Exchange and Teaching programme is predominantly aimed at recent graduates from a number of countries. I joined at the ripe old age of 25 and whilst I enjoyed my time I believe that this particular programme may not be of much interest to experienced teachers. Although you are brought together under one banner you soon realise that each teacher gets a different deal in relation to holidays, conditions and in some ways pay.

Set up a number of years ago to address the problem of poor English communication and the growing need for 'internationalisation', the programme has bloomed and developed over the years to quite respectable heights. However, as I mentioned earlier, everyone's experience is different and that includes in the classroom too. It is not unheard of for some teachers to be used as tape recorders: "Now kids, listen to the foreigner and repeat, then the rest of the lesson will be in Japanese"

Thankfully this rarely happened to me and once I had built trust amongst my colleagues I was allowed a certain amount of autonomy, although often I was viewed as the "Games master". Overall I would say I had a positive experience and believe my experience with organisations such as "Pilgrims Language Schools" certainly gave me those survival techniques I needed to alleviate any boredom for both the students and myself.

You can expect to have between 30-50 students in one class. Obviously individual contact can be minimal. However many JET's enjoy after school activities and I believe those that get involved have the best experiences. The students are junior and senior high school students aged 12 to 18. Some teachers may also visit elementary schools. This I actually found the most fun. Cash wise you are paid 300,000 Yen tax free (depending on your nationality). Out of this salary you must pay national insurance and health payments. Other deductions often depend on the direct employer, for example rent. I was only charged half rent and didn't have to pay the crippling key money and deposits often demanded from many private school teachers. The term begins in September; however all JETs are required for "training" in late July.

Do check your pay and conditions very carefully. A first degree is the minimum requirement, however the best jobs these days require further qualifications. As for cash, most people manage to save something if they don't go crazy at the all you can eat all you can drink restaurants. Come to Japan with a smile on your face, study a little Japanese and don't expect to change a proud country with a long history. I guess if you do that, you'll be able to leave with that bright smile still on your face.
After two years in the JET programme, David Leeming is now a "visiting professor" at Nagoya University of Foreign Studies.

fields.headline: What the US papers say
fields.trailText:
This gun-happy nation has so lost its collective mind, people have grown so strident about their so-called "right" to bear arms, we can no longer see the madness in our midst. With each new atrocity, the triggermen get younger. The corpses get smaller. The public grows even more numb. And still, each year gun-lovers call for more weapons, saying more aggressive firepower is the only solution for protecting ourselves. Madness.
Andrea Peyser, New York Post
fields.body:
This gun-happy nation has so lost its collective mind, people have grown so strident about their so-called "right" to bear arms, we can no longer see the madness in our midst. With each new atrocity, the triggermen get younger. The corpses get smaller. The public grows even more numb. And still, each year gun-lovers call for more weapons, saying more aggressive firepower is the only solution for protecting ourselves. Madness.
Andrea Peyser, New York Post

Why do we have a fully armed society? Who's defending what anymore? Why are concealable weapons still manufactured and sold to the general public? And so long as they are considered consumer products, why are guns less regulated for safety than toys? Ever so slowly and mostly under public pressure, firearms manufacturers are coming to grips with technological improvements: development of guns designed to be fired only by authorised users. Still, the no-more-laws gun lobbyists dismiss legislative efforts to try to mandate any move to these safer guns, claiming that they won't work all that well anyway.
The Washington Post

After the shootings at Columbine and at other schools around the country, the gun lobby has typically tried to divert attention from guns to issues like violence in movies and other social factors. But it is impossible, even for the gun lobby, to escape the clear meaning of yesterday's school killing. It happened because a very young child was able to obtain and fire a loaded weapon.
The New York Times

I don't know how many more columns I can write about the war America has waged against its children - a war so full of racism, classism and stinginess that we'd rather put money into prisons than into schools and communities. A war so insidious, children are joining the battle against each other. Even the most vicious perpetrator, at age 6, can only be said to be acting out the horror we as adults have created.
Detroit Free Press

Conflict resolution can begin there. I think it should be taught in every public school and that it should be mandatory. Beginning in kindergarten, students should learn how to resolve disputes along with their ABCs, all the way up to senior year, so that standing up for yourself will come to mean walking away. I believe it could be one of the most important weapons we could employ.
Katie Davis, The Christian Science Monitor

The facts about school violence
Violence at schools has been dropping since peaking in the early 1990s, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But incidents with multiple fatalities have become more common, such as the mass shootings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colorado.
Some other CDC findings about students and school violence:
 Since 1992, the total number of violent deaths at schools has decreased each year. But the number of violent incidents with multiple fatalities has increased from 1995-1998 as opposed to 1992-1995.
 In 1997, 8.5% of high school students brought a weapon to school, down from a peak of 11.8% in 1993.
 The homicide rate among people aged 14-17 decreased steadily from 1993 to 1997, and the rate in 1997 was at the lowest level since 1988.
 Over a 12-month period ending in 1997, 7.4% of students had been threatened or injured with a weapon on school property.
 80.3% of school districts had policies on students carrying weapons in 1997.
ABC news

webTitle: Will Costner take a risk on Soderberg's drug movie?

fields.headline: Will Costner take a risk on Soderberg's drug movie?
fields.trailText: It was too risky for Harrison Ford, but Kevin Costner is considering the role of a drugs czar in Steven Soderbergh's next project
fields.body:
Stuck at a red light since Harrison Ford just said no, Steven (Sex, Lies and Videotape) Soderbergh's drug-smuggling film Traffic could be on the road again.

Hollywood insiders are claiming today that the director had a successful meeting with Kevin Costner to discuss the role of the drugs czar whose plan for all-out war against the drug barons is compromised by his daughter's descent into crack addiction.

Costner is said to be very interested in the role, but the sticking point would be the necessary cut to his usual $20m fee - necessary to keep the film within budget. Harrison Ford, despite being interested in the role, reportedly blanched at his wage cut; although the official reason for his non-involvement was that the veteran actor - who has recently hired a new agent to find him less predictable parts - deemed the project too risky.

webTitle: Harper's long-term aims for the Windies

fields.headline: Harper's long-term aims for the Windies
fields.trailText: Just a few days after the West Indies cricket board announced Roger Harper's appointment as coach, Brian Lara resigned as captain. Harper is used to putting spin on a cricket ball, but his spin on Lara's departure would get the approval of a Westminster fixer: maybe the West Indies will see the re-emergence of Brian the batsman, was his reaction.
fields.body:
Just a few days after the West Indies cricket board announced Roger Harper's appointment as coach, Brian Lara resigned as captain. Harper is used to putting spin on a cricket ball, but his spin on Lara's departure would get the approval of a Westminster fixer: maybe the West Indies will see the re-emergence of Brian the batsman, was his reaction.

A bright, thoughtful man, Harper told me shortly after the news of his appointment that he'd be playing the long game. "My aim (long-term) is to establish a culture of professionalism in the team, where commitment, passion, enthusiasm and discipline is prevalent." None of those has been in evidence in recent West Indian performances, except for the series a year ago when they drew 2-2 with a very strong Australian side. "Moderate success and devastating failures", in Lara's words, eventually wore him down.

What struck me during our conversation was how much Harper sounded like the England captain Nasser Hussain. Just as England were going to South Africa essentially as part of a process of improving over time, all Harper would say about his immediate plans for the team was that he hopes to make them more competitive. Does that mean that he'd contemplate, even accept, failure in the short term - against Pakistan and Zimbabwe who are playing Test series and competing in a triangular one-day tournament in the Caribbean later this month? "I'm not going to tell you that I'll accept failure", he bristles, "but it's a possibility of course".

Harper's tune also reflects the nature of his appointment - a carefully thought out, deliberately corporate strategy by his board, including advertising the job, shortlisting and screening candidates, and interview. Everything, in fact, bar the headhunting. His advanced coaching certificate from England got him the job ahead of Viv Richards, triggering street protests and angry denunciation of the board in Antigua. So is it all going to be about, say, a five-year plan, and measurable indicators to see whether he and the new manager Ricky Skerritt are hitting their targets? "I think that's the only way to go. You have to set yourself long-term goals. You have to have these little goals, so as you rightly said, we have to check to see how we're doing and if we're progressing along the right lines and at the right pace". He maintains the superb fitness that made him arguably the best fielder in the world in his day, but he told me that's not going to be a preoccupation. "You have to take a holistic approach".

This is new language and new times for West Indies cricket. It's surely the end of the practice of giving the jobs of coach and manager to respected and successful old pros. It's a significant shift by the men who run the game. And it's why in their eyes, even a legend like Viv didn't make the grade. Richards can be excused by the briefness of his tenure, but it is a fact that he lost every match as coach - all the games in New Zealand, plus the World Cup match against Australia, when he took over from a cancer-stricken Malcolm Marshall. Marshall's record as coach and Clive Lloyd's as manager were dire. They included away-series whitewashes by Pakistan and South Africa. Yet this trio are three of the best cricketers ever to have played the game.

In Harper they've gone for a player who had a moderate record as a Test player. Stature and motivational powers, it seems, are not everything. If Harper is successful, then it'll be something for the Botham-for-England brigade to digest.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

Does that mean that he'd contemplate, even accept, failure in the short term - against Pakistan and Zimbabwe who are playing Test series and competing in a triangular one-day tournament in the Caribbean later this month? "I'm not going to tell you that I'll accept failure", he bristles, "but it's a possibility of course". Harper's tune also reflects the nature of his appointment - a carefully thought out, deliberately corporate strategy by his board, including advertising the job, shortlisting and screening candidates, and interview. Everything, in fact, bar the headhunting. His advanced coaching certificate from England got him the job ahead of Viv Richards, triggering street protests and angry denunciation of the board in Antigua. So is it all going to be about, say, a five-year plan, and measurable indicators to see whether he and the new manager Ricky Skerritt are hitting their targets? "I think that's the only way to go. You have to set yourself long-term goals. You have to have these little goals, so as you rightly said, we have to check to see how we're doing and if we're progressing along the right lines and at the right pace". He maintains the superb fitness that made him arguably the best fielder in the world in his day, but he told me that's not going to be a preoccupation. "You have to take a holistic approach". This is new language and new times for West Indies cricket. It's surely the end of the practice of giving the jobs of coach and manager to respected and successful old pros. It's a significant shift by the men who run the game. And it's why in their eyes, even a legend like Viv didn't make the grade. Richards can be excused by the briefness of his tenure, but it is a fact that he lost every match as coach - all the games in New Zealand, plus the World Cup match against Australia, when he took over from a cancer-stricken Malcolm Marshall. Marshall's record as coach and Clive Lloyd's as manager were dire. They included away-series whitewashes by Pakistan and South Africa. Yet this trio are three of the best cricketers ever to have played the game. In Harper they've gone for a player who had a moderate record as a Test player. Stature and motivational powers, it seems, are not everything. If Harper is successful, then it'll be something for the Botham-for-England brigade to digest. Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

fields.headline: Don't go changing
fields.standfirst:
There's a golden rule in Hollywood: if it moves, remake it. As cinema-lovers start fretting about director Tim Burton's plans to rehash Planet Of The Apes, John Patterson keeps his fingers crossed for the few classics left untouched
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: There's a golden rule in Hollywood: if it moves, remake it. As cinema-lovers start fretting about director Tim Burton's plans to rehash Planet Of The Apes, John Patterson keeps his fingers crossed for the few classics left untouched.
fields.body:
Here's a list capable of loosening the bowels of anyone professing to love the cinema. Because every single name on it belongs to a movie currently in the process of being remade by one of the Hollywood studios: Battlestar Galactica, Bedazzled, Buck Rogers, The Dirty Dozen, Fahrenheit 451, Fantastic Voyage, Flash Gordon, Gone in Sixty Seconds, I Am Legend, I Claudius, Jason And The Argonauts, Logan's Run, Modesty Blaise, Planet Of The Apes (now to be dragged back to life by Tim Burton), Rollerball, A Star Is Born, Them!, The Time Machine, and X: The Man With X-Ray Eyes. Every one a classic - every one near-guaranteed to become a travesty in the not-too-distant future. Bear in mind that in Hollywood nothing, but nothing, is sacred (there was once a TV remake of Casablanca, in which Bogart was replaced by David Soul). But there's hope, in the shape of those much loved movies as yet unmolested by the execs. To wit, the following are not being remade. Yet. There's still time.

Vertigo (Alfred Hitchcock, 1958)

They've already done a TV version of Rear Window with Christopher Reeve in the Jimmy Stewart role, so don't think for a minute this won't be shoddily re-trod in the near future. 1976's Obsession, directed by serial Hitchcock-thief Brian De Palma, was a variation on its themes. Now it's only a matter of time before someone turns this serene temple of cinema into a heaving celluloid pissoir . And then they'll do The Birds properly, as Hitch would have wanted it.

Highway To Hell (Mark Griffiths 1984)

This is the kind of movie you saw in a drunken stupor on late-night TV 10 years ago and never forgot. When you finally track it down on video - good luck - it's every inch the nihilistic trash classic you remembered. Eric Stoltz escapes from his cop escort to Death Row and goes on the lam with a superstitious hooker who's been writing to him in prison. Everybody dies horribly. Trouble is, you show this to three friends and suddenly Jerry Bruckheimer's remaking it with a NASA-sized budget while buying up and burning all extant copies of the original.

The Killer

(John Woo, 1988)

When video director Antoine Fuqua met Chow Yun-Fat ("the Cary Grant of the exit-wound") after the Asian superstar's arrival in Hollywood, his first words were "Hey, you should do an American remake of The Killer!" This suggestion alone should immediately have disqualified Fuqua from playing any part in Chow's career in Hollywood. Any fool can do bloodbags and shellcasings, as Fuqua proved with the aptly-titled Replacement Killers, but only Woo could have engineered a poignant marriage between slow-mo Peckinpah and Douglas Sirk's Magnificent Obsession. Bring me the head of Antoine Fuqua

Detour

(Edgar J Ulmer, 1944)

I can just picture some executive striding around the conference table in a fever of inspiration saying "Yeah, now this Detour thing might work if we just pour some money into it_" And no one in the room will point out that Detour's power lies precisely in its Poverty Row origins. Made in six days on rickety sets and in rear-projection booths, starring the luckless Tom Neal, who later did time for murdering his wife, Detour remains so dark and poisonous it will probably send potential re-makers squealing for their mummies. Which has got to be good.

Get Carter

(Mike Hodges, 1971)

Sadly, I cheated, because they're already remaking this toxic gangster classic. The script has been rewritten for Sylvester Stallone - it's like a nightmare, isn't it? - who will play a rather nicer Jack Carter than Michael Caine did in the original (he'll have a goatee). We will also be favoured with car chases, more gunplay, and a happy ending. This is exactly what happened when Mel Gibson re-adapted The Hunter (Richard Stark's source novel for John Boorman's Point Blank) to make Payback. He got cold feet about playing a bastard, fired the director, rewrote to death, and the gutless result was a foretaste of what we can expect from Carter 2000. If you need another Get Carter, choose the blaxploitation insta-remake, Hit Man.

Night Of The Hunter

(Charles Laughton, 1955)

The kind of jerry-built accidental masterpiece that every suburban idiot in film school thinks he could make just that little bit better. Never mind the uniquely bizarre friction created by the gathering of such mismatched talents as Laughton, Lillian Gish, co-auteur Stanley Cortez, James Agee, Shelley Winters, Peter Graves and the mighty mighty Robert Mitchum, because someone's going to get their nasty mitts on it anytime now and bugger it up six ways from Sunday.

The Magnificent Ambersons (Orson Welles, 1942)

They can do what they like with Citizen Kane, but not with its melancholy and beautiful successor. Because there are some 30 minutes missing from the final version of The Magnificent Ambersons (an act of revenge on Welles by RKO Studios, the pigs), one can easily envisage someone deeming it worth redoing and thus "fixing". After all, there's Booth Tarkington's Pulitzer Prize-winning 1916 novel to draw on, so who needs Welles's screenplay? The vultures, as ever, are circling...

fields.headline: Wheel spins back Bush's way
fields.trailText:
Another week, another group of states, and yesterday yet another 
extraordinary turn in this ever remarkable Republican presidential race. Last 
week belonged to John McCain. This week, just as emphatically, belongs to 
George W Bush, who nailed three wins in three very different contests in 
Virginia, North Dakota and Washington overnight. Next week, the key week, 
Super Tuesday week, the wheel spins again - and this time it will stop in 
deadly earnest.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Los Angeles for Guardian Unlimited
fields.body:
Another week, another group of states, and yesterday yet another extraordinary turn in this ever remarkable Republican presidential race. Last week belonged to John McCain. This week, just as emphatically, belongs to George W Bush, who nailed three wins in three very different contests in Virginia, North Dakota and Washington overnight. Next week, the key week, Super Tuesday week, the wheel spins again - and this time it will stop in deadly earnest.

Just for a moment, though, turn aside from the mesmerising Bush-McCain contest and consider the day's biggest winner. Al Gore has been a forgotten man through Republican dominated February. But he has been out there campaigning night and day, east coast and west, away from the limelight that has been lavished on the Republicans. And last night he quietly won a bigger prize than anyone.

By defeating Bill Bradley in an otherwise meaningless primary vote in Washington state yesterday, Gore proved he is the unstoppable winner in the Democratic race. Bradley had spent six consecutive days campaigning in Washington in the hope that a win there - in an often liberal and iconoclastic state - would get his challenge to Gore moving again. Last night, though, Gore won big - 69% to 30% - in Washington. Bradley's last throw ended humiliatingly.

Six months ago, Bradley stood on the steps of his old high school in Crystal City, Missouri, and launched his presidential bid. His slogan was "It Can Happen". For a while last autumn, as Gore stuck in second gear and Bradley milked the "I am not Al Gore" routine, it looked as if it just might. But Gore has regrouped and Bradley has thrown it away. Washington was six wasted days. Gore leads by 14 points in New York, Bradley's last best hope which votes next week. After last night, it is clear. It won't happen.

But Gore is the winner is a broader sense too. Last night, Bush recovered from Michigan and Arizona to duff McCain in a hat-trick of wins. From a Democratic point of view, it is the best of all possible results. The battle between McCain and Bush goes on, increasingly bitterly on the evidence of the religious wars between the two men this week, but in the end Bush looks to be emerging as the conservative and often underwhelming winner. McCain is the man the Gore people fear, so the script could have been written to suit Gore in every way.

Bush's wins took the wind out of McCain's sails last night. Coming down the California central valley with McCain yesterday, as he campaigned for next week's primary here, there was barely a hint that things might be going amiss in Washington. The news from Virginia did not surprise. The result from Washington, though, was an evident shock. The mood among the McCain people went from relaxed to grim, chatty to taciturn, in a matter of moments, as they arrived in Los Angeles to be greeted with news from the northwest. It was a reminder of just how difficult their task really is.

The three contests could hardly have been greater contrasts. North Dakota, where Bush romped home by 76% to 19%, is a prairie state with iron winters, strict teachings and a natural conservative take on the world. Bush's win there was expected, and McCain made only a single desultory visit to North Dakota, pausing for 30 minutes the day before yesterday to make a speech at Bismarck airport where the sound system failed. It was no surprise that the McCain message didn't get through either.

No less expected was Bush's win in much more important Virginia, a once Democratic state now turned Republican, as most other Southern states were long ago. McCain is unpopular with the tobacco industry, and with some northern Virginia residents who don't like his advocacy of more flights into Washington DC's Ronald Reagan airport. Defeat by 53% to 44% was hardly a surprise. The McCain people had written Virginia off, but the 80% Bush win among core Republican voters is a fact which could toll the knell for McCain outside the South as well as inside it.

Washington is the one that made a good night great for Bush. Part trendy Microsoft and high tech stuff, part old manual industry, Washington is a mixed bag. Seattle is one of the most relaxed cities in then world. Inland and to the east, though, the state moves sharply to the right. It has a record of going its own way, and last night it did. Bush's win - he led by 59% to 38% with 70% of the vote counted - was very big for a state in which McCain, like Bradley, felt the independents would play a key role. Like Bradley, however, McCain got it desperately wrong last night. Sleepless after Seattle in both cases. Next week is do or die.

fields.headline: The best introduction scene
fields.standfirst: The Talented Mr Ripley
fields.trailText: The Talented Mr Ripley
fields.body:
Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law) and his mysterious friend Tom Ripley (Matt Damon) have made a day trip to Rome. The pair are sitting in a sun-lit piazza drinking coffee. Tom sighs happily.

"There's just so much to see and do in one day."

Dickie laughs.

"The most important question is 'where do we eat?'"

He glances around him.

"I hope Freddie made a reservation."

Tom appears taken aback.

"Freddie?"

"Freddie. Freddie Miles. Freddie's organising the skiing trip."

A perturbed look crosses Tom's face.

"Oh, look", says Dickie. "Here he is."

A bright red sports car drives through the square, nearly knocking down several pedestrians and a handful of pigeons, coming to a halt with a screech of brakes. A large, florid-faced young man, dressed in the preppie-style and wearing a flat cap, stands up in the vehicle. It's Freddie (Phillip Seymour Hoffman). Dickie rises to greet him.

"Frederico!"

"Ciao Bella!" Freddie booms back.

He moves to join Dickie, passing a gaggle of young Italian women. He turns to Dickie and continues to bellow.

"Oh God, I just want to fuck every woman in this city, just once."

"Only once?"

"Absolutely."

Dickie turns to his original companion.

"Tom Ripley - Freddie Miles".

See also: A Clockwork Orange, Desperately Seeking Susan, The Wizard Of Oz

Don't see also: Ruthless People

Pointless trivia: Matt Damon was director Ang Lee's first choice for the lead role in civil war-drama Ride With The Devil, but turned the part down in favour of The Talented Mr Ripley.

fields.headline: Hideaway Haider
fields.standfirst:
His retreat is not the good news it seems

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider's decision to retire to Carinthia is very welcome. After 24 gruelling days as non-chancellor, Austria's most notorious non-Nazi has certainly earned the chance to put his feet up (as opposed to his arms).
fields.body:
Jörg Haider's decision to retire to Carinthia is very welcome. After 24 gruelling days as non-chancellor, Austria's most notorious non-Nazi has certainly earned the chance to put his feet up (as opposed to his arms). Mr Haider is now also not the leader of the Freedom party, a non-extremist political group which is not in favour of forcibly repatriating immigrants. He has delegated that honour to Susanne Riess-Passer who (believe it or not) is fast becoming an Austrian household name. Perhaps it is too much to hope that Mr Haider will in time retire from the Carinthia governorship, too, and repair to his Alpine estate which was not stolen from its original Jewish owners. High altitude, pine-clad obscurity is undoubtedly the best place for him. But the chances of Mr Haider embarking on a new career as a supplier of hot air for off-piste saunas are, sadly, remote.

So what is Mr Haider, apart from what he is not? The claim made by his associates, and by Wolfgang Schüssel, Austria's bow-tied virtual chancellor, that Mr Haider acted out of altruism for the sake of the new government is all window-dressing and Tyrolean fairy-lights. This resignation was about forward planning. Mr Haider remains as the man who carries the most political clout in Austria. He remains as the voice on the end of the line to Ms Riess-Passer. He can still pull strings in Vienna whenever he wants. But by distancing himself from a government mired in controversy at home and abroad and which must soon enforce austerity measures, including public sector job cuts, Mr Haider, jogging serene and unsullied through the virgin snows of Klagenfurt, hopes to position himself as prince-in-waiting, as Austria's real-time chancellor-to-be.

It is a stomach-churning scenario - but one which is not without appeal in some benighted quarters. Which is why EU governments were right yesterday to pooh-pooh Mr Haider's manoeuvre and vow to keep up the pressure on Austria.

webTitle: EU stands firm on Austria boycott

fields.headline: EU stands firm on Austria boycott
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: EU leaders pledged last night to maintain their collective boycott of Austria, dismissing the resignation of Jörg Haider as leader of the country's far-right Freedom party as a meaningless ploy.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Kate Connolly in Prague
fields.body:
EU leaders pledged last night to maintain their collective boycott of Austria, dismissing the resignation of Jörg Haider as leader of the country's far-right Freedom party as a meaningless ploy.

Portugal, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, set the tone, with the prime minister Antonio Guterres insisting: "The problem is not Jörg Haider but what his party represents."

Mr Guterres argued that Mr Haider's sudden departure showed that Austria was aware of the problems caused by role of the controversial Freedom party chief, whose party has formed a coalition government with the country's conservatives.

But the united response gave no clue as to how long the freeze would last - it was in evidence on Monday when Freedom party ministers were snubbed at regular EU meetings - or whether there was an exit strategy.

One interpretation was that the EU could increase pressure on Austria's entire coalition government, under the leadership of chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel, to step down.

In Britain, which was initially lukewarm to the idea of the unprecedented 14-to-one boycott, Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "The issue all along has not been Mr Haider's relationship with the Freedom party but the participation of the Freedom party in the government of Austria. That has not changed."

Mr Haider, infamous for his remarks on the Nazi SS and Hitler's economic policies, has made it clear that he intends to stand as chancellor in Austria's next elections.

All indications pointed to Mr Haider remaining the party leader in all but name - an eminence grise wielding power in the background.

fields.headline: Seeking Haider
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: If nothing else, Jörg Haider is a master of surprise. His resignation as leader of the Austrian Freedom party was quite unexpected. But then, he  is something else, an adroit and slippery political operator who ducks and dives with alarming agility.
fields.body:
If nothing else, Jörg Haider is a master of surprise. His resignation as leader of the Austrian Freedom party was quite unexpected. But then, he is something else, an adroit and slippery political operator who ducks and dives with alarming agility. Having convulsed Austrian politics, Haider now says that he does not "want to be seen as a shadow-chancellor". He has retired to his Carinthian lair, which by no means rules him out of a further attempt on national power.

And yet, visiting Austria one can see that the nature of Haider's demagoguery has been misunderstood outside the country. He has horrified the rest of Europe, he has sent Downing Street into spasms with his claim that he and Tony Blair are political brothers, he has been called a neo-Nazi and a new führer, a neo-fascist or a post-fascist. All of which misses the point. The truth is that he is not post- fascist so much as pre-fascist. Jörg Haider isn't Adolf Hitler's heir, he is Karl Lueger's.

A century ago, Europe was in the throes of economic and social turmoil which has many parallels with today. Then it was industrialisation, with drastic social change fed by railways, steamships and telegraphs. Now it's globalisation, the information revolution and hi-tech (which means low-employment) industries. Then as now there were great migrations of peoples, which produced nativist reactions. In Vienna, the reactionary movement was led by Dr Karl Lueger, head of the Christian Social party. Lueger's Christian socialism wasn't the same as the Rev Charles Kingsley's (or Tony Blair's, Haider might note). His party's platform was very distinctive: anti-Marxist but also anti-capitalist, anti- liberal and anti-semitic.

He found his support among the petty bourgeoisie and upper working class of Vienna. Lueger presented himself as the champion of the "little man", the artisan or shopkeeper threatened by big business and big bureaucracy. If there was no "anti-European" component in his rhetoric as in Haider's, maybe one can hear echoes from Lueger's attitude to the rest of the vast Hapsburg monarchy, whose sentimental admirers sometimes claim that it prefigured the EU.

Not without reason, the Viennese saw the Austro-Hungarian dual monarchy created in 1867 as a racket run in favour of Hungarian landowners. And, as now, they were frightened by mass immigration - today from Turkey or points further south.

Just as Haider does, Lueger claimed that he was addressing economic grievances rather than fanning racial hatred when he denounced Jewish and Slav incomers. Vienna had indeed been transformed: before 1848, Jews were forbidden to live in the city. Fifty years later there were 200,000 Jews in Vienna, one 10th of the population. There were hundreds of thousands of Czechs and Hungarians as well, who weren't particularly popular with the indigenous Viennese either. But as ever it was the Jews who got it in the neck, and Lueger's own cynical and calculating version of anti-semitism was "the socialism of fools".

Today, Haider has a habit of making outrageous statements before explaining them away, and he likes to claim that he isn't a racist. But in that too there are echoes of Lueger, and his most famous saying. Reproached once by a tougher-minded party colleague for showing kindness to individual Jews, Lueger replied: "I decide who's a Jew." Or as the smirking Haider might say: "I decide who's an immigrant."

Three times Lueger was elected mayor of Vienna, and three times he was vetoed by the Emperor Franz Josef, who disliked his bigotry and demagoguery as much as respectable Austria and Europe now dislike Haider's. When he was elected a fourth time in 1897, the emperor gave in. Lueger died in 1910, well before he could see the full fruits of his work.

Odious as Haider is, there may be a lack of proportion - or a failure of understanding - in the rage against him. Even if he praises Hitler's "orderly" economic policies, Haider has no territorial ambitions and no panzer divisions. Even if he became chancellor, he isn't going to invade Poland. Still, between pre-fascism and post-fascism comes fascism itself. Hitler learnt all his politics in Vienna, pan-German nationalism from other rabble- rousers such as Schoenerer, Jew-baiting and Slav-hating from Lueger, along with his appeal to the little man and his version of socialism.

If the conditions for a new Hitler barely exist today, there is something eerily familiar about the mood of social unease and economic upheaval breeding demagogues. With his mountebank flashiness, Jörg Haider can sometimes seem risible. But history does not only repeat itself as farce.

fields.headline: Eichmann's life
fields.standfirst: A chronologyThe David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: A chronology.
fields.body:
1906 Born in Solingen, Germany, March 19. Family moved to Austria.

1932 Joined Austrian Nazi party, recruited to Himmler's elite SS.

1941 Began creating death camps, developing gassing and organising mass convoys of European Jews.

1942 Formally charged with implementation of "Final Solution".

1944 Reported to Himmler that 4m Jews had died in camps; 2m others killed by mobile extermination units.

1945 Put in US internment camp.

1946 Escaped to Argentina.

1960 Caught by Israeli secret agents.

1961 Tried in Jerusalem for crimes against Jewish people and humanity.

1962 Executed in Tel Aviv, May 31.

webTitle: 'I will not try to paint a pretty picture'.

fields.headline: 'I will not try to paint a pretty picture'.
fields.standfirst: The Eichmann diary: further extractsThe David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Eichmann diary: further extracts.
fields.body:
Acknowledging the horror of the Holocaust:

I am in Israel. The giving of evidence is complete and in eight days the prosecutor general and my defence will give their summations. So it will be around three or four months before the court comes to a verdict. Then I will call the child by its name. The president of the court wanted me to call it by its name; I obeyed and said that the events concerning the Jews that the German government in power at the time set in motion during the last great war are the greatest crime committed in the history of humanity . . . Most of the actors, who will now enter into history, I knew. I spoke with some of them and I can venture to assess them. I am going to describe life of that time as it was, as I lived through it and as I saw it. I will try not to paint a pretty picture. What only yesterday I believed I had to worship, today lies in the dust of the wreckage.

On the shame of Versailles and the rise of National socialism:

Young people were told of the national shame, traitors and the like. And then you hear the propaganda - there is a party that has even written the extinction of national shame on its banner . . . There was nothing about Jews, except the occasional mention, who would take that seriously? Who thought much about things at all. Old people perhaps. Young chaps were only interested in heroism, helping to extinguish the shame. Our gods demanded it. It must have been the same in ancient times. Why not trust them?

On his army service:

Military service was bloody elbows and knees - animal-like subordination - I accepted it all in place of the bohemian coffee houses and wine bars of my home, motorsports, mountain sport and being with my fiancee. I did this of my own free will, indeed, I gave up a lot for them. As long as the Fatherland could be free and the misery of the Germans had an ending."

On the creation of Theresienstadt, a concentration camp in occupied Czechoslovakia:

During a press conference in Prague, Heydrich [protector of Bohemia and Moravia], in his typically impulsive style, got carried away and named an impossibly imminent date for the de-Jewification of [his lands]. To fulfil his promise, Theresienstadt was cleared of German troops stationed there, and the Czech civil population resettled. At that time, Heydrich asked my opinion as to how I imagined a solution. He asked dozens of persons and offices. I told him he should make available a town with sufficient hinterland. In such a town, Jews from Bohemia and Moravia could be settled.

On watching the gassing of Jews in sealed trucks during 1942:

The buses were driven to a kind of meadow with a prepared mass grave. The doors of the buses opened and the contents were emptied into the graves. It was horrible. A civilian jumped into the graves and broke the gold teeth off. When you are confronted with a horror of this kind, a sort of unreality comes over you. It is difficult to explain to a non-psychologist. You have to pinch the back of your hand because you don't believe this is real. I pinched myself to see that this was not just a bad dream.

That evening in May when I was attacked 30m from my home in Buenos Aires, when my hands and feet were tied, and I was tied to the bed, I had to pinch the backs of my hands, too, to see if it was real. It was the same here. I was not really an executor or even an observer. A kind of non-reality paralysed me . . . I was asked by one of the judges if we had no courage. And I told him, no, we had obedience, faithfulness to the cause, but not courage.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Did I imagine it or did Lord Archer's chum Fatty "Robin" Oakley, the BBC's political editor, really say on Radio 5 Live on Monday afternoon that there have been smears against Ken Livingstone, but that no one is suggesting they came from Labour? If Fatty said this, I worry for his health: we say that the smears are coming not only from Labour, but from people very close indeed to Mr Tony Blair. You may also recall, from the John Ware's mayoral Panorama (the one before Vivian White's splendid effort on Monday), how Tom Baldwin of the Times reported an approach by a senior Labour figure encouraging him to write about what would be, were it the truth, an intensely personal aspect of Ken's private life. As for the monstrous smears about Mo Mowlam's brain tumour leaving her unable to work properly, where does Fatty think they've been coming from? No, on balance, I must have imagined Fatty saying such a foolish thing.
fields.body:
 Did I imagine it or did Lord Archer's chum Fatty "Robin" Oakley, the BBC's political editor, really say on Radio 5 Live on Monday afternoon that there have been smears against Ken Livingstone, but that no one is suggesting they came from Labour? If Fatty said this, I worry for his health: we say that the smears are coming not only from Labour, but from people very close indeed to Mr Tony Blair. You may also recall, from the John Ware's mayoral Panorama (the one before Vivian White's splendid effort on Monday), how Tom Baldwin of the Times reported an approach by a senior Labour figure encouraging him to write about what would be, were it the truth, an intensely personal aspect of Ken's private life. As for the monstrous smears about Mo Mowlam's brain tumour leaving her unable to work properly, where does Fatty think they've been coming from? No, on balance, I must have imagined Fatty saying such a foolish thing.

 A rumour sweeps through the newspaper world that Mirror editor Piers Morgan is pleading with Spectator media correspondent Steve Glover to state categorically in the next issue that Piers is about to be sacked. Famously, it is Steve's uncanny gift to predict the demise of editors who in fact prove to be ostentatiously successful that makes him media punditry's answer to William Rees Mogg. Only last week the Times's Peter Stoddart, whose sacking Steve has been anticipating for ages, became editor of the year at the What the Papers Say awards. Steve himself was rather briefly and painfully an editor himself once, although never quite an editor of the year. But that's all a long time ago, and it's not our way to intrude on private grief.

 After an amusing Central Line journey, I call London Transport's press office to ask when programming train information into the dot matrix things on platforms was yielded to a chimpanzee intelligence experiment? Or was it a half-term amusement for children? "What do you mean?" asks Heather. Well, at Shepherds Bush the machine began by saying three minutes, then said four, five and six minutes, went back down to three, and the train came 17 minutes later. There are no chimps or children involved, Heather insists. The equipment is computerised, but can be manually overridden in order - and Heather was most keen that this phrase appear - "to ameliorate service perturbation".

 Apologies for the cock up, but yesterday's column lacked the last line of the chorus to Millbank Believer, Frank Dobson's new campaign song with words by Nick Drew set to the tune of I'm A Believer by the Monkees. Here is that chorus in full: Then they fixed Red Ken, Now he's going crazy. I can smile again, no doubts in my mind. I'll be mayyyyyy-oooor, oooh ooh you amaze me! You couldn't faze me, if you tried.

 Readers are reminded that today marks the beginning of Philip Gould Month. The focus group king turns 50 shortly (he is hiring the entire millennium wheel for his party), and in order to dispel the tedious obscurity that clings still to this architect of New Labour, we are seeking information (and amusing photographs) to help piece together a biographical mosaic. So far we have learnt only that Philip was known as "Big Ears" at school. Or that was how he was perceived, we gather, by 67.4% of the classroom sample.

 At the press launch for the BBC touring exhibition Future World, hacks were amused to hear host Nick Ross refer dismissively to "heritage analogue technology". That's a telly, by the way. So put away that £1,200 wide-screen heritage analogue technology until the Antiques Roadshow is next in town, and rush out for a new digital set.
