fields.headline: Patten in interview mode
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia must understand international outrage over atrocities in Chechnya - and stop blaming the West for its failures, says Chris Patten, the European Union's British commissioner for external relations.
fields.body:
Russia must understand international outrage over atrocities in Chechnya - and stop blaming the West for its failures, says Chris Patten, the European Union's British commissioner for external relations.

In combative remarks ahead of an unprecedented three-way meeting between the EU, the US and Russia tomorrow in Lisbon, Mr Patten warned that for all the importance of building a strategic relationship with Moscow, human rights abuses cannot simply be passed over.

Last week he formally expressed "shock" and "deep concern" at reports of mass graves near Grozny, and will be taking up the issue forcefully with Igor Ivanov.

"Russian leaders have to understand the depth of outrage at what people have read in their newspapers and seen on their TV screens," he told the Guardian in his 15th floor office in the Commission's Charlemagne building.

"Even if only half the stories were true they would still be horrific. We cannot behave with Russia as though nothing untoward had happened, as though we could simply conduct business the way that we wanted to before the Chechnya hostilities."

Yet the EU has hardly been robust: in January aid programmes were partially diverted to humanitarian relief, though that, diplomats say, was only at Mr Patten's insistence that member states could not afford to backtrack on threats issued at the Helsinki summit.

Sanctions, like those against Serbia or Iraq, are unthinkable: there is too much at stake, from nuclear safety to arms control, to alienate Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

But he adds:"Some of the horrors inflicted on the civilian population are going to create scars that are going take a very long time to heal. There is a sort of spiritual pollution about closing your eyes to human rights abuses on such a dreadful organised scale."

Handling Russia underlines a general difficulty: the last governor of Hong Kong is the first European commissioner with a serious chance of giving the EU the ability to match its economic might with real political and diplomatic muscle.

He is a true heavyweight in Romano Prodi's commission, a world-class politician and intellectual with a hefty budget and a brief that extends across the globe. But all too often his hands are tied - both by Europe's governments and the EU's own deficiencies.

Now 55, and claiming to have abandoned any further political ambitions thanks to the disarray in the Conservative Party, Patten sounds more like a manager than a visionary.

"We provide a lot of the timberwork that bridges the rhetoric about foreign policy and what you can actually achieve on the ground -in trade, aid and economic assistance," he says. "My own very strong view is that demonstrating that we can do the things that we are charged with doing competently and well is the best way of ensuring that we are listened to in the debate about the European foreign and security policy.

"This is a job where grandstanding would be profoundly unhelpful and where decent old-fashioned competence has a lot to be said for it."

He is impatient with questions about his relationship with Javier Solana, the former Nato chief and secretary-general of the EU council of ministers who is in charge of putting some military flesh on the bones of a more internationally-assertive union.

No slouch himself when it comes to charm and publicity, Patten looks positively low-key compared to Solana's high-profile world statesman act, complete with bodyguards and restless globetrotting that makes Brussels tongues wag.

"We've got different jobs and different bases of authority," Patten says wearily. "He represents the council. I sit in the council but I represent the commission. We have things to say about the security aspects. We are not a serious player on the military side, but we are a very serious player as far as the money is concerned."

Training judges and customs officials, de-mining, democratisation, humanitarian relief, and financial support for the Middle East peace process all represent the sort of "soft power" where the EU should be able to excel.

Reforming external assistance programmes is a priority, with billions of euros of projects not executed, though some predict a spat with the Danish development commissioner Poul Nielsen, one of three other colleagues Patten coordinates with.

"If I'm overwhelmed by anything its by how much there is to do, not by how little," he says. "Its intellectually exciting, and it matters. I think you can make progress. We're already starting to."

Next week he will be in the Balkans, including Kosovo - and he has a characteristically Pattenesque quip about it needing a police presence that is something "between a military force and Dixon of Dock Green."

British politics seem distant for Margaret Thatcher's former party chairman, though he welcomes Michael Portillo's newly-pragmatic line on the single currency while refusing to criticise Tony Blair for not batting more resolutely at that wicket.

On balance, Commissioner Patten provides as good a sense of strategic vision and canny political sense as he did as Governor Patten - but without the furious personal attacks from Beijing.

He firmly rejects suggestions that a more capable EU will undermine Nato - a favourite Euro-sceptic line.

"We are talking about Europe living up to to its rhetorical flourishes. For decades politicians in Britain have said Europe should do more for itself. Well, here, to some people's surprise, it has risen, perhaps belatedly, to the challenge. Now we have to make sure that we don't fail.'

webTitle: Murdoch at the portal to superpower status

fields.headline: Murdoch at the portal to superpower status
fields.trailText: Over the past month Rupert Murdoch has dispatched his trusted lieutenant Peter Chernin to talk to Jerry Yang, the 31-year-old co-founder of Yahoo, about investing in the group's satellite operations.
fields.body:
Huddled in a corner of the hotel bar, four Generation X-ers sat drinking beer and chatting. Not an unlikely event, until you realise who was there. James Murdoch, one of the four, said that he and his brother Lachlan often chatted with the two young founders of Yahoo: "They're great guys."

The affection of the younger Murdochs for the bright young things of the world's most popular internet portal is now shared by their father's generation.

Over the past month Rupert Murdoch has dispatched his trusted lieutenant Peter Chernin to talk to Jerry Yang, the 31-year-old co-founder of Yahoo, about investing in the group's satellite operations. Chernin and Murdoch senior have also visited Nokia executives to discuss an alliance with the wireless telephone company and have been chatting with Bill Gates of Microsoft.

Rupert Murdoch's discussions are as informative as the bar-room chats of his sons. Few media executives are credited with a greater grasp of short-term financial interest as well as keeping an eye on long-term goals. Murdoch's position as large shareholder and patriarch gives him more reasons than most to fret about his firm's daily share price as well as the future shape of the industry.

Larry Haverty, media analyst at State Street Research, describes the question faced by Murdoch and his ilk as a "terrible short-term conundrum". Their businesses could have a great future providing content for a mass medium, but few investors recognise it. Gerald Levin at Time Warner emphasised this last month when he decided to accept the current share price of America Online as a valid reflection of long-term prospects, rather than short-term mania.

Murdoch has spent much of the past year berating stock market investors for failing to recognise the online value of his business. While the message has won over some converts there is still work to do. Even after a big run-up in News Corp's share price its total stock market value is about $40bn less than that of Yahoo.

News Corp's plan to spin off its satellite operations is seen as a direct attempt to take advantage of the soaring stock prices for internet shares. But it is also an indicator of longer-term strategy. Murdoch, without the advantage of Time Warner's cable assets, has staked his group on providing content via satellite and wireless links.

His vision suggests that, in a few years' time, we will be just as willing to dial up Yahoo's services from a television set-top box as we will be to watch a video. But, perhaps in recognition of the fact that the holy grail of interactive television has remained just that for years, News Corp is also keen to learn more about wireless operators.

Thus the "show and tell" meeting with Nokia. Other large media and technology companies are also keen to take part in the rush for internet domination - a situation which is worrying for those who believed the internet would remain the domain of small interests.

In this atmosphere, Yahoo is a particularly valuable asset for several reasons. It acts as a gateway to the internet for most first-time users and it has so far eschewed takeovers in favour of alliances. Murdoch - who, in the light of the Time Warner deal, recently compared his company to an industry "minnow" in danger of being swallowed - sees Yahoo as a chance of being a superpower. His rivals are unlikely to remain quiet while he tries to achieve that.

webTitle: Tycoon's son snatches Hong Kong Telecom

fields.headline: Tycoon's son snatches Hong Kong Telecom
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Asia's biggest corporate takeover, the £24.6bn sale of Cable & Wireless HKT, has been won by Pacific Century CyberWorks, a 10 month-old loss-making internet firm with a runaway share price.
fields.body:
Asia's biggest corporate takeover, the £24.6bn sale of Cable & Wireless HKT, has been won by Pacific Century CyberWorks, a 10 month-old loss-making internet firm with a runaway share price.

PCCW, run by Richard Li, has transformed itself into an internet and telecommunications operation worth £38bn. Mr Li is the son of Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing.

The announcement was a severe blow to state-owned Singapore Telecommunications which was the first suitor to propose a "merger of equals" with C&W's HKT, the former Hong Kong Telecom. Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, which announced a £645m investment in SingTel to support that bid, dealt the Singapore group a further blow by withdrawing its funding yesterday.

Graham Wallace, chief executive of Cable & Wireless, said: "The SingTel offer was not as good as the PCCW offer. The merger with SingTel at roughly market prices was HK$18 per share and this deal with PCCW is over HK$24."

He said the cash component the British firm could extract from the sale of its 54%-owned Hong Kong subsidiary was a key factor. C&W shares slid 30p to £13.15 yesterday.

PCCW has made two alternative offers to C&W and the other 46% minority shareholders in C&W HKT.

An all-stock offer of 1.1 PCCW shares for each C&W HKT share valued the bid at £24.6bn. The alternative combined offer of 0.7116 of a PCCW share and $0.929 (60p) cash for each C&W HKT share priced the takeover at £23.2bn.

The higher offer values C&W's stake at £8.4bn. "I think it's fair to say it was at the top end of our expectations," Mr Wallace said. "We will use the cash to fund our aggressive capital investment programme of expanding in the data and IP services markets in business-to-business customers globally. We will spend £1.9bn on capital expenditure this year and £1.9bn probably next year."

If the minority C&W HKT shareholders accept the all-cash offer C&W will be left with an 11.2% shareholding in PCCW and about £7.1bn in cash. The maximum C&W can end up with under the deal is a 20.9% stake and cash of £3.8bn.

Mr Wallace expects C&W will take initially about £5bn in cash from the deal. An additional £1.5bn in cash will be raised post-takeover as C&W intends to sell a further 4% of its stock in a secondary placing. C&W might consider a return of capital to shareholders with the cash raised as a defensive move given it will be an attractive proposition to a predator, said analysts.

To reduce its PCCW shareholding even further, C&W has agreed with US internet investment firm CMGI to swap £323m PCCW shares - amounting to 0.7% of the stock - in return for £323m of CMGI shares.

The takeover gives PCCW 4.8m customers - something the firm has lacked since its inception. It also provides C&W with a potential new customer for its data network service.

C&W will gain two board seats on PCCW, with the latter planning to pay a £452m special dividend to shareholders before the deal is completed.

Advisers to the deal included Greenhill, Merrill Lynch and Warburg Dillon Read.

Like very rich father, like son

Graham Wallace, chief executive of Cable & Wireless, is candid about his dealings with Richard Li. "He's got a rich father. That always helps," he says. "I liked him. He's got a quick mind. And when talking to him you can see he's always thinking ahead."

The quickness was epitomised by the way Li's embryonic Pacific Century CyberWorks hijacked the proposed merger between Hong Kong Telecom and SingTel. Li apparently secured up to $11bn in financing from a syndicate led by HSBC Holdings on top of more than $1bn raised recently in a share placement.

His business methods mirror those of his father, who last week created pandemonium with a share offering in an internet company called Tom.com that was 669 times oversubscribed; 300,000 would-be investors queued for application forms.

Father and son now control some 60% of Hong Kong's telecoms market, including the Hutchison-Whampoa group.

webTitle: Smith 'livid' at Whitehall memo on marbles

fields.headline: Smith 'livid' at Whitehall memo on marbles
fields.standfirst: Elgin marbles: special report
fields.trailText: MPs have reopened the row over the Elgin marbles by planning to visit the Parthenon this month as part of a fact finding tour before they hold an inquiry into the illict trade in works of art.
fields.body:
MPs have reopened the row over the Elgin marbles by planning to visit the Parthenon this month as part of a fact finding tour before they hold an inquiry into the illict trade in works of art.

Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the Commons culture, media and sport committee, is to take his members on a tour of Greece and Italy to look at archaeological sites - including a visit to Athens provisionally fixed for March 31.

The decision has caused anger and disappointment among civil servants in the culture department who say in a memo that any visit by MPs will send "the wrong signals" to the Greek government and reopen the issue of the British museum returning the 2,500-year-old treasures to Athens. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, last night was livid at comments made by his officials after the Guardian sent a copy of the memo back to the department.

The MPs' trip - not yet officially announced - leaked out fter the department of culture inadvertently sent the confidential background memo to an Australian television station planning a documentary on the Parthenon marbles.

Mr Smith, who had not seen the memo, is reported to have asked for the civil servant who wrote it to be reprimanded. He is said to have told officials that the language was "emotive, childish and not suitable for internal circulation let alone being sent to outsiders".

The memo discloses that officials from the department have held lengthy discussions with the clerk to the select committee about the trip and the terms of the investigation.

It records: "The committee accepts that it will not be able to avoid the issue of the Parthenon sculptures but the main thrust of the inquiry will be about modern day illicit trade and the return of such objects.

"Unfortunately, the committee is planning a visit to Greece in advance of its inquiry."

The embarrassing memo includes accusations that President Clinton was "bounced" into saying the marbles should be returned and says that Britain was using "delaying tactics" at UN meetings to stop the issue of the marbles being raised by Greece.

It also attacks the Cambridge historian William St Clair, who exposed the scandal of the cleaning of the marbles at the British museum.

It says that a museum symposium on the scraping of the marbles, kept secret for 60 years, "largely discredited St Clair's allegations".

It discloses that Mr Smith paid a special visit to examine the sculptures and decided that "St Clair's account was greatly exaggerated and somewhat unbalanced." The memo says that when President Clinton last November called for the return of the marbles he had been given "the usual incorrect Greek version of events".

It also says Britain was using a "delaying tactic" at Unesco meetings to stop the return of the marbles by claiming it would be contrary to the European convention on human rights.

Last night Graham Binns, chairman of the British committee for the restitution of the marbles, described the memo as "shocking, totally out of order and the ministry should be shamed by it.

"The document is a long and disingenuous spin."

fields.headline: Shipman decision to appeal distresses relatives of murder victims
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman, the Manchester GP jailed for life for the murder of 15 of his patients, has launched an appeal against his conviction, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman, the Manchester GP jailed for life for the murder of 15 of his patients, has launched an appeal against his conviction, it emerged yesterday.

As families of the victims voiced their dismay at the news that their ordeal may not be over, Preston crown court confirmed that Shipman had lodged his appeal there last week. Officials are preparing papers to be sent to the court of appeal in London which has not yet received the "effective" application for the appeal.

The GP, who has always denied the murders, was convicted last month after a four-month trial in Preston before Mr Justice Forbes. He was also found guilty of forging the £386,000 will of one of his victims, Kathleen Grundy, 81, a former mayoress.

The jury of seven men and five women deliberated for six days before returning their unanimous verdicts for the murders, which took place between March 1995 and June 1998.

Since the inquiry began, de tectives have investigated 175 deaths of patients who were registered at Shipman's Market Street surgery in Hyde, Greater Manchester. After the trial, the crown prosecution service said it had enough evidence to proceed on another 23 cases, although officials said they would not go ahead.

Last night, relatives of Shipman's victims said they were devastated at the latest development. Peter Wagstaff, who speaks on behalf of a group of relatives, said: "It is prolonging the agony and grief and it is further upset."

His mother was 81 when she was visited by Shipman at her home in Rock Gardens, Gee Cross, Hyde, on December 9 1997. He told her family she had died from a heart attack.

Mr Wagstaff said the families feared that any appeal would interfere with their demands for a full public inquiry into Shipman's activities.

"For a trial that went on for three and a half months, with 180 witnesses, I find it very difficult to believe there are grounds for an appeal."

Father Denis Maher, of St Paul's Roman Catholic church in Hyde, added: "At first I didn't think he would have the audacity or the arrogance to appeal. On the other hand it is consistent with his behaviour. He has never shown any remorse. The man doesn't have any concept of the hurt and pain he has caused here."

Shipman, who was convicted in the 1970s for forging prescriptions to feed his own pethidine habit, stockpiled vast quantities of morphine from terminally ill patients to murder his victims. The father-of-four altered computer records and notes to cover his tracks.

webTitle: Warning to Blair over NHS deaths

fields.headline: Warning to Blair over NHS deaths
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was yesterday given a direct warning that heart patients are dying because they are waiting too long for operations, despite fresh government reassurance that it can "rebuild" the NHS.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was yesterday given a direct warning that heart patients are dying because they are waiting too long for operations, despite fresh government reassurance that it can "rebuild" the NHS.

Dr Peter Wilde, a heart specialist at Bristol royal infirmary, told the prime minister that his department could no longer "hold the line" and was on the point of breaking government waiting list targets of 18 months.

Ten patients - half of those who had died while waiting for cardiac surgery in the last six months - could have been saved if they had been treated earlier, he said.

Patients who should have received urgent treatment in a month, were having to wait as long as six, while less urgent cases had been waiting a year and a half.

The warning, which came amid a chorus of concerns raised by health professionals at a BBC Newsnight debate with the prime minister at St Thomas's hospital, London, will raise fresh fears over whether the government is moving fast enough to carry out Mr Blair's pledge to make the NHS "the envy of the world".

Ministers are themselves frustrated at the slow pace of change, and are acutely aware that the health service is the key area on which voters will judge government delivery.

The prime minister denied there was a crisis in the service and accused the media of being "alarmist" in its reporting of bed shortages and long waits for operations, but doctors, nurses and hospital managers told him that the government's waiting list targets were distorting clinical priorities and meant "unethical" decisions were being taken about which patients to treat.

Sharon Bennett, a London GP, warned: "Most managers are under extreme pressure to achieve the targets. Waiting lists are being manipulated and as a doctor I find that completely unethical."

Mr Blair insisted voters were in favour of the policy and said it would be a mistake to abandon the waiting list initiative. He promised more money, beds and staff for the NHS, but said management of the system needed to be reformed and modernised.

The prime minister resisted pressure to make unequivocal an earlier pledge to increase funding of the NHS to match average EU levels by 2005: a commitment which would cost the government £12bn.

Leaving himself the escape route introduced after he made the original pledge, he said: "We should be able to afford it, provided that we carry on managing and running the economy properly." Details of the next three-year funding tranche will be announced in July.

Over 40 years, the NHS had received big injections of cash followed by huge cutbacks, he argued. "If we are to make the health service work, we need to have year-on-year increases. I can't deliver everything at once."

Bristol royal infirmary is due to alert the south west regional health authority today that it is bursting through the 18-month waiting limit promised under the patients' charter.

Dr Wilde, clinical director of cardiothoracic services, at the hospital, told Mr Blair: "We have 700 patients on our waiting lists of which 100 have been waiting for more than a year for open heart surgery.

In the last six months, 20 patients have died while waiting for this surgery, some of whom might have been expected to die, but of course many will die because we have so many people waiting so long."

Some 70% of the unit's patients are urgent cases, Dr Wilde said. Speaking after the debate, he described the unit as "chronically underfunded", receiving only 45% of the UK average resources for heart surgery despite pleas to the health authority and a strong clinical track record.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, whose friend and constituent Ian Weir died last year, the day before he was due to have a triple heart bypass after a seven-month wait for treatment, pledged last October to target coronary heart disease.

Together with cancer and mental health, it is one of three new priorities for the government, equal in importance to the cutting of waiting list numbers. The death rate from heart disease in August in England and Wales stood at 230 per 100,000 people aged 45 to 64, more than twice the rate in France.

The British Medical Association warned at the time that improvements would not be made unless new money was found for more doctors and medical resources.

Mr Blair used his visit to St Thomas's - where he opened a £1m accident and emergency unit upgraded under a £115m government initiative to modernise casualty facilities in 182 hospitals - to spell out a five-point plan to reform A&E care and management.

The plan, part of which is already in operation in some hospitals, will involve giving trained A&E nurses increased powers to order tests and prescribe drugs; fast-tracking patients to the appropriate speciality; and cutting waiting times by separating treatment of major and minor conditions.

webTitle: Missing Russian reporter heard 'screams of torture'

fields.headline: Missing Russian reporter heard 'screams of torture'
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian reporter Andrei Babitsky returned to Moscow yesterday after being missing for a month in Chechnya.
fields.body:
The Russian reporter Andrei Babitsky returned to Moscow yesterday after being missing for a month in Chechnya.

He said he was beaten at a detention camp and heard the screams of people who were being tortured.

The return of Mr Babitsky, who went missing after Russia said it had handed him over to Chechen rebels in return for captive soldiers, caused as much surprise as his first reappearance on Friday in Dagestan, to the east of Chechnya.

Mr Babitsky, who reported for US-funded Radio Liberty behind rebel lines, said he was first detained at the Chernokozovo camp.

"I can say to you that at first I was not in the hands of the special security forces but of sadists who detained me at the Chernokozovo concentration camp," he said in an interview on Radio Liberty's website.

Rights groups say they have the testimony of people held at the camp with accounts of rapes, beatings and killings. Russia denies the allegations.

"This is a very serious statement and it demands a very careful investigation," Itar-Tass news agency quoted the head of the interior ministry's press department as saying of Mr Babitsky's allegations.

Mr Babitsky was detained near the Chechen capital, Grozny, in mid-January. Russia announced the swap early in February, but it was not immediately known who was holding him. Russia and loyalist Chechens insisted the rebels had him but Chechen fighters denied the allegation.

He told commercial NTV television that he had heard people being tortured.

"Tortured, I cannot find another word," he said of one woman. "There were cries which showed a person is experiencing torturous, unbearable pain for a long time."

He said he heard guards shouting at another man that they would cut off a part of his body, while another man was beaten constantly.

Mr Babitsky had been held in police custody in Dagestan on charges of holding a false passport and was only released after the acting president, Vladimir Putin, intervened by saying he was against holding the reporter for a such an offence.
Reuters

webTitle: Whitewash fails to hide the horror

fields.headline: Whitewash fails to hide the horror
fields.standfirst:
Exclusive Fresh evidence emerges of brutality inside the 'filtration' camps

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Beyond the barbed wire confines of the Chernokozovo detention centre, a screaming crowd of women hurled themselves beneath the wheels of the military bus carrying journalists back from a propaganda tour of the camp.
fields.body:
Beyond the barbed wire confines of the Chernokozovo detention centre, a screaming crowd of women hurled themselves beneath the wheels of the military bus carrying journalists back from a propaganda tour of the camp.

Dozens laid themselves out on the dusty road in front of the bus; others, waving white flags, gripped on to the windscreen wipers of the moving vehicle, snapping them off from their sockets. The windscreen cracked beneath the pressure of their fists beating on the glass.

"Our sons and husbands are in there," one woman shouted through the window. "They're being tortured. You have to help them."

The military commander in charge of the tour, flushed and sweating, ordered the soldier driving not to stop. It was only when the wheels hit the first protestor that the vehicle finally came to a halt.

This was the second day running that this group of around 60 women had risked their lives to try tell journalists that conditions inside the now-notorious filtration camp were far worse than the military wanted the outside world to believe.

Armed soldiers were brought in to pull the protestors from the road, grabbing them roughly by their arms and dragging them by their clothes. As propaganda exercises go, this one had not been a success.

Confronted by growing allegations of abusive regimes within the filtration camps of Chechnya, Russian officials had organised an open day at Chernokozovo in a doomed attempt to prove that conditions there were beyond reproach.

A swift clean-up operation had also been orchestrated to give the prison regime a veneer of humanity. Throughout the compound there was a faint smell of fresh paint. The newly whitewashed walls hinted at a deeper whitewash operation undertaken by camp officials.

But despite the military's elaborate attempt to control the flow of information from within, visibly frightened prisoners managed to whisper accounts of beatings and abuse received at the hands of Russian guards. The entire camp system had, they said, been transformed in the space of a week in preparation for the arrival of foreign visitors.

"Before that it was like a horror film in here. It was as bad as you can imagine. Everything you've heard about this camp is true. They beat people terribly," one inmate muttered.

Leading the tour around the depressing ruins of what used to be a Soviet era factory, senior prison officer, Major General Mikhail Nazarkin, stressed that recent reports into conditions at Chernokozovo had misrepresented the place.

This month Human Rights Watch described conditions in Russia's "filtration" camps (established to filter civilians out from Chechen fighters) as "unspeakable" and alleged that hundreds Chechen men were being arbitrarily detained and subjected to torture, beatings and on occasion rape in a number of detention centres across Russian-occupied regions of the separatist state.

A second report released on Saturday by Physicians for Human Rights said researchers had documented medical evidence of at least nine individual cases of torture at Chernokozovo after interviewing former detainees. Some were said to have to been severely beaten, others were alleged to have been subjected to torture using an electric current.

Nazarkin dismissed these reports outright. "Recently there has been a wave of negative articles. But these reports that we beat, torture and practically shoot our prisoners - it's all the most supreme nonsense.

"The people employed here take these allegations personally and are offended that anyone might really think believe people working in an honest profession like ours could behave so badly."

Reporters were led first to inspect the brand new camp kitchen, where a huge vat of thick soup was being prepared. The camp chef encouraged television journalists to film as he pointed to the variety of fresh vegetables floating on the surface. Inmates were fed hot meals three times a day, he said. "We have everything here - meat, fish, soup. We give the prisoners tea to drink too, if they want it," he added.

Chernokozovo's 16 cells are lined up along a dark corridor at the centre of the compound, behind an entrance way of tangled razor wire. There were beds for 12 men in most of the cells; despite reports that as many as 1,000 Chechens were detained at the camp, officials said the total population stood at just 99.

In cell number one, 12 prisoners were standing in a line, their hands behind their back, their heads bowed, ready for inspection. They appeared to have been carefully primed on what they should and should not say. What followed was a strange piece of theatre.

The first inmate on display was Aslan Sadullayev, 21, who arrived at the camp only two days ago, and who admitted he was there because he was a Chechen fighter. Speaking in a loud, firm voice - apparently for the benefit of the officers standing by him and supervising the conversation - he described the conditions in the camp as "very good", said the guards treated the prisoners "with great respect" and declared that he had never heard of anyone being mistreated.

All the prisoners were dressed in several layers of clothing, many of them wore hats; the room felt cold and damp. Sadullayev added decisively: "I an honestly say that we are not cold here."

Only the twitching of a clenched jaw muscle in between his clipped responses and the occasional desperate, expressive glance thrown in entreaty when the officials were looking away, indicated that he might not be free to say all that he wanted. At times he looked as if he might choke on his words.

In a second cell, further along the corridor, most prisoners had already spent several weeks in Chernokozovo. These men also lined up dutifully to answer questions, but by now several of the camp officials were beginning to become distracted and prisoners were able to intersperse their louder, formal responses with muttered denials.

Magomed Abuvakhevich, a tired-looking man in his 40s, said he had been imprisoned over two months ago because he had been unable to produce his passport for inspection when soldiers demanded to see his papers. He said that conditions in the camp had changed radically about eight days ago - as international concern about the filtration camp phenomenon mounted.

"Before then we hardly had one meal a day, now we have three. They painted the cell where we sleep; suddenly the camp officials started treating us well. And then for the first time visitors started arriving," he said beneath his breath.

Standing next to him was Isa G., 42, a former school caretaker from a nearby village, arrested on January 28, whispered that he had experienced two severe beatings at the hands of the camp officials.

"I was taken, by myself, from the cell at night to another roomf. Then three masked men beat me on my legs. I don't know why they arrested me; I don't know why they beat me. But things have changed here in the last few days," he said.

In another corner of the cell, one inmate began weeping. One of the officers leading the tour saw him, laughed and explained that these were crocodile tears, designed to melt the hearts of impressionable foreigners.

In the corridor outside, a freshly-painted sign set out the prison timetable, announcing in cheerful red and blue letters that prisoners visited the camp baths at 16.00 hours. Camp administrator, Lieutenant Colonel Takir Sakorov, declared that all the prisoners had exactly the same rights as any prisoner elsewhere in Russia.

"They do, of course, have the right to a lawyer," he said. "Only unfortunately there aren't any lawyers in Chechnya. They're too afraid to come here."

After a quick tour, officials were eager to get journalists swiftly out of the compound. But a crowd of around 60 women - most of them apparently relatives of those men detained inside - were waiting outside.

Waving white flags, they banged on the side of the bus to try to make it stop, before prostrating themselves on the road in front. The driver only stopped when the wheels hit the first protestor.

In the ten minutes before dozens of armed soldiers arrived to force the women away, they shouted out stories of relatives who were interred within. Journalists were prevented from leaving the bus to talk to them, but some women passed hand-written appeals, begging for help in freeing their relatives through the window. Others wrote names of missing men in the grime on the side of the bus.

One woman claimed that busloads of prisoners had been removed that morning in anticipation of the visit. "They take them away every time anyone comes to inspect," she said

One note said simply: "We know that the international community no longer believes Putin's lies. Please help to stop this torture."

"They take them away every time anyone comes to inspect," she said One note said simply: "We know that the international community no longer believes Putin's lies. Please help to stop this torture."

webTitle: The answer is 'don't know'. Now what's the question?

fields.headline: The answer is 'don't know'. Now what's the question?
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, came with his associates to the Commons yesterday for a chat with the treasury select committee. A very cosy affair it was too.
fields.body:
Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, came with his associates to the Commons yesterday for a chat with the treasury select committee. A very cosy affair it was too.

"You know my team, I think," he told the chairman. "A happy band," the chairman replied. "Thank you. Oh, I'm sorry, I thought you said 'happy birthday', said Mr George. It was that kind of occasion.

Luckily perhaps, because Mr George had no information to offer. Apparently, the governor spends his life adrift on a vast, unfathomable sea of ignorance. Now and again he sights a hard statistic or an incontrovertible fact, but as he shouts and waves his shirt, it disappears over the horizon.

Or as Willem Buiter, a Dutch economist on the bank's MPC, monetary policy committee, (his colleague DeAnne Julius is American - no wonder the economy is in good shape; we've drafted in a crack team of foreigners to run it) said: "We do not have perfect foresight. But we do not have perfect hindsight either."

Only an economist could say: "Not only do we not know what is going to happen, but we haven't much idea of what already has happened," and say it with such elegance.

Indeed, Professor Buiter is a master of the non-answer. Michael Spicer, a Tory, kept trying to persuade him that Gordon Brown was handing out too much of our cash.

Mr Spicer: "Would any member of the MPC dispute the fact that public spending is now increasing faster than the rate of receipts?"

Prof. Buiter: "It all depends on what you mean by 'now'." Dazzling.

Mervyn King, a deputy governor, proved every bit as adept as his boss.

Were wage rises keeping pace with productivity? he was asked.

"The latest earnings data is not easy to match up with the settlement data," he said, which translates in demotic English as "search me, mate."

So was productivity rising? Who the heck knows? Or, as Mr King put it, "in times of trend productivity growth, it is very difficult to detect changes in a trend, because productivity is a volatile variable, reflected in the cyclical position." ("I'll just get me coat," as they say on The Fast Show.)

Mr George was asked whether the bank should intervene to bring down the value of sterling. "Intervention in today's market is a form of posing a question," he said runically.

A light went on in Michael Spicer's head. "It's a rain dance," he exclaimed, "You can't do anything about it!"

"Exactly," intoned Mr George. "I don't know what a rain dance is, but we can't do anything about it."

The MPs kept probing to find out if there were any limits to this majestic ignorance. Why was the euro so badly undervalued? Mr George felt this might be a psychological problem. "But I don't know."

They pressed him. "You ask me and I feel pathetic. I don't know. But I don't know if anyone else does know." Clearly we were still some way from touching bottom.

How far was the pound overvalued? "I don't know," flashed back the reply.

Teddy Taylor wondered whether the pound was due to go down. Surely it couldn't rise any further?

"I don't think anyone would be confident enough to say that in the short term it might not go up further," Mr George said. It almost sounded like an opinion.

Teddy Taylor was desperate for him to denounce the euro. "If the next time you come here, the pound has gone up further and the euro has collapsed, what would you and your colleagues say?"

Did he imagine Mr George would commit himself to anything concrete like that? "We would probably have a re-run of the discussion we have had today," the governor said, with a secret smile.

fields.headline: Our African disgrace
fields.trailText: It is a disgrace that there are only five South African helicopters assisting in the rescue of flooded Mozambique. What is the point of the UN if it can't do better than this? Developed countries speak of rapid reaction forces as the future of their military strategies. Could there be a better and more useful training ground than pulling children from trees and rooftops as flood waters close in?
fields.body:
It is a disgrace that there are only five South African helicopters assisting in the rescue of flooded Mozambique. What is the point of the UN if it can't do better than this? Developed countries speak of rapid reaction forces as the future of their military strategies. Could there be a better and more useful training ground than pulling children from trees and rooftops as flood waters close in?

Dan McGanty
Holmbury St Mary, Surrey

 Have I lost my sense of proportion, or is the £2.5m which the government has offered for relief in Mozambique really derisory and inadequate? It is, after all, not even as much as an average Saturday night lottery jackpot win.

When there is bombing to be done or a Dome to be bailed out the noughts in the sums multiply like soap bubbles. Can the prime minister not do another of his famous interventions over the heads of his ministers and crank up this feeble contribution to a level which reflects rich Britain's true relationship to the poverty of Mozambique?

Leonard Pepper
Oxford

 The EU pontificates on the width of theatre seats while Mozambique drowns. Do you wonder why some of us view the prospect of closer integration into fortress Europe with despair?

Susan Adams
Oxford

fields.headline: Dreams and nightmares
fields.trailText: • Manchester Central Library is still "freely accessible to persons of all classes without distinction" (The other dome of discovery, February 26). This is in sharp contrast to the British Library which is very choosy as to who it admits. Had this been the case in Karl Marx's day, he would have had to have spent more time in Manchester with Friedrich Engels. The case for wider regional and national funding is overwhelming.

 The Portico Library in Manchester (Letters, February 29) is an elegant and excellent place. Could it cater for the research needs of the biggest student population in Europe? In your dreams. And while £65pa isn't a huge sum, it's too much for many people. Library access should be a right, not a privilege.

Adele Geras
Manchester

 Around 20 years ago I briefly shared a flat with a Liberian librarian (Letters, February 26 and 29).

Dave Hewitt
Alva, Clacks
sa39@dial.pipex.com

 It is quite appropriate that Branson should bid to run the National Lottery (Camelot promises the moon, February 29). Anyone who has braved the lottery that is the Virgin Railways price structure will vouch for his credentials. Is creating a millionaire a day just a way of making sure there are people who can afford his trains?

Richard Towers
Lymm, Cheshire
rtowers@tyndal.u-net.com

 No wonder Pete Townshend once hoped he'd die before he got old. He obviously had a premonition that one day he might wake up and discover he'd turned into Sid James. According to the photographic evidence of his Lifehouse concert (Reviews, February 28), he was right.

Jeremy Miles
Bournemouth, Dorset

fields.headline: Children's right to learn
fields.trailText: I applaud your series The right to education (February 28 and 29) and the efforts of Oxfam. However, I wish some coverage could be given to efforts to change primary schooling in developing countries. The impression is given that all that is required is a major transfer of resources which may come about if we write to Tony Blair.
fields.body:
I applaud your series The right to education (February 28 and 29) and the efforts of Oxfam. However, I wish some coverage could be given to efforts to change primary schooling in developing countries. The impression is given that all that is required is a major transfer of resources which may come about if we write to Tony Blair.

This is a classic case of Marshall plan-itis. If we have learnt anything about development over the past 40 years, it is that it is not susceptible to a simple prescription called "aid". Transfers of resources cannot themselves be instrumental in resolving social development problems - whether in the field of education or in any other. It is a kind of neo-colonialism to believe the problem and its resolution begin and end with us.

Many children do not go to school because the schools are lousy, they learn nothing, there are no facilities, the teachers behave oppressively, discriminate against poor pupils, and sometimes fail to show up for weeks on end. A lot of countries have embarked on programmes to motivate teachers, improve performance, make the curriculum more useful, bring in girls to the classroom - a host of things, maybe only on a small scale, but they can be built upon. If they are, then existing resources can be used better and more resources will follow. People don't give aid or provide investments for bad ventures. That is the main reason why aid transfers are low. Let's look at what pioneering and enlightened educators are doing on the ground, and lend our support to that.
Maggie Black
Oxford
maggie@black.win-uk.net

It is good to know so many efforts are being made to improve education for girls and women. It can be very difficult to bring about change, especially where cultural habits are ingrained; from experience, we know the will is there, but the problem lies in lack of cash and equipment.

I am a member of Altrusa, a US-based organisation, whose membership consists mainly of professional women. The London group is concentrating on two projects: Empowerment Through Work, which supports classes in literacy and tailoring for village women in the state of Haryana, India; and Child Brides of Ethiopia, which encourages women's education in Ethiopia, where so many girls are harmed by marriage and childbearing at too early an age.

In both cases we have excellent local support and we have learned that quite modest contributions can be valuable.
Valerie Anand
Mitcham, Surrey
valerie.anand@virgin.net

You did not mention bonded labour or child domestic work as reasons for children being denied education. In west and central Africa children as young as seven are trafficked within and across national borders to work as domestic workers, market stall holders and other forms of manual labour; approximately 90% are girls.

In Nepal, Pakistan and India, girls are forced to work 12-hour days as bonded labourers in the fields, carpet factories, brick kilns and quarries. This labour denies them their right to education.
Mike Dottridge
Anti-Slavery International

You report that in Punjab many of the girls are "literate in 7th-century Arabic". Given such hurdles, can anyone be surprised that in some areas of Pakistan literacy among women "is as low as 1%"?

In Asia and sub-Saharan Africa there are millions of children (not just girls) who are expected to become literate in a language they have never heard spoken outside a classroom.
Gerry Abbott
Manchester

webTitle: How we are helping part-time workers

fields.headline: How we are helping part-time workers
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee paints a bleak picture of the government's proposals on part-time work (Stabbed in the back, February 25). Her version is wide of the mark. She charges that by opting to cover "employees" rather than "workers" we will be ducking our commitments under the European directive and depriving 6m part-timers of their rights.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee paints a bleak picture of the government's proposals on part-time work (Stabbed in the back, February 25). Her version is wide of the mark. She charges that by opting to cover "employees" rather than "workers" we will be ducking our commitments under the European directive and depriving 6m part-timers of their rights.

This is a misunderstanding. Where dis crimination remains it must be ended. Our proposals do just that. They will ensure that 6m part-timers can enforce their rights speedily and effectively. This is part of a wider drive to improve the position of part-timers, many of whom are women.

For example about 1.2m women have benefited from the minimum wage; about 1m women have gained from the new right to time off for family emergencies; and around 2m part-timers have benefited from the new right to paid annual holidays. The government is strongly committed to promoting the status and flexibility of part-time work and to providing decent minimum standards.

Stephen Byers MP
Secretary of state for trade and industry

webTitle: The third way is just the same old way

fields.headline: The third way is just the same old way
fields.trailText: Anthony Giddens should know better: the evidence suggests social justice requires progressive taxation (A third way budget, February 29). The idea, reminiscent of Reagan, that higher rates of tax may cut revenue is irrelevant to the UK's low marginal rates.
fields.body:
Anthony Giddens should know better: the evidence suggests social justice requires progressive taxation (A third way budget, February 29). The idea, reminiscent of Reagan, that higher rates of tax may cut revenue is irrelevant to the UK's low marginal rates.

Of course, things beside taxation affect inequality, but cuts in income tax accrue overwhelmingly to the better off, for the poor have little taxable income. And the reason the working families' tax credit will reduce poverty is because it is a "rebadged" benefit, not a true tax cut.

I fear thriving government coffers reflect the economic cycle, not third-way fiscal policies. This makes cutting taxes now especially unappealing, for it implies a downturn may force the government to choose between reversing the cuts (a political taboo) and squeezing public spending.

A meaningful notion of social justice must involve reducing inequalities in living standards. Third-way rhetoric cannot escape the reality that redirecting resources from rich to poor - whether directly or through financing of universal services - remains a crucial means of delivery.

Tom Clark
London School of Economics
T.M.Clark@lse.ac.uk

 By switching the emphasis from progressive to regressive taxation, the Tory government began transferring the burden of tax from the wealthy to the poor.

Professor Giddens is now advocating these policies as New Labour's "third way". The failure of such policies is seen in the rising chaos and tragic waste in health, education and transport.

Patrick Brady
Geraldine Thorpe
London Guildhall University

 Perhaps the most vital thing to consider in the "coming economic rethink" (Letters, February 28) is that equity is a valid objective not only on ethical grounds but also on efficiency grounds.

Under the pretence of making markets more "free", neo-liberal policies often deprive those who embody a high level of human capital the opportunity to join the production chain because they are financially disadvantaged. What results from this waste are incomplete markets and market failures.

Rafael Pereira Gomes
London
r.gomes@ucl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Gun licence
fields.trailText: Your suggestion that the government will prepare tough new controls on arms brokers (Arms trade faces curbs, February 28) is welcome. A public statement is now needed to confirm that it will live up to the promise of this suggestion.
fields.body:
Your suggestion that the government will prepare tough new controls on arms brokers (Arms trade faces curbs, February 28) is welcome. A public statement is now needed to confirm that it will live up to the promise of this suggestion.

This legislation should not only apply to the brokering of arms to embargoed destinations, as suggested in the government's white paper on strategic export controls. To prevent arms getting into the hands of wanton killers, each individual deal made by brokers to any country, embargoed or not, should require a licence.

British arms dealers Miltech brokered the export of at least six shipments of guns from Albania to Zaire in 1994, a country at the time not subject to any embargo. The weapons were then shipped across the border and used in the Rwandan genocide.

Licensing individual arms deals to all countries could have stopped those shipments and helped prevent a catastrophe, as well as a British company's complicity in genocide.

Kate Allen
Amnesty International UK Stewart Wallis
International Director, Oxfam

fields.headline: Mozambique's agony
fields.standfirst:
An immense calamity. A pitiful response

More about the floods in Mozambique
Listen to Chris McGreal in Mozambique
fields.trailText:
An immense calamity. A pitiful response

More about the floods in Mozambique
Listen to Chris McGreal in Mozambique
fields.body:
President Clinton recently praised Mozambique as the fastest growing economy in Africa. The words were barely out of his mouth before the rain of Cyclone Eline began to fall. The savage cruelty which lies behind the terrible pictures of families clinging with their belongings to tree tops is that in the last 10 years, Mozambique had emerged as one of Africa's most striking success stories. For the last three years, it has had economic growth rates of over 10% per annum. It had become the model for countries trying to recover from civil war as it succeeded in putting the ravages of a 16-year war behind it. Mozambique shot to the top of the queue for debt relief; only last August, the Paris Club of lenders agreed to cancel a large tranche of debt. Now, these considerable achievements on the part of one of the poorest countries in the world are at severe risk of being wiped out. The floodwater is due to rise again today and for thousands of Mozambicans crowded on to roofs and islands of dry land, this means almost certain death.

Given the scale of the catastrophe, now two weeks in the making, the response of the international community has been pitiable. Until recently, there were only a paltry five helicopters rescuing those stranded; that number has now increased to 12 but it is still woefully inadequate. Clare Short, the secretary of state for international development, insisted in the House of Commons on Monday that the difficulty in finding more helicopters is logistical not financial; the ministry of defence says the opposite. What makes this confusion so depressing is that the urgent need for helicopters is obvious - and yet not even that is being met. Less obvious but equally urgent will be the need for seeds and tools for planting as soon as the flood waters sub side; Mozambique has two more months left of its planting season. If no crops are planted, hundreds of thousands villagers will be dependent on food aid for a year. And beyond that begins the work of reconstructing the roads, rebuilding the schools and health clinics into which the Mozambican government had recently pumped so much investment.

How badly this catastrophe sets Mozambique back depends entirely on the quality of the international relief effort. With appropriate and prompt support now, a package of debt cancellation - Mozambique is still paying $1.3m a week in interest payments - and long-term aid, it could overcome the floods. But there is a real danger that as western bureaucrats squabble, this could develop into a body-blow from which it could take the country decades to recover. It is all a matter of political will. The threat is that after the dramatic pictures have faded from television screens, the pressure on Ms Short, her counterparts and the international agencies will be off. Mozambique will be left to struggle - rather like the Honduras after Hurricane Mitch or the eastern states of India after the floods there - with unfulfilled promises.

The bigger picture confronting the international community is that climate change is bringing increasingly erratic and violent weather patterns - and we know that they hit poor countries disproportionately hard. California or the Netherlands can invest in sophisticated defence systems as sea levels rise, but Bangladesh cannot. Investment in disaster preparedness has to become an international responsibility. For the last three years, it has had economic growth rates of over 10% per annum. It had become the model for countries trying to recover from civil war as it succeeded in putting the ravages of a 16-year war behind it. webTitle: Nato derails UN scheme for Mitrovice

fields.headline: Nato derails UN scheme for Mitrovice
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: An ambitious UN plan to reunite ethnically divided Mitrovice, in part by arresting paramilitaries and ringing the Kosovan city with checkpoints to control access by hardliners, has been scuttled because key Nato governments are not ready to mount foot patrols for fear of suffering casualties.
fields.body:
An ambitious UN plan to reunite ethnically divided Mitrovice, in part by arresting paramilitaries and ringing the Kosovan city with checkpoints to control access by hardliners, has been scuttled because key Nato governments are not ready to mount foot patrols for fear of suffering casualties.

According to well placed sources, the French commander who runs the northern sector of Kosovo that includes Mitrovice, General Pierre de Saquis de Sannes, has not yet complied with an urgent request from General Klaus Reinhardt, the commander of the international peacekeeping force, K-For, to start "robust, dismounted, community-based operations".

Instead, Gen De Saquis de Sannes is continuing the less risky option of armoured vehicle patrols and static guard positions.

The damaging dispute has highlighted the chaotic chain of command within K-For, whose commanders prefer to take final orders from their national governments.

The glaring inadequacies in K-For's continuity have become such a sore spot for the force's command that General Silvio Mazzarolli, the Italian deputy commander of K-For, was hastily withdrawn to Italy a few days ago when he criticised it publicly.

Bernard Kouchner, the French former minister who heads the UN mission in Kosovo, has had frequent arguments with Paris.

Shocked by the violence of the past few weeks in Mitrovice, and determined to prevent the city's postwar division hardening into a partition, he has completed a four-stage plan which was shown yesterday to senior ethnic Albanian politicians in the joint administrative council. The plan has also been given to Oliver Ivanovic, the leader of the Serb national council in northern Mitrovice.

It aims to seal off the city with a few well controlled access points on the north and south sides to stop gun running by Serbs and Albanians.

Extra international police and troops would patrol regularly and conduct "intrusive" weapons searches in people's homes.

Street demonstrations would be restricted, and known extremists such as the Serbs who patrol the main bridge with walkie-talkies would be expelled from the city. The cafe Dolce Vita, where Serb hardliners gather at the northern edge of the main bridge, would be shut down.

The UN would assign several foreign judges under high security to convict and sentence trouble-makers and an extra detention centre would be set up. The later stages of the plan foresee a joint Serb-Albanian council for the reunited city.

UN officials feel the plan must be put into action fast and are angry with K-For's hesitation. "[Kosovo Liberation Army] pressure on K-For is very strong. It is making veiled threats for another march on the north, and this time to force their way through. K-For is not prepared to stop them properly," said one senior UN official.

The US has also not yet complied with the K-For commander's request for foot patrols in northern Mitrovice. Germany, too, is unwilling to supply police for the city.

fields.headline: Cycle of opportunity
fields.standfirst: Jobs are on offer - if you can get there
fields.trailText: The statistics say it all. Unemployment is at a 20-year low but there are still far too many pockets of very high unemployment. Yet, as Gordon Brown emphasised yesterday, areas of high unemployment nearly always lie within easy travelling distance of areas where vacancies - and there are a million of them nationwide - are plentiful. The story is the same in London, where the worst three unemployment black spots happen to be (Haringey, Newham and Lewisham) or Liverpool, or the north-east. A typical example is the 32-year-old Welshman quoted in yesterday's Guardian who had been unemployed for a year. He knew there were jobs nearby, but claimed he needed transport because he could not afford a car.
fields.body:
The statistics say it all. Unemployment is at a 20-year low but there are still far too many pockets of very high unemployment. Yet, as Gordon Brown emphasised yesterday, areas of high unemployment nearly always lie within easy travelling distance of areas where vacancies - and there are a million of them nationwide - are plentiful. The story is the same in London, where the worst three unemployment black spots happen to be (Haringey, Newham and Lewisham) or Liverpool, or the north-east. A typical example is the 32-year-old Welshman quoted in yesterday's Guardian who had been unemployed for a year. He knew there were jobs nearby, but claimed he needed transport because he could not afford a car.

Maybe high unemployment in Newham, where Mr Brown spoke yesterday, is partly due to the cost of travelling on the underground. Maybe more jobless people would be attracted to work if the minimum wage were raised to help them pay their fares. Maybe people are unaware of the incentives now available, such as the working families tax credit that guarantees every working family more than £10,000 a year. We do not know exactly why it is that unfilled vacancies are so often juxtaposed with unemployment - which is why the government's focus on micro- rather than macroeconomic policies is doubly welcome (especially when the national economy is almost on automatic pilot). There are now so many job incentives that it must be almost as bewildering for the people eligible for them as it is for analysts trying to calculate how much of the decline in unemployment is due to them and how much to the cyclical recovery of the economy.

Initially, the government leaned quite heavily on policies inherited from the Tories, but it has now developed its own distinctive approach. No government in recent memory has combined such a genuine concern for encouraging people back into jobs with such well thought out measures to achieve it. Next month it will provide targeted support for 15 areas of high long-term unemployment with programmes tailored to individual needs. Ministers resent being accused of going back to a Tory "on your bike" culture. But this does not mean bikes should not play a part. There is, after all, a huge difference between being told to get on your bike to find a job, and using it to travel once you have found one.

webTitle: Barak hints at exit from Golan heights

fields.headline: Barak hints at exit from Golan heights
fields.standfirst:
Israel and the Middle East: special report

Cryptic remark may be enough to kick-start Israel's peace talks with Syria
fields.trailText: Israel and Syria were edging towards the resumption of stalled peace talks yesterday after the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, gave indications of a major concession over the Golan heights.
fields.body:
Israel and Syria were edging towards the resumption of stalled peace talks yesterday after the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, gave indications of a major concession over the Golan heights.

Syria gave a cautious welcome to Mr Barak's comments, which pave the way for an Israeli withdrawal from the long-disputed territory.

The talks broke up in January when Syria refused to go further until Israel gave a commitment to restore the Golan, which it has held since the 1967 war.

Mr Barak told a cabinet meeting on Sunday that the previous four Israeli prime ministers had been prepared to withdraw from the territory, in comments which suggested this was an endorsement of the position he was now about to take. He made the remarks knowing they would be made public.

Reports that a date for renewed talks had already been set for later this month were treated with scepticism by British, US and Israeli diplomats yesterday. But both US and British diplomatic sources interpreted Mr Barak's cryptic remarks as sufficient to get the process under way again.

Tensions within the Israeli government over the best way forward spilled over yesterday when the country's minister for internal security, Shlomo Ben-Ami, confirmed that he and three other senior figures were sceptical about reaching an accord with Syria.

Mr Ben-Ami, speaking in London, stressed the difficulties of doing business with a "hermetically sealed" state such as Syria, so long the standard-bearer in the ideological conflict against Zionism.

In contrast to Mr Barak, Mr Ben-Ami said he did not believe Israel could take part in peace talks with both Syria and the Palestinians at once. Mr Barak reiterated yesterday that he would pursue both tracks, but Mr Ben-Ami favoured concentrating on negotiations with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. He said his view was shared by three ministers: the former prime minister Shimon Peres, Yossi Beilin and Haim Ramon.

Asked whether there had been any response from Syria to Mr Barak's concession, Mr Ben-Ami carefully avoided answering, lending credence to speculation that a resumption of the US-brokered talks was being discussed behind the scenes.

A senior Arab diplomatic source in Amman was reported as saying yesterday: "Syrian-Israeli negotiations will resume after Eid al-Adha in the United States. An announcement is expected to that effect in the next 10 days or so." The four-day Muslim holiday, which depends on the sighting of the moon, is expected to end by March 20.

Syrian radio yesterday welcomed Mr Barak's comments but added it was insufficient for a resumption of talks. The same line was taken in newspapers controlled by the Syrian government, which described Mr Barak's comments as important but failing to go far enough.

The Golan heights are an emotive issue with Israelis, who fear they might be used for shelling Israeli villages. Israel wants to maintain a monitoring station there but Syria has refused.

Any settlement with Syria would require a referendum, and Israel's parliament, the Knesset, is due to vote tonight on opposition proposals that would mean acceptance would require a majority of all eligible voters - a result which would be difficult to secure.

Mr Ben-Ami said that whatever happened with Syria, Israel will pull out of Lebanon by July at the latest.

Given that Israel was fulfilling the terms of a UN security council resolution, he said he expected the international community to ensure its border was respected. If not, Israel maintained the right to self-defence, suggesting Syria would be the target of any retaliation.

The prospects for a resumption of Israeli negotiations with Mr Arafat continued to look bleak yesterday. The US Middle East envoy, Dennis Ross, left the region on Monday, having failed on a mission to solve a month-long impasse between Israel and the Palestinians.

Part of the conflict is a dispute over 6.1% of West Bank land that Israel was to hand over to the Palestinians.

Mr Arafat, who met the European commission president, Romano Prodi, in Gaza yesterday, said Israel was responsible for Mr Ross's failure.

fields.headline: Bradley facing knockout blow
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Senator John McCain of Arizona and Governor George W Bush of Texas were on course to divide the electoral spoils in yesterday's latest Republican presidential primary contests in Virginia and Washington state last night, but the Democratic hopeful Bill Bradley looked set to lose a last-ditch gamble to reignite his flagging campaign against Al Gore.
fields.body:
Senator John McCain of Arizona and Governor George W Bush of Texas were on course to divide the electoral spoils in yesterday's latest Republican presidential primary contests in Virginia and Washington state last night, but the Democratic hopeful Bill Bradley looked set to lose a last-ditch gamble to reignite his flagging campaign against Al Gore.

Opinion polls taken before yesterday's primaries gave Mr Bush the lead over Mr McCain in Virginia, but in Washington Mr McCain was the frontrunner thanks to independent voters' support.

Yesterday's contests pointed to a continuing neck-and-neck contest between the two Republicans heading into next week's crucial "super Tuesday" primaries, in which 16 states will choose their presidential candidates in both parties.

A Gallup national opinion poll showed Mr McCain's approval ratings now exceed Mr Bush's for the first time in the contest, but the Texas governor still leads among core Republican voters, who hold the key in next Tuesday's day of reckoning.

Mr McCain continued to set the agenda on the campaign trail yesterday, attacking Mr Bush for becoming a prisoner of the religious right and warning that the Texas governor could not create a national majority to defeat Mr Gore.

"Too many Americans believe that we've become an exclusionary party rather than an inclusionary one," Mr McCain told reporters. "We have to send a message that we want everybody in, rather than some people out."

Mr McCain told an eve-of-poll rally in Tacoma on Monday night that he was looking for "a big victory in the state of Washington that will send a great message around America and the world".

Mr Bush said earlier in Bellevue that he would reinvigorate his cause by winning the primary in Washington "because I am the one candidate who can speak to education and education reform".

But both candidates signalled that yesterday's contests were stepping stones to the main event on March 7 by spending the day campaigning elsewhere in the US. Mr McCain took his message to voters in the pivotal state of California, while Mr Bush addressed supporters in Ohio and Georgia, which also vote next week.

The big loser in yesterday's battles seemed set to be Mr Bradley. The former New Jersey Democratic senator and one-time basketball star had gambled everything in recent days on gaining an upset pre-super Tuesday advantage over Mr Gore in yesterday's "open" primary in Washington.

Although yesterday was not an official Democratic primary in the north-western state, Washington's unusual election rules placed all the presidential candidates on a common ballot paper yesterday, creating a cross-party "beauty contest" in which Mr Bradley hoped to finish ahead of Mr Gore, who has had a clear advantage in every aspect of the Democratic race so far.

While Mr Gore and the Republican rivals have tried in recent days to take their message to all of the states which vote on March 7, Mr Bradley has spent the whole of the past week campaigning to ambush the vice-president in Washington, in the hope of generating a bounce for his faltering presidential bid.

There was little sign from the polls that Mr Bradley's Washington strategy was likely to bear fruit, while opinion polls in New York, which votes next week and has been seen as Mr Bradley's best super Tuesday hope, showed Mr Gore ahead of his challenger by 52% to 38%.

Mr Bradley's campaign had at first seemed to win over many Democrats dissatisfied with the Clinton administration, but Mr Gore has since responded strongly. If Mr Bradley fails to win any of the March 7 contests - as seems likely - he will come under enormous pressure from the Democratic establishment to abandon his challenge.

webTitle: Christian right gives Bush easy victory

fields.headline: Christian right gives Bush easy victory
fields.trailText: The roller-coaster contest for the Republican party's November 2000 US presidential nomination swung back in favour of George W Bush last night as the Christian right turned out in force to give the Texas governor an easy victory in yesterday's Virginia primary election.
fields.body:
The roller-coaster contest for the Republican party's November 2000 US presidential nomination swung back in favour of George W Bush last night as the Christian right turned out in force to give the Texas governor an easy victory in yesterday's Virginia primary election.

Mr McCain's camp dismissed its loss in Virginia by claiming that Mr Bush was a "regional candidate" who could win in conservative southern states but who could not rally a national, presidency-winning majority.

Mr Bush was the favourite to win yesterday's third contest, the Republican caucuses in North Dakota. But as the Republican battle continues at full tilt into next week's crucial encounters, the Democratic challenger, Bill Bradley, seemed to be losing his last-ditch gamble to revive his challenge to Al Gore in Washington. Mr McCain continued to set the agenda on the campaign trail yesterday, attacking Mr Bush for becoming a prisoner of the religious right and warning that the Texas governor could not create a national majority to defeat Mr Gore. "Too many Americans believe that we've become an exclusionary party rather than an inclusionary one," Mr McCain told reporters. "We have to send a message that we want everybody in, rather than some people out." He told an eve-of-poll rally in Tacoma on Monday night that he was looking for "a big victory in the state of Washington that will send a great message around America." Mr Bush said earlier in Bellevue that he would reinvigorate his cause by winning the primary in Washington "because I am the one candidate who can speak to education and education reform". But both candidates signalled that yesterday's contests were stepping stones to the main event on March 7 by spending the day campaigning elsewhere in the US. Mr McCain took his message to voters in the pivotal state of California, while Mr Bush addressed supporters in Ohio and Georgia, which also vote next week. The big loser in yesterday's battles seemed set to be Mr Bradley. The former New Jersey Democratic senator and one-time basketball star had gambled everything in recent days on gaining an upset pre- super Tuesday advantage over Mr Gore in yesterday's "open" primary in Washington. Although yesterday was not an official Democratic primary in the north-western state, Washington's unusual election rules placed all the presidential candidates on a common ballot paper, creating a cross-party "beauty contest" in which Mr Bradley hoped to finish ahead of the vice-president, who has had a clear advantage in every aspect of the Democratic race so far. While Mr Gore and the Republican rivals have tried in recent days to take their message to all of the states which vote on March 7, Mr Bradley has spent the past week campaigning to ambush Mr Gore in Washington in the hope of reviving his campaign. There was little sign from the polls that Mr Bradley's Washington strategy was likely to bear fruit, while opinion polls in New York, which votes next week and has been seen as his best super Tuesday hope, showed Mr Gore ahead of his challenger by 52% to 38%. Mr Bradley's campaign had at first seemed to win over many Democrats dissatisfied with the Clinton administration, but Mr Gore has since responded strongly. If Mr Bradley fails to win any of the March 7 contests - as seems likely - he will come under enormous pressure from the Democratic establishment to abandon his challenge.

webTitle: Oxford fracas as drink account closed

fields.headline: Oxford fracas as drink account closed
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Police became unexpected guests at an investment bank's recruitment drive for undergraduates at Oxford when discussions about the exchange rate mechanism and deflation became a little too well-oiled.
fields.body:
Police became unexpected guests at an investment bank's recruitment drive for undergraduates at Oxford when discussions about the exchange rate mechanism and deflation became a little too well-oiled.

A generous tab provided by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, whose executives were on their annual hunt for bright sparks, was closed prematurely and several would-be tycoons were refused further drinks.

Economic debate then spilled out into Walton Street - once the home of Thomas Hardy's upright Jude the Obscure - and became physical.

"There was a small fight," said a spokesman for Thames Valley police, "and we stopped it." As in the good old days of Boat Race night, the action was rated as "minimal police involvement" and no names were taken or arrests made.

The evening had earlier seen a banking presentation. But when charging for refills was introduced as a deflationary measure before midnight (though the tab was still below the agreed total), tempers snapped.

"I'm told there were no bankers involved," said Richard Balkwill of Freud's, the restaurant in a converted church which was hired until the small hours by Morgan Stanley. "The scrapping was between people we'd had to stop serving. We called the police to prevent them hurting one another."

The restaurant rated the evening overall a "probable success" in terms of Oxford students showing they had a bit of zing, but Mr Balkwill described student newspaper estimates of an £8,000 tab and individual drink tallies topping £100 as "nonsense - wildly inflated".

A spokesman for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said: "We have been carrying out these evenings at Oxford successfully for many years and just regret that a small number of people took advantage of our hospitality and spoiled the evening for others."
