webTitle: Ex-wife who wed in secret must repay £110,000

fields.headline: Ex-wife who wed in secret must repay £110,000
fields.trailText: A woman aged 54 has to repay her first husband £110,000 in maintenance after England's senior family judge ruled that she had concealed a second marriage to a man 20 years her junior.
fields.body:
A woman aged 54 has to repay her first husband £110,000 in maintenance after England's senior family judge ruled that she had concealed a second marriage to a man 20 years her junior.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss dismissed Beatrice Handschin's claim that a marriage certificate showing she had married Kamel Madjoudj at Hackney registry office, east London, in 1991 was a forgery.

Handschin claimed that Mr Madjoudj had gone through a false marriage ceremony with a woman impersonating her, but Dame Elizabeth, president of the high court's family division, ruled that she had been "clearly lying" and was well aware that if she remarried her £20,000 a year maintenance would come to an end.

Handschin, who was born in Switzerland, will have to reimburse her first husband, Douglas Wilson, sums received from 1991 to 1997, when he received a copy of the marriage certificate from an anonymous source and stopped payments. She will also have to pay interest of some £50,000 and costs estimated at £100,000.

She married Mr Wilson, a businessman, in 1968. She was granted custody of their daughter and two sons when the couple divorced in 1989.

She received £20,000 a year in maintenance, £9,000 a year for the children and the family home, a £400,000 property in Brixworth, near Northampton, free of mortgage.

She claimed that it would have been "ridiculous" for her to marry Mr Madjoudj and that she could not have been in Hackney for the ceremony because she was attending university and visiting the school of one of her sons that day.

Handschin met Mr Madjoudj while he was working at a hotel in Northampton in 1989, when she was 44 and he was 24. They became lovers.

Handschin opened a restaurant with Mr Madjoudj, who had come to Britain in 1985 with no work permit, raising the money by mortgaging her home for £51,000. She continued with her German degree at East Anglia university.

She told the court that he became aggressive and violent towards her. The relationship ended, she claimed, after he phoned her from the restaurant to tell her that he was in love with her daughter, Vanessa, now 26, and wanted to have sex with her and marry her.

Police were called after a serious argument, and Mr Madjoudj produced the marriage certificate. Handschin said this was the first time she had heard about the marriage.

Two handwriting specialists told the court that her signature on the marriage certificate was either genuine or a very clever forgery.

Mr Madjoudj told the court that Handschin had "persuaded him to marry her". He added: "She told me you have to keep it very, very quiet."

The judge said there were significant inconsistencies in Handschin's evidence, "which range from inaccuracy and exaggeration to reckless disregard for the truth and, in some instances, she was clearly lying".

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Baby died lying with parents
fields.body:
Baby died lying with parents

A three-week-old girl suffocated as she lay between her sleeping parents, an inquest heard yesterday. The coroner, Stephen Chan, recorded a verdict of accidental death on Lauren Greenslade of Holloway, north London, who died on September 27 last year.

He said Natalie Jennings and Dean Greenslade, in their 20s, were not aware of the "well documented" risk of placing a baby between two adults "relaxed and under the influence of drink and drugs".

St Pancras coroner's court heard that they had been celebrating their anniversary with drink and cannabis. They arrived home after midnight, having collected Lauren and their other child, two, from Ms Jennings's parents.

Mr Greenslade said in a statement to police that since Lauren "hated" her Moses basket "we put her into bed with us". He awoke to find her lying lifeless face up.

Cannabis 'can kill tumours'

An active ingredient in cannabis may prove to be an effective treatment for brain tumours, according to a study reported yesterday in the journal Nature Medicine.

Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), which causes the cannabis "high", destroyed malignant tumours in laboratory rats, said scientists led by Manuel Guzman at Complutense university, Madrid.

Malignant tumours called gliomas were induced in 45 rats, a third of which were injected with THC and a third with a similar but synthetic cannabinoid, while the remainder were left untreated.

Within 18 days the untreated rats died, but both THC and its synthetic substitute destroyed the tumours in a third of the treated rats over seven days. They prolonged the life of another third by up to six weeks.

Malignant brain tumours are notoriously resistant to treatment. Cannabis compounds are thought to kill tumour cells by inducing programmed cell death, or apoptosis, via a signalling mechanism within the cell. They are already being investigated as treatments for multiple sclerosis, pain and nausea.

Hunt for 6ft crocodile in park pond

A 6ft crocodile is believed to be living in a pond in Heaton Park, Newcastle upon Tyne, where people out walking their dogs have heard the reptile foraging for food.

Police thought it was a hoax call when a passer-by raised the alarm. But the Reptile Trust in Durham has been called in.

Searchers failed to find the creature, but from descriptions they believe the reptile could be a spectacled Cayman alligator.

Peter Heathcote, director of the trust, said: "We are taking these reports very seriously and we would urge anyone who sees this crocodile or alligator to contact us straight away and not to approach it themselves."

Last summer three smaller alligators were brought to the trust after being found across Tyneside. The animals were about 3ft-long but the trust fears others might have been abandoned.

Obesity link to season of birth

A cold snap before birth can lead to obesity, according to research in the International Journal of Obesity. Scientists believe that genes alone may not be to blame for the condition in later life.

They monitored the weights from birth of 1,750 men and women born in Hertfordshire between 1920 and 1930. Although, as in other studies, big babies were likely to make big adults, they discovered this was true only for those born in the first six months of the year. And the relationship between birth weight, body mass index and obesity applied only to those born in this period when the winter was cold.

David Phillips of Southampton university, the report's co-author, said the study tied in with research suggesting that environmental temperature affected weight gain in young animals. It was not known if this was "due to increased food intake, decreased metabolism or a bit of both, and it will be difficult to find out.

"Whatever the explanation, obesity now joins a long list of disorders that exhibit differences in prevalence according to season of birth."

Museum offers taste of the past

The world's first museum gallery devoted to biscuits will open next month, in a town once internationally renowned among the sweet-toothed. Reading in Berkshire was known as Biscuit Town.

Huntley and Palmer was a major employer. The football team was called the Biscuitmen, and the jail, immortalised in the Ballad of Reading Gaol by its most famous inmate, Oscar Wilde, was the Biscuit Box.

The gallery includes an Antarctic biscuit, still in its airtight tin, and emergency biscuits which Captain Scott took on his last disastrous expedition to the South Pole.

Captain Scott's biscuits were a high protein recipe invented by the factory for the explorer. The tin and biscuit are said to have been recovered from their last shelter by an expedition in the 1950s.

The museum's curator of contemporary history, Xavier Pes, has found that the firm was still making biscuits for the return journey from the South Pole in the months before the news of the death of Scott and his team reached England.

The bakery moved to Merseyside in 1976. The Huntley and Palmer gallery opens next month in the museum and concert hall complex in the Victorian town hall, which has had a £14m restoration, with a £4.1m heritage lottery grant.

Mr Pes is compiling oral histories of the works for the gallery.

"You can still stop anyone in the street in Reading, and if they didn't work there their mother or grandmother will have."

The giant works started from a small high street bakery, owned by Mr Huntley, whose dynamic cousin George Palmer joined him from the west country. Mr Pes thinks Huntley would have been quite happy spending his life in his little cake shop.

Palmer invented a galaxy of special biscuits, and became mayor, MP and one of the grandees who helped build the town hall in 1875.

"The factory was so much a part of the town that people still feel a bit lost without it. Many people find the gallery very moving," said Mr Pes.

Youth soap to feature male rape

Male rape and on-screen nudity are to feature in a one-off late night episode of youth soap Hollyoaks.

The Channel 4 series, aimed at teenagers and young adults, will broadcast an hour-long post-watershed instalment focusing on "human sexuality" on March 15.

Among its main story strands will be a first-time sexual encounter, an examination of sex in a long-term relationship and the violent rape of a regular male character by a bully.

While the physical attack on Luke Morgan, played by Gary Lucy, will not be shown on screen, the immediate lead-up to it will.

The 11pm special will show a shaken Luke taking a shower after his ordeal - and younger viewers watching the next day's regular early evening episode will be left in little doubt about what he has endured.

Hollyoaks creator Phil Redmond yesterday defended the episode, saying it aimed to tackle one of the last great social taboos responsibly.

Criticising the recent "dumbing down" of TV in the wake of the setting up of the broadcasting standards commission, he said he wanted to put difficult topics on the "social agenda".

"Again we've picked up the stone and said, 'look what's underneath'," he said. "This is what I wanted to do as a storyteller, in the same way that Alan Bleasdale and Willy Russell want to write about certain things.

"The late night episode of Hollyoaks, as we've done with Brookside, allows us to go a bit further than we can at 6.30." Redmond denied the show's producers were being irresponsible.

This is not the first time Hollyoaks has courted controversy. Last May, it broadcast a lesbian kiss.

webTitle: ME toll on pupils moving to secondary school

fields.headline: ME toll on pupils moving to secondary school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is something that generations of children have long-suspected: beginning "big school" is bad for your health.
fields.body:
It is something that generations of children have long-suspected: beginning "big school" is bad for your health.

The strain of starting secondary school is a major cause of ME in children, according to research published today. The majority of young sufferers get the illness at the age of 11, and three quarters succumb during September and December, coinciding with the first term at their new school.

The findings, in the Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine, were unearthed by psychiatrists and paediatricians at St Mary's and St Thomas' hospitals in London who studied 25 child and adolescent sufferers of chronic fatigue syndrome - more commonly known as ME.

They isolated attending secondary school as the single social factor contributing to the onset of the illness, which afflicted each patient, aged 12-19, for an average three years, with each sufferer missing a year of school on average. Only one in five sufferers came from a single parent family, and three quarters were from an upper middle class background.

Elizabeth Garralda, professor of child and adolescent psychiatry at Imperial College, London, who headed the research, said: "This would seem to suggest little evidence to suggest social stress other than secondary school entry."

Professor Garralda added that the stress of attending secondary school did not in itself prompt the illness, which causes profound fatigue, insomnia, aches and pains, and mental slowness.

"In general, chronic fatigue syndrome affects children who are already unwell because of a flu-type illness or glandular fever," she said. "We believe it's probably the combination of being very unwell plus the stress of having to adapt to secondary school plus probably some biological and psychological vulnerabilities which cause it.

"This has never been brought out before and it's very intriguing."

She added that while half attended public school - with half of these being boarders - it was impossible to deduce whether such schooling proved more stressful.

"These findings are probably more related to the fact that people in this socioeconomic group are more likely to be persistent in contacting their doctors if their children are suffering from symptoms," she said.

"On the other hand, many of these children are high achievers who put themselves under pressure to do well."

She said it was difficult to determine which treatment had had the best effect, since so many had been tried: 56% of the children had tried alternative medicine and 52% psychological treatment.

fields.headline: Cell TVs reward young offenders
fields.standfirst: Jails watchdog praises incentive scheme for good behaviour
fields.trailText: An incentive scheme that offers young offenders privileges including Gameboys, in-cell television and camping and canoeing trips in return for good behaviour has helped transform a troubled juvenile jail, a report from the chief inspector of prisons reveals today.
fields.body:
An incentive scheme that offers young offenders privileges including Gameboys, in-cell television and camping and canoeing trips in return for good behaviour has helped transform a troubled juvenile jail, a report from the chief inspector of prisons reveals today.

Sir David Ramsbotham says the incentive scheme was "very impressive" and had helped implement a major overhaul at Werrington young offenders' institution, near Stoke-on-Trent, which 18 months ago he had described as a disgrace.

About 25 of the 106 young offenders at Werrington who have reached the top level of the privileges and incentives scheme are allowed to have Nintendo computer games consoles in their cells.

Inmates pay £2 a week to hire the consoles, bought out of the proceeds of a refreshment stall used by visitors. The jail also has four Gameboys which are given out each week to inmates who have behaved particularly well.

The chief inspector said that the attractions of television and computer games were used as the prime incentives to ensure a well behaved population at Werrington and, together with an effective anti-bullying scheme, were impressive examples of good practice.

Each cell had also been equipped with a television which carried the five terrestrial channels plus a video channel.

Prison staff monitor the content of programmes and any deemed unsuitable on grounds of sex or violence were either replaced by a video or switched off if it was late in the evening.

Staff also organised "leadership expeditions" which consisted of about a dozen young offenders taking part in activities such as rock climbing, cross-country cycling trips, camping, and canoeing.

"These were not expensive junkets, but challenging episodes in the individual young person's lives where they were subtly introduced to the concepts of teamwork, individual responsibility, achievement, dealing with failure and helping others through the process," said Sir David.

Big improvement at the juvenile training centre had also been achieved by reducing its population by nearly half from 180 to 102, a new injection of resources and staff and support from prison service headquarters.

A prison service spokesman said: "The computer sets are only given out as a reward for very good behaviour. If their marks slip, they are taken away and the offenders know it.

"Staff are very pleased with the way it is working and say it's something the lads really respond to."

When the chief inspector of prisons visited Werrington in 1998 he published a scathing report in which he said teenage offenders had to eat their food in their cells, which were little more than lavatories.

He said that the overcrowded conditions in which teenagers were kept in pairs in cells meant for one were so disgraceful that were Werrington to be a social services secure custody unit, it would have been closed for lack of provision of appropriate facilities.

Sir David Ramsbotham says the incentive scheme was "very impressive" and had helped implement a major overhaul at Werrington young offenders' institution, near Stoke-on-Trent, which 18 months ago he had described as a disgrace. About 25 of the 106 young offenders at Werrington who have reached the top level of the privileges and incentives scheme are allowed to have Nintendo computer games consoles in their cells. Inmates pay £2 a week to hire the consoles, bought out of the proceeds of a refreshment stall used by visitors. The jail also has four Gameboys which are given out each week to inmates who have behaved particularly well. The chief inspector said that the attractions of television and computer games were used as the prime incentives to ensure a well behaved population at Werrington and, together with an effective anti-bullying scheme, were impressive examples of good practice. webTitle: Speed limit to end power boating on Windermere

fields.headline: Speed limit to end power boating on Windermere
fields.trailText: Water skiers and jetski enthusiasts are to be banned from the Lake District national park after the government approved a local council bylaw which imposed a 10mph speed limit on Windermere.
fields.body:
Water skiers and jetski enthusiasts are to be banned from the Lake District national park after the government approved a local council bylaw which imposed a 10mph speed limit on Windermere.

The decision concludes a bitter eight-year battle between environmentalists, local residents, national park authorities, sport enthusiasts and businesses.

The spat has involved a 13-week public inquiry with 3,000 written representations, a controversial decision by the then Conservative environment secretary, John Gummer, to reject the recommendations, a high court appeal, and a review by the department of the environment.

Chris Mullin, the junior environment minister who approved the law, said: "I can understand that it will disappoint those who will no longer be able to enjoy the lake in power boats or on skis, and it will cause concern to some businesses. But I am satisfied that the speed limit is justified".

Yesterday, Sir Chris Bonington, mountaineer and president of the council of national parks, said the speed limit, which will not come into force until March 2005, would stop "noisy and dangerous sports" on Windermere.

"Most people come to the Lake District national park for quiet enjoyment and we are delighted that the government has recognised how important this is," he said.

The Friends of the Lake District, a local campaigning group, was equally pleased. "The huge majority of lake users and many local residents will be absolutely delighted," said Ian Brodie, its director.

"People will now be able to appreciate the full beauty of this corner of the national park."

However, Sport England, the statutory government agency which has long lobbied to prevent the speed limit being imposed, was disappointed.

"Consistently, before, at and since the Windermere inquiry, we have proposed that use of Windermere for water skiing and power boating could have been managed effectively to complement other usage of the lake and its surrounds," a spokesman said.

"We are disappointed that a managed approach has not been agreed. This is to the detriment of water skiers and power boaters who have used the lake for generations", he added.

Windermere is the only lake in the national park where power boats are allowed. The ban is not expected to extend to sailing boats which travel faster than 10mph.

webTitle: Call for world to police GM science

fields.headline: Call for world to police GM science
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The public had lost trust in genetically modified foods and the only way to restore it was to set up a world body to police biotechnology, the government's chief food safety adviser said yesterday.
fields.body:
The public had lost trust in genetically modified foods and the only way to restore it was to set up a world body to police biotechnology, the government's chief food safety adviser said yesterday.

Sir John Krebs, who is chairing the Edinburgh conference on GM food safety, said that the new body should monitor the multinationals and advise governments on consumer safety and ethics. His call was backed by Sir Robert May, the government's chief scientific adviser, and John Durant, head of science communication at the Science Museum.

Professor Durant said: "There is a crisis of credibility for policy makers. There should be no hidden agendas. There should be clear and specific reasons for policy being made behind closed doors. In Britain we have the opposite. In my view that is the wrong way round."

He welcomed Tony Blair's call at the weekend for open and transparent decisions. "We need to change the culture. The policy makers got it wrong. GM food is a socially sensitive technology. It is significantly out of step with public opinion, or has become so."

Sir John, who is chairman of the government's new food agency, said that, in his end of conference report today, he would recommend the world body be set up, and he hoped it would be accepted by the G8 countries when they met in Japan in July.

The government's chief scientific adviser, Sir Robert May, also attending the conference, said he was keen on the idea. "We need a consensus among scientists round the world about what is acceptable and what is safe." It should be like the intergovernmental panel on climate change set up by the United Nations to advise governments, and he would recommend the idea to the prime minister. "On climate change we have 170 countries giving their views, and all-embracing input and opinion; we need the same for bio-technology, a world body that can point the way forward."

The two were not clear on who should run the body, but Sir John said it was essential that the developing countries played a key role. The conference had heard from Zhang-liang Chen of Beijing university that China had 23% of the world population but only 7% of the land surface; without GM agriculture China would not be able to feed its people. However, Suman Sahair from India had said that his country could see no benefits, only threats to sustainable farming from sterile seeds and multinationals trying to corner the world food market.

Sir John commented: "We have to get these people together, and those from Africa, who want the technology to grow crops on dry land, and Greenpeace, which wants a worldwide moratorium on the whole science, and get to the bottom of the arguments.

"We need industry, regulators, scientists, consumers, and we need to consider ethics, values and beliefs, issues of world trade, intellectual property rights, and exploitation of the developing world. By ironing out these problems and reaching a consensus then politicians can decide the way forward."

Sir Robert, who is a fan of genetic engineering but believes scientists should proceed with caution, said a second generation of GM products was needed that would provide something that the public wanted; shoppers had no wish to buy GM products because there was no gain but there was a potential risk. If there was an incentive because there was a gain, it would be a different matter. He gave as an example mobile phones: there was a potential risk but a great gain in convenience, so people were prepared to accept them.

For the developed world, GM peanuts from which proteins that caused serious allergic reactions had been removed would present such an advantage; for the developing world, there was "golden" rice with added vitamin A, which would prevent deficiencies in millions of poor people.

In Britain, how genetic engineering affected the wellbeing of the countryside needed to be addressed, said Sir Robert. Did it bring even more intensive agriculture, or less use of herbicide and insecticide?

"We can use this technology in different ways. We need to address food safety, rethink the effect on the countryside, and consult the consumer, we need to get away from fixed positions and reach a consensus."

webTitle: Hidden risks of grafting genes into foodstuffs

fields.headline: Hidden risks of grafting genes into foodstuffs
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Food allergies which can kill pose a risk when genes from other plants and animals are grafted into foodstuffs without the consumer knowing, Carston Bindslev-Jensen told the conference. He said if a fish or nut gene was grafted into a tomato it would not affect the look of the salad but it might kill a person with a serious allergy to fish or nuts.
fields.body:
Food allergies which can kill pose a risk when genes from other plants and animals are grafted into foodstuffs without the consumer knowing, Carston Bindslev-Jensen told the conference. He said if a fish or nut gene was grafted into a tomato it would not affect the look of the salad but it might kill a person with a serious allergy to fish or nuts.

The professor, of the university of Southern Denmark, cited as an example a brazil nut gene grafted into soya beans by Monsanto to make a superfeed for chickens. "It was very good for chickens but some of the nut genes passed into the chickens and could have have caused a serious problem if they had been eaten by people with an allergy to brazil nuts. They would never have known what caused their illness." Fortunately, he said, Monsanto abandoned the project.

His research team was experimenting to see if GM food did produce allergic reaction in people. So far he had found none, but his work was at an early stage.

So far, where genes had been spliced into a novel food the chances of allergic reaction were known. "Where we need to worry is where grass genes or dog genes, or from any species we don't normally eat, are added to something in our normal diet."

webTitle: Pilot dazzled by millennium wheel laser

fields.headline: Pilot dazzled by millennium wheel laser
fields.trailText: The pilot of an airliner bound for Heathrow was dazzled by a laser from the millennium wheel as he flew down the Thames on his approach to the airport.
fields.body:
The pilot of an airliner bound for Heathrow was dazzled by a laser from the millennium wheel as he flew down the Thames on his approach to the airport.

None of the passengers on board the packed British Midland Boeing 737 was aware of the problem, but the pilot reported the incident to the civil aviation authority after landing.

The pilot said he was "temporarily dazzled by a searchlight type beam" near the British Airways London Eye wheel.

The CAA discovered that lasers (above) were being set up for the millennium celebrations. Its report said the lasers were normally switched off whenever an aircraft was near.

But on the night of December 29, "there was so much aerial activity over the river that nobody could differentiate between press helicopters or anything else. The lights have now been removed."

The CAA said last night that the issue of lasers and searchlights over cities was now so serious that air regulatory authorities worldwide were discussing how to tackle the problem.

BA said yesterday that the lasers had been cleared "with the relevant authorities including the CAA", and were discontinued immedi ately after the celebrations. The CAA said that the lights were removed before the complaint was investigated. It was unable to confirm whether BA had contravened an air safety order.

webTitle: Whelan turns fact to fiction with TV spin on New Labour

fields.headline: Whelan turns fact to fiction with TV spin on New Labour
fields.trailText: The plot is a real pot boiler. A senior Labour politician is forced to resign in a financial scandal that also claims the job of his old adversary, a spin doctor.
fields.body:
The plot is a real pot boiler. A senior Labour politician is forced to resign in a financial scandal that also claims the job of his old adversary, a spin doctor.

Within a year however, the politician is back in the cabinet but the spin doctor remains outside the fold, so he takes revenge by writing a supposedly fictional TV series blowing the lid off his old party's exploits.

But this is fact, not fiction. A little over a year after he was forced to step down as Gordon Brown's loyal press secretary in the wake of the Peter Mandelson home loan scandal, Charlie Whelan is about to set the Labour leadership's teeth on edge once again, through TV drama.

The former spin doctor turned media commentator has been asked to co-write a series for ITV based on the in ner machinations of his old party that is being billed as a Labour version of Michael Dobbs's hugely successful House of Cards adaptations.

The project, the working title of which is New Babe on the Block, centres around a newly elected female Labour MP, who schemes her way up the party's greasy poll using a steamy combination of sex and intrigue.

The characters will, of course, be fictitious. Take Bobby for example, the senior cabinet minister with a little dog called Peter. No resemblance at all to Mr Whelan's traditional sparring partner, Peter (Mandelson), the senior cabinet minister whose dog, coincidentally, is called Bobby.

House of Cards did little to enhance the reputation of the political class.

But insiders say the Labour drama, co-written with producer Mark Redhead and likely to be screened before the next election, could be far more embarrassing for the party leadership.

"House of Cards was about an unreal world," a source said last night. "Charlie and Mark want this to have a flavour of New Labour, to give a taste of what it's really like in there."

A friend of Mr Whelan went further. "It's going to blow the lid on what's going on, with all the machinations, money and sex."

But sources insist that the series will not be a trashy, tabloid take on Labour. Mr Redhead's factual drama credits include the Murder of Stephen Lawrence, screened last February, and This is Personal, which dealt with the hunt for the Yorkshire Ripper.

Mr Whelan, who is expected to be paid "well into five figures", is believed to have been approached by Mr Redhead because of his inside knowledge of New Labour and his sardonic take on politics.

fields.headline: Times libel 'shattered' composer
fields.standfirst: Diary accused 'romantic futurist' of organising hecklers to wreck performances by atonal modernists
fields.trailText: A high court libel jury was told yesterday that a composer was shattered when he read an item in the Times diary that described him as "slushy" and accused him of organising hecklers to wreck performances of atonal music by modernists.
fields.body:
A high court libel jury was told yesterday that a composer was shattered when he read an item in the Times diary that described him as "slushy" and accused him of organising hecklers to wreck performances of atonal music by modernists.

Keith Burstein, described as having undergone a conversion from the modernist style to what he calls "romantic futurist", feared the article would put him out of work, his friend, the journalist Edward Pearce, told the court.

The jury is being asked to assess the damages payable to Mr Burstein for what he claimed was a serious libel in a "newspaper of record which people trust to get it right". Judge Richard Walker has ruled, as a matter of law, that the words complained of were libellous, and the jury is only concerned with the amount of compensation.

The diary item, in June 1997, referred to a forthcoming memorial concert for the late Labour leader John Smith. It said: "The music is by Keith Burstein, an aggressively self-righteous, rather slushy composer who used to organise bands of hecklers to go about wrecking performances of modern atonal music, particularly anything by Sir Harrison Birtwistle."

Mr Pearce told the court: "[Mr Burstein] was seriously shocked and shattered anyone should accuse him of some thing that bore no relation to anything he had ever thought of doing. He was anxious about the effect on the sort of people who would commission his work - musical and choral societies and perhaps string quartets. He was quite frightened that, with a slur like that, he might be unsaleable."

David Price, solicitor advocate for Mr Burstein, told the court the diary had suggested his client was the ringleader of the hecklers and was guilty of anti-social behaviour, verging on the criminal. "When a musician is accused in the Times of wrecking performances, what right-thinking person in the world of music would wish to associate himself or herself with someone like that?"

Mr Burstein had immediately complained about the article, but the Times had re fused to apologise and offered the "nominal" sum of £500 to settle the action.

Mr Pearce told the court that his friend was distressed by the "arrogance" of letters from the newspaper's solicitor, who effectively said: "Who are you, little man. To hell with you."

Cross-examined by Justin Rushbrooke, counsel for the Times, Mr Pearce agreed Mr Burstein had undergone a conversion from the modernist style of music and now described himself as "romantic futurist".

"He reached the conclusion in about 1990 that that style of music was not for him and he reverted to the schools which go back to Schumann and through to Elgar - music with harmony, the more melodic sort. He believes passionately in that sort of music, and that the era of modernism has shot its bolt."

Mr Pearce added that Mr Burstein was a quiet, softly-spoken person who led a monastic life and was "utterly serious" about his music - "I got him to go to his first football match only two weeks ago".

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Terrorism act raid on bookshop
fields.trailText: A man was being questioned last night following raids by West Midlands police and MI5 officers on two houses and a bookshop in Birmingham.
fields.body:
A man was being questioned last night following raids by West Midlands police and MI5 officers on two houses and a bookshop in Birmingham.

In a terse statement, the force said the searches had begun yesterday morning with 40 to 50 officers and had been executed under the prevention of terrorism act.

A spokesman said the warrants were issued in connection with "links to terrorist offences which have been committed outside the United Kingdom. One person was arrested in connection with firearms offences and the investigations are on-going".

Police refused to give any further details, but the Maktabah al Ansaar bookshop in Sparkbrook was the subject of one raid. It sells books such as The Virtues of Jihad, Declaration of War, and Dissent of the Muslim Lands. Several cars in the area were also searched.

Although the police refused to elaborate, it is thought that the raids are connected with the conviction of eight Britons last summer in the Yemen as part of a plot by Islamic fundamentalists to bomb targets in Aden.

Among the eight, Mohammed Mustafa Kamel, 17, the son of Abu Hamza, a radical cleric in north London, was alleged to have masterminded the plot, and was given a three year sentence. Mohsin Ghai-lan, 18, stepson of Abu Hamza, received seven years. The eight and their families have vigorously protested their innocence throughout.

Although the police refused to elaborate, it is thought that the raids are connected with the conviction of eight Britons last summer in the Yemen as part of a plot by Islamic fundamentalists to bomb targets in Aden. Among the eight, Mohammed Mustafa Kamel, 17, the son of Abu Hamza, a radical cleric in north London, was alleged to have masterminded the plot, and was given a three year sentence. Mohsin Ghai-lan, 18, stepson of Abu Hamza, received seven years. The eight and their families have vigorously protested their innocence throughout.

webTitle: Blunkett urged to ease up on lifelong learning

fields.headline: Blunkett urged to ease up on lifelong learning
fields.standfirst: Woodhead warns against moral authoritarianism
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, last night warned education ministers against "moral authoritarianism" in their campaign to produce a nation of lifelong learners.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, last night warned education ministers against "moral authoritarianism" in their campaign to produce a nation of lifelong learners.

He said the government was treading a fine line between encouraging adults to continue their education and forcing them to pursue academic and vocational courses that they did not find rewarding.

"Opportunities to learn should not be turned into impositions to be obeyed," he said in his annual lecture. "If individuals are ignorant and slothful and are happy in their ignorance and sloth, then if we are talking about their leisure time I can only say so be it."

Mr Woodhead was commenting on a speech in January by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, calling for people of all ages to be engaged with learning to produce "communities once again proud of their self-determination".

That was "a utopian ideal", desirable but unachievable, said Mr Woodhead. He stopped short of outright criticism of Mr Blunkett but made fun of Malcolm Wicks, further education minister, for praising a 107-year-old who was still involved in lifelong learning.

"I have some sympathy with the 25% of 85-plus-year-olds who said they had done enough learning and ... the 22% who said simply that they were too old. Some non-learners even confessed to liking to spend time with their grandchildren. Shame on them!"

Although this was a trivial point, it raised fundamental questions, he said. "What is lifelong learning realistically going to achieve and against what timetable? ... Do we want the state to involve itself in our individual decisions as to what we learn and how we play?"

Mr Woodhead warned ministers against "talking up" vocational courses by pretending they were the same as academic study. "We must recognise that different courses are needed to meet the needs of different kinds of student."

It was a mistake to try to persuade every 16-year-old to stay in full-time education. Some were better off going into a job with apprenticeship training.

But he welcomed the government's conversion to "intelligent" expansion of the universities. Instead of trying to produce more graduates with full degrees, ministers wanted two-year programmes oriented to "employability skills, specialist knowledge and broad understanding needed in the new economy".

Expanding higher education should not be an end in itself. It was vital that every student had a reasonable chance of completing the qualification successfully.

Currently one in five students dropped out. "This is no good - no good for the individual or the taxpayer," he said.

 The Local Government Association last night launched a pre-emptive strike against Mr Blunkett's plan to shame 400 secondary schools in which less than a quarter of pupils got five good passes at GCSE.

He is expected to say today that they should be doing far better, despite having many pupils from poor families.

But the association said their teachers "should be supported, not publicly humiliated". It was backed by local authority education officers, who said the government was underestimating the link between poverty and poor school performance.

webTitle: Government aims to halve deaths of child pedestrians

fields.headline: Government aims to halve deaths of child pedestrians
fields.trailText: A target of halving serious road accidents involving child pedestrians will form part of a package of government measures to be unveiled today, aimed at making speeding as socially unacceptable as drink-driving.
fields.body:
A target of halving serious road accidents involving child pedestrians will form part of a package of government measures to be unveiled today, aimed at making speeding as socially unacceptable as drink-driving.

Tony Blair and the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, will promise to cut the annual toll of child road deaths and serious injuries from an average of around 200 to about 100 by 2010, and by 40% across all ages.

Local authorities will be encouraged to enforce 20mph limits around schools.

Ministers are also looking at delaying the earliest young people can take their tests until six months after their 17th birthday, or raising the driving age to 18. Learners may have to fill in a "log book" showing their experience before taking their test. Other measures include banning drink-drive repeat offenders from driving for two years, and tougher sentences for speeding drivers.

The proposals follow the government's review of road safety, and will be backed with several million pounds of expenditure.

Keith Hill, the junior transport minister, told MPs yesterday: "We have to persuade drivers to slow down, and make speeding as socially unacceptable as drinking and driving."

The government planned a renewed effort to tackle cannabis use by drivers, Mr Hill said. Ministers were considering using a "drugalyser", suggested by Tory MP Ann McIntosh in the Commons yesterday.

Mr Hill said more publicity would be given to the effects of tiredness on drivers, "which we now suspect contributes to 10% of all accidents".

The Tory transport spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, welcomed the thrust of the plans. "The number of road casualties remains intolerable, equivalent to 100 Paddington disasters every year," he said.

The RAC said the target reduction in deaths was ambitious and needed "new and robust measures designed to reduce casualties among, or caused by, the highest risk or most vulnerable groups".

The environmental group Transport 2000 said the government had lost its nerve and had "wimped out" of imposing 20mph limits in all 30mph areas. Lynn Sloman, its assistant director, said: "With this review, it had the chance to make the streets safer for everyone. But apart from minor tinkering, the government does not seem to be prepared to do anything that would have any real effect."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sound news for diabetics
fields.body:
Sound news for diabetics

Life could be made easier for diabetics thanks to a technique which could do away with needles being used to draw blood.

Diabetics sometimes have to draw blood four times a day to test glucose levels. But the new method, pioneered in the US and reported in Nature Medicine, uses ultrasound to extract through the skin a fluid which has the same concentrations of glucose as in blood samples.

Teacher jailed for sex assaults

A former teacher at a public school was jailed yester day for sexually assaulting male pupils. Dennis Fletcher, 50, of Birchington, Kent, who taught French at Junior King's prep school in Canterbury, was given three years at Maidstone crown court.

Fletcher, who admitted seven counts of sexually assaulting children under 16 and making an indecent video, will be placed on the sex offenders' register.

Police may drop shock collars

Police forces have been urged to stop using electric shock collars to train dogs. The move yesterday by the Association of Chief Police Officers follows a review of dog training after the death of police dog Acer in Essex in 1997. Eight forces still use the collars, which deliver an electric shock to dogs when triggered by the handler.

Children hit by lightning

Two children were rushed to hospital last night after reportedly being struck by lightning.

The boy and a girl, both aged about 10, were taken to hospital after the incident in north London. An ambulance spokesman said: "They both seem to have had a lucky escape."

Football fans released

Seven Chelsea fans travelled to Marseille for last night's Champions' League match after being cleared of fighting on the French underground.

They spent more than 14 hours behind bars after fights broke out between English supporters and Frenchmen on Lyon Metro.

Lottery wins unclaimed

Almost £70m worth of National Lottery prizes have gone unclaimed during the past year, including a jackpot worth £1.2m. If prizes are not claimed within 180 days they are distributed to good causes.

fields.headline: Banks agree to cashpoint surcharge
fields.trailText: Cash machine users face charges of at least £1 to withdraw their money after banks and building societies yesterday agreed to new surcharges.
fields.body:
Cash machine users face charges of at least £1 to withdraw their money after banks and building societies yesterday agreed to new surcharges.

The move by members of the Link network of 27,000 cash machines appeared to set them on a collision course with the competition authorities.

The banks and building societies agreed that, from next year, customers of rival companies should be charged for using their cash machines.

The move was pioneered last year by Barclays, which wanted to introduce a £1 surcharge on its rivals' customers when they used its cash machines. That move was blocked until yesterday by the Nationwide building society, which opposes surcharging.

The new agreement will see customers warned on screen that they face an extra cost each time they withdraw cash.

At present, banks such as the Abbey National charge customers up to £1.50 to use cash machines run by most rivals. The Abbey said last night it expected the surcharge to eventually replace "disloyalty" fees.

Barclays insisted that £1 was its "stake in the ground for 2001", defying a recommendation by Don Cruickshank, who was appointed by the chancellor Gordon Brown to scrutinise banks last year, that fees should be no more than 30p.

Any move by the banks to press ahead with charges which appear to make them profits from customers, is likely to prompt action by the competition commission.

webTitle: Tate favourite with a past that belies its tranquillity

fields.headline: Tate favourite with a past that belies its tranquillity
fields.standfirst: First report on the spoliation of works of art during the Holocaust and World War II period
fields.trailText: An 18th century landscape that has been a favourite at the Tate gallery since 1961 has a history which belies its sunny image of an English palace in a tranquil setting.
fields.body:
An 18th century landscape that has been a favourite at the Tate gallery since 1961 has a history which belies its sunny image of an English palace in a tranquil setting.

The painting, A View of Hampton Court Palace, painted by Jan Griffier in 1710 (pictured right), is the only work of art for which a formal claim has been made to a British national collection.

It was lodged with the Tate last year by the three children, all living in England, of the original owner.

Lord Janner, who is advising them, says the case is urgent - the children are elderly, and one is very ill.

The picture was in a small but outstanding collection assembled by a Jewish banker in Düsseldorf. In 1937, when he was shot by the Nazis, his widow managed to get her three young children onto a refugee ship bound for England.

She then packed her pictures and escaped to Belgium. In her years in hiding in Brussels she sold the paintings to buy food, one by one, in the galleries on the Avenue Louise. They would have fetched a pittance - many of the galleries became notorious for their bargain-priced works from forced Jewish sales.

In 1944 she was betrayed, and imprisoned in Mechelen concentration camp. She survived, and in 1946 joined her family in England. She died in 1968.

There was one piece of evidence in the case which Sarah Jackson, a claims officer at the Art Loss Register, said was unique. In 1990 the children found some glass negatives of their mother's paintings, which she had preserved through the war. One of them showed the Tate's Griffier.

The gallery believed its picture was in a private collection in Germany until 1955. It was sold to the friends of the Tate for £400.

webTitle: Brown attacked for using 'fiddled' figures on jobless

fields.headline: Brown attacked for using 'fiddled' figures on jobless
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown was accused last night of performing an "unbelievable somersault" after the chancellor revived the Tories' system for measuring unemployment which Labour condemned as a fiddle in opposition.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown was accused last night of performing an "unbelievable somersault" after the chancellor revived the Tories' system for measuring unemployment which Labour condemned as a fiddle in opposition.

As part of a renewed government drive to cut the jobless figures, the treasury used the "claimant count" system to show that there is virtual parity between job vacancies in Britain and the number of unemployed people.

A chart released by the treasury showed there were 1.1m unemployed people in Britain in January, marginally higher than the number of job vacancies, at just over 1m.

The chancellor, who has set himself a target of achieving full employment, used the figures in yesterday's treasury chart to step up pressure on the unemployed to move into work. "I say to the unemployed who can work - you must now meet your responsibility to earn a wage."

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, last night accused Mr Brown of behaving hypocritically because in opposition Labour attacked the "claimant count" system for providing "fiddled" figures which gave a false impression of low unemployment. In January 1997 Ian McCartney, now a cabinet office minister, said the "totally meaningless" system allowed the Tories to lie "systematically" about unemployment levels.

Before the election, Labour preferred to rely on other systems for measuring unemployment, such as the figures compiled on a system approved by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) which always comes out with a higher figure. In January the ILO estimated there were 1.7m unemployed.

Mr Portillo said: "This unbelievable somersault beggars belief. Mr Brown campaigned against the claimant measurements, with Labour describing them as fiddled figures. But always the opportunist, now the claimant figures look better he is all for them. The public will not mistake the stench of hypocrisy."

A Labour spokesman said: "This is ridiculous. The Tories should welcome the fact that 800,000 more people are in work since Labour came into power and that there are 1m vacancies in the economy. They should also welcome the measures announced today to help the remaining unemployed people get jobs."

The attack will come as an embarrassment to the chancellor who has revived memories of the Norman Tebbit "get on your bike" era with his unequivocal message that many unemployed people have no excuse to remain out of work.

fields.headline: Synod decides to monitor broadcasters
fields.standfirst:
Church of England's concern over transmission times brings unanimous vote to create a team to look at the quality of religious programmes

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England's mounting aggravation with broadcasters boiled over yesterday when the general synod unanimously supported plans to set up a monitoring unit to check the quality of religious programmes.
fields.body:
The Church of England's mounting aggravation with broadcasters boiled over yesterday when the general synod unanimously supported plans to set up a monitoring unit to check the quality of religious programmes.

One bishop suggested that the TV comedy programme Goodness Gracious Me might fall under the church's scrutiny.

Taking exception to last weekend's edition of the show which had Asian couples attempting to join their local church, sampling the communion wine as if it was vintage, bribing the vicar for a better pew and taking exception to a black bishop, the Bishop of Wakefield called for health checks on programmes.

The BBC itself yesterday admitted censoring the programme before it was repeated by cutting the sketch but said it had been shown after the broadcasting watershed.

The Right Reverend Nigel McCulloch, who chairs the churches communications committee, was applauded as he said: "A mechanism for monitoring the provision and quality of religious programmes ... would send out a signal to all broadcasters that we are taking this matter very seriously and systemically.

"Such a body with cooperation from other churches and interested bodies, knowing who is broadcasting what and when, would lead to regular qualitative as well as quantitative assessments.

"This would offer a factual health check and inform the general public debate, covering not just the religious programmes but for example Goodness Gracious Me which was so particularly offensive."

A succession of speakers stresssed they were anxious not to condemn the BBC but insisted that the number of religious programmes had decreased and were being shown at increasingly anti-social hours.

Nigel Holmes, a former BBC local radio producer, told the synod: "What I say is said in love and the words are those of a devotee but BBC network religious radio hours have fallen by an unprecedented 15% in a single year."

Mr Holmes claimed he had received support from Joan Bakewell, who recently resigned as presenter of the Heart of the Matter series, and from Melvyn Bragg who had bemoaned "many missed opportunities" in the sorry state of religious broadcasting.

David Hope, the Archbishop of York and chairman of the ecumenical central religious advisory council, warned: "If we are to restore acts of worship on Sunday morning they need to be of a high standard. Having seen some of them I don't wonder that people turn them off."

Outside the synod the Bishop of Wakefield insisted that a monitoring body would examine all output touching on religious matters including comedy shows and news bulletins.

"I want to make sure every aspect of religious presenta tion is monitored so we can make sure belief is reflected. Goodness Gracious Me touched on the blasphemous," said the bishop, who admitted he had not seen the programme.

A BBC spokeswoman said: "The corporation welcomes the very constructive and intelligent debate at synod although we remain concerned that some criticisms about our religious output are founded on flawed statistics."

The National Secular Society last night warned the church to lay off the BBC. Keith Porteous Wood, its general secretary, said: "The corporation should no longer see it as a prime duty to promote Christianity and the Church of England should not expect to have huge chunks of expensive peak air time allocated to its propaganda."

Unchanging face of BBC religion

Comparison of this week's BBC religious broadcasting schedules and those of 10 years ago show remarkable similarities. Prayer for the Day, the Daily Service, Songs of Praise and even Radio 2's Good Morning Sunday remain in place although timings have changed.

On Sunday February 25 1990 BBC was showing This is the Day: "Linda Mary Evans joins John and Hilary Maitland in their home in Frodsham, Cheshire, for a service of prayer and devotion," at 9.30am. Everyman at 10.10pm was about a white Irishman earning his living as a black actor because his complexion was so dark. Songs of Praise at 6.40pm came from the Houses of Parliament.

Radio 4 had a service at 9.30am from Sussex and Radio 2 had an evening half hour programme from a church in Glasgow.

Last Sunday BBC 1 had the Heaven and Earth Show from 10am-11am, Songs of Praise at 5.20pm and Heart of the Matter at 11.05pm. Radio 4 had Bells on Sunday at 5.50am, the Sunday religious affairs programme at 7.10am and Sunday Worship at 8.07am.

On Sunday February 25 1990 BBC was showing This is the Day: "Linda Mary Evans joins John and Hilary Maitland in their home in Frodsham, Cheshire, for a service of prayer and devotion," at 9.30am. Everyman at 10.10pm was about a white Irishman earning his living as a black actor because his complexion was so dark. Songs of Praise at 6.40pm came from the Houses of Parliament. Radio 4 had a service at 9.30am from Sussex and Radio 2 had an evening half hour programme from a church in Glasgow. Last Sunday BBC 1 had the Heaven and Earth Show from 10am-11am, Songs of Praise at 5.20pm and Heart of the Matter at 11.05pm. Radio 4 had Bells on Sunday at 5.50am, the Sunday religious affairs programme at 7.10am and Sunday Worship at 8.07am.

fields.headline: Shadow cast over great masters
fields.standfirst:
Ministers facing huge bill after galleries list 350 works that may have been stolen

First report on the spoliation of works of art during the Holocaust and World War II period
fields.trailText: The shadow of the Nazis hung over 350 works of art in British national collections yesterday, as museum and gallery directors published an inventory of pieces whose history between 1933 and 1945 cannot be proven beyond question.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The shadow of the Nazis hung over 350 works of art in British national collections yesterday, as museum and gallery directors published an inventory of pieces whose history between 1933 and 1945 cannot be proven beyond question.

The list includes works by Rubens, Van Gogh, Picasso, and dozens of impressionist paintings which have become suspect because they have no certain history for the period when Jewish collectors were murdered or forced to sell masterpieces for a pittance to buy food or a ticket to emigrate.

More than half the works are in the collections of the National Gallery and the Tate - 109 and 80 paintings respectively.

The list has been placed on the internet, and may lead to claims which will cost the government millions in compensation.

Labour peer Lord Janner yesterday welcomed it as "epic". "We are talking about stolen properties," he said. "This is a moral issue on a major scale." He added: "It is inconceivable that the government would not assist museums and galleries to do what is moral and just."

The directors stressed that nothing on the list had been positively identified as stolen, and that many had probably been in Britain for the entire suspect period. The purpose of publishing the list was "to bring the debate into the public domain", said Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate and chairman of the National Museum directors' conference.

Officially the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and a government advisory panel will decide how to handle any claims for restitution. The government has given no commitment either to pay compensation or to return the works of art. Most of the galleries are legally barred from disposing of their collections, and a return would need an act of Parliament.

However Sir Nicholas gave his private opinion yesterday that the government would have to grasp the nettle and pay up at the full market price if any of the works were found to be tainted.

"It is difficult to see how one could justify it if compensation were paid at the historic value," he said. "This is something the government will have to address - it would be out of the question for the museums to pay the compensation. This is a national issue."

The disputed works include three Picassos in the Tate collection, a Caravaggio, Degas, Delacroix and another Picasso in the National Gallery, and drawings by Van Gogh, Corot and Gericault in the British Museum. The museum holds the only work known to have been looted, but for which it is believed reparation has already been made - a drawing by Hans Baldung, once attributed to Dürer. It was among 30 drawings stolen from the Lubomirski museum in Lvov, then in Poland, by the Nazis in 1941. The British Museum believes the drawings were returned to the Lubomirski family, whose ancestors founded the museum, in the 1940s, and subsequently sold. It acquired its drawing by bequest in 1997.

Compiling the list has taken the museums and galleries a year's work, and much more remains to be done. Only the Imperial War Museum, the Museum of London and the Natural History Museum, which have completed checks, and some closed 19th century collections such as the Sir John Soane and the Wallace, are certain that they hold nothing suspect.

The demands on the museums have been heavy. The British Museum has only completed work on a fraction of the more than 2m items in its collection.

The National Gallery was the first to publish its list 18 months ago. After a public appeal for more information, and thousands more hours of research, it has only managed to remove 21 pictures from the original list of 130.

The report has thrown up many ironies. The largest group of questioned pictures in the Tate comes from a single bequest, including many major cubist works by Georges Braque and Juan Gris, which were left by the Jewish art collectors Gustav and Elly Kahnweiler. They are believed to have acquired many of the works through Gustav's brother,a noted Paris dealer.

Sir Nicholas believes there is no documentation for many of the pictures because they were obtained by the family directly from the artists, and many were probably gifts. They now join the list of suspect paintings, even though Gustav and Elly emigrated from Frankfurt to Britain in the 1930s because of Hitler's rise to power.

Many of the Tate's questioned paintings will hang in the magnificent new Tate Modern, when it opens on Bankside in May. Sir Nicholas said yesterday: "We shall hang all of those with uncertain provenance in the belief that public exposure is the best way to elicit further information."

Potentially the number of claims could run into thousands: yesterday's list only covers part of the national collections. The non-national collections, including hundreds of local authority museums and galleries, have still to begin work on their own collections. In some parts of the country, such as Glasgow and Southampton, local authorities were pioneers in buying contemporary art between the wars, precisely the type of work that is most likely to be contentious.

The government has already announced that it is setting up an advisory committee, headed by the retired appeal court judge Sir David Hirst, to advise on any claims. It is expected to begin sitting within the next two months.

National gallery

webTitle: Royal rasta Prince Charles joins carnival mood in 'no-go' Trench Town

fields.headline: Royal rasta Prince Charles joins carnival mood in 'no-go' Trench Town
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Deep among the slum yards of Trench Town, where Bob Marley's music is still revered, Prince Charles yesterday met Rita Marley, widow of the reggae king.
fields.body:
Deep among the slum yards of Trench Town, where Bob Marley's music is still revered, Prince Charles yesterday met Rita Marley, widow of the reggae king.

"It's more than words can express. It's a great feeling and a great accomplishment for him to visit us in Trench Town," she said. "We would like to thank her majesty the Queen for trusting us to look after her son in an area which people had always said was no-go."

In return, Prince Charles accepted a rasta hat, which he reluctantly modelled for the cameras crammed into a community centre. "I've had enough, it's too hot," he said, before slipping on the red, green and gold headgear. The prince's unwillingness to pose appeared to be justified, as the dreadlocks sewn into the wool tumbled down over his face.

Trench Town - immortalised in the music of Marley, who grew up here - once housed much of Kingston's middle class. But gangs armed by rival political parties turned it into a ghetto, a no-go area for police.

Rita Marley claimed that such is the sense of distrust among the population that not even the prime minister of Jamaica would dare show his face. But times are changing, and the prince had come to support the Kingston Restoration Company, part-funded by the British government, which is helping to regenerate the area.

Crowds pressed against the walls of the community centre to catch a glimpse of the prince meeting the widow of their hero, who died in 1981 but whose music lives to inspire a new audience. "Bob Marley said in one of his songs: 'Can anything good come out of Trench Town?' The answer is yes," said Rita Marley.

Later the prince met many who had gathered on the street in the sweltering heat to greet him on the final day of his Caribbean tour. Dispensing with protocol, one man rejected the usual handshake in favour of an enthusiastic "high five", to which the prince responded in kind.

The prince had earlier experienced the typical living conditions of people here - packed into shacks around the communal yards that give their name to Caribbean gangs operating in Britain. But these "yardies" are far from gun-toting drug rivals. While crime rates are high and the threat of violence is never far away, these are ordinary people fighting hunger and poverty.

fields.headline: Girl had sex 'because friends did'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old told police that she had sex with two boys because she wanted to see "what it was like" after girls in her class boasted of their sexual exploits, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old told police that she had sex with two boys because she wanted to see "what it was like" after girls in her class boasted of their sexual exploits, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

She had told police: "Most of the girls in my class claim to have had sexual experience and I wanted to see what it was like."

Two cousins from north London, who were aged 16 and 17 at the time they had sex with the girl in September and October 1998, were placed on probation for 12 months.

Judge Richard Hawkins said he had viewed the video interview of the girl and agreed that she looked older than 12. He accepted that the youths thought she was nearer their own ages.

Charles Salter, defending the younger youth, said the girl's sister had called in police because she was concerned at her behaviour with boys. Paul Crampin, defending the older boy, said: "He does have perhaps a confusing view of events. He was hoping to embark on a relationship with her."

The youths were found guilty at an earlier hearing of unlawfully having intercourse with the girl. The court was told DNA linked one youth to sex in her bedroom and the other to sex in his bedroom.

The girl, who had moved to Britain from Zaire, told police she had consented - but in law she was too young to give consent, the jury was told.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
The US justice system giveth, the US justice system taketh away: it's a lesson former Miller Brewing exec Jerod McKenzie learnt the hard way this week, with a Wisconsin appeals court instructing him to return the $25 million he originally won in a 1997 unfair dismissal suit. And what relevance does this have to anything in particular? Well, the entire furore was started by an episode of Seinfeld - the one, to be precise, in which Jerry fails to recall the name of an ex-girlfriend, remembering only that it rhymes with a female body part (after wrongly guessing at Gipple and Mulva, he finally twigs it was Dolores). Anyway, the hapless McKenzie was fired for regaling the office with said joke the following day - and, it should be noted, photocopying an encyclopaedia entry on the offending appendage and showing it to his female co-workers. Unfortunately for him, however, while jurors in the original case overlooked his history of bad behaviour in the office - and an alleged sexual harassment case - the appeals court ruled he'd failed to prove Miller had financially damaged him (as he was approaching retirement) and demanded the money back. The Supreme Court beckons; Jerry was unavailable for comment.

Meanwhile, just time to mention another impending legal dust-up for the ever-troubled Tommy Lee and Pamela Anderson, only this time neither narcotics nor spousal abuse will be appearing on the rap sheet. No, the problem is the couple's unnamed Rottweiler who, alleges one Doreen Cott, took a chunk out of her in an unprovoked attack three years ago. Cott is now seeking unspecified damages for medical expenses and loss of wages, arguing the mutt had a "vicious nature which should have been known to the defendants". Not for the first time, you couldn't make it up...

webTitle: Researchers urge bank of human tissue

fields.headline: Researchers urge bank of human tissue
fields.trailText: Banks of frozen human tissue which might one day be cloned to make new organs should be set up, Britain's leading scientists will tell the government today.
fields.body:
Banks of frozen human tissue which might one day be cloned to make new organs should be set up, Britain's leading scientists will tell the government today.

A committee of the Royal Society, the "club" of the most distinguished scientists, said in a document to ministers that dramatic advances in the study of stem cells - the precursor cells of blood, skin, bone and nerve cells - could be used one day to help sufferers from Parkinson's disease, hepatitis, leukaemia, diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis.

But the document is certain to raise once again the spectre of human cloning, and the use of human embryos not just for fertility research but also for treatment in a wide range of diseases. A committee led by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, has been considering the possibilities for months.

The Royal Society implicitly backed the use of embryo stem cells in its document. It talked of the technical and ethical problems in getting stem cells from human embryos.

These stem cells, already cultivated in US laboratories, are able to serve up replacement tissue forever. "There is considerable scope for developing therapeutic treatments that use stem cells," said Richard Gardner, chairman of the Royal Society group. "Organs damaged by injuries or disease do not always need replacing, and repair would be possible if a suitable source of tissues was available. Stem cells are a potential source of such tissues."

British groups are poised to begin experiments with embryo stem cells, if they get the go-ahead from the government. A frozen bank of different kinds of stem cells, screened for genetic defects and virus infection, would allow researchers to look for new ways of tackling disease.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What market traders watch on television
fields.trailText: What market traders watch on television.
fields.body:
Pete Baint, greengrocer:

"I love that programme where they all dress up as women, The League Of Gentlemen. I think it's hilarious. Really dark, and very funny. I like the woman from the job centre, Pauline, and her friendship with Mickey. I think they've got it spot on. I lived in a village when I was growing up and it was full of weirdos. All the women did look like men."

Susan Greenstock, electricals:

"People used to say I was like Cath from EastEnders but I think it was only because I used to plaster myself in make-up every morning. The 80s, you see. Then I went and got a make-over at some department store as a treat from my daughter and the blusher went in the bin. My aunt's an extra, does all sorts, a lot of films, but she never gets to meet the stars. They have separate trailers. She said she once had a chat with Dudley Moore about something like growing rhubarb, but I've never read he's a keen gardener or anything so I don't think I believe her."

Rashi Singh, clothing:

"What do you want to know? TV? Are you asking if I've got a licence, mate, because I've just got one last week. What do I watch? Anything, really. I watch the news when I'm at the gym, or anything that's on TV, while I'm on the treadmill. I really enjoy A Question Of Sport and The 11 O'Clock Show and all that."

Bryan Fullerton, greengrocer:

"Never watch it, love. I leave it for the missus and the mother-in-law to sit and coo together about the Holiday programme or Watchdog. That Anne Robinson, thinks she's God's gift. All those people moaning. Moan moan. Anyway, I don't watch it. Now thank you."

David Spink, toys:

"You'd think I might watch some kids' programmes, with a stall like this, but I can't bear them. Half term this week and we've got to go and see Toy Story 2 and rent the Lion King for the hundreth time and I'm just going to leave my better half to do it. God, she'll hate me for saying that, but she knows I'd rather be in the pub."

Sian Pattenden spoke to traders in the Holloway area

fields.headline: The one that got away
fields.trailText: The Fugitive: The Final Chapter | Ape-Man
fields.body:
Hollywood did its best with the story of Sam Sheppard, the neurosurgeon accused of killing his wife Marilyn in 1954. The gory murder, and Sheppard's continued protestations of innocence, inspired a 60s TV series starring David Janssen and a 1993 movie starring Harrison Ford, in both of which the wronged doctor goes on the run to find the real (one-armed) culprit. The truth, as revealed in The Fugitive: The Final Chapter (BBC1) was stranger and less heroic.

In 1999, nearly 50 years after Marilyn Sheppard was bludgeoned to death in her comfortable Cleveland home, her body was exhumed and re-examined by the Ohio State Prosecutor, Bill Mason, a man determined to prove that his predecessors were right to send Sam Sheppard to prison for ten years. Now Sheppard's son, Sam, who was seven years old when his mother was murdered in a nearby bedroom, is determined to prove his father's innocence and to gain financial compensation for half a century of misery.

The details of the proceedings were grim enough: Marilyn Sheppard's unborn child was brought to the coroner's lab in a suitcase, while the prosecutor's team argued over a nightmarish model of the victim's battered head. But what emerged most disturbingly from The Fugitive: The Final Chapter was the arbitrary nature of American justice. Sheppard's first trial was a media circus. Sheppard was found guilty and went to jail for ten years. Appeal after appeal was rejected, while Quinn Martin Productions got to work on the TV show. Then, with the idea of a doctor wrongly accused of his wife's murder firmly embedded in the public conscious ness, a new appeal ordered Sheppard's release in 1964. The Supreme Court dismissed the original trial as unfair, but allowed the Cleveland prosecutor to retry him. This time he got off.

The ratings for The Fugitive tailed off, the show was dropped, and there it might have ended, but for Sheppard Jr's claims. He believes he's found the killer; the prosecutor is determined to uphold the original verdict. The trial is now on, and whatever the truth of the matter, it was hard not to feel sympathy for Sheppard Jr as the prosecution team infiltrated his briefings, questioned his motives and referred to his mother as "Marilyn". "I wish they'd call her Mrs Sheppard, at least while I'm there", said the son, quivering with rage.

The most unlikely figure in the whole shadowy drama was Sheppard's second wife Ariane, a wealthy German who funded the 1964 appeal and married Sheppard on his release. An outrageous platinum blonde with a taste for leopardskin and huge hairdos, she partied hard in 60s Cleveland despite the fact that her half-sister had been married to Josef Goebbels. But eventually Sheppard was too much even for her: addicted to booze and dope since his time inside, he started waving guns around and eventually sent her running to the divorce courts. In a final bizarre twist, Sheppard was forced to give up neuro surgery and ended up earning a buck in the wrestling ring, where he fought as "Killer Sheppard".

Mercifully for the family, Marilyn Sheppard's remains have been reinterred; nothing emerged from the second autopsy. Sheppard himself died at the age of 46. His son is understandably bitter. "My family deserves monetary damages. Let's cut the crap."

BBC2 continued its investigations into the origins of human life in the second part of Ape-Man. Last week's opener was a woolly affair full of cod science and a lot of talk about shamanism; last night's programme actually got down to some hard history, and was much the better for it. There was still a superabundance of silly effects, jump-cuts and overwrought music, but at least there was a straightforward story in there too. And so we found ourselves in various African locations some three million years ago, where certain apes were beginning to evolve human characteristics. One enthusiastic professor believed this meant that they picked up weapons and went on eye-gouging, blood-drinking rampages; current thinking, however, favours a picture of our ancestors as small, elegant creatures who were clever enough to start sucking the brains out of dead animals. This rich diet improved their own mental capacity, leaving their root-chewing cousins on the evolutionary starting blocks. The reason? "Vegetarians don't have big brains", the most contentious claim of a contentious evening.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Spotlight | Frontiers
fields.body:
Uniquely, Joan Collins has no photograph with her entry in Spotlight (3.45pm, Radio 4), her agent having presumably reckoned that not many Tibetan hermits subscribe to this vast theatrical casting directory. Keith Moss launched his irreplaceable reference work in 1927, irritated by the need constantly to spread mugshots across his casting floor. Now no actor dare skip the annual fee for inclusion. Should the Great Green Room beckon before publication, however, there is a refund.

Peter Evans looks at a possible answer to bacteria resistant to antibiotics. In Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) he recalls the technique first developed in 1915 by the British researcher Francis Twort. He discovered the bacteriophage ("bacteria eater"), a virus able to insert its DNA into any recalcitrant bacterium and eventually destroy it. Though widely used in Eastern Europe, the technique died out in the West with the emergence of antibiotics. Now it looks due for a revival.
