fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Heaven And Earth | Cool Hand Luke | The Shawshank Redemption
fields.body:
Heaven And Earth
(Oliver Stone, 1993)
10pm, UK Arena

The final part of Stone's angrily compelling Vietnam trilogy, following Platoon and Born On The Fourth Of July. In attempting to portray the conflict from the Vietnamese viewpoint Stone's script falls into neat simplicities - an early-50s prologue showing a paddy-field paradise quickly lost on the arrival of the French. It's grindingly long, but the brutalising experiences of Le Ly (Hiep Thi Le), are all too horribly accurate. Tommy Lee Jones plays the GI who takes her home to San Diego.

Cool Hand Luke
(Stuart Rosenberg, 1967)
10.10pm, Sky Cinema

Captivity being the theme of the evening, here's Paul Newman on top form as the prisoner who maintains inner freedom despite the brutalities of a Deep South chain gang. Much in the style of the old Warner Bros melodramas, the hardnut action is lightened by a witty, funny streak - such as the much celebrated egg-eating contest. Strother Martin is the vicious camp boss, George Kennedy won an Oscar for his tough convict who comes to respect Luke.

The Shawshank Redemption
(Frank Darabont, 1994)
12midnight, FilmFour

The Green Mile director Darabont's first film, also prison-set, also taken from a Stephen King story. This contains all the clichés of jailbait drama, but breaks free to create a richly emotive tale of male comradeship. Tim Robbins (pictured) is accountant Andy Defresne, convicted of wife-murder in the 40s, despite protesting his innocence; Morgan Freeman is Red, the fixer, who befriends him at the bestial Shawshank State Prison. With just a poster of Rita Hayworth and a tiny geological hammer to call his own, Defresne survives the sadistic regime of governor Bob Gunton by becoming his bookkeeper - but will he and Red realise their dream of boatbuilding on the beach? Beautifully acted, and crafted in fine detail by Darabont, all the way to the admittedly unlikely denouement.

fields.headline: Unchanging face of BBC religion
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Comparison of this week's BBC religious broadcasting schedules and those of 10 years ago show remarkable similarities.  Prayer for the Day, the Daily Service, Songs of Praise and even Radio 2's Good Morning Sunday remain in place although timings have changed.
fields.body:
Comparison of this week's BBC religious broadcasting schedules and those of 10 years ago show remarkable similarities. Prayer for the Day, the Daily Service, Songs of Praise and even Radio 2's Good Morning Sunday remain in place although timings have changed.

On Sunday February 25 1990 BBC was showing This is the Day: "Linda Mary Evans joins John and Hilary Maitland in their home in Frodsham, Cheshire, for a service of prayer and devotion," at 9.30am. Everyman at 10.10pm was about a white Irishman earning his living as a black actor because his complexion was so dark. Songs of Praise at 6.40pm came from the Houses of Parliament.

Radio 4 had a service at 9.30am from Sussex and Radio 2 had an evening half hour programme from a church in Glasgow.

Last Sunday BBC 1 had the Heaven and Earth Show from 10am-11am, Songs of Praise at 5.20pm and Heart of the Matter at 11.05pm. Radio 4 had Bells on Sunday at 5.50am, the Sunday religious affairs programme at 7.10am and Sunday Worship at 8.07am.

webTitle: Livingstone tries new mayor tactic game

fields.headline: Livingstone tries new mayor tactic game
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special reportTwo Labour MPs urge Dobson to stand down
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone declared yesterday that he still expected to be Labour's official candidate for mayor of London, in a switch of tactics aimed at capitalising on the first public demands from within the party for Frank Dobson to pull out of the race in his favour.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone declared yesterday that he still expected to be Labour's official candidate for mayor of London, in a switch of tactics aimed at capitalising on the first public demands from within the party for Frank Dobson to pull out of the race in his favour.

As two leftwing Labour MPs, Paul Flynn and Audrey Wise, called on Mr Dobson to accept he was not the real winner of Labour's selection and stand down, Mr Livingstone signalled that any move to run as an independent would be put on hold to give Labour time to "sort out the mess".

But Labour's Millbank headquarters moved swiftly to stamp on any suggestion that the party's candidate might throw in the towel, insisting that Mr Livingstone was "deluding himself", while the former health secretary ruled out any suggestion he might step aside.

After visiting a jobs scheme near Heathrow airport yesterday with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, Mr Dobson declared: "I was elected under a system that all three candidates agreed to and I'm not go ing to step down because it suits one of the candidates who lost".

Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, said: "Ken is well aware that Frank Dobson is and will remain Labour's candidate for London mayor.

"It is a fact that is not up for negotiation."

The former Greater London council leader used a debate in Westminster with the other main parties' mayoral hopefuls, Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer and Tory Steve Norris, to issue a rallying call to Labour members not to resign from the party in protest against the selection "fix" but fight to overturn it.

His new tactics followed days of speculation that he would announce an independent candidacy this week.

But an early declaration now appears to have been ruled out.

There was renewed contact between Mr Livingstone's campaign team and Ms McDonagh yesterday following Monday night's "comradely" meeting with the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

Both sides agreed to more discussions, though no date was fixed and suggestions that Mr Prescott might have made the Brent East MP any kind of offer were discounted.

Mr Flynn, MP for Newport West and a consistent New Labour critic, made his call for Mr Dobson to step down in the latest issue of the leftwing Socialist Campaign Group News.

Last night, Mrs Wise, the Preston MP, said Mr Dobson would "earn a debt of gratitude" if he "extricated himself" before further damage was inflicted on the party.

Arrangements for the election remained on hold yesterday after talks between parties over the format of a free mailshot to voters broke down.

The Tories and Liberal Democrats refused to accept a hastily drawn-up government compromise over the mailing, dismissing proposals for a booklet containing a summary of each candidate's manifesto as "completely inadequate".

Ministers yesterday conceded the principle of a free mailshot, following last week's government defeat in the Lords on the issue.

fields.headline: Yesterday good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Paddy Ashdown. He may have just turned 59 but loses no opportunity in showing he's no slouch. The ex-Lib Dem leader yesterday unveiled plans for Europe's largest fitness drive, Commit to Get Fit, in his role as honorary president of the trade association for the fitness industry.

Bad day

Mike Gapes, Labour MP for Ilford South. An early morning debate on Britain's relationship with Russia was suspended because the MP, who was meant to be the opening speaker, was caught up in heavy traffic.

Revelation of day

A staggering £290m was raised in parking revenue throughout London during the last financial year, according to a written reply from junior transport minister Keith Hill. Westminster city council raised the most of all the boroughs, almost £102m.

Today

The fate of maverick Tory Teresa Gorman will be decided in a debate on a standards and privileges committee report which condemned her lack of candour over business dealings. The report recommends her suspension for a month.

webTitle: Goodhew saved my life, says MP recovering from heart attack

fields.headline: Goodhew saved my life, says MP recovering from heart attack
fields.trailText: Swimmer Duncan Goodhew saved the life of the veteran Labour MP, Robert Sheldon, with a textbook resuscitation from a heart attack, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Swimmer Duncan Goodhew saved the life of the veteran Labour MP, Robert Sheldon, with a textbook resuscitation from a heart attack, it emerged yesterday.

Mr Sheldon, the 76-yar-old chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, was taking a morning walk towards the Commons when he fell in St James' Park. Mr Goodhew was passing and heard him collapse.

Trained, like all top swimmers, to recognise the symptoms of cardiac arrest, Mr Goodhew, the 1980 Olympic gold medallist, delivered cardio-pulmonary resuscitation.

"People told me what happened," Mr Sheldon said yesterday. "Within a minute of my falling down he was on the job, and within 12 minutes I was in the ambulance. Anything like this can very often be the end of you. He saved my life, undoubtedly. I could not have timed that walk better. He is a great man."

Mr Goodhew said yesterday he "wouldn't claim I had saved him", but revealed Mr Sheldon's heart had to be restarted three times before the ambulance arrived. "We had terrible trouble loosening his collar. When I turned him into the recovery position it was clear that things were not going very well at all," he said. "I just did for him what I have no doubt he would have done for me."

Mr Goodhew hailed a woman passer-by and gave Mr Sheldon mouth-to-mouth resuscitation while she delivered a chest message. In the ambulance, Mr Sheldon received electric shock defibrillation to restore the rhythm of his heart. He was taken to St Thomas's hospital, close to parliament, and is now at home.

The drama took place at 8.45am on February 17, the day the standards and privileges committee, delivered a critical report on Tory MP Teresa Gorman.

Mr Sheldon said last night he had only found out about Mr Goodhew's intervention on Sunday. "The extraordinary thing is that I feel no effects at all," he said. "I want to get back to work."

webTitle: Commons question MP faxes wedding offer to partner

fields.headline: Commons question MP faxes wedding offer to partner
fields.trailText: Caroline Flint, the Labour MP for Don Valley, faxed her constituency assistant, Phil Cole, an instruction yesterday.
fields.body:
Caroline Flint, the Labour MP for Don Valley, faxed her constituency assistant, Phil Cole, an instruction yesterday.

"In this leap year 2000, as custom demands, I seek an answer to my question: will you marry me?

"Lovingly yours, Caroline."

The response was swift, and romantic in a Blairite kind of way. Mr Cole, pausing only to page her to check that it wasn't a spoof, faxed her: "Yes, yes, yes."

Being a busy MP, rushing around with constituency concerns, being foreign minister Peter Hain's parliamentary aide, Ms Flint didn't actually see the fax until late in the evening.

Not until the Guardian, getting in the way somewhat, asked her about it. "I've not been back to my office," she said. "God, has he sent me a fax? That's very exciting."

Thankfully, the couple had already spoken over the phone and he had agreed resoundingly to her request. Though her asking him was a bit of a surprise, the idea of marriage was not a bolt from the blue.

They've been together now for 10 years and have been talking off and on about marriage.

"It's one of those things where you sit around and say, 'shall we?' And we've never got around to popping the question," said Ms Flint, a former local government official. But in the end she decided: "Someone's got to do it." He's 39, she's 38.

"He's hitting 40 this year and I thought I would make an honest man of him, basically." And thus she took advantage of established, February 29, leap year convention and proposed to her man.

Mr Cole said last night he was very happy. "Both of us are very definite about it all," he said. "You have to plan these things, otherwise you just drift along."

When she's in parliament, he - having given up his London public relations job when his partner was elected in 1997 - lives in Doncaster with his son Nick, 14, and her children Karim, 13, and Hanna, 11. He runs her constituency office and then she comes home at weekends; they won't even be seeing each other until tomorrow.

They'll have plenty to discuss. He's thinking about a romantic weekend somewhere - "apart from Labour conference, we've not been away without the kids since Caroline got elected."

And she's thinking about a venue for the wedding. "We've talked Las Vegas, we've talked a beach somewhere, we've talked the chapel here in Westminster," she said, before adding, constituency-consciously, "or it could be RAF Finningley."

fields.headline: Joe Wolfson
fields.standfirst: California surfer riding big waves on a small board
fields.trailText: Dr 360, also known as the bodyboard surfer Joe Wolfson, spun his last circle in his Volkswagen on the Marina del Rey freeway in Los Angeles rather than on a giant wave. But, suffering from cancer, he probably preferred this death at the age of 50 to the alternative of a hospital bed.
fields.body:
Dr 360, also known as the bodyboard surfer Joe Wolfson, spun his last circle in his Volkswagen on the Marina del Rey freeway in Los Angeles rather than on a giant wave. But, suffering from cancer, he probably preferred this death at the age of 50 to the alternative of a hospital bed.

During the 1970s, Wolfson pioneered the art of body surfing and bodyboarding - riding the waves on a smaller, blunter platform than the traditional surfboard, which was too long for his diminutive frame. Also known as "Joefish" by his family, Wolfson got his "Dr 360" nickname from his ability to turn complete circles four or even five times across the face of a huge breaker while on the board. He won respect for the bodyboard in the surfing community, and went on to win various national and international competitions.

His early childhood was spent in Brooklyn, as the eldest of three children of a couple who were trade union and labour activists. The family moved to Long Beach, California, in 1956. With his parents' blessing, Wolfson was bussed to a largely black high school, and it was during this time that he was first attracted to surfing.

It became his life; he had always lived one block from the Pacific in Manhattan Beach, where he moved after completing his studies at the University of California, Los Angeles. Every winter, Wolfson would go to Puerto Escondido, in Mexico, for more surfing. Eventually, he designed and sold his own bodyboard, but gave away almost everything he earned, mostly through helping children.

Early in 1998, he began to be plagued by a bad cough, and was eventually diagnosed as having an inoperable tumour between his windpipe and lungs. Wolfson, who neither smoked nor drank and always stayed lithe and fit enough to spend all day in the water, was stunned when doctors gave him only a few months to live.

He took leave from his job as a local authority recreation official and withdrew nearly $100,000 (£62,500) from his bank account, paying for a friend's eyes surgery, two years' tuition at UC Berkeley for another friend's son, and several gifts to youngsters he knew. Then, in November 1998, he donned his wet suit and paddled out on his Dr 360 board, leaving behind a suicide note and $5,000 for his farewell party.

Wolfson had been in the water - at night with temperatures of about 55F - for three hours, and was comatose when he was spotted by a lifeguard, who gave him the kiss-of-life and paddled him back to shore. His body temperature was only 81F, but he regained consciousness in hospital, and was furious enough to rip the life support tubes out of his arms. As he recovered, he read 33 letters from children at a school where he did volunteer work as a basketball coach.

When he left hospital, Wolfson met the children, apologised to them for "sending the worst possible message" by trying to commit suicide, and said that their letters had made him decide to fight his cancer. The story of the event made national headlines across the United States and caught the attention of Hollywood, where Wolfson signed a contract for a film. It might still be made.

Always energetic, he arranged a huge 50th birthday party and, with his new celebrity status, appeared to be having such a good time that people questioned whether he was really terminally ill. Last year, he even made his winter jaunt to Escondido, before returning to California and his youngsters.

Doctors wanted Wolfson to have chemotherapy, but he reportedly told his room-mate, college football coach John Featherstone, that he thought it would be useless and unpleasant. No cause is known for the crash, in which his car spun off the road and hit a tree.

Wolfson is survived by his parents and two sisters.

fields.headline: Sir Eric Mensforth
fields.standfirst: Engineer whose business acumen created the British helicopter industry
fields.trailText: During the mid and late 1950s, Sir Eric Mensforth, who has died aged 93, established helicopter development and production on a continuous, substantial scale in Britain. He changed the west country company, Westland, from a producer of fixed-wing aircraft to one whose work was based on the helicopters of the United States company Sikorsky, part of the United Aircraft group.
fields.body:
During the mid and late 1950s, Sir Eric Mensforth, who has died aged 93, established helicopter development and production on a continuous, substantial scale in Britain. He changed the west country company, Westland, from a producer of fixed-wing aircraft to one whose work was based on the helicopters of the United States company Sikorsky, part of the United Aircraft group.

It was on January 10 1947 that, after much bargaining - in which Westland was strongly supported by the helicopter division of British European Airways - an agreement was signed between Westland and the American company, licensing production of the Sikorsky S-51 helicopter. As a result, its British equivalent, the Westland-built WS-51 Dragonfly, flew on October 5 1948. Some 139 of the aircraft were to follow; a number were delivered to BEA, the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force. BEA used its Dragonflies to launch the world's first scheduled and sustained passenger-helicopter service, between Cardiff and Liverpool.

In the mid-1930s, Mensforth became a board member of a subsidiary of the engineering conglomerate, John Brown. At the time, the parent group was looking for an outlet in the aircraft industry - and Mensforth recommended Westland Aircraft, then a small company in Yeovil, Somerset. As a result, in 1938 John Brown took over the company and Mensforth was appointed as its joint managing director.

Two years earlier, the first Westland Lysander army co-operation aircraft had flown. During the fall of France in 1940, Lysanders suffered heavy casualties - 120 out of 175 were lost - but they later became famous for their hazardous night-time work in occupied France with the Special Operations Executive and the resistance. By 1943, a total of 1,427 Lysanders had been built at Yeovil, together with a further 225 in Canada.

Mensworth found himself from 1943 to 1945 seconded to the ministry of aircraft production as a part-time production adviser. Meanwhile, Westland, apart from producing Lysanders, Supermarine Spitfires and Seafires, concentrated on the design of a single-seater, twin- engined fighter, the P9 Whirlwind, of which 116 were built. This was succeeded in production at Yeovil by a larger and faster twin-engined, single-seater, high-altitude fighter, the P14 Welkin, with an early pressurised cabin. But the aircraft suffered serious handling problems and, although 77 were built between 1940 and 1947, further development was abandoned.

The next project, the W34 Wyvern, was a 500mph, long-range, torpedo-carrying, aircraft-carrier based fighter, initially powered by the new 24-cylinder, 46-litre, 3,500hp Rolls Royce Eagle engine - the last piston-engine to be built by Rolls Royce. In all, Westland built 124 Wyverns between 1945 and 1956, with various propeller-turbine engines in addition to the original Eagle. Once described as "very nearly a very good aero plane", the Wyvern - and, in particular, its turbo-prop engines - suffered many serious, and sadly fatal, difficulties.

But, by then, Mensforth had decided that the future of Westland lay more in the possibilities of rotary-wing aircraft than in fixed-wing military and civil machines. He believed that Westland would not encounter the problems it had had with high performance, fixed-wing aircraft because of Sikorsky's helicopter experience.

Eric Mensforth was the second son of Sir Holberry Mensforth, and was educated at Altrincham county high school, University College School, London, and King's College, Cambridge, where he read mechanical sciences. He then joined the engineering section of the Woolwich Arsenal, and from there went to Mather and Platt Ltd, before gaining two years of international engineering experience with Klocknernak BG in Germany.

After a short time with the English Electric Company, he was appointed to the board of Markham and Co Ltd, of Sheffield, a John Brown construction company. Then came Westland.

From 1945 until 1953, and from 1968-71, Mensforth was vice-chairman at Westland. He was chairman between 1953 and 1968, and president from 1979 until 1985, when he retired at the age of 76. During the 50 years between 1945 and 1995, 10 different major helicopters were built in Britain along the lines established between Sikorsky and Westland. More than 1,800 helicopters went into service with the navy, the army and civil operators, including BEA and later British Airways. So the move from fixed-wing to rotary-wing aircraft was indeed justified.

Mensforth's publications included Air Frame Production (1947), the Cantor Lectures: Future Of The Aeroplane (1959) and the 1964 Lord Sempill Lecture, Production Of Helicopters And Hovercraft. Small in stature but substantial in business wisdom and vigorous in its application, Sir Eric served on many engineering, industrial and academic bodies, and was lord-lieutenant of South Yorkshire from 1974 to 1981.

His wife Betty predeceased him, and he is survived by three daughters.

 Sir Eric Mensforth, engineer, born May 17 1906; died February 20 2000

fields.headline: Bruno Zevi
fields.standfirst: Architectural philosopher who railed against the evils of classicism
fields.trailText: If ours is the age of fragmentation in music, the novel, and art, then in architecture its theoretician was the Italian Bruno Zevi, who has died aged 81 of a coughing fit brought on by influenza. Initially a socialist, later a libertarian, he was fundamentally a Zionist. Deeply affected by his experience in the Mussolini era, he believed that all notions of architectural order, organisation, and clarity - as expressed in the bombastic buildings of Marcello Piacentini, an "official architect" of the time - were a cultural disease to be countered by an aesthetic of disorder, disruption and disturbance.
fields.body:
If ours is the age of fragmentation in music, the novel, and art, then in architecture its theoretician was the Italian Bruno Zevi, who has died aged 81 of a coughing fit brought on by influenza. Initially a socialist, later a libertarian, he was fundamentally a Zionist. Deeply affected by his experience in the Mussolini era, he believed that all notions of architectural order, organisation, and clarity - as expressed in the bombastic buildings of Marcello Piacentini, an "official architect" of the time - were a cultural disease to be countered by an aesthetic of disorder, disruption and disturbance.

To this view he allied a vast learning and art-historical discipline absorbed from his contemporaries, the art historians and critics Ragghianti, Longhi and Briganti. He became Italy's most celebrated polemicist for architecture as a means of exposing what he saw as the evil ideas of classicism.

In 1940, forced by Mussolini's racial purity laws to leave Italy, Zevi studied at Harvard with Walter Gropius. Discovering an enthusiasm for Frank Lloyd Wright's conception of a democratic, open architecture, he returned to Italy in 1945, published Verso l'architettura organica (Towards Organic Architecture) and was offered the history chair at Venice school of architecture. In 1948, he published Saper Vedere la Città (How To Understand The City), which examined the influence on the city of Ferrara of the Renaissance architect Biagio Rossetti, and the interaction between architecture, urban fabric, economics, history and politics.

These two books alone place Zevi among the greatest historians and theoreticians. They were followed in 1948 by Saper vedere l'architettura (How To Look At Architecture) - still a favourite among Italian students - and Storia dell'Architettura Moderna (1950), a polemic against rationalist-centred history.

Moving to Rome university in 1963, Zevi created a school of first-class architectural historians. In 1970 he published Erich Mendelsohn: Complete Works, and in 1974 the brilliant Poetica dell'Architettura Neoplastica, which comprehensively explained the Dutch De Stijl movement of the 1920s and early 1930s. In 1979, with post-modernism in full flood, Zevi resigned his professorship in disgust.

Looking back at a particular kind of fascist architecture, Zevi convinced himself that columns, colonnades and symmetry were everywhere the language of repression and cruelty. Whether considering ancient Rome or the Renaissance, he saw architectural history as a battle between these styles of oppression and the anti-styles of liberation. He dedicated himself to rooting out neoclassicism, order, and symmetry wherever he found them - never questioning the validity of his own assumptions.

The intensity with which he often expressed himself might shock an English-speaking reader; when Ignazio Gardella died, Zevi sent that noble architect to his grave with cries of "obscene massacre" over a neo-classical project he had worked on with Aldo Rossi, a satan of the drawing-board whose architecture was filled with neoclassical references.

Zevi attacked everything: the American Louis Kahn's architecture "evoked the ambiguity of the taste of the emperor", while the Pantheon, a symmetrical dome (and therefore fascist) was liquidated as "claustrophobic". The other architectural interventions of Hadrian in Rome were only acceptable insofar as they could be read as "a break, a revolution in the continuum of the urban fabric, interrupting it, modifying it, deviating it".

In 1973, Zevi set out these ideas as a set of invariants - a sort of anti-classical codebook that attempted to define modernity as a language of asymmetry and dissonance, which he propagated via his magazine L'architettura, cronache e storia. This exciting theory of architecture as rupture and fragmentation marks him out as the seminal theoretician for all currents of modernism interested in iconoclasm and deconstruction, from Alvar Aalto in the 1930s to Daniel Libeskind in the 1990s.

Zevi also brought his provocative point of view to reviewing architectural events for the weekly L'Espresso, providing a link between the reader and the hermetic world of the architect. He passed judgment on everything, sometimes foolishly - writing off Bernini's St Peter's Square as a dreadful mess - sometimes presciently; he wrote in 1973 that James Stirling had "the gifts and the qualifications to become, if he wants to, the most important European architect".

Zevi was a major architectural scholar and polemicist; with his passing suddenly everything has gone flaccid; it is a disaster.

He married Tullia Calabi in 1940, although they later separated. He leaves a son and a daughter.

 Bruno Zevi, architectural historian and academic, born January 22 1918; died January 9 2000

webTitle: Tehran police on trial over students

fields.headline: Tehran police on trial over students
fields.standfirst:
More about Iran

They were beaten and left to die seven months ago. Yesterday the same pro-democracy student demonstrators faced their police attackers in a military court to demand justice.
fields.trailText: In the unprecedented open trial, the students accused the police of illegally entering Tehran university dormitories on the night of July 8, smashing windows and furniture and beating students with clubs.
fields.body:
In the unprecedented open trial, the students accused the police of illegally entering Tehran university dormitories on the night of July 8, smashing windows and furniture and beating students with clubs.

Earlier that day police had tried to halt a peaceful demonstration by students over the closure by a conservative-dominated court of the pro-reform newspaper Salam, once a leading symbol of free expression in Iran.

Student protests erupted for the next six days at Tehran university and in universities across the country. The demonstrations spilled onto the streets of the capital, marking the worst social unrest since the aftermath of the 1979 Islamic revolution.

The former Tehran police chief Brigadier-General Farhad Nazari, the commander of special riot squads, seven other officers and 12 conscripts face charges of illegally entering the dormitories, beating students, and destroying their property. Lawyers say they could each face up to 10 years in prison.

The outcome of the trial is expected to indicate whether the call by the moderate president, Mohammad Khatami, for a society based on the "rule of law" prevails in Iran, or whether partisan politics takes precedence over justice.

But students and their supporters in the reform movement, who won a solid victory in parliamentary polls on February 18, say the prosecutions do not go far enough. They are demanding legal action against hardline vigilantes, whom the students say led the assault.

Reformers have vowed to make the judicial system - now in the control of the conservative establishment - less politicised. They have also promised to pass legislation restricting the heavy hand of law enforcement agencies.

Such moves will be met with strong resistance. The conservative clerical establishment is reluctant to give citizens rights similar to those in western democracies, and believes that violent repression by security forces is justified if the Islamic system is under threat.

The students told a packed courtroom about the events of the night of July 8-9, when at least one person was killed and more than 200 injured. Their lawyer accused the police of conspiring with gangs of Islamic extremists to take revenge on the students for their protest over the closing of Salam.

"There were some people coordinating between the police and those in plainclothes. The prosecutor must pay attention to this fact," Mohsen Rohami, a pro-reform cleric representing the students, told the court.

One student explained how he lost his eye when a teargas canister hit him and police refused to allow the ambulance to take him to the hospital.

"A teargas canister hit my eye. It was like a bullet," said Mohsen Jamali, whose shattered right eye was later removed in hospital.

"When I left for the university my mother was so happy. But had she known what would become of her son, she would never had shed tears of joy upon hearing that I had won a place at the medical college after graduating top of my class," Mr Jamali said.

Another student, Ramin Karimi, told the court that police beat him up and then threw him out of a third-floor window. As he fell, he said, the police shouted that they were offering him up as a sacrifice to God.

"Imam Hossein, we hope you accept this from us," he quoted the police as saying in a reference to one of the holiest figures in Shi'ite Islam.

Exodus follows sharia violence

Thousands of Ibo tribespeople fled northern Nigeria yesterday, fearing reprisals for killings in the south-east.

At least 50 people were killed in the south-east on Monday after last week's riots in the northern city of Kaduna, which left hundreds dead when Muslims demanding Islamic sharia law clashed with local and Ibo Christians.
Reuters, Kano, Nigeria

India to boost military power

The Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, yesterday announced a 28% increase in defence spending for the next financial year.

India launched a huge military offensive against Pakistani forces in Kashmir last summer. Reuters, New Delhi

Coup plotters jailed for life

Sheikh Hamad bin Jassem bin Hamad al-Thani, a former cabinet minister and a cousin of the Qatari emir, Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, was jailed for life yesterday along with 32 of his supporters for their role in a failed 1996 coup. All denied the charges.
Reuters, Doha, Qatar

US youths face trial in Germany

Three US teenagers were yesterday facing murder charges in Germany after two drivers were killed and five people were injured by rocks thrown from a bridge at cars on a motorway.

The youths were arrested at a US army housing area near Darmstadt, south of Frankfurt. Police said all three - aged 14, 17 and 18 - admitted throwing stones and each now face a 10-year jail sentence under the German justice system.
AP, Darmstadt

2.2m call for EU hunting curbs

The largest nature conservation petition ever collected will be presented to Nicole Fontaine, the president of the European parliament, today as wildlife protection societies from all 15 member states demand tougher EU action against French hunters.

The petition was signed by more than 2.2m people.
Jon Henley, Paris

Epic Antarctic journey ends

The German adventurer Arved Fuchs claimed yesterday to have become the first expedition leader to have repeated an epic 1,000-mile Antarctic boat and mountain journey undertaken by the British explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton 84 years ago.
Tony Paterson, Berlin

webTitle: Six-year-old boy shoots girl dead at US primary school after quarrel

fields.headline: Six-year-old boy shoots girl dead at US primary school after quarrel
fields.trailText: A six-year-old girl was shot dead yesterday by a boy in her class the day after a playground quarrel at their Michigan primary school, setting a new low for the epidemic of gun violence spreading through the United States education system.
fields.body:
A six-year-old girl was shot dead yesterday by a boy in her class the day after a playground quarrel at their Michigan primary school, setting a new low for the epidemic of gun violence spreading through the United States education system.

Prosecutors investigating the killing at the Buell elementary school in a working-class suburb of Mount Morris said the six-year-old boy fired a single shot, striking the girl who died half an hour later in hospital.

"There may have been some kind of scuffle or quarrel on the playground between this little boy and girl," said Art Busch, a county prosecutor.

The boy was taken into custody but is too young under state law to be charged. But Mr Busch said that manslaughter charges might be brought against whoever had allowed him access to the weapon.

The 20 other children in the class were interviewed by police as a crowd of appalled parents gathered outside the school demanding to know how a six-year-old had been able to smuggle a gun into the school.

Since a rash of suburban secondary-school shootings over the last two years, metal detectors have become a common sight outside classrooms, but primary schools had hitherto been thought immune to gun fever.

"I thought it was a desk or something falling," said Corey Sutton, nine, a Buell pupil. "The principal came over the PA [public address] system and told teachers to shut their doors and lock them ... My heart was pounding."

"We're interested in how the little boy came into possession of the weapon," Mr Busch said. "We've had other school children take guns to elementary schools before, but it never went this far. It's a sign of our times where we have a fully armed society that doesn't take its responsibility to secure its weapons seriously."

He said that President Bill Clinton had telephoned community leaders to offer counselling assistance from educa tion department experts in Washington.

The shooting is bound to raise the stakes in the heated gun control debate during an election year. It is an emotive issue which separates most Democrats and some moderate Republicans from social conservatives who resent government attempts to limit what they see as a constitutional right to bear arms.

Mr Clinton said he was outraged at the incident and said it should serve as a reminder to Congress to act on draft legislation aimed at tightening restrictions on gun ownership and enforcing safety devices like childproof trigger locks.

"How did that child get that gun? Why could the child fire the gun?" Mr Clinton said. "If we have the technology today to put in these child safety locks, why don't we do it?"

Legal measures have been drafted which would require gun locks, more background checks on would-be gun-buyers, and a longer "cool-down" period between ordering a gun and receiving it. But the legis lation's progress in congress has faltered in the face of opposition from rightwing Republicans and the National Rifle Association.

Speaking in Florida, the president said more children die in the US in accidental shootings than in any other of the world's 25 largest countries. He suggested that American voters bear that fact in mind when they vote in this year's elections.

webTitle: Police wash hands of farm squatters

fields.headline: Police wash hands of farm squatters
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's police chief said yesterday that he would not order action against thousands of black squatters who have illegally invaded white-owned farms on the grounds that it was a "political issue".
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's police chief said yesterday that he would not order action against thousands of black squatters who have illegally invaded white-owned farms on the grounds that it was a "political issue".

Thirty farms were overrun this week by war veterans and poor black people, who claim they are taking back land seized by white colonists in the Rhodesian era.

The squatters, who arrived on buses and appeared to be well organised, clearly have the backing of President Robert Mugabe and his government.

The police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri, said the police would not intervene against the trespassers because "it is above the police. It is a political issue. What do you expect the police to do?"

Although most of the invasions have been peaceful, there were reports yesterday that an elderly white couple had been beaten and their home ransacked by squatters.

The vice-president, Joseph Msika, who is in charge of land redistribution, said the government would take no action over the incursions until it had heard from provincial leaders.

Mr Mugabe has used the land issue to boost the popularity of his ruling Zanu-PF party before parliamentary elections in the middle of next month.

The president is still smarting from the recent defeat at the polls of his draft constitution. The popularity of his Zanu-PF party has dwindled in the face of an economic crisis, fuel shortages, high inflation and unemployment. The country's involvement in the Congo war is also unpopular.

fields.headline: Search for the Star Dust
fields.standfirst: In 1947 a passenger plane vanished over the Andes.  Stacy Marking's uncle, Peter Young, was on board. Now the wreckage has been found and the mystery of the crash may have finally been solved . . .
fields.trailText: In 1947 a passenger plane vanished over the Andes.  Stacy Marking's uncle, Peter Young, was on board. Now the wreckage has been found and the mystery of the crash may have finally been solved . . .
fields.body:
In 1947 my uncle disappeared in Argentina. His plane vanished in the Andes on a flight between Buenos Aires and Santiago. In January this year, after 53 years, wreckage from the plane was found by climbers on mount Tupungato, a peak of 21,850ft. Last week, soldiers from the 11th Argentine Mountain Regiment set up base camp at Tres Quebradas (Three Ravines) and, leaving the mules and journalists, continued to climb the bleak, volcanic mountain. The landscape, even in summer, is dusted with snow and in deep, permanent shadow.

Using the last days of clear weather before winter sets in, the soldiers climbed another 7,000ft to the frozen wreckage. It is an arduous and dangerous climb, and two of them are now in hospital. But they succeeded in recovering an oxygen cylinder, parts of the propellers, scraps of clothing, an empty wallet. Below the peak, the melting glacier has yielded one of the plane's wheels, tyre still inflated. The expedition has also rescued three bodies, preserved in the permanent frost, and part of a fourth. They may have finally solved the mystery of the plane's disappearance.

On August 4 1947, the Times reported: "A British South American Airways four-engined Lancastrian, the Star Dust . . . is reported missing and is believed to have made a forced landing in the Andes mountains. Six passengers are stated to be on board."

One of these was my uncle, Peter Young, who had boarded in Buenos Aires. The report continues: "Contact with the aircraft was lost at 9 o'clock last night, and it was due to arrive at Santiago at 1 o'clock this morning."

The plane had come from London, with its crew of four ex-RAF bomber pilots, and the "star girl" stewardess. It was a flight that then took three days, six hours and 10 minutes. There were three possible routes to take to Santiago de Chile, all of them hazardous. It is not a great distance across the Andes, but in the way stand Aconcagua, the highest peak in South America (23,000ft), and the volcanic mount Tupungato. As the weather deteriorated, the pilot made an unscheduled stop in the pretty mountain resort of Mendoza. He decided to take the most direct route, but there was a risk of severe icing. A Chilean Air Force operator received a Morse code message - STENDEC - which was repeated, but has never been deciphered. And then the Star Dust disappeared.

In the 1970s, generals such as Pinochet in Chile and Videla in Argentina made South America a continent famous for its Disappeared. The generals succeeded in altering the English language, and adding a new passive tense to an English verb that was once exclusively active.

There have been two theories that the Star Dust was "disappeared". One involves a conspiracy by Peronistas to destroy official British government papers on board; the other, sabotage by people determined that the new airline BSAA should not succeed. It is more likely that the wings were iced.

Two days after the first reports, there is a chilly announcement by the postmaster-general in the Times of August 6, that "air mail correspond-ence for Chile posted in the United Kingdom on July 29 was on board the aircraft Star Dust, which is overdue on its flight from Buenos Aires to Santiago". In October a search party from Santiago found a different plane. The search continued without success.

In March 1948 the stationery office issued a report (price 9d) concluding that "the actual cause of the accident remains obscure". The foreign office issued a statement that "the cause of the disaster may never be known, and in the light of former accidents in the Andes, the aircraft may not be found for years, if ever".

I remember that the news of Peter's disappearance came in August, for I was outside, stamping on tar bubbles. The family heard the news over the wireless, giving Peter's name. My aunt fainted. My grandmother never believed it. Because the first reports spoke of "a forced landing", she never gave up hope that, somewhere in the inaccessible Andean peaks he was alive, and would be rescued.

There's a photograph of uncle Peter in Buenos Aires, in a dashing white South American suit and correspondent shoes. And a pile of post cards, saved by my grandmother. The first card is from Romania, where he tutored the young Prince Michael. I think he got the job, after Oxford, because his enterprising uncle John had tutored the family of the Prince of Tek, and had once stood Queen Mary in a corner. Not many people got the better of her.

I don't know why he went on to South America. The postcards come thick and fast from Cuernavaca, Lima, Santiago and Rio de Janeiro. There's a postcard showing one of the monster-gods of the Aztecs, a huge stone gargoyle baying for sacrificial human blood. "It proves," Peter writes, "that the Mexicans like a joke."

He travelled across South America constantly. A month or two after the outbreak of the second world war, he writes from Lima: "This is where I have been staying during the past two weeks, out in the country. In two days' time I leave for Chile and at the end of the month go to Buenos Aires, where I look forward to finding some letters from you." Newly married, he writes from Buenos Aires: "We arrived back from Chile after a three-day journey across the Andes," and he hopes that the family "are not being much worried by raids, and have enough food."

There was a shortage of glamour in the England of 1946. With my brother I had come from a colour-filled childhood in India to the dark and grime of post-war England. At Christmas we stayed with my grandmother, briefly released from boarding schools of Dickensian horror.

That Christmas, Peter arrived from Argentina with a concertina, a collapsible opera hat and a glamorous wife in fox furs and high heels. She smelled wonderful. My cousins Caroline and Ruth and I - we were seven and six and four - still remember that Christmas vividly. Peter brought us chocolate in silver paper, and dolls with open-and-shut eyes that had real lashes. The war-dark house sparkled, and as they put on their 78s and danced the tango, it was better than Fred and Ginger.

Near my grandmother's house there was a Doctor Barnardo's, where I made friends with a girl called Sylvia - I think I too felt like an orphan. We were inseparable, and since neither of us had ever been to the theatre, Peter took us both to Cinderella. It was the first time I can remember laughing in England.

I even remember the joke. The Ugly Sisters decided they must slim for the Prince's Ball. They waddled in to a "slimming chamber" trailing a real dachshund on a lead behind them. They emerged, slender in fishnet tights, trailing a string of sausages. We were shocked for a moment, but Peter said he could hear the dog barking in the wings, so we knew it was all right. Sylvia and I fell off our seats, helpless with laughter. The usherette was bootfaced, and threatened to throw us out. But Peter charmed her, and told her we were orphans, and dusted us down.

He was always generous. He gave my parents £100 for their wedding present - truly a fortune - and with it they bought a Ford 8, in which my mother ferried wounded troops recuperating in Poonah. It lasted until 1943, when spare parts could no longer be found in India. In the 60s, long after his disappearance, my cousins and I each received £500, the kind of money that can make all the difference to your life.

Only once was there a chance that his body might be found. In 1970 I was in Santiago, interviewing Salvador Allende for this paper, when there came a report that an Andean glacier had melted, and moved, and that an aircraft fuselage had been glimpsed on the inaccessible reaches of mount Tupungato. I felt I owed it to my uncle to finish his story, but by the time I reached Argentina the wreckage had once more vanished under the Andean snows.

And now at last, some at least of the bodies have been found. I hope that DNA tests don't mean the bones and bodies will now be separated. I feel that all 11 of the dead, English, Palestinian, German, should be buried and commemorated, as they died, together.

fields.headline: No: 1585
fields.standfirst: David Hasselhoff
fields.trailText: David Hasselhoff
fields.body:
Not the chisel-jawed, pectorally inflated Captain Mitch Buchannon, hero of long-running lifeguard drama Baywatch, illicit favourite of single men everywhere? I wouldn't have put it like that myself, but yes. Only it's Baywatch Hawaii.

Pardon? They abandoned California for the island earlier this year, changing titles and augmenting the traditional riot of red Lycra and silicone with a smorgasbord of hula skirts and floral garlands.

Still, as long as David's in the water, I'll be watching. Funny you should mention that. Because he won't be.

No! I'm afraid not - after 10 seasons providing moral guidance for the likes of Pamela Anderson and Donna D'Errico (you know, Donna D'Errico), Dave's been axed. And, predictably, he's none too impressed.

I don't blame him. Then again, he's hardly been loyal to the cause. He'd already publicly discussed his desire to "pursue other interests".

Such as? Well, there's his flourishing - in Germany - pop career: remember, this is the man whose albums Knight Rocker and Lovin' Feelings had 'em jumping in the aisles from Rostock to Baden-Baden. And there's his new show, Double Cross, in which he stars as "a suave guy who drinks champagne and romances pretty women".

Sounds fantastic. All the same, David's piqued about the manner of his exit - he's to disappear this May in an enormous explosion. "I thought it was a joke when I read the script. I'm upset," he quivered. "I was planning to leave, but not like that!"

And what are the producers saying for themselves? That's the thing. Despite the apparently conclusive nature of their leading man's demise, they're insistent they've left his fate open-ended and that he's "welcome" to return - presumably in Baywatch: The Reconstructive Surgery Clinic.

Brilliant. When's that starting? You haven't really got the hang of this, have you?

Do say: "Could you just sign my copy of Lovin' Feelings before you go, Mr Hasselhoff?"

Don't say: "Aloha! Dead man walking!"

Dead man walking!"

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report of Jörg Haider's resignation, page 15, yesterday, we mistakenly said that Austria's foreign minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, was a member of the Freedom Party. Mrs Ferrero-Waldner, in fact, has always been a member of the ÖVP, the Austrian People's Party, and has never had any personal affiliation with the FPÖ. In addition, we spelt Mrs Ferrero- Waldner's name wrong, and for both of those mistakes we apologise.
fields.body:
In our report of Jörg Haider's resignation, page 15, yesterday, we mistakenly said that Austria's foreign minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, was a member of the Freedom Party. Mrs Ferrero-Waldner, in fact, has always been a member of the ÖVP, the Austrian People's Party, and has never had any personal affiliation with the FPÖ. In addition, we spelt Mrs Ferrero- Waldner's name wrong, and for both of those mistakes we apologise.

 In a panel, we said that Haider had criticised Jacques Chirac, "the French prime minister". Chirac is the president of France. A photograph purporting to show the young Adolf Eichmann - in a panel accompanying our coverage of the David Irving libel case, page 3, yesterday - did not in fact show Eichmann. It was a photograph of Alois Brunner who is still being sought for Nazi war crimes.

 In a report headed Fans tackle club over 'broken' bond deal, page 5, yesterday, we mistakenly referred to Freddie Fletcher, chairman of Newcastle United Plc and chief executive of Newcastle United as having resigned following newspaper allegations. In fact, we meant to refer to Freddy Shepherd, chairman of Newcastle United Football Club. We apologise for any offence or embarrassment.

 In our leader about the Labour party's centenary, page 23, February 26, we referred to the party's foundation in the Methodist Memorial Hall in Farringdon Street. We should have said the Congregational Memorial Hall. The hall was built in 1872 to commemorate the ejectment of clergy (later to become Congregationalists and Presbyterians) from their churches in the 17th century. It was built on the site of Fleet prison where many of their martyrs had been incarcerated.

 In a report on page 10, yesterday, we said, "More than a third of voters (69%) in an ICM poll said they wanted to be given a chance to have a say on whether to abolish Westminster's first past the post electoral system." What we meant to say was "more than two-thirds" wanted a say. The 69% was correct.

 In our third leader, page 21, yesterday, we said, "Treasury statisticians will confirm that this [an extra day of public holiday every leap year] would add a mere 0.25% of a day to the annual quota." They probably will not. We should have said 0.25 or 25% of a day but not 0.25% (a little under four minutes).

 We continue to confuse flaunting and flouting, as in the following from page 3, G2, February 28: "She may also be wondering if it was inevitable that she would be punished for so openly flaunting the conventions of Mexican culture."

fields.headline: Ernst sells consultancy for £7bn
fields.trailText: Ernst & Young, one of the big five accountancy firms, yesterday announced plans to hive off its consultancy arm in a $11bn (£7bn) deal with management services and information technology group Cap Gemini of France.
fields.body:
Ernst & Young, one of the big five accountancy firms, yesterday announced plans to hive off its consultancy arm in a $11bn (£7bn) deal with management services and information technology group Cap Gemini of France.

The biggest deal yet seen in the consultancy field comes amid mounting pressure on accountants from the US securities and exchange commission over alleged conflicts of interest between audit and consultancy.

Less than two weeks ago another of the big five, PricewaterhouseCoopers, disclosed plans to separate its consulting arm from its audit business.

Yesterday's deal is likely to trigger a series of partnerships across traditional technology and consultancy divides as the internet opens new horizons, making technology a core element of company strategy.

The French company expects the cash-and-shares agreement will propel it into the important north American market and improve its position in Germany for consultancy and internet-related services. About 18,000 staff will join Cap Gemini's 40,000, although completion of the transaction is subject to the approval of Ernst & Young partners, including at least 75% support among the consulting business partners.

Results are expected in April and if the scheme is approved then Cap Gemini shareholders will meet by the end of June to vote on the proposal which the French company believes will be earnings enhancing from 2000.

Cap Gemini will issue up to 43.5m shares and pay €375m (£228m) in cash if all Ernst & Young consulting entities participate in the transaction.

This would leave about 36% of the combined group's equity with Ernst & Young auditing and consulting partners.

Cap Gemini's stock in Paris jumped over 13% after a brief suspension on news of the deal.

Although the deal was already factored into Cap Gemini's share price, analysts said the speed with which Cap had finalised a complex transaction was a surprise for the market.

One analyst said the deal would increase the proportion of Cap Gemini turnover attributable to consulting to over 50% from the current level of 23%.

"We have an absolute shared vision of where we have to go. We did have other opportunities, we were approached by an array of other organisations, but we only wanted to talk to Cap Gemini," said Phil Laskawy, the chairman and chief executive of Ernst and Young's consulting business.

How they stack up

PricewaterhouseCoopers

More than 850 offices in 150 countries. 150,000 people employed. Takes in $15,300m a year in sales.

Andersen Worldwide

Largest accounting firm in world. Turnover last year $16,300m. Offices in 78 countries and tie-ups in 46 others. Employs135,000 people.

Ernst & Young (pre-split)

Rooted in tax consultancy. Has presence in 130 countries. Sales last year over $12bn. Employs 98,000.

KPMG

Bigger in Europe than US. Takes in $12bn a year. Staff above 100,000.

webTitle: Sacked M&S firm falls £90m into red

fields.headline: Sacked M&S firm falls £90m into red
fields.standfirst: 4,500 jobs go as Baird gives up hope of selling factories
fields.trailText: The scale of the damage inflicted on textiles group William Baird by Marks & Spencer's decision to buy more goods abroad was underlined yesterday when the company revealed it plunged £90.7m into the red last year.
fields.body:
The scale of the damage inflicted on textiles group William Baird by Marks & Spencer's decision to buy more goods abroad was underlined yesterday when the company revealed it plunged £90.7m into the red last year.

The company, which is suing Marks & Spencer for breach of contract, said the store's decision to terminate its contract after 30 years had resulted in costs of £103.5m.

The company is closing all 14 of the British factories it used to supply M&S and 4,500 workers are losing their jobs.

Shareholders have also suffered. Baird shares, which were trading at about 115p before the M&S decision, have slumped and last night closed down 2p at 47.5p. Yesterday the company announced it was cutting its dividend in half to 5.25p per share for the year.

Baird insists it does have a future but not in British manufacturing. Aside from its M&S business it owns branded clothing labels such as Windsmoor, Planet and Tenson, but they are manufactured abroad. Its branded womenswear showed an 11% increase in sales during the year, although operating profits in this sector fell 7%.

Meanwhile, the company wants compensation from M&S and is claiming £53.6m for "repudiatory breach of contract" and consequential losses. Baird claims that, despite not having a written contract, it was not given reasonable notice before it was sacked as one of M&S's top four suppliers. It maintains that if it had been given more time it could have managed the decline of the British manufacturing businesses and avoided much of the cost involved.

The £53m claim is based on Baird's assessment of the difference between summary termination and a three-year notice period, reflecting lost profit and higher termination costs. The company says it is unfair that M&S should be benefiting from savings of £450m by restructuring its supply chain - with Baird paying the price. Only 300 Baird staff have applied for voluntary redundancy.

M&S has applied to the courts to have the legal action struck out and has vowed to "vigorously fight" it. But yesterday Baird's chief executive, David Suddens, said he believed the case should go to arbitration rather than court.

"We believe that a judge will ultimately say this should be arbitrated, not litigated, and we would comply with that," he said.

Mr Suddens believes that either way the outcome of this case will be watched closely. If the judge allows it to go ahead he believes M&S will be eager to settle, but if it is struck out M&S will find itself facing demands for proper legal contracts from suppliers fearful of getting the Baird treatment. Mr Suddens is hoping for a judgment in April.

He said Baird had given up hope of selling some of the now redundant British factories to its competitors as M&S redistributes the Baird turnover to other suppliers. "They [M&S] are distributing our sales to other suppliers but those other suppliers are not interested in buying our assets," he said.

Profit before the one-off shutdown costs was £13.2m, down from £30.5m last year, partly as a result of the decline in sales through M&S last year.

fields.headline: House prices up £69 a day
fields.trailText: The average house rose in value by £69 a day in February, according to the latest survey, suggesting the property boom is accelerating despite four interest rate rises.
fields.body:
The average house rose in value by £69 a day in February, according to the latest survey, suggesting the property boom is accelerating despite four interest rate rises.

Last month's 2.2% increase in house prices is the largest monthly rise since Nationwide building society started compiling monthly data in 1991. It lifts the annual house price inflation figure to 15% - more than double wthe level of a year ago.

The average home is now worth £77,072. This is £2,012 more than the £75,060 achieved a month ago and £10,000 more than in February last year, when the average price tag was £67,021 and annual price inflation stood at 6.8%.

Nationwide said the sharp increase reflected rising consumer confidence, recent pay increases and a further fall in unemployment.

"February's house price rise is consistent with our view that the market will remain buoyant this year," said David Parry of Nationwide.

The findings come days after a survey by Bradford & Bingley estate agents showed houses are selling in record time, while official land registry data showed average London property prices have risen 23% in a year.

The latest data might strengthen the argument for a further interest rate rise to cool the housing market.

The 15% annual increase is the highest since the third quarter of 1989, the period which immediately preceded the start of the the market fall.

fields.headline: Former bank official sues for £171m
fields.trailText: A former Bank of New York vice-president who resigned over a money laundering scandal said yesterday that she was suing the bank for $270m (£171m) for defamation.
fields.body:
A former Bank of New York vice-president who resigned over a money laundering scandal said yesterday that she was suing the bank for $270m (£171m) for defamation.

Natasha Kagalovsky, senior vice-president and head of the bank's east European division, was suspended in August after allegations that up to $10bn was illegally moved from Russia via the bank. The case is believed to be the largest laundering scandal in US history.

Ms Kagalovsky resigned in October, saying she had been unfairly victimised by rumours surrounding the scandal. Ms Kagalovsky and her lawyers alleged yesterday that bank executives had targeted her because she is Russian.

She also claimed she had been made a scapegoat as the bank tried to demonstrate its eagerness to co-operate with the investigation. "When they removed such a high-ranking person from the bank it probably looked very good to [the investigators]," she said.

The civil suit was filed with a Moscow district court last Thursday and the Bank of New York has until April 10 to respond, said Ms Kagalovsky's lawyer, Stan ley Arkin. She is seeking $270m compensation for the "grievous and irreparable" damage done to her reputation. The claim was made in Russia because Ms Kagalovsky had business connections there and felt her standing in the country was particularly damaged by the scandal - and because the bank has a considerable business presence in Russia, her lawyer said.

"Just as Russian companies that do business in the United States are subject to US laws, and are sued in America, there is no reason that an American company which does business in Russia should not be sued in Russia," Mr Arkin said.

Ms Kagalovsky was not indicted last autumn, when the US judiciary charged Lucy Edwards, another bank executive.

fields.headline: S&N to dump Center Parcs
fields.trailText: Scottish & Newcastle yesterday threw in the towel on its Center Parcs and Pontins holiday subsidiaries, putting them up for sale and promising to stick to brewing and retailing.
fields.body:
Scottish & Newcastle yesterday threw in the towel on its Center Parcs and Pontins holiday subsidiaries, putting them up for sale and promising to stick to brewing and retailing.

City experts expect S&N to raise around £750m for the two businesses and to spend the money buying a continental brewer such as Kronenbourg.

The Edinburgh-based group has struggled to escape criticism that it overpaid when it bought Center Parcs in 1989. Like Pontins, the holiday villages have required substantial investment but have failed to turn in consistently growing profits. In the last full year to April 1999, operating profits at Center Parcs fell 2% to £59m.

Venture capitalists or continental competitors such as Accor of France are believed to be the most likely buyers for the 13 Center Parc centres. These employ 10,000 staff, 3,400 of them at the British sites in Nottingham, Suffolk and Wiltshire.

Venture capitalists rather than British rivals such as Rank are expected to lead the field of probable buyers for the 14 Pontins sites, 11 of which are in the UK, with two in Jersey and one in Ireland. They employ nearly 2,500 staff.

Chief executive and deputy chairman of S&N Brian Stewart put an upbeat gloss on the disposals.

Mr Stewart said: "The management and staff of Center Parcs have done a remarkable job in building an outstanding record of success in the UK and in returning the continental villages to a position of accelerating growth."

He added that while S&N had great confidence in the potential of Center Parcs and recognised the progress made at Pontins - officially known as Holiday Club Pontins - the group believed it would achieve more shareholder value by focusing on its core businesses.

Analysts believe that S&N could obtain £600m-£900m for the two businesses though some argue that S&N will struggle to reach the top end of the range. The operations are in the books at £917m, £822m of which is ascribed to Center Parcs.

Sale of the assets will take place through an auction organised by financial advisers Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

Last night the shares closed at 410p, up 21p.

fields.headline: Alldays repackaging proves ineffective
fields.trailText: Alldays, the convenience store operator, has not helped its shareholders in the past couple of years. Not so long ago the shares were changing hands at a whopping 621p, valuing the company at £280m. Yesterday they hit a new low of 46p, down 3p, which values the entire business, including 657 stores and another 145 franchised outlets, at a mere £20.5m. And this after the company borrowed £200m from its banks last autumn to strengthen its business.
fields.body:
Alldays, the convenience store operator, has not helped its shareholders in the past couple of years. Not so long ago the shares were changing hands at a whopping 621p, valuing the company at £280m. Yesterday they hit a new low of 46p, down 3p, which values the entire business, including 657 stores and another 145 franchised outlets, at a mere £20.5m. And this after the company borrowed £200m from its banks last autumn to strengthen its business.

Alldays has had some serious problems, but now has new cash backing, new management, and - it would insist - reinvigorated prospects.

Yesterday the signs of improvement were few as the group reported it had plunged nearly £91m into the red last year, compared with a £10m profit a year earlier.

fields.headline: Family ousts sweet empire chief
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the Thorntons chocolate shop empire departed yesterday, only four days after the firm issued a surprise profit warning - its third in 18 months.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the Thorntons chocolate shop empire departed yesterday, only four days after the firm issued a surprise profit warning - its third in 18 months.

The company said Roger Paffard, who joined Thorntons in 1996, was leaving the company "by mutual agreement". But it was clear that he had been asked to step down.

A spokesman for Thorntons said: "It is time for a change at the top. We have had some tough times and a few disappointments. It is time for a different approach."

Thornton's shares, which two years ago were changing hands at 290p, have been melting rapidly since the turn of this year, losing more than a quarter of their value.

Yesterday, as Mr Paffard's departure was announced, they sank another 4p to a new low of 126p - which values the company, including 528 shops and a new factory, at just £83m.

John Thornton, the chairman and a member of the founding family which still controls 32% of the company, is to take day-to-day control of the company until a new chief executive is recruited.

Last night there was speculation that Thorntons could be vulnerable to a takeover bid - possibly from one of the big Swiss companies such as Jacobs Suchard.

Mr Paffard, who previously worked for the office supplies group Staples and furniture retailer Sharps, is likely to receive compensation of £186,000 for his loss of office - in line with his salary last year and his one-year contract.

Last week Thorntons warned that its profits to the end of June this year were unlikely to match City expectations of around £12m, or last year's level of £10m.

The alert came only 11 days before the company was due to announce half-time profit figuress and one analyst commented that "to have to make a profit warning one week before the interim figures smacks of incompetence".

Last year's results were also downgraded after a similar profit warning.

At that time Mr Paffard accepted the blame, saying that his senior managers had been so busy concentrating on the developments such as warehousing and manufacturing that they had neglected the ranges going into the shops.

They were short of new lines and ran out of popular prodcuts; and customers, said Mr Paffard, were "unforgiving".

webTitle: It's lawyers at dawn in the wild east

fields.headline: It's lawyers at dawn in the wild east
fields.standfirst: Kazakhstan interests v Reuben brothers in courtrooms around the world
fields.trailText: It is less than 10 years since the break-up of the Soviet Union opened the door on a feast of business opportunities for western companies willing to hazard the money, time and know-how for which the bombed-out Soviet economy was crying out.
fields.body:
It is less than 10 years since the break-up of the Soviet Union opened the door on a feast of business opportunities for western companies willing to hazard the money, time and know-how for which the bombed-out Soviet economy was crying out.

During the past few days, settlement of a half-billion pound legal case fought between one former Soviet republic and a big player in the London metals market shows how sour such gambles can turn.

At stake in the case was no less than 20% of the GDP of Kazakhstan, once a bulwark of the Soviet Union's central Asian flank. While the case was underway, the now-independent country could not be sure that shipments of its critical alumina, chrome and iron ore would not be seized in jurisdic tions where judgment had been given in favour of partner turned courtroom enemy Trans-World, a Geneva minerals and industrial group founded by David and Simon Reuben, whose trading arm is based in London.

Spanning three jurisdictions and pitting against each other two of the new breed of "wild east" tycoons, the case has produced conflicting accounts of just what happened to resources-rich Kazakhstan in the 1990s.

On Monday, both sides said they were pleased with the outcome, an undisclosed payment by Kazakh interests to Trans-World to buy the company's rights in three metals plants. This mutual pleasure was the first thing either side had agreed on for a very long time.

Trans-World's case is that the Kazakh interests - the government plus businessman Patokh Chodiev - represent the worst side of post-communist commercial life, letting the Geneva conglomerate invest in what had been an insolvent minerals industry then forcing the company out of the country just as the plants were turned around.

The Kazakhs' case is that Trans-World and its allies were predators. Mr Chodiev told a court in the British Virgin Islands: "In the period of Trans-World's management - the plants were managed in such a way as to bring them to the very verge of bankruptcy."

The precise size of the settlement is confidential. There have been suggestions of £94m, a considerable comedown from the £500m Trans-World had been seeking. This figure is denied by those close to Trans-World.

What is certain is that a £63m award made against Trans-World in January last year by the Kazakh supreme court now will not be paid. On the other hand, neither will Trans-World share in the plant's profits at a time when commodity prices are strengthening after years of slump.

Meanwhile, Trans-World's prize fighter in the ex-Soviet tycoon championship, businessman Lev Chernoi, is sharing in the settlement, although to what extent is not known. Mr Chernoi was a central figure in the Kazakh venture, striking a verbal contract for the whole deal in August 1994 with the Chodiev Group.

What happened between summer 1994 and October 1997, when Trans-World was effectively evicted from Kazakhstan, depends which side is telling the tale.

According to Trans-World, huge sums were invested in clapped out facilities, with a £104m loan arranged from United Global Bank, the Samoa-based banking vehicle of Simon Reuben, at competitive rates. Come October 1997, with Trans-World preparing to inject a further £620m into the industry, its representatives were forced out of plants, on one occasion at gunpoint.

Frustrated in the local courts, Trans-World sued in the British Virgin Islands, home of the joint venture.

Come October 1999, and Mr Chodiev told the islands' court that he would be in contempt of its order to hand over joint-venture shares to a local receiver, ahead of the case being heard next year.

Finally, Trans-World points to last week's announcement that the World Bank is having to subsidise a special political risk insurance for firms doing business in Kazakhstan.

The Kazakhs tell a different story. According to the Kazakh interests, Trans-World's actions were "intended to ensure the financial and economic dependence" of the industry on the company. The UGB loans fitted this pattern and charged excessive interest.

In autumn 1997, the state property committee investigated the plants, disclosing "numerous violations" of the civil law.

In January 1997, the Kazakh supreme court ruled in favour of the Chodiev/government interests and voided interest payments on the UGB loans.

Summing up, the Kazakhs said of the industry under Trans-World management: "A paradoxical situation was artificially created, where the more product [we] shipped out the deeper in debt [we] became."

With the parting of the ways, Trans-World remains entangled in a second court case, this in Switzerland against Russian entrepreneur Oleg Delipaska and associates regarding another joint venture, the Syanks aluminium plant in Siberia.

By 1997, David and Simon Reuben briefly controlled two-thirds of the former Soviet Union's aluminium industry. But perhaps they are more than happy no longer to do so.

fields.headline: Terence Chapman Group
fields.trailText: When Terence Chapman Group, an IT consultancy specialising in banking software, floated last summer, the City was nonplussed.
fields.body:
When Terence Chapman Group, an IT consultancy specialising in banking software, floated last summer, the City was nonplussed.

Yes, Hoare Govett got the £92m float away and the price moved to a reasonable premium to the 135p sale price as trading got under way.

But over the next three months the price drifted back below the offer price (time for the alarm bells to go off at the brokers) and it was only at the beginning of November, when Chapman mentioned that magic word, internet, that investors took notice. It said it was launching a "second generation internet broking solution" - a back office processing system for online brokers - and over the next two months the shares went from below 150p to above 600p.

The good news continued up to January 21 when Chapman again stated that everything was going swimmingly during its first year as a quoted company. To outsiders, this looked a genuine, established product and service supplier to the e-boom.

Yesterday, we got a different view. The group's performance for the year to end-August "will fall short of expectations". In fact it doesn't expect to make any more money during the second half than it did in the first half, where only a small operating profit is envisaged. It blames a lack of consulting work. The shares crashed from 567p to 410p yesterday - a fall of 28%. They will probably bounce back this morning as amateur punters on autopilot go bargain hunting. But serious investors are advised to avoid the stock until its trading situation becomes clearer. The shares could fall farther.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The agony and the ecstasy of investing in hi-tech stocks was evident yesterday as they accounted for most of the big losers and gainers.
fields.body:
The agony and the ecstasy of investing in hi-tech stocks was evident yesterday as they accounted for most of the big losers and gainers.

Durlacher, the internet investment specialist, was the worst performer, down 287p to £30.37 This followed the 235p decline in the shares on Monday when the company said it was backing Simon Fuller's new internet pop music venture.

Of the 10 main losers, only the banker Schroders, down 81p to £12.31 ahead of full-year results on Friday, was outside the technology and telecom sectors.

However, the London market rallied towards the close, helped by the recovery on Wall Street, particularly on the Nasdaq.

Irish internet security firm Baltimore Technologies continued to respond to last week's results, soaring £10.75 to £116.50, while London Bridge Software ended the day 220p higher at £64.50 following better than expected results.

Pharmaceutical research and development business, Cambridge Antibody Technology, rose 357p to £23.75. Another pharmaceutical stock, Lincoln-based Elan Corporation, was also among the big gainers, finishing 175p up at £24.

Standing out from among yesterday's performers were Barclays, up 102p to £15.26, and Reuters, 63p higher at £13.69.

Overall the market saw a return of interest in the heavyweight financial sector as fears of another rise in interest rates receded. Banks led the blue chip sector, a welcome return from the dire performance of recent months. Abbey National took the top spot on the FTSE 100 leaders board, up 66p to 711p with Royal Bank of Scotland , fresh from its NatWest triumph, up 73p to 833p, helped on its way by Lehman Brothers' view that the new combine should be ranked as an outperform rather than neutral stock.

Lehman also pointed to the attractions of the former building societies now in the banking arena, such as Alliance & Leicester, 49p higher at 567p.

At the end of the day, the FTSE 100 index was 133.0 points higher at 6,232.6, just short of its 6,245.5 high for the day. Volume in London was good, with 1.687bn shares changing hands in 132,002 transactions.

But this will be of little comfort to those holding a clutch of hi-tech stocks which showed big net losses on the day, including the computer services businesses, CMG, down 199p to £61.74 and Terence Chapman, off 157p at 410p, and the Royalblue software company, down 175p to £22.65.
