fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 300 axed from Scottish Widows
fields.body:
300 axed from Scottish Widows

More than 300 fund managers and their administrative staff face the axe in London because their business is being relocated to Edinburgh. In what being seen a multi-million pound victory for the Scottish capital, the job cuts are the result of Lloyds TSB's £7bn acquisition of Edinburgh-based Scottish Widows, which yesterday announced plans to create a new "global" brand by the end of June.

ABB Alstom cuts hit France

Industrial conglomerate ABB Alstom Power chairman Claude Darmon said 10,000 jobs are to be cut from an international workforce of 54,000, of which 5,341 will be in Europe. Some 1,500 job losses are likely to be made in France, said the French union, CGT.

'New order 'at Coca-Cola

Coca-Cola Beverages expects unit case volumes to expand by between 6% and 8% this year, marking a recovery from 1999's 4% decline.

Chief executive Neville Isdell said he anticipates big changes for companies like his - a main link in the global distribution chain of American soft drinks group Coca-Cola Company - under newly appointed Coca-Cola chief Doug Daft.

"New management are recognising that there is a new order out there. Therefore new structures, and new ways of addressing what already exists in the business are overdue," said Mr Isdell.

CCB reported a 1999 pre-tax loss of £36.1m, steeper than its 1998 pro-forma loss of £15.5m. Revenue fell to £1.129bn from a pro-forma £1.205bn in 1998.

Long distance market hots up

Boeing and General Electric yesterday announced plans for two new lines of long-range jet liners - including what will be the world's longest range aeroplane, capable of flying non-stop from New York to Malaysia. The twin-engined jets, the 777-200 and 777-300, are designed to compete head to head on cross-Pacific routes with a new jet produced by Europe's Airbus Industrie.

webTitle: Brown refuses to compromise on savings tax

fields.headline: Brown refuses to compromise on savings tax
fields.trailText: Fritz Bolkestein, Europe's internal commissioner, went away empty-handed yesterday after the latest attempt to persuade Britain to back plans for an EU tax on savings.
fields.body:
Fritz Bolkestein, Europe's internal commissioner, went away empty-handed yesterday after the latest attempt to persuade Britain to back plans for an EU tax on savings.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, refused the latest overtures from Brussels aimed at safeguarding the City's eurobond market while providing data to help crack down on evasion.

Treasury sources described the hour-long meeting as friendly but said the government's position remained unchanged. Mr Brown said that he would only agree to handing over information collected by the inland revenue provided that the $3 trillion eurobond market was exempt from the withholding tax - a 20% levy on interest payments to foreign investors.

The chancellor said he would only agree to eurobonds being included if there was a guarantee that the tax would apply to all financial centres, not just those inside the EU.

Speaking before the meeting, Mr Bolkestein said: "I am somewhat saddened that the needle is stuck in the groove. It is not my intention to have a 'one size fits all' tax system. The City would benefit from a harmonised financial services market. It's a pity that this issue stands between us."

The commissioner said that the EU was aware of the need to extend the scope of the tax outside Europe but added that it was important to take the first steps. "I have not given up hope of convincing Gordon Brown of the soundness of the commission's position," he said.

fields.headline: Thatcher ex-PPS banned
fields.standfirst: Directors of crashed legal advice firm punished
fields.trailText: Sir William Shelton, former parliamentary private secretary to Lady Thatcher, has been banned for five years from serving as a company director, it emerged yesterday. He was found to have engaged in "unfit conduct" when on the board of legal advice company Access to Justice.
fields.body:
Sir William Shelton, former parliamentary private secretary to Lady Thatcher, has been banned for five years from serving as a company director, it emerged yesterday. He was found to have engaged in "unfit conduct" when on the board of legal advice company Access to Justice.

He said last night: "I think it's very unfair." But he will not be appealing. Sir William, aged 70, said he was no longer a company director.

Also banned for five years was fellow Access director Lord Moyne, formerly Jonathan Guinness, who is under investigation by Swedish prosecutors over the £42m collapse of an unrelated company, Trustor. Sir Charles Blois, a Suffolk farmer and yachtsman, and Kensington businessman Michael Wynne-Parker were also banned for five years.

fields.headline: IMF plans crisis showdown
fields.standfirst: Job row puts US and Germany in a position where one or the other must back down
fields.trailText: The board of the International Monetary Fund will hold a crisis meeting tomorrow to try to break the deadlock over the appointment of a new leader amid fears that the escalating row between Europe and America could unsettle financial markets.
fields.body:
The board of the International Monetary Fund will hold a crisis meeting tomorrow to try to break the deadlock over the appointment of a new leader amid fears that the escalating row between Europe and America could unsettle financial markets.

With analysts drawing parallels between the dispute over the IMF's vacant managing directorship and the transatlantic battle over interest rates which triggered the 1987 stock market crash, the board was due to hold a straw poll of members' views on the three competing candidates.

Germany, backed by Britain and France, said yesterday it remained adamant that its deputy finance minister, Caio Koch-Weser, was the man for the job.

"His candidacy is certain," said the German finance minister, Hans Eichel. "It is impossible that the US is trying to tell us who the European candidate shall be."

But America remained implacable in its opposition to Mr Koch-Weser, although US treasury secretary Larry Summers stressed that the administration was not against another European in the post.

"The traditions with respect to selection have served us very well," Mr Summers said, referring to the precedent of the IMF being headed by a European.

The White House triggered a row on Monday by publicly opposing Mr Koch-Weser within hours of him being endorsed by EU finance ministers.

Analysts at Medley Global Advisors in New York said: "US and European officials are at each other's throats in ways we have not seen since 1987, when the battle over interest rates between the US treasury and the Bundesbank triggered the stock market crash."

Observers say that neither of the two other candidates - Stanley Fischer, the IMF's acting leader, and former Japanese vice-finance minister Eisuke Sakakibara - is likely to command enough support to succeed Michel Camdessus, who stepped down as the IMF's managing director earlier this month.

This suggests that the row over Mr Koch-Weser will be resolved either by the Americans or the Germans backing down. Sources in Washington said the US administration would stand firm. "They've used a nuclear warhead on this and its hard to see them giving in," said one.

The only other option is a formal vote of the IMF's 24-member board, but choosing a leader in that way is unprecedented. The Washington-based institution traditionally takes decisions by consensus.

Mr Koch-Weser, 55, worked at the World Bank for 25 years before joining the centre-left government in Berlin last year, but his low political profile and lack of financial experience have counted against him in Washington. Britain and France both wavered before supporting him.

Downing Street said yesterday: "We think Mr Koch-Weser is a strong and experienced candidate and we are prepared to support him. The views of the White House are for the White House."

webTitle: When the only colour is green

fields.headline: When the only colour is green
fields.trailText: Forget the gearstick and bewildering array of switches and buttons you have scarcely mastered before buying a new model. The car of the future will come with a single joystick to activate web-based data services; it will even talk to you and tell you where to go.
fields.body:
Forget the gearstick and bewildering array of switches and buttons you have scarcely mastered before buying a new model. The car of the future will come with a single joystick to activate web-based data services; it will even talk to you and tell you where to go.

Within 10 years at most, the car will be so green that its hydrogen-powered engine will emit only water vapour and, in a hybrid version, deliver a consumption rate of two litres per 100 kilometres travelled.

"You will be able to programme everything with a single switch or joystick," said Wolfgang Ziebart, BMW's development director "and see everything on an in-car screen. Your car will recognise your voice - and you can have a conversation with it, like talking to your partner."

Mr Ziebart and his team, in common with other manufacturers, is working on devices such as navigational finders which also allow the driver to pre-book the opera or a meal.

The new technology will be intuitive, and the steering wheel will remain in place for the foreseeable future to give a reassuring sense of control.

At the Geneva Motor Show yesterday manufacturers fell over themselves to present their new ecologically friendly engines to offset the soaring cost of petrol under the impact of rising oil prices - which hit $30 a barrel last month.

Fiat announced two refined versions of its ultra-compact Ecobasic car, one running on diesel and the other on a dual electric and petrol engine, which use less than three litres of fuel for every 100 kilometres, or 90 miles per gallon.

Not to be outdone, Rick Wagoner, the president of General Motors, announced a new fuel-cell vehicle based on the Zafira people carrier which has a range of 250 miles and a top speed of 88mph.

Elsewhere, responding to reporters' questions at the show, Mr Wagoner agreed that General Motors was "interested" in buying BMW but had seen no sign that the Quandt family, BMW's main shareholder, was willing to sell.

webTitle: Civil servants muscle in on business

fields.headline: Civil servants muscle in on business
fields.standfirst: Opportunity for reform is dodged
fields.trailText: Trade is rapidly becoming a Cinderella of government policy. The Wilson report into export promotion, so enthusiastically backed by the prime minister, was seen as the opportunity to effect a step-change improvement in export performance, but it has been pigeonholed and the civil servants have taken over.
fields.body:
Trade is rapidly becoming a Cinderella of government policy. The Wilson report into export promotion, so enthusiastically backed by the prime minister, was seen as the opportunity to effect a step-change improvement in export performance, but it has been pigeonholed and the civil servants have taken over.

The export market place has radically changed. Large projects and companies no longer dominate. British trade is much more specialised and success in maintaining market share and employment is reliant on small hi-tech firms, predominantly in the service sector.

Wilson led to the setting up of British Trade International, charged with implementing change. Since BTI's formation last year, a national strategy has been published which concentrates on administration and organisations, but which fails to quantify the improvements needed to bring them about.

The role of the private sector in these organisations is as part-time non-executive advisers, but copies of the most recent board meeting minutes, which have found their way into these offices, demonstrate that they are - to put it simply - stuffed with civil servants.

An internal BTI report has now proposed a central executive organisation based at the department of trade and industry headquarters in Westminster. It will be run by exactly the same individuals as before, but with different business cards and logos. So no changes here.

It also proposes that the regions be controlled from the centre and that more civil servants will be needed in the regions to shape and control the delivery mechanisms.

Does it need doing? If ever there was an example of how civil servants avoid radical change, operate to maintain the status quo and then seize the opportunity to extend centralised controls, this is it. It also seems to be increasingly accepted that the cost of these operations will be significantly more than before and that public sector budgets should be be increased accordingly.

The new organisation will not be allowed to include public/private sector agencies as delivery mechanisms although several exist in the regions and might reduce costs and improve effectiveness. In the world of fast-moving technology and entrepreneurial spirit, the BTI proposals are half-baked.

BTI organisations should be be run by a public/private sector executive board responsible to its members/shareholders, with a government body regulating and monitoring performance.

It means that the regions should be allowed to propose how they would organise themselves , rather than be given models and controls together with the promise of more civil servants. As a first step, directors should be recruited from the private sector so that they can be in the majority within six months. That way action lies.

Trading insults

Politicians on the stump are dangerous creatures, not least in the US. They have a habit of saying whatever will please which ever group of voters they are addressing. Their time horizons are bounded by the next election.

Look at George W Bush. Campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination in Seattle on Monday he came perilously close to saying that if he makes it to the White House he would prevent US trust-busters breaking up Microsoft.

That might be regarded as a primarily - though scarcely exclusively - domestic matter. But there are international issues, too, with the potential to become dangerously entwined in US politics. The World Trade Organisation has just found against the US and in favour of the European Union regarding corporations' exemptions over foreign earnings. Under WTO rules the tax regime must be changed or dismantled by October 1 - within weeks of the presidential election. Even a demob-happy President Clinton is unlikely to dish the Democratic presidential hopeful - presumably Al Gore - by bowing to the WTO and, by extension, the EU.

There is another, more immediate US/EU flashpoint over the top job at the International Monetary Fund. The post traditionally goes to a European; EU members (at least publicly) want a German, Caio Koch-Weser. The Americans reckon he is not up to the job - an attitude the German chancellor has described as regrettable.

By the standards of the ritual taunting heard every Saturday at soccer stadiums up and down Britain that might not sound much. In the corridors of international financial institutions, however, it is heavy stuff.

The EU already has enough sticky issues with the US - bananas, hormones in beef, for example - without further divisive questions becoming ensnared in the US presidential selection process. Europe's politicians must know it is almost impossible to ask their US counterparts for restraint on the stump. It will be up to Brussels to provide the patience.

fields.headline: Genome pioneers hint at £3.5bn float
fields.trailText: Healthcare company Nycomed Amersham yesterday raised the prospect of a part flotation for its life sciences arm, which could be valued at more than £3.5bn because of its involvement in mapping the human genome.
fields.body:
Healthcare company Nycomed Amersham yesterday raised the prospect of a part flotation for its life sciences arm, which could be valued at more than £3.5bn because of its involvement in mapping the human genome.

The business makes hi-tech machines for sequencing genes, analysing proteins and developing drugs. Its technology is used by academics and drug development companies racing to develop gene-based medicines.

US group Pharmacia & Upjohn has owned 45% of it since a tie-up between the two companies in 1997. But Nycomed's chief executive, Bill Castell, said he was "reviewing the ownership structure" in the light of the "new gene economy".

Mr Castell said: "The board is looking very seriously at how we ensure that the excellence we have, in technology and in the market, continues in the new economy."

He said three options were under consideration - buying complete control from Pharmacia & Upjohn, floating an "appropriate stake" or maintaining the status quo.

Finance director Giles Kerr said a flotation of Pharmacia's stake could be compared to Dixon's spin-off of internet business Freeserve. "It would allow a separate stock market price to be placed on the business's technology," he said. "If some investors wanted to invest purely in life sciences, they would be able to do that."

The life sciences operation, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, increased its operating profits by 6% to £82.2m. Its sales rose 11% to £543m, helped by the launch of MegaBace, a new machine for examining genes.

Valuations of the business varied widely - Michael King of SG Securities suggested that it was worth between £1.5bn and £2bn. However, another analyst said it could attract a price tag of up to £3.6bn. He pointed out that a similar company in the US, Perkin Elmer, had a market capitalisation of 12 times its annual sales: "That is a new-economy-type valuation. It's an infrastructure play on the booming biotech industry."

Among Amersham Pharmacia Biotech's customers last year was the US department of energy, which bought 96 MegaBace machines - typically costing $220,000 each. The department is using them to study the effect of nuclear fallout on the body.

Nycomed Amersham's remaining division makes imaging products to diagnose heart problems, cancer and other illnesses. The group's overall operating profits rose 11% to £251m. However, pre-tax profits fell 12.6% to £170m, due to exceptional items of £55.2m to cover merger integration.

Mr Castell said: "We correctly predicted growth would accelerate in the second half. We are where we hoped we would be - at the heart of the genomics revolution."

 Directors of biotech company KS Biomedix yesterday cashed in on the firm's soaring share price. Finance director Martin Myerscough and his non-executive colleague Jeffrey Wright each made £2.4m by selling 345,000 shares. Chairman Basil Butler sold 60,000 for £420,000.

fields.headline: Longbridge under threat
fields.standfirst: BMW chief says strong pound puts £1.5bn investment at risk
fields.trailText: BMW, the German car maker, could be forced to scrap its plans to build a new medium-sized car at Rover's Longbridge plant, near Birmingham, because of the soaring pound, a senior executive said yesterday.
fields.body:
BMW, the German car maker, could be forced to scrap its plans to build a new medium-sized car at Rover's Longbridge plant, near Birmingham, because of the soaring pound, a senior executive said yesterday.

Peter Forster, BMW's group production director, said that even if the European Commission approved the government's £152m aid package the planned £1.5bn investment at Longbridge could be cancelled if sterling remained at its current level - more than 40% higher than when BMW bought Rover six years ago.

"We believe the strong pound step by step erodes the manufacturing base and makes it increasingly difficult to manufacture in the UK," he said. His comments represent one of the strongest pleas from a foreign industrialist for min isters to talk down the pound.

His warning came as the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, admitted to MPs yesterday that there was little the bank or the treasury could do about sterling's over-valuation, which he acknowledged was damaging industry.

Mr George said the monetary policy committee had considered intervening on the foreign exchanges at its latest meeting to get the pound down but, to have been effective Britain would have had to sell sterling on a "massive scale".

Talk of intervention was enough to take some of the steam out of the pound on the foreign exchange markets yesterday, but it was the less critical sterling/dollar rate which reacted, falling nearly two cents to a seven and half month low of $1.5790.

BMW shed 9,000 Rover jobs last year in an attempt to cut costs and close a productivity gap of 30% at its UK subsidiary which lost more than £800m last year. The strong pound is said by Rover executives to have knocked £230m off the bottom line.

Mr Forster also warned that "between 1,000 and 5,000" more jobs would go at Rover whose workforce has shrunk to slightly more than 29,000. This is despite the launch next spring of the new Mini which will employ up to 2,500 from within the Rover group.

But the new Rolls-Royce due to go on sale in 2003 will be built in the UK - probably within the M25 area - and BMW will take on 800 skilled British employees to produce it.

fields.headline: Hopes for growth
fields.trailText: Shire Pharmaceuticals is pinning its hopes for the year on drugs for treating Alzheimer's disease and kidney failure after reporting healthy growth in underlying profits.
fields.body:
Shire Pharmaceuticals is pinning its hopes for the year on drugs for treating Alzheimer's disease and kidney failure after reporting healthy growth in underlying profits.

Reminyl, Shire's treatment for Alzheimer's, is set for European launch in the second half of the year. Lambda, which reduces the amount of phosphate in the blood of patients with kidney problems, should be lodged with regulators by the year's end.

Following its £1.8bn merger with American rival Roberts Pharmaceutical, Shire's operating profits jumped 154% to $59.2m (£37m). However, after exceptional charges of $129m to cover the deal the group made a pre-tax loss of $78.9m.

Chief executive Rolf Stahel said integration following the merger was "95% complete". Shire's management has taken over Roberts' salesforce and the American company's British head office in Guildford is to be closed.

Sales of Adderall, Shire's drug for attention deficit disorder, leapt 92% to $142m.

fields.headline: Rebel yell (TM)
fields.standfirst: Office life on tape
fields.trailText: Garage seditionaries and indie-label booms may come and go, but 20 years of pop-brat snarling at the corporations haven't left much of a dent. It's not that the big companies ever needed to suppress rebellion, more that rebellion was long ago co-opted by the market.
fields.body:
Back in punk rock's olden days, it was possible to believe for a moment that the music industry might be under threat. The Sex Pistols proclaimed it an act of revolution to take large payoffs from outraged major labels and run; while The Clash, signed to what was then CBS, had a fiery line of rhetoric about changing the system from the inside.

Today, what's changed? John Lydon and Joe Strummer are marginal recording artists, while EMI, the Pistols' former Great Satan, has undergone a £12bn merger with the Time Warner record labels. Garage seditionaries and indie-label booms may come and go, but 20 years of pop-brat snarling at the corporations haven't left much of a dent. It's not that the big companies ever needed to suppress rebellion, more that rebellion was long ago co-opted by the market: the most incendiary war cries must eventually get recycled on The Best Dissident Album Ever!

When they do, they'll be sold mail-order and marketed with crass catalogue copy written by reluctant corporate drones like Christopher Wilcha. He's the director of The Target Shoots First, a witty, provocative video best described as a docucomedy video diary. Wilcha, a New York philosophy graduate and music fan, was recruited in 1993 by Columbia House, a mail-order company that sells CDs by the ton to middle America (it was co-owned by Time Warner and Sony, so Wilcha got to use both companies' canteens). Fearing that his credentials as a punk-rock dude would be compromised, Wilcha decided to take his camcorder to work every day and film his corporate life in an effort, he says, "to convince myself that where I work is not who I am".

Much of the video is a Nicholson Baker-style anthropological study of office rituals - from weepy-huggy leaving parties to the staff summer picnic (attendance mandatory), where Wilcha wins a Grateful Dead waistcoat. Knuckling down to managerial instruction about "achieving", "motivating" and "empowerment", Wilcha struggles not to capitulate, but observes himself changing, with increasing horror.

The picture of office life with its phoney bonhomie is familiar enough. But what's really intriguing is the question of Wilcha's function in the firm. He is drafted in as a creative in-house rebel to help sell "alternative music" - alternative in this context meaning anything left of Garth Brooks. What keeps him sane is his precarious sense of embodying some kind of subversive faction within the system. He successfully launches a spuriously hip magazine designed to sell the music that the company is traditionally wary of: his most radical gesture is to list Erik Satie and Miles Davis on the same page. He writes ad copy for Nirvana, designed to present the band as a mature million-selling act: "The world waits to see what happens when teen spirit turns into adult rage." What happens, writes Wilcha, will be "a resounding punk-rock YES!" He is horrified to find the words "punk rock" excised from his copy.

Wilcha's video presents itself as a satirical critique of the mechanisms by which the system assimilates the counter-culture. For which, read simply: the way that some moderately intelligent marketing people contrive to sell noisy rock to a conservative American market. Incisive and engaging though it is, The Target Shoots First isn't as earth-shattering as we'd hope - only a real indie ingenu would be shocked by the revelation that corporations were profiting from youth culture. What's truly surprising is that Wilcha was able to film himself and his colleagues every day without anyone objecting. His boss looks baffled at first, and the CD factory workers refuse to be filmed, but otherwise, he was free to make his video and so make the company look entirely ridiculous.

Wilcha's anti-corporate strike makes salutary and timely viewing, fitting neatly with the spirit that fuelled the World Trade Talks protests in Seattle (although, as public enemies go, Columbia House is rather clumsier and more artless than Starbucks, the Seattle protesters' despised fabricator of artificial hipness). But is the video really an effective act of corporate sabotage, or is Wilcha just biting the hand that fed him, and presumably fed him handsomely? You can't help wondering whether Wilcha has been sued yet: surely Columbia House's employment contract has clauses to cover this kind of malarkey. Or perhaps his film is another futile dissident gesture that the machine can easily assimilate. I'd never heard of Columbia House before: just goes to show, Wilcha's film is the sort of advertising you just can't buy. This stuffy organisation is now known as the company that offered house room to a groovy piece of digital propaganda: it acquires a funky cachet by association with its in-house rebel. Wilcha may be aiming a big counter-counter raspberry at the company; but it wouldn't surprise me if the company's response were just a resounding punk-rock SO WHAT.

fields.headline: Camelot pledges £5bn in lottery bid
fields.trailText: Camelot yesterday pledged to raise an extra £5bn for good causes if its contract to run the national lottery is renewed.
fields.body:
Camelot yesterday pledged to raise an extra £5bn for good causes if its contract to run the national lottery is renewed.

The lottery operator said that it will match the £15bn which a rival consortium led by Sir Richard Branson yesterday promised to deliver to good causes - around 50% more than it expects to raise by the time its contract expires next year.

A Camelot spokeswoman denied accusations from the People's Lottery that its commitment was a last-minute response to its rival.

"The £15bn figure has always been in our bid," she said, adding that wider participation and an increased spend among players would secure the extra £5bn.

Camelot, which has been criticised for the salaries and bonuses it has awarded its staff, did not publicly reveal the amount it planned to raise until after Sir Richard's People's Lottery had outlined its bid yesterday morning.

A spokesman from the People's Lottery said: "On Monday Camelot were talking about raising more than £10bn; today that figure is miraculously up to £15bn. It is not clear how they will generate this and is just not credible."

The spokesman claimed that Camelot would have to add another £10bn to declining sales over the course of the seven-year contract in order to meet its target.

The two heavyweight bidders were surprisingly joined by a mystery third bidder shortly before yesterday's midday submission deadline.

A national lottery commission official said a man handed in a bid shortly before the deadline on behalf of a "charity consortium", and that efforts were being made to clarify the contents of the bid.

Sources close to Camelot and the People's Lottery appeared unconcerned by the arrival of the unexpected bidder and said they were not aware that any of their suppliers or partners had been contacted by the unknown bidder.

The People's Lottery claims it will introduce a game that will inject "new excitement" into playing and boost sales. Sir Richard said six balls will be selected from 53 as opposed to the present six from 49. Both rivals also plan to introduce online gaming.

The commission has a June deadline to award the new licence, which runs until 2008.

fields.headline: Beautiful optimisery
fields.standfirst:
The Mighty Wah
Talk of London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
The Mighty Wah
Talk of London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
It's been a long time since we've seen a rock 'n' roll show like this. A show where, as well as good tunes, a tight band and the usual stuff, you get jokes, anecdotes, love, humiliation, unashamed sentimentality, and a feeling that the whole thing matters so much to the artist, he may break down any second. It's an old-fashioned idea, giving everything on stage for rock 'n' roll, creating glory from teetering chaos, snatching victory from defeat. But legendary Liverpudlian ligger, blagger, self-confessed prick and occasional singer-songwriter Pete Wylie does all this and more at his inspirational comeback show.

Wylie is a contemporary and rival of Julian Cope and Ian McCulloch, and got his taste of chart success in the mid-80s. You might remember Story of the Blues or Sinful or Come Back, all played brilliantly here. Since then, he has done little except break his back in 1991. A new album, Songs of Strength and Heartbreak, was due out last year but, in true Wylie style, he was dropped before it did.

This show is to promote its release on an indie, and Wylie proceeds to play with this misunderstood loser status for 90 minutes of passionate cabaret and Clash-meets-Springsteen anthem-toting. By the end, he has made our jaws ache with inspired one-liners, brought a lump to our throat with wanton displays of vulnerability, dedicated songs to Bill Shankly, Gerry Conlon of the Guildford Four and pretty much each one of us individually, and confessed that his last band dumped him less than a week ago. Considering that tonight's group make like the E Street Band after overdosing on Sunny Delight, it's no wonder he treats them like heroes.

He describes his over-riding character trait as "optimisery" - that is, life is the greatest thing and the very worst, simultaneously. In this spirit, you get a chubby man in a black ruffled shirt pointing out his girth and re-christening himself Peteloaf, before singing the finest song of his career. Heart as Big as Liverpool sums up everything about Wylie: a song about death that affirms life, a chorus that takes your breath away, the slightly guilty pleasure of falling for a song so crass, so overblown, so Ferry Cross the Mersey. But everything about Pete Wylie shows up cynicism for the coward's way out that it is. If there is a more extraordinary rock gig this year, I hope to God I'm there.

fields.headline: Penetrating soundworld
fields.standfirst:
Stockhausen's Gruppen
Royal Festival Hall, London/ Radio 3
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Stockhausen's Gruppen
Royal Festival Hall, London/ Radio 3
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The BBC's Composer Portrait series at the Royal Festival Hall, combined with the LSO's celebrations of Pierre Boulez's 75th birthday at the Barbican, has provided London with a feast of contemporary orchestral music over the last month, including what is perhaps the most extraordinary of modern masterpieces, Stockhausen's Gruppen.

Even now, 42 years after its premiere, a live performance of Gruppen is a special event, not only because of its unique demands - it involves three orchestras - but because the music possesses such power and originality. As Stockhausen reminded us in an illustrated talk between the two performances of the work on Monday, he has continued to explore music in space, as he describes it, but he has never done so with the sheer youthful virtuosity he brought to this score.

The Festival Hall isn't the best place to hear such a work - the orchestras all had to be placed more or less in front of the audience, so the sounds couldn't rotate around the space as they should. But with David Robertson, Martyn Brabbins and Pascal Rophé in charge of the three bands of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the performance fairly sizzled. Complex webs of instrumental lines spread across the orchestras, often in three different tempi simultaneously; call-and-response passages echoed from one side to the other; most majestic of all, sounds gradually moved from side to side, drawing everyone into their orbit.

There's a theatrical charge to much of the writing - comic moments, passages of enormous grandeur, little kernels of exquisite lyricism. When much of Stockhausen's recent music is so uneven, it was salutary to be reminded of one of his most exceptional achievements.

Gruppen was prefaced here by a group of piano pieces from the same wondrously productive period - nine of the Klavierstücke written in the 50s, in which many of the technical innovations used in the orchestral work were first explored. Nicolas Hodges played the obsessive and compelling ninth piece; the rest were allotted to the superb Dutch pianist Ellen Corver, who also included the 1984 Klavierstück XIV, part of Montag from Stockhausen's opera cycle Licht. After the clarity and discipline of the early pieces that really came as a nasty shock, as if warm treacle had suddenly been poured over this unique and penetrating soundworld.

fields.headline: The pink ceiling
fields.standfirst:
A barrister was convicted this week of blackmailing a client in 1983 when she threatened to tell his employer he was gay. But that was years ago - people's careers aren't put at risk by their sexuality now. Or are they? Jane Czyzselska reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A barrister was convicted this week of blackmailing a client in 1983 when she threatened to tell his employer he was gay. But that was years ago - people's careers aren't put at risk by their sexuality now. Or are they?
fields.body:
As employee empowerment develops apace, it seems beyond belief that anyone would confident enough to blackmail a colleague or client. Yet that is exactly what Carol Winston-Churchill, who is a barrister, attempted with an American investment banker. Last week at the Old Bailey, Winston-Churchill pleaded guilty to threatening to tell David Brown's Manhattan employers, Bear, Stern & Company, that he was gay after his plans to buy a house in Jamaica in 1983 fell through.

Brown had already given Winston-Churchill £100,000 for conveyancing fees. She refused to return it when the deal was called off. When his lawyers began proceedings to recover the money, she threatened him. The banker, who has since died, was not, in fact, homosexual; he went straight to the police. However, Winston-Churchill apparently believed that she could exploit the stigma associated with homosexuality at the time. But that was nearly 20 years ago; could such a thing happen in the modern workplace?

The last thing 35-year-old David Coppola expected when he joined the London office of a multinational bank was a succession of professional snubs and a salary just over half that of younger, less qualified colleagues. As a senior consultant in commercial banking, Coppola had been targeted as a fast-track high-flier. A successful and well-liked key player in his field, his scheduled progression through the initial two-year tenure was guaranteed. Or so he thought.

After five years with the company, he has been promoted only once and achieved a salary package far from commensurate with his position. The reason, he alleges, is his sexuality. "In the first year, the fact that I'm gay came out gradually over post-work drinks. I never made a big deal of it and eventually most of my colleagues sussed it anyway," he says. At this stage, Coppola reckons he should be at the peak of his career. His peers are on around one and half times his present salary and are rising through the ranks. His career appears to have reached a standstill.

"Glass ceiling" is a term usually applied to women who are unable to achieve senior directorial positions as a result of gender prejudice within the workplace. Until now, the gay glass ceiling has not come under close scrutiny by the national lesbian and gay campaigning organisations. Research and monitoring of individual cases is minimal, in part because it is difficult to quantify, in part because the position of the individu als affected has not been publicised. "We do get approached by people who believe their sexuality, combined with other people's prejudice, makes promotion problematic," says Phil Greasley, who is a campaigner with the lobby group Lager (Lesbian and Gay Equal Rights). "We try to do as much for them as we can, but it's difficult to prove. An employer is free to choose who to promote and who not to, and it's easy to assess people so that they don't reach a level for promotion. Sometimes 'attitude' or 'approach' are mentioned in a negative way."

It's the small details that add up to important evidence, though. And, Greasley thinks, if it can be shown that a person has been unfairly treated, it's not always necessary to prove that sexuality is the reason. Coppola has a briefcase full of details. He believes he has been regularly excluded from significant meetings, business trips and conferences, and kept isolated and uninformed.

Coppola is not alone in his complaint. In other instances, too, a gay glass ceiling appears to be firmly, if unofficially, lodged in company structure. Paul McBride is a human resources manager working for a city council. Around the predominant male managers, McBride's honesty about his sexuality makes people twitchy. He came out to his colleagues six months after joining the council. Eight years later, he has reservations about having done it because of the still largely "blokish" office culture.

"I'm not the kind of person who talks about their sex life a lot, but I have found it in my interest to play it down. The further up the organisation I go, the more I find myself spending time with women at the same level because we have quite a lot of common experiences. We don't get invited to the pub or to play golf."

For some, the absence of a family causes problems. The corporate publication Management Today cites Sir Bob Reid, deputy governor of the Bank of Scotland, who believes that anyone - gay or straight - who lacks a solid family backdrop is suspicious. "The whole thing about life is that you get into trouble because you don't have a wide breadth of experience. You have to be suspicious of people who don't have children jumping on their sofas at home. They don't know about real life."

McBride is not surprised by Reid's remarks: "There are still very strong male networks and although on the surface it doesn't look like that's what's going on, the higher up you get, most business goes on outside the office and you don't get invited. You just don't find out."

In 1996, Dr Nicholas Priestley, a clinical neuropsychologist was made clinical director of a private clinic in Bury. As one of the country's leading expert witnesses in head-injury litigation and one of the most senior doctors in his field, Priestley was regarded as the only suitable candidate.

Thrilled to be appointed, he had no idea that three years later he would be embroiled in an industrial tribunal with his employers, Westminster Healthcare, over sex discrimination and constructive dismissal. Priestley alleges that management and colleagues taunted him relentlessly about his sex uality and the integrity of his character. "In the corridor, colleagues would call me sick and perverted," Priestley claims. "They simply could not treat a gay man as an equal."

In two years he alleges he was ostracised and undermined by his co-workers, and asked on several occasions to "change" his personality (which he read as "sexuality"). Priestley made more than 30 written and verbal complaints to his employers about his treatment. In June 1998, Priestley felt he had no option but to hand in his resignation. Priestley's claims are denied by his employers, who say that there was no discrimination and that Priestley resigned for his own reasons.

Priestley hoped to win a moral victory at industrial tribunal but claims the 10-day hearing was unfair. He claims that at one point he was asked, when taking the oath, how he could swear on the Bible, given that he was gay. Priestley felt forced to abandon his case, and a complaint has been made to the Lord Chancellor's department about the conduct of the tribunal.

Priestley is now a National Health Service consultant neuropsychologist at a hospital in Widnes.

Since his story has become public, with the backing of Stonewall, the gay rights group, the Trades Union Congress and now Liberty, Priestley has received overwhelming support from a number of Labour MPs who are keen to see his case used to bring about a change in the law on employment rights for lesbians and gay men. Speaking in the House of Commons on December 21 1999, Priestley's MP, David Chaytorm, said: "If Dr Priestley had been a woman, had had a disability of some kind, or had been a member of an ethnic minority, he would have had recourse to the law earlier. There is clearly a case for building discrimination on the grounds of sexuality into anti-discrimination legislation."

Priestley says that his case has acted as a catalyst for the introduction of a voluntary code of practice in the public sector in the near future, which although not directly effective in the private sphere, would make it more difficult for employers to discriminate in the workplace. Campaigners believe it's a start, though not much to shout about, and Nicholas Priestley concludes, "A statutory code of conduct must be implemented. Good employers are already implementing such policy - it's the bad ones who must be forced to change."

Such a move would finally change a culture which can sustain blackmail, and everyday acts of prejudice as well as the glass ceiling.

&#'149; Jane Czyzselska writes regularly on gay rights at work for Attitude magazine. Some names have been changed to protect the individuals concerned.

Research and monitoring of individual cases is minimal, in part because it is difficult to quantify, in part because the position of the individu als affected has not been publicised. "We do get approached by people who believe their sexuality, combined with other people's prejudice, makes promotion problematic," says Phil Greasley, who is a campaigner with the lobby group Lager (Lesbian and Gay Equal Rights). "We try to do as much for them as we can, but it's difficult to prove. An employer is free to choose who to promote and who not to, and it's easy to assess people so that they don't reach a level for promotion. Sometimes 'attitude' or 'approach' are mentioned in a negative way." It's the small details that add up to important evidence, though. And, Greasley thinks, if it can be shown that a person has been unfairly treated, it's not always necessary to prove that sexuality is the reason. Coppola has a briefcase full of details. He believes he has been regularly excluded from significant meetings, business trips and conferences, and kept isolated and uninformed. Coppola is not alone in his complaint. In other instances, too, a gay glass ceiling appears to be firmly, if unofficially, lodged in company structure. Paul McBride is a human resources manager working for a city council. Around the predominant male managers, McBride's honesty about his sexuality makes people twitchy. He came out to his colleagues six months after joining the council. Eight years later, he has reservations about having done it because of the still largely "blokish" office culture. "I'm not the kind of person who talks about their sex life a lot, but I have found it in my interest to play it down. The further up the organisation I go, the more I find myself spending time with women at the same level because we have quite a lot of common experiences. We don't get invited to the pub or to play golf." For some, the absence of a family causes problems. The corporate publication Management Today cites Sir Bob Reid, deputy governor of the Bank of Scotland, who believes that anyone - gay or straight - who lacks a solid family backdrop is suspicious. "The whole thing about life is that you get into trouble because you don't have a wide breadth of experience. You have to be suspicious of people who don't have children jumping on their sofas at home. They don't know about real life." McBride is not surprised by Reid's remarks: "There are still very strong male networks and although on the surface it doesn't look like that's what's going on, the higher up you get, most business goes on outside the office and you don't get invited. You just don't find out." In 1996, Dr Nicholas Priestley, a clinical neuropsychologist was made clinical director of a private clinic in Bury. As one of the country's leading expert witnesses in head-injury litigation and one of the most senior doctors in his field, Priestley was regarded as the only suitable candidate. Thrilled to be appointed, he had no idea that three years later he would be embroiled in an industrial tribunal with his employers, Westminster Healthcare, over sex discrimination and constructive dismissal. Priestley alleges that management and colleagues taunted him relentlessly about his sex uality and the integrity of his character. "In the corridor, colleagues would call me sick and perverted," Priestley claims. "They simply could not treat a gay man as an equal." In two years he alleges he was ostracised and undermined by his co-workers, and asked on several occasions to "change" his personality (which he read as "sexuality"). Priestley made more than 30 written and verbal complaints to his employers about his treatment. In June 1998, Priestley felt he had no option but to hand in his resignation. Priestley's claims are denied by his employers, who say that there was no discrimination and that Priestley resigned for his own reasons. Priestley hoped to win a moral victory at industrial tribunal but claims the 10-day hearing was unfair. He claims that at one point he was asked, when taking the oath, how he could swear on the Bible, given that he was gay. Priestley felt forced to abandon his case, and a complaint has been made to the Lord Chancellor's department about the conduct of the tribunal. Priestley is now a National Health Service consultant neuropsychologist at a hospital in Widnes. Since his story has become public, with the backing of Stonewall, the gay rights group, the Trades Union Congress and now Liberty, Priestley has received overwhelming support from a number of Labour MPs who are keen to see his case used to bring about a change in the law on employment rights for lesbians and gay men. Speaking in the House of Commons on December 21 1999, Priestley's MP, David Chaytorm, said: "If Dr Priestley had been a woman, had had a disability of some kind, or had been a member of an ethnic minority, he would have had recourse to the law earlier. There is clearly a case for building discrimination on the grounds of sexuality into anti-discrimination legislation." Priestley says that his case has acted as a catalyst for the introduction of a voluntary code of practice in the public sector in the near future, which although not directly effective in the private sphere, would make it more difficult for employers to discriminate in the workplace. Campaigners believe it's a start, though not much to shout about, and Nicholas Priestley concludes, "A statutory code of conduct must be implemented. Good employers are already implementing such policy - it's the bad ones who must be forced to change." Such a move would finally change a culture which can sustain blackmail, and everyday acts of prejudice as well as the glass ceiling. &#'149; Jane Czyzselska writes regularly on gay rights at work for Attitude magazine. Some names have been changed to protect the individuals concerned.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cayte Williiams talks to the parents who have successfully negotiated a balance between the demands of career and children.
fields.body:
Alexie Riley, 37 speech therapist

At 23 I was a single parent and went back to work full-time when my baby was three months old. For six months life was hell. I ran myself ragged all day and didn't sleep at night. In desperation I went to see my boss. There weren't any part-time jobs so I thought I would have to resign. I burst into tears and she suggested I drop one of my clinics so I could go part-time and hire someone to take on the extra work. I learned that you don't have to suffer in silence, and that if you don't ask, you don't get.

Jessica Aldridge, 28 art director

After I had my baby everyone I worked with wrote me off. I mix in a world where you have to be very cutting-edge, and nobody thought I could be that as a mum. One guy, a production designer I worked with, used to call me "mummy", which I thought was funny until I realised how undermining and patronising it was. It took me six to nine months to prove myself again and I'm now more successful than before. I concentrate better because I have less time and another mouth to feed. You just have to ignore people's ignorance, work hard, and let the results speak for themselves.

Rachel Hoile, 36 advertising creative

Before the baby, I was part of a work-hard, play-hard culture. When I went back, I realised there would be no more of that. For a week I cried in the toilets: I missed my baby and missed the good ol' days at work. But it got better. I survived the first few weeks by not expecting much. I just did my work and rushed home. Slowly, I realised work was better than before. I pace myself now; I don't let trivial things worry me; I am no longer embroiled in office politics. My advice? Get the best childcare you can, then disentangle your feelings from those of the baby. You miss her, but she's fine. Remember, mothers have always worked.

Richard Hyde, 34 architect

I work for a family-friendly company and had a month's paternity leave. I was in charge of a team of young, childless people and they kept phoning me on the wretched mobile so I felt like I was in the office. I tried to put my foot down but I thought, "I am responsible for these people like I am for my wife and children." It's a modern dilemma for a working father to get the balance right. In the end, I went freelance because I wanted to be close to my family.

Joanna Palmer, 34 PR consultant

I didn't have any break after my child was born, which was a mistake. I was back at my desk two weeks after the birth because my clients only wanted to deal with me. We would have lost them if I had taken time off. I was fine at the time but a few months later realised I hadn't had any time to recover for myself. I negotiated a deal whereby I worked on finite projects relating to my clients, while someone else did the day-to-day maintenance. That way we kept the business but my hours were more flexible. I think that as a mother you have to have devoted baby-time and working-time otherwise you don't give anything 100% of your attention.

webTitle: Marketing switches to sites for teenagers to work, rest and pay

fields.headline: Marketing switches to sites for teenagers to work, rest and pay
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Last year there was Handbag.com, Charlotte Street.com and Ready2shop.com. It was the year companies recognised the sales potential of women surfing the net. This year the marketeers have gone one step further - websites for children and teenagers developed on the catch-em-young model of winning customers.
fields.body:
Last year there was Handbag.com, Charlotte Street.com and Ready2shop.com. It was the year companies recognised the sales potential of women surfing the net. This year the marketeers have gone one step further - websites for children and teenagers developed on the catch-em-young model of winning customers.

A fully encrypted kids-only site, eKids, launches in the US today promising concerned parents a safe, fun and educa tional environment where their children can play, learn and communicate with other children around the world.

"The internet is like a physical street. Most parents don't want their children roaming the streets totally unsupervised," says chief executive El St John. Advertising is banned to prevent parents from being pestered for goods by their children, though the company admits sponsors will be sought.

UK players looking to introduce secure child-focused sites include HIT Entertainment, the television company behind Bob the Builder, and Britt Allcroft, owner of the Thomas the Tank Engine franchise.

Kids will even get their own currency to spend on the web. American children already have Rocketcash and Cybermoola. In the UK there are Y-creds, developed by Kevin Sefton, a former consultant to AOL. Parents can credit their child's account, with each Ycred - which come in £5 units - worth 1p.

But the big potential is in sites aimed at teenagers with time on their hands and money to spend.

According to research from NOP the teenage segment is the fastest-growing demographic online. NOP found that 98% of 12-16 years olds use a computer at home or school; 60% will be online by the spring, compared to 44% last summer. Girls spend more time online than boys.

For a grouping so web-savvy they are poorly served. "Beyond sites offering computer games there is very little fo cused content on the web," said David Pannell, a consultant at investment bank Durlacher.

All that could be about to change. From April, a site backed by some of the biggest business names will aim directly at teenage girls.

Wowgo is the brainchild of chief executive David Peller, a solicitor who helped bring Wagamama noodle bars to London, and chairman David Gold, of the Gold Greenlees Trott advertising agency.

Mr Peller says: "Having recognised that teen girls are both difficult to reach through traditional media and underserved in a digital environment, we have positioned ourselve to capture the huge opportunity this market represents in terms of size, value and influence."

He plans a "24-hour global digital community for teenage girls" with chatrooms, exclusive content, gossip sites and - of course - commerce.

Little surprise that Unilever, whose brands include Dove and Calvin Klein fragrances, is backing the enterprise, along with Durlacher and Hewlett Packard, with £6m cash.

Arch-rival Procter & Gamble (Clearasil, Pantene and Tampax) will launch a competing site in the summer with Excite.

Mr Pannell says technological change has forced the companies' hands. "Children are spending less time watching TV and more time surfing the web and playing computer games. Fast moving consumer goods companies are adjusting their marketing strategies accordingly."

webTitle: BT offers free internet for evening surfers

fields.headline: BT offers free internet for evening surfers
fields.trailText: BT Internet customers will be able to use the net free during the evening, the telecoms group announced yesterday.
fields.body:
BT Internet customers will be able to use the net free during the evening, the telecoms group announced yesterday.

Its customers, who already have free internet calls at the weekend, will also see their monthly subscription reduced from £11.75 to £9.99.

Last month the chancellor, Gordon Brown, called on BT to reduce the cost of using the internet - inadvertently wiping billions off its market capitalisation.

Ben Andradi, managing director of BT Internet, said the move "supports BT's strategy to become the leading consumer ISP [internet service provider] and portal, and is the first in a series of internet initiatives". He denied that the changes were a result of the chancellor's call. "We have been working on this pricing package for some time. We are responding to customers' needs."

He added that BT Internet would be announcing a broadband service shortly. BT Internet has about 210,000 customers while BT Click, the group's no-frills service, has about 500,000. Analysts saw the new package as a belated attempt to catch up with Freeserve and AOL UK, which dominate the British internet market.

Some analysts believe the days of the free subscription model, pioneered by Freeserve in Britain, may be coming to an end. Eric Paulak a, research director with the Gartner Group, said the interconnection revenues which ISPs relied on were declining and advertising was not generating enough money. Free subscription ISPs would have to raise more revenue through commission on customers' deals with internet retailers.

Introduction of high speed access to the internet would result in higher operating costs which would have to be covered. He said free subscription ISPs would probably be able to introduce monthly fees by offering new services or greater speed.

Others might follow the example of an ISP owned by Vestel, a Turkish domestic consumer electronics group whose internet customers sign a three-year contract and receive a free computer and a Visa card. Customers paid a small subscription but the ISP got its income from revenue-sharing agreements with retailers accepting the Visa card over the net and in stores.

fields.headline: Valmont, the cuddly seducer
fields.standfirst:
Les Liaisons Dangereuses
Yvonne Arnaud, Guildford
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Les Liaisons Dangereuses
Yvonne Arnaud, Guildford
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Christopher Hampton's witty comedy of sexual depravity slips comfortably into middle age in this slightly clunky touring production. The dialogue is still delicious, like shards of the finest cut glass, but here direction, design and some performances mean you can see all the seams in a play that now comes across less like an 18th century Closer and more like a BBC costume drama. Sophie Ward's Madame de Tourvel is too much of a simpering late 19th century heroine and needs far more grave dignity to make her fall from grace seem really tragic.

But there is dangerous fun to be had, not least from Siobhan Redmond's Marquise de Merteuil, whose sexual sport is the corruption of the innocent but whose raison d' etre is the revenge and humiliation of those who have crossed her.

Together with her former lover, the rakish Vicomte de Valmont, she conspires to have the 15-year-old daughter of her friend deflowered and corrupted. An extension of their nasty little games of sex and power is his desire to seduce Madame de Tourvel, a woman renowned for her happy marriage and high morals. What neither reckons on in their well-laid plans is the arrival of love.

Redmond is fantastic; her eyes glint and she glides across the stage like an erotically malevolent cobra. This is a woman who preaches excess but is all self-control. Her power and survival in the sexual world of men has been bought at a terrible price, her own humanity. Victory is not just hollow but also temporary: as the play ends, 1789 and revolution loom.

Redmond and Clive Wood's Valmont play well off each other and there is a real sexual tension about their encounters. Wood is a very fine actor, and he charts both his relish for the game and his confusion as it spirals out of his control. But he's far too cuddly to persuade as the bed-hopping rake whom no woman can resist. You'd be more likely to offer this Valmont a cup of cocoa than your virginity.

 At Theatre Royal, Bath (01225 448844) until Saturday. Tours to Alexander Theatre, Birmingham (0870-607 7535), March 7-11, then Norwich, Milton Keynes, Nottingham and throughout Britain until June.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Half past nine on this already baking Monday morning and Miss B and I regard each other with suspicion across the table of a greasy cafe. I am not comfortable with her story, which is why I wanted to take her away from the little crowd of managers in the tribunal waiting room and talk to her on her own, but the move has made her defensive.
fields.body:
Half past nine on this already baking Monday morning and Miss B and I regard each other with suspicion across the table of a greasy cafe. I am not comfortable with her story, which is why I wanted to take her away from the little crowd of managers in the tribunal waiting room and talk to her on her own, but the move has made her defensive.

It's an ugly story. She and Mr Y used to go out with each other, after meeting at the haulage firm that Mr Y is now suing for race discrimination. According to Miss B, the relationship ended in violence, but not before Mr Y had told her about his plan to accuse his colleagues of racist abuse. She says he sees this as an easy way to get some money. If she's right, Mr Y is a clever man, because his account is oddly muted for a lie; nothing extreme, the odd put-down, joking references to monkeys, the small change of racist banter.

I want Miss B to trust me but see no reason why she should; she is 19 but hard, her bare legs swollen above cheap heels. "I haven't got anything against him. I just don't think it's right what he's doing."

"And you're quite sure none of what he says is true?"

She slides her eyes away. "I never heard anything."

Back at the tribunal, Mr Y looks scared. Another tough white girl clutches his arm and shoots hard looks at Miss B. No one's story alters much. The manager denies making the remarks Mr Y puts to him one by one.

In a moment of frustration, Mr Y says: "Maybe you just thought I wouldn't mind you saying those things?"

"I didn't say them."

Miss B is up next. Mr Y questions her: "If I had this big plan like you say, why would I tell you about it?"

"Because you're not as smart as you think."

And then Mr Y himself, whom I cross-examine gingerly because he might be telling the truth, or the tribunal might think that he is: "If all this is true, why did you wait three years to complain about it?"

"Because I thought I could put up with it."

"But you could have complained at any time; why didn't you?"

The look Mr Y gives me is a look that I take away with me. "Because I need to have a job and probably it would be worse somewhere else."

The tribunal retires and then comes back to say it can't make a decision today. We'll get it in writing. I'm just glad I don't have to call it.

fields.headline: Finding family in a trumpet
fields.standfirst: Music leaves no room for love in Side Man, finds Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText:
Side Man
Apollo Shaftesbury, London
fields.body:
There is a scene in Warren Leight's play when three jazz trumpeters sit side by side on bar stools listening to a bootleg recording of legendary trumpeter Clifford Brown, made the night before his fatal car crash. As the music curls like smoke across the auditorium of the Apollo Shaftesbury in London, the men's eyes begin to glaze and their jaws become slack in response. They look like customers in an opium den or junkies who have just had a fix.

The idea - oft mooted elsewhere - of the relationship between jazz and drugs comes across strong in this play, a haunting riff of a drama about parent-son relationships, the madness of disappointment and the way the gift of music can open some doors of perception and slam others shut. As the young Clifford (named in honour of the dead Brown) muses about his father, the jazz trumpeter, Gene: "I never understood how he could sense everything when he was blowing and sense nothing when he wasn't." Always married to his music and more at ease with his musician friends than in his own home, it is Gene's neglect of his wife, Terry, that tips her over the edge into madness.

This is a memory play, and like so many memory plays it is seen through a spun sugar haze in which the distant past is always better than the near past and the near past better than the awful present. "From what I understand," says Jason Priestley's not surprisingly emotional Clifford, "everyone was happy before I was born."

There is added poignancy in the fact it takes place between 1953 and 1985, which saw the decline of New York's jazz clubs. Gathering around the radio to hear Elvis Presley's first record, one of the characters predicts: "That kid will do for jazz what the talkies did for Buster Keaton." Gene and the others laugh him off, blithely unaware that they are dodos on the edge of extinction.

The evening often comes within a whisker of sentimentality and sometimes falls into the trap of romanticising jazz musicians, but there is something tough about both the writing and its sentiments. "Wow, she broke Bakelite," observes the teenage Clifford as his mother hurls a cup in a drunken rage at the feckless Gene. Nothing will break this play: at times it is almost unbearable to watch as it charts the disintegration of Gene and Terry's marriage, with the boy Clifford condemned to play peacekeeper and Red Cross in the middle.

The accents of the American cast take some getting used to, but the acting is diamond hard in that thrillingly wired way that is so distinctively American. Priestley, leaving Beverly Hills 90210 far behind, is immensely touching; Edie Falco, of Sopranos fame, goes noisily nutty as she realises that she will always play second fiddle to jazz, and Frank Wood is superb as Gene, a man who can talk to his son through his trumpet but can't even look him in the eye.

 At the Apollo Shaftesbury, London W1, till May 6. Box office: 0171-494 5070.
